('49', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 1
('49', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. NOTES
('49', 0, 2, 3, 49) DOG IN THE MANGER
('49', 0, 3, 4, 67) The volume of information being gained daily shows how wickedly the salt tax has been designed.
('49', 0, 3, 5, 163) In order to prevent the use of salt that has not paid the tax which is at times even fourteen times its value, the Government destroys the salt it cannot sell profitably.
('49', 0, 3, 6, 334) Thus it taxes the nation’s vital necessity, it prevents the public from manufacturing it and destroys what nature manufactures without effort.
('49', 0, 3, 7, 477) No adjective is strong enough for characterizing this wicked dog in the manger policy.
('49', 0, 3, 8, 564) From various sources I hear tales of such wanton destruction of the nation’s property in all parts of India.
('49', 0, 3, 9, 673) Maunds if not tons of salt are said to be destroyed on the Konkan coast.
('49', 0, 3, 10, 746) The same tale comes from Dandi.
('49', 0, 3, 11, 778) Wherever there is likelihood of natural salt being taken away by the people living in the neighbourhood of such areas for their personal use, salt officers are posted for the sole purpose of carrying on destruction.
('49', 0, 3, 12, 994) Thus valuable national property is destroyed at national expense and salt taken out of the mouths of the people.
('49', 0, 3, 13, 1107) Nor is this all.
('49', 0, 3, 14, 1124) I was told on entering the Olpad taluka that through the poor people being prevented from collecting the salt that was prepared by nature or from manufacturing it they were deprived of the supplementary village industry they had in addition to the spinning wheel.
('49', 0, 3, 15, 1388) The salt monopoly is thus a fourfold curse.
('49', 0, 3, 16, 1432) It deprives the people of a valuable easy village industry, involves wanton destruction of property that nature produces in abundance, the destruction itself means more national expenditure, and fourthly, to crown this folly, an unheard of tax of more than 1,000 per cent is exacted from a starving people.
('49', 0, 3, 17, 1739) I cannot help recalling in this connection the hue and cry that was raised when I first proposed the burning of foreign cloth.
('49', 0, 3, 18, 1866) It was considered to be an inhuman, wasteful proposal.
('49', 0, 3, 19, 1921) It is generally admitted that foreign cloth is harmful to the people.
('49', 0, 3, 20, 1991) Salt on the other hand is a vital necessity.
('49', 0, 3, 21, 2036) Yet it has been and is daily being wantonly destroyed in the interest of a wicked exaction.
('49', 0, 3, 22, 2128) This tax has remained so long because of the apathy of the general public.
('49', 0, 3, 23, 2203) Now that it is sufficiently roused, the tax has togo.
('49', 0, 3, 24, 2257) How soon it will be abolished depends upon the strength the people
('49', 1, 0, 1, 2324) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 1, 1, 2, 2364) are able to put forth.
('49', 1, 1, 3, 2387) Happily the test will not be long delayed.
('49', 1, 2, 4, 2430) EXAGGERATED STATEMENTS Paragraphs have appeared in the Press to the effect that 18 of my companions have become ill and incapacitated.
('49', 1, 2, 5, 2565) This is a gross exaggeration.
('49', 1, 2, 6, 2595) It is quite true that that number had to take two days’ rest at the Broach Sevashram.
('49', 1, 2, 7, 2681) But that was because they were fatigued and footsore.
('49', 1, 2, 8, 2735) With the exception of the case of smallpox which proved to be quite mild, there was no illness worth the name.
('49', 1, 2, 9, 2846) One of the companions certainly had strong fever.
('49', 1, 2, 10, 2896) But that fever too proved to be due to overzeal in marching.
('49', 1, 2, 11, 2957) He had a wiry constitution and was over confident about his ability to pull through without resting.
('49', 1, 2, 12, 3058) He would not therefore rest till nature absolutely compelled him.
('49', 1, 2, 13, 3124) But both are quite well now though being weak they are still being made to rest a few days.
('49', 1, 2, 14, 3216) They expect to join the company at Surat.
('49', 1, 2, 15, 3258) A third, though still a little footsore, insisted on walking, but had to rest at Ankleshvar.
('49', 1, 2, 16, 3351) All the others are fit and marching daily.
('49', 1, 2, 17, 3394) It has become necessary to make this statement in order to prevent anxiety on the part of guardians and friends.
('49', 1, 2, 18, 3507) It would be ungrateful not to mention here the great attention the villagers are paying to the satyagrahis and the exceptional care that was bestowed upon the smallpox patient by the Charotar Education Society at Anand and on the footsore men by Dr. Chandulal’s staff at Sevashram.
('49', 1, 2, 19, 3789) A moral may also be drawn from these accidents.
('49', 1, 2, 20, 3837) The modern generation is delicate, weak and much pampered.
('49', 1, 2, 21, 3896) If they will take part in national work, they must take ample exercise and become hardy.
('49', 1, 2, 22, 3985) And no exercise is as good and as effective as long vigorous marches.
('49', 1, 2, 23, 4055) Gymnastics and the like are good and may be added to walking.
('49', 1, 2, 24, 4117) They are no substitutes for walking, justly called the prince of exercises.
('49', 1, 2, 25, 4193) Our march is in reality child’s play.
('49', 1, 2, 26, 4231) Less than twelve miles per day in two stages with not much luggage should cause no strain.
('49', 1, 2, 27, 4322) Those who have not been footsore have gained in weight.
('49', 1, 2, 28, 4378) I may add too that the hot Condy’s fluid, baths and wet sheet packs are proving a most efficient remedy for smallpox.
('49', 1, 3, 29, 4496) THE TRUE SPIRIT
('49', 1, 4, 30, 4512) Shrimati Khurshedbai Naoroji came the other day to Sandhier, a halting station during the march.
('49', 1, 4, 31, 4609) She was accompanied by Mridu labehn, the daughter of Sjt.
('49', 1, 4, 32, 4667) Ambalal Sarabhai, Madalasa, the little dau ghter of Jamnalalji, Shrimati Vasumatibehn and Radhabehnfrom the

('49', 2, 1, 2, 4815) Ashram.
('49', 2, 1, 3, 4823) They had to await a lift for Sandhier.
('49', 2, 1, 4, 4862) They wanted to turn to national account the time at their disposal.
('49', 2, 1, 5, 4930) They saw that the surr oundings of the place were not overclean.
('49', 2, 1, 6, 4995) They therefore decided to clean up the rubbish and so asked for brooms from the surprised villagers.
('49', 2, 1, 7, 5096) As soon as the villagers realized what had happened, they also joined these national scavengers, some of whom were drawn from aristocratic families and the village of Sayan perhaps never looked as clean as when these sisters utilized their spare time for scavenging.
('49', 2, 1, 8, 5363) I commend this true service, this mute speech of the sisters to the army of young men who are pining to serve and free the country.
('49', 2, 1, 9, 5495) Freedom will come only when we deliver a simultaneous attack on all the weak points.
('49', 2, 1, 10, 5580) Let it be known that all these sisters have enlisted as civil resisters and are eagerly, even impatiently, awaiting marching orders.
('49', 2, 1, 11, 5713) In this campaign of swaraj by self purification, it will be nothing surprising if the women outdo the men.
('49', 2, 2, 12, 5820) MOTILALJI’S MUNIFICENCE
('49', 2, 3, 13, 5844) The palatial Anand Bhavan, the pride of the Nehrus, is to be national property from 6th instant, the national Satyagraha Day.
('49', 2, 3, 14, 5970) Motilalji has much service to his credit.
('49', 2, 3, 15, 6012) Jawaharlal is his living gift to the nation.
('49', 2, 3, 16, 6057) There was no need to add brick and mortar.
('49', 2, 3, 17, 6100) But I know he has been pining to part with that spacious house which has the historical associations now made known to the public.
('49', 2, 3, 18, 6231) Truly, Motilalji has spent as he has earned.
('49', 2, 3, 19, 6276) Let us prove worthy of his services and his gifts.

('49', 2, 5, 22, 6371) This will be in the readers’ hands on Thursday 3rd instant.
('49', 2, 5, 23, 6431) If there is no previous cancelling, they all may regard this as the word from me that all are free and those who are ready are expected to start mass civil disobedience regarding the salt laws, as from 6th April.
('49', 2, 5, 24, 6644) Let me gather up what has been said in these pages at various times.
('49', 2, 5, 25, 6713) The only stipulation for civil disobedience is perfect observance of non violence in the fullest sense of the term.
('49', 2, 5, 26, 6829) Mass civil disobedience means spontaneous action.
('49', 2, 5, 27, 6879) The workers

('49', 3, 1, 2, 6931) will merely guide the masses in the beginning stages.
('49', 3, 1, 3, 6985) Later the masses will regulate the movement themselves.
('49', 3, 1, 4, 7041) Congress volunteers will watch developments and render aid wherever needed.
('49', 3, 1, 5, 7117) They will be expected to be in the forefront.
('49', 3, 1, 6, 7163) Volunteers may not take sides in any communal quarrels.
('49', 3, 1, 7, 7219) Wherever there is a violent eruption, volunteers are expected to die in the attempt to quell violence.
('49', 3, 1, 8, 7322) Perfect discipline and perfect co operation among the different units are indispensable for success.
('49', 3, 1, 9, 7423) If there is true mass awakening, those who are not engaged in civil disobedience are expected to occupy themselves and induce others to be engaged in some national service, such as khadi work, liquor and opium picketing, foreign cloth exclusion, village sanitation, assisting the families of civil resistance prisoners in a variety of ways.
('49', 3, 1, 10, 7764) Indeed if there is a real response about civil resistance regarding the salt tax, we should by proper organization secure boycott of foreign cloth through khadi and secure total prohibition.
('49', 3, 1, 11, 7955) This should mean a saving of 91 crores per year, and supplementary work for the millions of unemployed.
('49', 3, 1, 12, 8059) If we secure these things, we cannot be far from independence.
('49', 3, 1, 13, 8122) And not one of these things is beyond our capacity.

('49', 3, 2, 15, 8196) 3. PROHIBITION
('49', 3, 3, 16, 8211) Pandit Dev Sharma “Abhaya” proposes to launch a prohibition campaign in the area around Hardwar.
('49', 3, 3, 17, 8308) I have given him my approval saying that if he has the self confidence he should certainly take up the work.
('49', 3, 3, 18, 8417) The idea of non co operation was born out of the spirit of self purification.
('49', 3, 3, 19, 8495) That is why in 1920 21 such a great campaign for prohibition became possible and even succeeded.
('49', 3, 3, 20, 8592) The campaign had later to be halted, or one may say it stopped by itself, because impurity, that is, coercion, had entered it.
('49', 3, 3, 21, 8719) This time people have realized that coercion will not bring lasti ng results.
('49', 3, 3, 22, 8797) Therefore, in areas where there is no risk of violence and where workers in sufficient numbers are available, prohibition campaign can and should be launched.
('49', 3, 3, 23, 8956) This campaign can be carried on in three ways: 1. by visiting the homes of addicts and dissuading them from
('49', 4, 0, 1, 9064) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 5
('49', 4, 1, 2, 9104) drinking; 2.by persuading the liquor booth owners to close their business; and 3. by picketing the liquor booths.
('49', 4, 1, 3, 9218) All these three can also be taken up simultaneously.
('49', 4, 1, 4, 9271) In the first two there is no risk whatever.
('49', 4, 1, 5, 9315) In the third a risk of violence exists.
('49', 4, 1, 6, 9355) In regard to this the Government may issue prohibitory orders.
('49', 4, 1, 7, 9418) If such orders are issued we should not be frightened.
('49', 4, 1, 8, 9473) The easiest way to offer civil disobedience is to disregard them.
('49', 4, 1, 9, 9539) Clearly, everyone cannot do picketing nor can it be resorted to everywhere.
('49', 4, 1, 10, 9615) So the campaign will be somewhat restricted in area.
('49', 4, 1, 11, 9668) But even though it is restricted it is good work and it may also bring good results.
('49', 4, 1, 12, 9753) Therefore if those who have the self confidence take up such a campaign, it can only give me pleasure.
('49', 4, 2, 13, 9856) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 3 4 1930

('49', 5, 1, 2, 10614) 5. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, VANJH 1
('49', 5, 2, 3, 10651) April 3, 1930
('49', 5, 3, 4, 10665) Only two days now remain before we conclude this march.
('49', 5, 3, 5, 10721) We shall then set to work.
('49', 5, 3, 6, 10748) A large number of people will be present.
('49', 5, 3, 7, 10790) I told you about the scarcity of water in Dandi.
('49', 5, 3, 8, 10839) We shall have to use water as if it was milk, like the Jain sadhu who lived in the forest.
('49', 5, 3, 9, 10930) I must also tell you that they are finding it very difficult to arrange for our meals.
('49', 5, 3, 10, 11017) So after reaching Dandi all that you will be given three times a day would be _ seer of gram, _ seer of puffed rice, and boiled water with a tola of ghee and jaggery added.
('49', 5, 3, 11, 11190) You shall get used to this for we have to lead austere lives.
('49', 5, 3, 12, 11252) Another piece of information that I have received is that the Government intends to use fire engines to stop us.
('49', 5, 3, 13, 11365) We have prepared ourselves for death from cannons and guns, compared to which this is nothing.
('49', 5, 3, 14, 11460) Of course, even with jets of water, the Government can kill us through torture.
('49', 5, 3, 15, 11540) It is certainly painful.
('49', 5, 3, 16, 11565) However, you must bear in mind that not one of us will retreat.
('49', 5, 3, 17, 11629) I do not think the Government will be so cruel, but we must be prepared.

('49', 6, 1, 2, 11797) 6. SPEECH AT NAVSARI
('49', 6, 2, 3, 11818) April 3, 1930
('49', 6, 3, 4, 11832) Navsari is the headquarters of our Parsi brethren.
('49', 6, 3, 5, 11883) The total number of Parsis in the world is less than a hundred thousand and of these the majority live in the Bombay Presidency, chiefly in Navsari and Bombay.
('49', 6, 3, 6, 12043) If I come across a Parsi friend anywhere in the country while touring, I never fail to recognize him.
('49', 6, 3, 7, 12145) An English writer called Lang while comparing charitable attitudes the world over has established that in generosity Parsis, if we consider their number, top the list.
('49', 6, 3, 8, 12313) The Parsi brethren who are like a drop in the ocean, have made the world talk of their generosity.
('49', 6, 3, 9, 12412) History records no other instance of a community having practised such dispassionate generosity.
('49', 6, 3, 10, 12509) Whenever I have stretched out my hand before Parsis, it has never returned empty.
('49', 6, 3, 11, 12591) In the satyagraha in South Africa too, Parsi brethren were in the forefront.
('49', 6, 3, 12, 12668) Sheth Rustomji sacrificed his all.
('49', 6, 3, 13, 12703) That is why I have sung his praises like a minstrel.
('49', 6, 3, 14, 12756) How can I repay this debt to the Parsis?
('49', 6, 3, 15, 12797) Being a beggar, how can I repay my debts with money?
('49', 6, 3, 16, 12850) I am not a saheb or a Viceroy that I may give them high offices or titles.
('49', 6, 3, 17, 12925) Hence, today, having come to Navsari, I shall sing their praises and take away something from them.
('49', 6, 3, 18, 13025) Parsi brethren are, of course, there in this struggle.
('49', 6, 3, 19, 13080) A Zoroastrian friend who is like a brother to me and who is suspected of having cancer, is nevertheless dying to take part in this struggle.
('49', 6, 3, 20, 13221) Take the case of Dadabhai’s grand daughters.
('49', 6, 3, 21, 13266) These sisters are just crazy and impatient to join the struggle.
('49', 6, 3, 22, 13331) What more then need I say about the assistance from Parsis?
('49', 6, 3, 23, 13391) However, I want something special.
('49', 6, 3, 24, 13426) You may take it that the salt tax is as good as abolished.
('49', 6, 3, 25, 13485) Ever since I set out from the Ashram, at various places Parsis have showered blessings on me and said: “May you triumph.
('49', 6, 3, 26, 13606) God is with you.
('49', 6, 3, 27, 13623) And come back after securing swaraj.” And I shall return, if I am alive, after winning swaraj.
('49', 6, 3, 28, 13718) You can make the largest contribution if, instead of joining in the salt struggle, you participate in the prohibition movement.
('49', 7, 0, 1, 13846) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 7, 1, 2, 13886) We ruin ourselves by spending Rs. 25 crores on liquor.
('49', 7, 1, 3, 13941) Because of this evil habit our homes have been destroyed.
('49', 7, 1, 4, 13999) Although I was a lawyer in South Africa, I moved about a good deal among our labo uring brethren there.
('49', 7, 1, 5, 14103) These labourers also came to see me about their problems.
('49', 7, 1, 6, 14161) And, since I had made myself part of their lives they told me their joys and sorrows, their tales of woe.
('49', 7, 1, 7, 14267) And they would break down and cry while telling me how they had ruined themselves through drink.
('49', 7, 1, 8, 14364) I know from experience that many of my labourer brethren in Ahmedabad are in a similar plight.
('49', 7, 1, 9, 14459) Those who are given to drink often cannot distinguish between wife, mother and daughter.
('49', 7, 1, 10, 14548) Man degenerates into brute.
('49', 7, 1, 11, 14576) Whoever gets entrapped in this vice bec omes an animal.
('49', 7, 1, 12, 14632) I have with my own eyes seen the captain of a ship, when drunk, rolling in vomit.
('49', 7, 1, 13, 14714) I ask my Parsi brethren to help me rescue addicts from this vice.
('49', 7, 1, 14, 14780) Mithubehn saw people given to drink.
('49', 7, 1, 15, 14817) It moved her and leaving her mother, her home and her belongings she has plunged into the cause of prohibition.
('49', 7, 1, 16, 14929) However, the sacrifice by one Parsi lady is not sufficient to complete this task.
('49', 7, 1, 17, 15011) The heart of every Parsi must be touched for the sake of this cause.
('49', 7, 1, 18, 15080) And, where it seems necessary, persons like me may even have to offer satyagraha.
('49', 7, 1, 19, 15162) Parsis are intell igent and capable and they earn crores of rupees.
('49', 7, 1, 20, 15230) They are god fearing.
('49', 7, 1, 21, 15252) If, from today, Parsi owners of liquor booths give up this trade on realizing that to do business in liquor is a sin, other liquor booth owners will certainly follow their example.
('49', 7, 1, 22, 15433) When we save thus 25 crore rupees we shall have rehabilitated crores of poor homes.
('49', 7, 1, 23, 15517) The gods will then shower flowers upon us.
('49', 7, 1, 24, 15560) If you can enter the hearts of people and make them give up liquor, it will generate such power that we shall be able to achieve whatever we want.
('49', 7, 1, 25, 15707) I ask the ladies in particular to help in this.
('49', 7, 1, 26, 15755) They should visit the homes of those who drink and plead with them.
('49', 7, 1, 27, 15823) I have seen women of the Salvation Army do this.
('49', 7, 1, 28, 15872) Why should not the women of India do the same?
('49', 7, 1, 29, 15919) Are they—the Hindu, Muslim and Parsi women—less capable of doing good?
('49', 7, 1, 30, 15990) Are not those who are caught in the vice their own brothers?
('49', 7, 1, 31, 16051) If I go and reason with them, they will quarrel with me as they will with other men.
('49', 7, 1, 32, 16136) They will not, however, be disrespectful or insulting to any woman.
('49', 7, 1, 33, 16204) They are not such beasts that they will not understand you.
('49', 7, 1, 34, 16264) As soon as they come in contact with you they will be awakened, they will step back and, seeing the love and affection
('49', 8, 0, 1, 16383) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 9
('49', 8, 1, 2, 16423) pouring from your eyes, they will conclude that it is some sati or yogini confronting them and ashamed of themselves they will give up liquor.
('49', 8, 1, 3, 16566) When you sisters come to know the wives and daughters of drunkards, when you make friends with their ignorant, straying children, when you see that they continue to drink although they own nothing but the sky above them and the earth below, you cannot but feel inspired to take up this sacred cause.
('49', 8, 1, 4, 16866) I leave this message for the sisters in case the Government whisks me away to prison.
('49', 8, 1, 5, 16952) Gujarati women are trained in such matters.
('49', 8, 1, 6, 16996) Women in no other part of India have received as much training as they have.
('49', 8, 1, 7, 17073) Hence all you sisters must plunge into the field which has already been prepared by Mithubehn.
('49', 8, 1, 8, 17168) In this non violent struggle, women can play an even greater part than men because they are the very embodiment of renu nciation and compassion, i.e., of non violence.
('49', 8, 1, 9, 17336) A man understands the dharma of non violence through his intellect whereas a woman has imbibed it even before her birth.
('49', 8, 1, 10, 17457) A man escapes with very little responsibility, but women have to serve their husbands, their children and other members of the family.
('49', 8, 1, 11, 17592) Parsis have laid me under a crushing burden of debt to them.
('49', 8, 1, 12, 17653) They have made a slave of me by their words of love.
('49', 8, 1, 13, 17706) And a slave enjoys the right to demand more from his master.
('49', 8, 1, 14, 17767) In this yajna of self purification, I shall not be satisfied even if you drown me in money or provide me with volunteers.
('49', 8, 1, 15, 17889) I shall be satisfied only when the entire Parsi community hears my appeal and when Parsi brothers and sisters identify themselves with the work that Mithubehn is doing.

('49', 9, 2, 17, 19915) 8. LETTER TO REGINALD REYNOLDS
('49', 9, 3, 18, 19946) BIJALPUR, April 4, 1930
('49', 9, 4, 19, 19970) MY DEAR REGINALD, I was delighted to have your letter.

('49', 10, 1, 2, 20856) 9. SPEECH IN VIJALPORE
('49', 10, 2, 3, 20879) April 4, 1930
('49', 10, 3, 4, 20893) After this meeting is over, I have to make two more speeches before I reach my destination.
('49', 10, 3, 5, 20985) I shall make a speech at Dandi if I have to.
('49', 10, 3, 6, 21030) Forty one Headmen have handed in their resignations and the President of the Taluka Committee has congratulated them.
('49', 10, 3, 7, 21148) Besides the 47, I have been informed today of some seven more.
('49', 10, 3, 8, 21211) Bharat Bhushan Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya has resigned from the Legislative Assembly and six others have followed him.
('49', 10, 3, 9, 21331) These six are also well known men.
('49', 10, 3, 10, 21366) On the one hand Bharat Bhu shan Malaviyaji has resigned, on the other the Headmen have resigned.
('49', 10, 3, 11, 21463) The action of the latter is more valuable, for Malaviyaji was not a Government servant.
('49', 10, 3, 12, 21551) He had entered the legislature with a view to serving the coun try if possible.
('49', 10, 3, 13, 21631) I can think of no one who has served the country with such single minded devotion as Malaviyaji has.
('49', 10, 3, 14, 21732) Nevertheless I assign greater value to the resignations of the Headmen of Gujarat.
('49', 10, 3, 15, 21815) The reason is that Malaviyaji has not been a part of the administration of this country.
('49', 10, 3, 16, 21904) The latter is run by these Headmen and Malaviyaji in fact only lends a gloss to the administration which we fear.
('49', 10, 3, 17, 22018) The gloss can always be separated from the utensil.
('49', 10, 3, 18, 22070) Headmen, however, are not a gloss which can be separated.
('49', 10, 3, 19, 22128) They along with the Talatis are the two legs on which this Government rests.
('49', 10, 3, 20, 22205) An enumeration of the Headmen and Talatis in the seven lakh villages of this country would give us fourteen lakhs of such legs and in this manner the resignation of each Headman would amount to the loss of one leg.
('49', 10, 3, 21, 22420) It is for this reason that these resignations have value.
('49', 10, 3, 22, 22478) This is so, however, only if they have been tendered sincerely.
('49', 10, 3, 23, 22542) Sardar, who once had an income ranging bet ween Rs. 1,000 and Rs. 2,000 a month has to beg for his meals today.
('49', 10, 3, 24, 22654) For him, it was not easy to resign.
('49', 10, 3, 25, 22690) The poor Headman, on the other hand, receives a paltry sum of Rs. 50 or 51 8 0 by way of a bounty.
('49', 10, 3, 26, 22789) What are the Headmen then clinging to?
('49', 10, 3, 27, 22828) If they want to be loyal to Sardar they will have to be disloyal to the Government.
('49', 10, 3, 28, 22912) I am going to Dandi.
('49', 10, 3, 29, 22933) But I would request you not to follow me there.
('49', 10, 3, 30, 22981) If you do, come as soldiers carrying your food on one shoulder and water on the other.
('49', 10, 3, 31, 23068) Come with the intention of doing some work.
('49', 10, 3, 32, 23112) Do not come with the idea of having a picnic.
('49', 10, 3, 33, 23158) The stock of khadi is fast being exhausted.
('49', 10, 3, 34, 23202) You must use it sparingly in the same manner as you use ghee.
('49', 10, 3, 35, 23264) If you cannot obtain khadi, it is your duty to come clad
('49', 11, 0, 1, 23321) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 11, 1, 2, 23362) only in loin cloths made of khadi, but on no account must you come clad in foreign cloth.
('49', 11, 1, 3, 23452) Those who drink must not come to take the pledge.

('49', 11, 2, 5, 23540) 10. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('49', 11, 3, 6, 23574) DANDI, April 5, 1930
('49', 11, 4, 7, 23595) God be thanked for what may be termed the happy ending of the first stage in this, for me at least, the final struggle for freedom.
('49', 11, 4, 8, 23727) I cannot withhold my compliments from the Government for the policy of complete non interference adopted by them throughout the march.
('49', 11, 4, 9, 23862) After the graceless and childish performance in the matter of Mr. Vallabhbhai’s arrest and imprisonment and equally unprovoked arrest and imprisonment of Mr. Sen Gupta, I was wholly unprepared for this exemplary non interference.
('49', 11, 4, 10, 24092) I am not so foolish as to imagine that the Government has suddenly lost their proved capacity for pro voking popular resentment and then punishing it with frigh tfulness.
('49', 11, 4, 11, 24263) I wish I could believe this non interference was due to any real change of heart or policy.
('49', 11, 4, 12, 24355) The wanton disregard shown by them to popular feeling in the Legislative Assembly and their high handed action leave no room for doubt that the policy of heartless exploitation of India is to be persisted in at any cost, and so the only interpretation I can put upon this non interference is that the British Gove rnment, powerful though it is, is sensitive to world opinion which will not tolerate repression of extreme political agitation which civil disobedience undoubtedly is, so long as disobedience remains civil and, therefore, necessarily non violent.
('49', 11, 4, 13, 24916) It remains to be seen whether the Government will tolerate, as they have tolerated the march, the actual breach of the salt laws by countless people from tomorrow.
('49', 11, 4, 14, 25080) I expect extensive popular response to the resolution of the Working Committee.
('49', 11, 4, 15, 25160) I have seen nothing to warrant the cancellation of the notice I have already issued, that all committees and organizations throughout the length and breadth of the land are free, if they are prepared, to commence from tomorrow civil disobedience in respect of the salt laws.
('49', 11, 4, 16, 25435) God willing, I expect with my companions (volunteers) to commence actual civil disobedience at 6.30 tomorrow morning.
('49', 11, 4, 17, 25553) 6th April has been to us, since its culm 
('49', 12, 0, 1, 25595) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 13
('49', 12, 1, 2, 25636) ination in Jallianwala massacre, a day for penance and purification.
('49', 12, 1, 3, 25705) We, therefore, commence it with prayer and fasting.
('49', 12, 1, 4, 25757) I hope the whole of India will observe the National Week commencing from tomorrow in the spirit in which it was conceived.
('49', 12, 1, 5, 25880) I am positive that the greater the dedication to the country’s cause and the greater the purification, the speedier will be the glorious end for which millions of India consciously or unconsciously are striving.
('49', 12, 2, 6, 26092) Speeches and Writings of Mahatma Gandhi, p.

('49', 12, 8, 12, 26315) DANDI, April 5, 1930 I know I have countless friends in America who are in deep sympathy with this struggle but mere sympathy will avail me nothing.

('49', 12, 8, 14, 26672) In all humility but in perfect truth I claim that if we attain our end through non violent means India will have delivered a message for the world.

('49', 14, 1, 2, 27896) 15. SPEECH AT DANDI
('49', 14, 2, 3, 27916) April 5, 1930
('49', 14, 3, 4, 27930) When I left Sabarmati with my companions for this seaside hamlet of Dandi, I was not certain in my mind that we would be allowed to reach this place.
('49', 14, 3, 5, 28080) Even while I was at Sabarmati there was a rumour that I might be arrested.
('49', 14, 3, 6, 28155) I had thought that the Government might perhaps let my party come as far as Dandi, but not me certainly.
('49', 14, 3, 7, 28260) If someone says that this betrays imperfect faith on my part, I shall not deny the charge.
('49', 14, 3, 8, 28351) That I have reached here is in no small measure due to the power of peace and non violence: that power is universally felt.
('49', 14, 3, 9, 28475) The Government may, if it wishes, congratulate itself on acting as it has done, for it could have arrested every one of us.
('49', 14, 3, 10, 28599) In saying that it did not have the courage to arrest this army of peace, we praise it.
('49', 14, 3, 11, 28686) It felt ashamed to arrest such an army.
('49', 14, 3, 12, 28726) He is a civilized man who feels ashamed to do anything which his neighbours would dis approve.
('49', 14, 3, 13, 28821) The Government deserves to be congratulated on not arresting us, even if it desisted only from fear of world opinion.
('49', 14, 3, 14, 28939) Tomorrow we shall break the salt tax law.
('49', 14, 3, 15, 28981) Whether the Gover nment will tolerate that is a different question.
('49', 14, 3, 16, 29049) It may not tolerate it, but it deserves congratulations on the patience and forbearance it has displayed in regard to this party.
('49', 14, 3, 17, 29179) If the civil disobedience movement becomes widespread in the country and the Government tolerates it, the salt law may be taken as abolished.
('49', 14, 3, 18, 29321) I have no doubt in my mind that the salt tax stood abolished the very moment that the decision to break the salt laws was reached and a few men took the pledge to carry on the movement even at the risk of their lives till swaraj was won.
('49', 14, 3, 19, 29559) If the Government tolerates the impending civil disobedience you may take it for certain that the Government, too, has resolved to abolish this tax sooner or later.
('49', 14, 3, 20, 29724) If they arrest me or my companions tomorrow, I shall not be surprised, I shall certainly not be pained.
('49', 14, 3, 21, 29828) It would be absurd to be pained if we get something that we have invited on ourselves.
('49', 14, 3, 22, 29915) What if I and all the eminent leaders in Gujarat and in the rest of the country are arrested?
('49', 14, 3, 23, 30009) This movement is based on the faith that when a whole nation is roused and on the march no leader isnecessary.
('49', 14, 3, 24, 30120) Of the hundreds of thousands that blessed us during our
('49', 15, 0, 1, 30176) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 15, 1, 2, 30217) march and listened to my speeches there will be many who are sure to take up this battle.
('49', 15, 1, 3, 30307) That alone will be mass civil disobedience.
('49', 15, 1, 4, 30351) We are now resolved to make salt freely in every home, as our ancestors used to, and sell it from place to place, and we will continue doing so wherever possible till the Government yields, so much so that the salt in Government stocks will become superfluous.
('49', 15, 1, 5, 30612) If the awakening of the people in the country is true and real, the salt law is as good as abolished.
('49', 15, 1, 6, 30714) But the goal we wish to reach is yet very far.
('49', 15, 1, 7, 30761) For the present Dandi is our destination but our real destination is no other than the temple of the goddess of swaraj.
('49', 15, 1, 8, 30881) Our minds will not be at peace till we have her darshan, nor will we allow the Government any peace.
('49', 15, 1, 9, 30982) Those Headmen who have resigned their posts should prove themselves true to their word and should regard it as a sin to serve this Government till freedom is won.
('49', 15, 1, 10, 31145) For the last four or five days, I have been speaking about other constructive activities also, and they should be taken up immediately in this Jalalpur taluka.
('49', 15, 1, 11, 31305) Surat district is notorious for the drink habit, and the Jalalpur taluka is particularly so.
('49', 15, 1, 12, 31398) Now that the wind of self purification is blowing here, it should not be a difficult task to eradicate the drink evil altogether.
('49', 15, 1, 13, 31528) There is sin in every leaf of the palm tree.
('49', 15, 1, 14, 31573) Its only value lies in the ruin it brings us.
('49', 15, 1, 15, 31619) This plant is like poison to us.
('49', 15, 1, 16, 31652) All palm trees should therefore be cut down.
('49', 15, 1, 17, 31697) There should not be a single person in Jalalpur taluka wearing foreign cloth.
('49', 15, 1, 18, 31775) Everyone who comes to Dandi should come with the intention to participate in, and offer his mite to, this swaraj yajna.
('49', 15, 1, 19, 31895) I would not like anyone coming to Dandi wearing foreign cloth.
('49', 15, 1, 20, 31958) If it is our wish to turn Dandi into a place of pilgrimage or a bulwark of swaraj, everyone coming here should be dressed exclusively in khadi.
('49', 15, 1, 21, 32102) I know that the stocks of khadi in the khadi stores are about to be exhausted, and if, therefore, you fail to get a full length sari or dhoti and come wearing only a khadi langoti, you will be welcome here as a civilized person.
('49', 15, 1, 22, 32331) If, ignoring my suggestion, any of you come to Dandi wearing foreign cloth, I shall have to place at the points of approach to Dandi, volunteers who will kneel before you and request you to wear khadi.
('49', 15, 1, 23, 32533) If you feel offended by their doing so and slap them in the face, those satyagrahis will let themselves be slapped.
('49', 15, 1, 24, 32649) Dandi was chosen not by a man but by God.
('49', 15, 1, 25, 32691) How otherwise
('49', 16, 0, 1, 32705) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 17
('49', 16, 1, 2, 32746) could we have chosen for the battle field of satyagraha such an out of the way place—a place where no food grains are to be had, where there is scarcity of water, where thousands can assemble only with difficulty, walking ten miles from the railway station, and where if you are travelling on foot, you have to negotiate creeks full of slush and mud?
('49', 16, 1, 3, 33097) The truth is that in this struggle we have to put up with suffering.
('49', 16, 1, 4, 33166) You have made the road from Navsari to Dandi famous throughout the world by arranging for free drinking water at frequent intervals all along it.
('49', 16, 1, 5, 33312) If this struggle did not have your approval, your blessings, why would you be doing this?
('49', 16, 1, 6, 33402) Dandi should be a sacred ground for us, where we should utter no untruth, commit no sin.
('49', 16, 1, 7, 33491) Everyone coming here should come with this devout feeling in his heart.
('49', 16, 1, 8, 33563) If you brothers and sisters come forward as true volunteers and commit civil disobedience of the salt law, no matter what force the Government threatens to use against you, and if you do whatever else you may be required to do, we shall have in us the power to attain in a single day what we hold to be our birt hright.
('49', 16, 1, 9, 33883) Time was when I was infatuated with British rule, as British law taught that the person of every individual is sacred.
('49', 16, 1, 10, 34002) According to that law, the police cannot kill or manhandle a man even though he might be guilty of murder.
('49', 16, 1, 11, 34109) It is the duty of the police to produce the man alive before the court.
('49', 16, 1, 12, 34181) Nor has the police any authority outside the jail to seize from a person even goods alleged to have been stolen.
('49', 16, 1, 13, 34294) But here the very opposite is true.
('49', 16, 1, 14, 34330) How otherwise can the police have the authority to decide whether I hold a handful of salt or pebbles?
('49', 16, 1, 15, 34433) Every man’s house is his castle.
('49', 16, 1, 16, 34466) Our body also is a fort of a kind.
('49', 16, 1, 17, 34501) And once salt has entered that fort, it should not be allowed to be forced out of it even if horses are made to trample on your heads.
('49', 16, 1, 18, 34636) From today we should begin cultivating the strength of will to see that a fist holding salt does not open even if the wrist should be cut off.
('49', 16, 1, 19, 34779) Unauthorized entry into a house is a barbarous act.
('49', 16, 1, 20, 34831) It is for a judge to decide whether I hold in my hand salt or dust.
('49', 16, 1, 21, 34899) The English law holds the human person to be sacred.
('49', 16, 1, 22, 34952) If every official assumes the authority of a judge and enters our homes, he would be acting as a robber.
('49', 16, 1, 23, 35057) But the officers in India, when they feel impelled, throw the English laws to the winds or ignore them completely at their sweet will and, resorting to the Act of 1818, render them all ineffective.
('49', 16, 1, 24, 35255) They have started arresting one leader after another.
('49', 17, 0, 1, 35309) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 17, 1, 2, 35350) according to the principle of this struggle, that the leader is one who endures the utmost suffering, one of those left outside should assume leadership and take the movement forward.
('49', 17, 1, 3, 35534) This is a struggle not of one man but of millions of us.
('49', 17, 1, 4, 35591) If three or four men can fight and win swaraj, they will rule the country afterwards.
('49', 17, 1, 5, 35677) Hence, in this struggle for swaraj millions should offer themselves for sacrifice and win such swaraj as will benefit the vast masses of the country.
('49', 17, 1, 6, 35827) The Government is taking away from us all the eminent leaders one after another.
('49', 17, 1, 7, 35908) If we get ready to follow in their footsteps and do the duty shown by them, we can smile at what the Government is doing, but if we fail to do our duty we should feel ashamed.
('49', 17, 1, 8, 36084) The leaders are behind the bars, and now we in our turn should take their place.
('49', 17, 1, 9, 36165) It is true that many of the leaders in and outside Gujarat have been jailed, that many volunteers have been wounded because they would not part with the salt in their hands, and that, at places, some were beaten so hard that they became unconscious.
('49', 17, 1, 10, 36415) But I remain unmoved.
('49', 17, 1, 11, 36437) My heart now is as hard as stone.
('49', 17, 1, 12, 36471) I am in this struggle for swaraj ready to sacrifice thousands and hundreds of thousands of men if necessary.
('49', 17, 1, 13, 36580) Since we have embarked upon a movement which will send thousands to jail, how can we weep over their imprisonment?
('49', 17, 1, 14, 36695) In this game of dice we are playing, the throw has been as we wanted.
('49', 17, 1, 15, 36765) Should we then weep or smile?
('49', 17, 1, 16, 36795) This is God’s grace; let us remain unmoved and watch His miracles.
('49', 17, 1, 17, 36862) If in spite of our breaking several salt laws the Government takes no notice of the camp here till the 13th, we shall disband it after that date and go somewhere else.
('49', 17, 1, 18, 37030) But this plan depends entirely on the Government.
('49', 17, 1, 19, 37080) For the present, we can but take what the Government gives.
('49', 17, 1, 20, 37140) If you have not yet gone out to remove salt, let the whole village get together and go.
('49', 17, 1, 21, 37228) Hold the salt in your fist and think that you are carrying in your hand salt worth Rs. 6 crores.
('49', 17, 1, 22, 37325) Every year the Government has been taking away from us Rs. 6 cores through its monopoly of salt.
('49', 17, 1, 23, 37422) You can today take the pledge not to eat salt supplied by the Government.
('49', 17, 1, 24, 37496) You have a mine of salt right at your doorsteps.
('49', 17, 1, 25, 37545) There is at Rohtak a humble, brave and selfless publicworker named Lala Shyamlal.
('49', 17, 1, 26, 37627) At the time of the non co operation movement
('49', 18, 0, 1, 37672) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 19
('49', 18, 1, 2, 37713) in 1921 he gave up his law practice but resumed it whenthe tide was low and earned thousands of rupees.
('49', 18, 1, 3, 37817) However, his heart melted once more after the Lahore Congress and he pleaded to be taken into the Ashram.
('49', 18, 1, 4, 37923) He also expressed his eagerness to join this march of saty agrahis to Dandi.
('49', 18, 1, 5, 38000) But why should I exchange this gold mohur for a mere pice?
('49', 18, 1, 6, 38059) So I sent him back to Rohtak.
('49', 18, 1, 7, 38089) As he writes to me, he took leave of me after he had understood the value of non violence better than before.
('49', 18, 1, 8, 38199) He has now vowed never to give up non violence and never to prove disloyal to the Ashram principles.
('49', 18, 1, 9, 38300) This Lala Shya mlal has now been arrested on a charge of spreading disaffection against the Government.
('49', 18, 1, 10, 38404) He must have made some speech on the lines of my writings in Young India in which I preach disaffection as our moral duty.
('49', 18, 1, 11, 38527) In the first place, they should apply Section 124A to the person who has been every moment praying for the destruction of the Empire and has also been attempting to destroy it—apply it, that is, to myself.
('49', 18, 1, 12, 38733) But the true position is that Section 124A can be applied only to a person who wishes to overthrow the Government by rebellion or armed action.
('49', 18, 1, 13, 38877) It can never apply to a person who wishes to destroy the Empire through self suffering by following the path of non violence and truth.
('49', 18, 1, 14, 39013) But I am no judge.
('49', 18, 1, 15, 39032) I have even been disbarred.

('49', 25, 1, 2, 53052) 20. MY NOTES
('49', 25, 2, 3, 53065) SOME QUESTIONS
('49', 25, 3, 4, 53080) QUESTION.
('49', 25, 3, 5, 53090) Should one insist upon khadi in jail?
('49', 25, 4, 6, 53128) ANSWER.
('49', 25, 4, 7, 53136) I was not aware of this problem when I conceived the khadi vow.
('49', 25, 4, 8, 53200) I feel that such insistence is unnecessary.
('49', 25, 4, 9, 53244) Ordinarily a saty agrahi should not oppose any of the prison rules which do not violate his dharma.
('49', 25, 4, 10, 53344) But everyone should decide his own duty in this regard.
('49', 25, 4, 11, 53400) If someone has taken a vow that under no circumstances will he wear anything but khadi, he should certainly insist upon khadi.
('49', 25, 4, 12, 53527) But I would consider it improper for one to take such a vow and go to jail.
('49', 25, 5, 13, 53603) Q. Anyone who follows the rule of eating only after having spun 160 strands of yarn would prefer the spinning wheel to the takli.
('49', 25, 5, 14, 53733) Should one therefore insist on being provided with a spinning wheel and facilities for carding?
('49', 25, 5, 15, 53829) Spinning on a takli would take much time and interfere with prison work, hence the spinning wheel is an abs olute necessity.
('49', 25, 5, 16, 53954) Is one justified in insisting upon spinning 160 strands or should one be satisfied with less?
('49', 25, 6, 17, 54048) A. Spinning is a yajna so one can insist upon being provided with a spinning wheel and facilities for carding.
('49', 25, 6, 18, 54159) Anybody who has taken the vow of spinning must insist on both.
('49', 25, 6, 19, 54222) It is not enough that a takli is provided.
('49', 25, 6, 20, 54265) Whether one should be satisfied with less than 160 strands depends upon the vow.
('49', 25, 6, 21, 54346) If the vow is to spin 160 strands one cannot do with less.
('49', 25, 7, 22, 54405) Q. What should one generally do when, for instance, the food provided is dirty, or when no urinals are provided, or when one is req uired to complete the calls of nature within two or three minutes and is not allowed to visit the lavatory again if the need arises, or when one is over burdened with work, or when one cannot sleep owing to the warders shouting out the roll call all night long?
('49', 25, 7, 23, 54799) What kind of insistence concerning what matter would be regarded as dharma?
('49', 25, 8, 24, 54875) A. The common rule in such matters is that those inconveniences with which one can put up and which do no harm to one’s self respect, should be tolerated while in the remaining matters one should fight as befits a satyagrahi.
('49', 25, 8, 25, 55101) I would not tolerate dirty food or filthy utensils.
('49', 25, 8, 26, 55153) I would not tolerate dirty urinals, but if facilities for this were provided in my cell I would not object to these.
('49', 25, 8, 27, 55270) I would certainly take my own time with regard to evacuation of the bowels and would not tolerate being hustled in this matter.
('49', 25, 8, 28, 55398) I would tolerate the noise of roll call.

('49', 26, 1, 2, 55480) TO THE HEARTLESS MEN
('49', 26, 2, 3, 55501) The heartless Gujaratis do not appear to be concerned about Gujarati women being killed every day by Primus stoves.
('49', 26, 2, 4, 55617) I have just been informed of the death of two women.
('49', 26, 2, 5, 55670) During the present pilgr image, I have had first hand experience of the dangers involved in using these stoves.
('49', 26, 2, 6, 55782) Even one of my experienced and skilled colleagues has had two narrow escapes.
('49', 26, 2, 7, 55860) As a result of this, I have prohibited the use of such stoves altogether.
('49', 26, 2, 8, 55934) Women do not know how to use a Primus stove, for it does require some skill.
('49', 26, 2, 9, 56011) And our women cannot put it on a table.
('49', 26, 2, 10, 56051) Hence, it is the duty of men to boycott it.
('49', 26, 2, 11, 56095) So long as they do not do so, the deaths of the young girls and women from the use of this stove will be on their heads.
('49', 26, 2, 12, 56216) Even Primus stoves which have been bought should be discarded.

('49', 26, 3, 16, 56437) 21. SWADESHI
('49', 26, 4, 17, 56450) The cloth merchants of Bombay are talking of boycotting foreign cloth.
('49', 26, 4, 18, 56521) The Gujarat Sabha of Ahmedabad is doing the same.
('49', 26, 4, 19, 56571) The intention of both is to help as much as possible the movement for the boycott of foreign cloth.
('49', 26, 4, 20, 56671) However, if either of them should make a mistake, harm may be caused to the movement.
('49', 26, 4, 21, 56757) We now find the following varieties of swadeshi: (1) Pure khadi, i.e., khadi made from hand spun and hand woven yarn.
('49', 26, 4, 22, 56875) (2) Cloth made in India in mills owned and run by Indians and from yarn that is also produced in such mills.
('49', 26, 4, 23, 56984) (3) Cloth made in such mills out of yarn that is wholly or partly of foreign origin.
('49', 26, 4, 24, 57069) (4) Cloth made in any mill which, although located in India, is owned and controlled by foreigners.
('49', 26, 4, 25, 57169) (5) Any object that is made in India.
('49', 26, 4, 26, 57207) (6) Any object for the making of which part of the work has been done in India, for instance, a musical instrument assembled here, though all its parts were made abroad.
('49', 27, 0, 1, 57377) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 27, 1, 2, 57418) The following are the various forms of boycott.
('49', 27, 1, 3, 57466) (a) Boycott of all foreign cloth.
('49', 27, 1, 4, 57500) (b) Boycott of British cloth alone.
('49', 27, 1, 5, 57536) (c) Boycott of all British goods.
('49', 27, 1, 6, 57570) (d) Boycott of all foreign goods.
('49', 27, 1, 7, 57604) In my opinion (1), i.e., pure khadi alone is swadeshi and, true boycott implies (a), i.e., boycott of all foreign cloth .
('49', 27, 1, 8, 57726) If item No.
('49', 27, 1, 9, 57738) (1) is proved to be swadeshi, other necessary items will prove their swadeshi character.
('49', 27, 1, 10, 57827) We shall be unable to satisfy the need for even one article of swadeshi which is essential, if we try to obtain all swadeshi goods which may be found to be desirable.
('49', 27, 1, 11, 57994) Only one form of boycott, i.e., item (a), boycott of all foreign cloth, is essential and this can be achieved through khadi alone.
('49', 27, 1, 12, 58125) The reader should remember that discussion on other swadeshi goods has been going on ever since the Congress came into existence forty five years ago.
('49', 27, 1, 13, 58276) Even so, no conclusion has been reached.
('49', 27, 1, 14, 58317) The question of pure swadeshi, that is khadi, was first taken up only nine years ago.
('49', 27, 1, 15, 58403) Nevertheless, we have achieved a fair amount of success there.
('49', 27, 1, 16, 58466) For the furtherance of this cause a national institution has come into being the like of which I do not find anywhere else in the world.
('49', 27, 1, 17, 58603) It is only through khadi that the experiment of civil disobedience on such a large scale became possible.
('49', 27, 1, 18, 58709) The reader should remember that although we have been talking about boycott of British goods for the past forty five years, we have not met with any success in this sphere.
('49', 27, 1, 19, 58882) Boycott of foreign cloth on the other hand has now proved so effective that the people have developed faith in the possibility of such a boycott.
('49', 27, 1, 20, 59028) In my opinion it would be harmful from a practical standpoint to divert the attention of the people from the boycott of foreign cloth and it will be short sightedness to think of attempting such a boycott without the help of khadi.
('49', 27, 1, 21, 59260) If such a boycott were possible with the help of Indian mills, this could have been achieved by now, i.e., during the last fifty years.
('49', 27, 1, 22, 59396) Yes, the mills could certainly help khadi in making the boycott effective.
('49', 27, 1, 23, 59471) I have already shown how this could be done in practice.
('49', 27, 1, 24, 59528) The swadeshi of Indian mills is not merely useless, it is also harmful.
('49', 27, 1, 25, 59600) This is because it puts khadi on a par with mill made cloth.
('49', 27, 1, 26, 59661) This is like the friendship between a tall and a short man.
('49', 28, 0, 1, 59721) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 29
('49', 28, 1, 2, 59762) short man has the same rights as the tall man, he really has none.
('49', 28, 1, 3, 59829) One can see with the naked eye that someone who is short cannot stand alongside someone who is tall.
('49', 28, 1, 4, 59930) Hence, if the tall man wishes to be just to the short man he should always put the latter in the front.
('49', 28, 1, 5, 60034) He should be ready to renounce anything in his favour.
('49', 28, 1, 6, 60089) It may even be necessary for him to lift the short man on his shoulder in order to sustain him.
('49', 28, 1, 7, 60185) The relationship between khadi and mill made cloth is exa ctly of this nature.
('49', 28, 1, 8, 60264) Whereas the latter is well set on its feet, the former has as yet only learnt to crawl.
('49', 28, 1, 9, 60352) Hence anyone who has not taken the vow to wear pure khadi can at least act in the following manner.
('49', 28, 1, 10, 60452) He can refuse to wear any cloth which has a single thread of foreign yarn in it.
('49', 28, 1, 11, 60533) Instead, he should take the vow of using pure khadi alone.
('49', 28, 1, 12, 60592) And, in case he is unable to do so, he should use cloth made in mills which are exclusively owned and controlled by Indians.
('49', 28, 1, 13, 60717) If khadi is not constantly kept in view, the result will be that the price of cloth made in mills in India—not Indian mills—will keep increasing and the boycott will never become effective.
('49', 28, 1, 14, 60907) 1. In this age, no amount of effort would make it possible for mills to make cloth sufficient to meet the country’s needs.
('49', 28, 1, 15, 61030) 2. The concern of mills generally is, and will be, profits.
('49', 28, 1, 16, 61090) 3. The Government can, at any time, suppress the mills.
('49', 28, 1, 17, 61146) 4. The present trend indicates that mills in this country are passing under foreign ownership and control.
('49', 28, 1, 18, 61253) 5. As mills are dependent upon foreign machines and foreign techniques, they could, all of a sudden, be faced with a difficult situation.
('49', 28, 1, 19, 61391) While on the contrary: (1) If the sentiment for khadi becomes widespread in the country, we can produce today as much khadi as we require.
('49', 28, 1, 20, 61530) (2) Khadi does not require as much capital as mills do.
('49', 28, 1, 21, 61586) (3) It does not require as much technical skill.
('49', 28, 1, 22, 61635) (4) It may be said that potentially there are thirty crores of labourers employed in the production of khadi.
('49', 28, 1, 23, 61745) (5) All the implements required for the production of khadi are made in the country.
('49', 28, 1, 24, 61830) (6) Khadi cannot be suppressed either by the Government or any other power.
('49', 28, 1, 25, 61906) (7) Khadi can be produced in every home.
('49', 29, 0, 1, 61947) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 29, 1, 2, 61988) (8) It is not necessary to make khadi at one place and send it to another.
('49', 29, 1, 3, 62063) At present it does have to travel to some extent because the sentiment for khadi has not gained much ground.
('49', 29, 1, 4, 62172) The reader will see from all this what precisely swadeshi dharma means.
('49', 29, 1, 5, 62244) While practising it, anyone who has imbibed the spirit of swadeshi will also readily abide by it in all other things.
('49', 29, 1, 6, 62362) Anyone who wears khadi out of ignorance, by way of imitating others or out of hypocrisy, will not be regarded as having taken the vow of khadi, des pite the fact that he wears it.
('49', 29, 1, 7, 62542) Such fashionable khadi wearers could not be regarded as advancing the sentiment for khadi.
('49', 29, 1, 8, 62633) Anyone who uses khadi with knowledge will start denying himself all foreign goods which he can do without.
('49', 29, 1, 9, 62740) Let us now turn to boycott.
('49', 29, 1, 10, 62768) It is madness to try and boycott everything.
('49', 29, 1, 11, 62813) The idea is indefensible.
('49', 29, 1, 12, 62839) It is impossible to boycott only British goods or British cloth.
('49', 29, 1, 13, 62904) This is because such goods or cloth can find their way into the country under the guise of other foreign goods or cloth.
('49', 29, 1, 14, 63025) During the days of the Partition of Bengal, British cloth was being sold as swad eshi with the British markings on it removed.
('49', 29, 1, 15, 63152) So when we think of boycotting British cloth alone, no purpose is served except that of giving an impetus to cloth made in Japan and other countries.
('49', 29, 1, 16, 63302) So far I have considered the matter only from the view point of the boycott of foreign cloth.
('49', 29, 1, 17, 63396) But if we consider the situation after swaraj, if we consider the interests of the starving millions, we can only think of khadi.
('49', 29, 2, 18, 63526) [From Gujarati]
('49', 29, 3, 19, 63542) Navajivan, 6 4 1930
('49', 30, 0, 1, 63562) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 31
('49', 30, 1, 2, 63603) 22. MILL OWNERS OF AHMEDABAD
('49', 30, 2, 3, 63632) In saying that I am greatly pleased at the kindness shown by the mill owners of Ahmedabad, I am not merely being polite: I am expr essing the deepest feelings of my heart.
('49', 30, 2, 4, 63804) Their presence on the eve of my departure from Sabarmati, their visits to me from time to time and finally their coming to Surat in a group out of their affection for me are a happy indication that this struggle is not directed against mill owners or against capitalists.
('49', 30, 2, 5, 64076) However, I myself attribute a special significance to their presence and their blessings.
('49', 30, 2, 6, 64166) I have been associated with them now for almost fifteen years.
('49', 30, 2, 7, 64229) During this period, despite the fact that perhaps some of them regarded my conduct as being detrimental to their interests, they have accepted me as a friend and our relationship has been cordial even when there has been a dispute between us.
('49', 30, 2, 8, 64472) I believe that their co operation on this occasion is, to some extent, because of that relationship.
('49', 30, 2, 9, 64573) If this conclusion is correct, I have the right to expect some more practical support from them in addition to their presence and their blessings.
('49', 30, 2, 10, 64720) They have taken a step forward by their decision that hence forth they will boycott foreign cloth and use only swadeshi cloth.
('49', 30, 2, 11, 64847) This resolution, though commendable, has loopholes.
('49', 30, 2, 12, 64899) Some may regard khadi as swadeshi.
('49', 30, 2, 13, 64934) Others may prefer mill made cloth with a border that is made of foreign yarn.
('49', 30, 2, 14, 65012) The dharma of swadeshi cannot be practised in this manner.
('49', 30, 2, 15, 65071) In my opinion, the purest form of swadeshi to the extent it is practicable is khadi.
('49', 30, 2, 16, 65156) If this is not possible, then swadeshi should mean cloth made in mills owned and controlled by Indians out of yarn spun in those mills.
('49', 30, 2, 17, 65292) If even this cannot be done, not only is swadeshi meaningless but it is also harmful from the point of view of boycott.
('49', 30, 2, 18, 65412) If mill owners encourage khadi and run their mills with an eye to attaining the object of swadeshi, I regard the boycott of foreign cloth as something very simple.
('49', 30, 2, 19, 65576) If I find the time, I hope to consider this subject in detail in a separate article.
('49', 30, 2, 20, 65661) Here I wish to show how and in what ways mill owners can specially assist this movement.
('49', 30, 2, 21, 65750) It is beyond argument that the relations between mill owners and workers should be friendly.
('49', 30, 2, 22, 65843) If, instead of opposing each other, they were to help each other they would encourage the cause of swaraj.
('49', 30, 2, 23, 65950) In this
('49', 31, 0, 1, 65958) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 31, 1, 2, 65999) regard the following points should be borne in mind: (1) Mill owners should carefully remove the everyday incon veniences the workers have to face.
('49', 31, 1, 3, 66147) (2) Since mostly I am not there and Sheth Mangaldas is old— even older than I am—there should be a permanent panch to solve problems as they arise.
('49', 31, 1, 4, 66295) (3) Mill owners should consider the Majoor Mahajan a friendly body and have faith in it.
('49', 31, 1, 5, 66384) They should make full use of its assistance and co operate fully with it.
('49', 31, 1, 6, 66458) (4) With a view to improving their moral and social condition labourers should be given financial and other assistance whenever there is need for it.
('49', 31, 1, 7, 66608) In other words, schools, hospitals, reading rooms and such other institutions meant exclusively for them should be supported without anything being expected by way of return.
('49', 31, 1, 8, 66783) (5) Those labourers, clerks and others who wish to participate in civil disobedience or such other national work, should be given help and wherever it becomes necessary to relieve them, this should be done reserving their right to return.
('49', 31, 1, 9, 67022) If it becomes necessary to support the families this should be done.
('49', 31, 1, 10, 67091) (6) In order to free labourers from the vice of drink, millowners should start canteens and provide recreation to suit their tastes.
('49', 31, 1, 11, 67224) In order to induce abstention those who give up liquor should be recognized and encouraged in various ways.
('49', 31, 1, 12, 67332) (7) There should be no profit motive behind the production of cloth by mills.
('49', 31, 1, 13, 67410) The purpose of such production should be boycott of foreign cloth.
('49', 31, 1, 14, 67477) (8) Mills should never produce cloth with the intention of passing it off as khadi; they should not mark it as khadi or stamp it with the spinning wheel; instead, they should produce such qualities of cloth as cannot be found in khadi at present.
('49', 31, 1, 15, 67724) In other words, they should decide upon the quality of cloth to be produced in consultation with the Charkha Sangh.
('49', 31, 1, 16, 67840) (9) Mills should stock khadi, propagate it and give of their talent and experience for its production.
('49', 31, 1, 17, 67943) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 6 4 1930

('49', 33, 0, 1, 68920) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 33, 1, 2, 68961) 25. INTERVIEW TO FREE PRESS OF INDIA 1
('49', 33, 2, 3, 69000) DANDI, April 6, 1930
('49', 33, 3, 4, 69021) Now that a technical or ceremonial breach of the salt law has been committed, it is now open to anyone who would take the risk of prosecution under the salt law to manufacture salt wherever he wishes and wherever it is convenient.
('49', 33, 3, 5, 69252) My advice is that a worker should everywhere manufacture salt and where he knows how to prepare clean salt should make use of it and instruct villagers to do likewise, telling the villagers at the same time that he runs the risk of being pro secuted.
('49', 33, 3, 6, 69503) In other words the villagers should be fully instructed as to the incidence of salt tax and the manner of breaking laws and regulations in connection with it, so as to have the salt tax repealed and it should be made absolutely clear to the villagers that this breach is to be open and in no way stealthy.
('49', 33, 3, 7, 69809) This condition being known they may manufacture salt or help themselves to salt manufactured by nat ure in creeks and pits near the seashore, to use it for themselves and for their cattle and to sell it to those who will buy it, it being well und erstood that all such people are committing a breach of the salt law and therefore running the risk of prosecution or even without prosecution to be subjected by the so called salt officers to harassment.
('49', 33, 3, 8, 70261) Thus the war against salt tax should be continued during the national week up to the 13th instant.
('49', 33, 3, 9, 70360) Those who are now engaged in this sacred work should devote themselves to vigorous propaganda for boycott of foreign cloth and use of khaddar.
('49', 33, 3, 10, 70503) They should also endeavour to manufacture as much khaddar as possible.
('49', 33, 3, 11, 70574) As to this and prohibition of liquor I am preparing a message for the women of India who, I am becoming more and more convinced, can make a larger contribution than the men towards the attainment of indep endence.
('49', 33, 3, 12, 70788) I feel they will be worthier interpreters of non violence than men, not because they are weak, as men in their arrogance believe them to be, but because they have greater courage or the right type and immeasurably greater spirit of self sacrifice.
('49', 33, 4, 13, 71036) 1 Gandhiji gave the interview after he had broken the salt law by picking up a lump of salt mixed with mud.
('49', 34, 0, 1, 71144) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 35

('49', 34, 1, 3, 71195) Now that you have infringed the salt law and Government have not interfered with you what do you intend doing afterwards?
('49', 34, 1, 4, 71317) —the Free Press representative.

('49', 34, 2, 6, 71367) ANSWER.

('49', 34, 3, 12, 71705) 26. SPEECH AT DANDI
('49', 34, 4, 13, 71725) April 6, 1930
('49', 34, 5, 14, 71739) At four in the afternoon Gandhiji addressed a meeting.
('49', 34, 5, 15, 71794) Reviewing the day’s Programme he remarked that the beginning of the national week had been very auspicious.
('49', 34, 5, 16, 71902) Whether Government arrested them or not they had to do their duty.
('49', 34, 5, 17, 71969) He was sure that all over India people must have started satyagraha on this day.
('49', 34, 5, 18, 72050) Proceeding, he said there was not much of natural salt at Dandi since Government servants had taken timely care to destroy it.
('49', 34, 5, 19, 72177) That was a monstrosity which it was their duty to get rid of.
('49', 34, 5, 20, 72239) When they made a beginning in the morning he had himself picked up more mud than salt, but after washing and cleaning he could get two tolas of pure
('49', 34, 6, 21, 72388) quality which was sufficient for his day’s requirements.
('49', 34, 6, 22, 72445) That was only a beginning but that signified great things.
('49', 34, 6, 23, 72504) Today those who had broken the law had become either thieves or owners.
('49', 34, 7, 24, 72576) He then referred to the raid at Aat.
('49', 34, 7, 25, 72613) Mr. Antia, the police officer in charge, had shown considerable prudence in his behaviour.
('49', 34, 7, 26, 72704) That was the victory of ahimsa.
('49', 34, 7, 27, 72736) What an amount of public money Government had wasted in confiscating that salt!
('49', 34, 7, 28, 72816) Gandhiji then made a reference to the arrest of Lala Shamlal of Rohtak under section 124A.
('49', 34, 7, 29, 72907) He paid a glowing tribute to Lala Shamlal for his excellent national work.
('49', 34, 7, 30, 72982) He could not understand the policy of Government in arresting other workers and leaving him alone.
('49', 34, 7, 31, 73081) Not that he was anxious to be arrested, but that was not a just course.
('49', 34, 7, 32, 73153) He did not expect any greater honours by his arrest.
('49', 34, 7, 33, 73206) He was already a Mahatma.
('49', 34, 7, 34, 73232) He did not want the title of Mahatma.
('49', 34, 7, 35, 73270) He was not at all anxious to go to jail.
('49', 34, 7, 36, 73311) Surely he enjoyed the good climate of Dandi.
('49', 34, 7, 37, 73356) Government must arrest him before others, because he was the greatest offender.
('49', 34, 7, 38, 73436) It was the duty of every person in Rohtak to commit breach of 124A under which Lala Shamlal was arrested.
('49', 34, 7, 39, 73542) In conclusion, Gandhiji asked the people not to eat taxed salt any more.
('49', 34, 7, 40, 73615) The Bombay Chronicle, 8 4 1930

('49', 38, 1, 2, 77179) 31. BARBAROUS
('49', 38, 2, 3, 77193) [April 7, 1930]
('49', 38, 3, 4, 77209) The threatened has after all happened.
('49', 38, 3, 5, 77248) I congratulate the Government on having commenced arrests in right earnest of salt tax resisters at least in Gujarat.
('49', 38, 3, 6, 77366) They have arrested Sjt.
('49', 38, 3, 7, 77390) Manilal Kothari and all his com panions, so also Sjt.

('49', 38, 3, 11, 77595) Ravishankar, the intr epid reformer who has weaned the brave but ignorant Rajputs of Kheda from many an error.
('49', 38, 3, 12, 77706) They have arrested Ramdas Gandhi, Keshavbhai Ganeshji, Chimanlal Pranshankar and others.
('49', 38, 3, 13, 77795) All this the Government had the right to do.
('49', 38, 3, 14, 77840) But they had no right to do what they did today 1 at the village Aat four miles from Dandi.
('49', 38, 3, 15, 77932) The police tried by force to snatch salt from the civil resisters.
('49', 38, 3, 16, 77999) This they had no right to do, if they were representing a civilized Government.
('49', 38, 3, 17, 78079) There was no provocation offered.
('49', 38, 3, 18, 78113) The resisters were not running away.
('49', 38, 3, 19, 78150) Their names could have been taken.
('49', 38, 3, 20, 78185) But they insulted these brave men and through it the nation by touching their sacred persons without warrant and without just cause.
('49', 38, 3, 21, 78318) One of the resisters by name Ukabhai Rama of Bardoli was slightly injured on the wrist.
('49', 38, 3, 22, 78406) I admit that the police went unarmed to the scene of action.
('49', 38, 3, 23, 78467) They will probably admit that there never was the slightest occasion for carrying arms.
('49', 38, 3, 24, 78555) For the people were obviously and absolutely peaceful, nevertheless this laying hands on the people for the purpose of seizing the salt they were carrying was morally wrong and even wrong I fancy according to English common law.
('49', 38, 3, 25, 78784) But I do not know what powers are given by a statute that makes a crime of undefined cowardice.
('49', 38, 3, 26, 78880) This first drawing of blood, however little, brought down practically the whole of the village to the scene.
('49', 38, 3, 27, 78989) Women were just yet to take no part in the act of civil disobedience, nor were the men of the village expected as yet to do so.
('49', 38, 3, 28, 79117) But they, men and women (some with babes in arms), immediately they heard that salt was being forcibly seized and that one of the volunteers was injured, rushed out, and men on one side and women on the other descended to the cha 
('49', 38, 4, 29, 79348) 1 Monday, April 7, 1930
('49', 39, 0, 1, 79372) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 39, 1, 2, 79413) nnel and began to dig out the salt.
('49', 39, 1, 3, 79449) As soon as I heard of the attempt at forcible seizure from the persons of the resisters, Monday being my day of silence, I wrote on a piece of paper that Shrimati Sarojini Devi and Sjt.
('49', 39, 1, 4, 79635) Abbas Tyabji should go, and if the police did not desist they should also dig out salt and challenge them to seize it from their hands.
('49', 39, 1, 5, 79771) But I charitably assume that the police had seen their mistake before these friends reached the scene and had not the heart to touch a whole villageful of people including women.
('49', 39, 1, 6, 79950) The sat yagrahis, how ever, would not be satisfied without my presence although I might not speak.
('49', 39, 1, 7, 80049) They wanted me evidently to see with my own eyes how they had behaved and with what zest the whole village was participating in the struggle.
('49', 39, 1, 8, 80191) Ukabhai Rama was brought to me with the salt rescued.

('49', 39, 1, 12, 80334) It brought life to the whole village.
('49', 39, 1, 13, 80372) Nevertheless, for the sake of the Government and for the sake of keeping the salt war on the gentlemanly plane, I wish this ugly incident had not happened.
('49', 39, 1, 14, 80528) Legal procedure may be a cumbersome business for the Gov ernment.
('49', 39, 1, 15, 80594) But since they have begun well let them not end ill.
('49', 39, 1, 16, 80647) Let it be a pure trial of strength between them and the people.
('49', 39, 1, 17, 80711) If they will resort to terrorism and if I am not mistaken, they will find the people, men as well as women.
('49', 39, 1, 18, 80819) ready for any ordeal they may prepare for them.
('49', 39, 1, 19, 80867) Salt in the hands of satyagrahis represents the honour of the nation.
('49', 39, 1, 20, 80937) It cannot be yielded up except to force that will break the hand to pieces.
('49', 39, 1, 21, 81013) Ukabhai, as he was describing the action of the police, said, “God gives strength to a satyagrahi to defend what is entrusted to him.” Let the people defend the salt in their possession till they break in the attempt, but they should do so without malice, without anger, without an angry word.
('49', 39, 1, 22, 81307) The police have the easiest way open to them of taking possession of the salt.
('49', 39, 1, 23, 81386) Let them arrest the civil resisters, and they can take possession of the salt for they have possession of their persons.
('49', 39, 1, 24, 81507) But it can become forfeit only after conviction, not before.
('49', 39, 1, 25, 81568) Young India, 10 4 1930
('49', 40, 0, 1, 81591) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 41
('49', 40, 1, 2, 81632) 32. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('49', 40, 2, 3, 81659) April 7, 1930
('49', 40, 3, 4, 81673) The reports received so far indicate that the magic wave of mass civil disobedience in Gujarat has had its effect on the Government.
('49', 40, 3, 5, 81806) The Government has lost no time in arresting the leaders of this movement but I understand that it must have paid similar attention to the leaders in other provinces as well.
('49', 40, 3, 6, 81981) This is something we can cong ratulate ourselves on.
('49', 40, 3, 7, 82034) It would have been surprising if the Government had allowed the satyagrahis to act as they pleased.
('49', 40, 3, 8, 82134) It would have been considered barbaric if it had attacked the life and property of the satyagrahis without any previous inquiry.
('49', 40, 3, 9, 82263) One cannot object to trial and conviction according to established procedure.
('49', 40, 3, 10, 82341) Prison and such other punishments are the ordeal through which a satyagrahi must pass.
('49', 40, 3, 11, 82428) A satyagrahi can be said to have fulfilled his purpose only when he does not flinch, when he does not betray those whom he represents and when he is not scared by the arrest of his leader.
('49', 40, 3, 12, 82617) The time has come when everyone will have to be both soldier and commander.
('49', 40, 3, 13, 82693) I shall be deeply grieved if even after these arrests, students who attend schools or colleges run or controlled by the Government do not leave these institutions.
('49', 40, 3, 14, 82857) People should make salt only after realizing the risk involved in doing so, or, alternatively, they should collect the salt that has naturally accumulated increeks and holes on the seashore and use it for themselves and their cattle and sell it to those who may wish to buy it.
('49', 40, 3, 15, 83135) Everyone should realize that in defying the salt law they run the risk of legal action being taken aga inst them.
('49', 40, 3, 16, 83249) It is also possible that the officers of the so called salt department may harass them without resorting to any legal steps.
('49', 40, 3, 17, 83374) The struggle against the salt law has to be carried on in this fashion during the whole of the National Week ending on 13th April.
('49', 40, 3, 18, 83505) All those who do not take part in this sacred task should devote them selves wholly to the powerful movement for the boycott of foreign cloth and use khadi.
('49', 40, 3, 19, 83662) They should try and make as much khadi as possible and carry on the struggle for prohibition.
('49', 40, 3, 20, 83756) I am preparing a message to the women of India.
('49', 40, 3, 21, 83804) I am bec oming increasingly certain that in the struggle for securing swaraj, the women of this country could contribute a greater share than the men.
('49', 40, 3, 22, 83955) I feel that women will be able to explain the meaning of non violence
('49', 41, 0, 1, 84025) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 41, 1, 2, 84066) to the country more effectively than men.
('49', 41, 1, 3, 84108) Not because men, out of vanity, regard them as weak but because they possess real courage in a greater proportion and an immeasurable sense of dedication.
('49', 41, 1, 4, 84263) [From Gujarati] Prajabandhu, 13 4 1930

('49', 46, 2, 5, 90991) The first day of self purification week has begun with auspicious omens.
