('49', 50, 1, 2, 94596) 47. SPEECH AT AAT
('49', 50, 2, 3, 94614) April 8, 1930
('49', 50, 3, 4, 94628) I am glad the Government has allowed me to remain free so that I can fulfil the promise I made to you yesterday.
('49', 50, 3, 5, 94741) Yesterday when Uk abhai was beaten and all of you suddenly jumped down in order to collect salt, you all, including even the women, must have found it difficult to stand the sight.
('49', 50, 3, 6, 94922) That incident will remain indelible in the history of India.
('49', 50, 3, 7, 94983) Our first battle is going to be fought at Aat.
('49', 50, 3, 8, 95030) Ours is a war of love in which we have to suffer too.
('49', 50, 3, 9, 95084) We shall not allow the salt to be taken away even at the risk of losing our lives, just as a mother would not allow herself to be robbed of her child even if she had to die for it.
('49', 50, 3, 10, 95265) 1 When this happens the whole of India will rise up.
('49', 50, 3, 11, 95318) India cannot tolerate such insult even when it is perpetrated against men.
('49', 50, 3, 12, 95393) God is the only ammunition that we possess.
('49', 50, 3, 13, 95437) You have glorified the second day of your struggle and I hope that all the villages of Gujarat and the whole of the country will follow your example.
('49', 50, 3, 14, 95587) Let the Government arrest all the national leaders it wants to.
('49', 50, 3, 15, 95651) It will find that its belief that the struggle will be terminated for want of leaders is false.
('49', 50, 3, 16, 95747) When you have collected the salt, do not waste a single grain of it.
('49', 50, 3, 17, 95816) You should be determined to eat only that salt upon which no tax has been levied.
('49', 50, 3, 18, 95898) If the Government levies an excise duty on paddy you would have no alternative but to eat paddy grown in your own fields; you have to follow a similar course with regard to salt also.
('49', 50, 3, 19, 96082) Do not let go of salt when the police tries to snatch it from your hands.
('49', 50, 3, 20, 96156) So long as your wrists are intact, do not let your fists be loosened.
('49', 50, 3, 21, 96226) Your fists will acquire the strength of iron if you have faith in satyagraha.
('49', 50, 3, 22, 96304) [From Gujarati] Prajabandhu, 13 4 1930
('49', 50, 4, 23, 96343) 1 This sentence is from The Bombay Chronicle, 9 4 1930.
('49', 51, 0, 1, 96399) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 52
('49', 51, 1, 2, 96440) `48. MESSAGE TO THE NATION 1
('49', 51, 2, 3, 96469) DANDI, April 9, 1930
('49', 51, 3, 4, 96490) At last the long expected hour seems to have come.
('49', 51, 3, 5, 96541) In the dead of night my colleagues and companions have roused me from deep slumber and requested me to give them a message.
('49', 51, 3, 6, 96665) I am, therefore, dictating this message, although I have not the slightest inclination to give any.
('49', 51, 3, 7, 96765) Messages I have given enough already.
('49', 51, 3, 8, 96803) Of what avail would this message be if none of the previous messages evoked a proper response?
('49', 51, 3, 9, 96898) But information received until this midnight leads me to the belief that my message did not fall flat, but was taken up by the people in right earnest.
('49', 51, 3, 10, 97050) The people of Gujarat seem to have risen in a body as it were.
('49', 51, 3, 11, 97113) I have seen with my own eyes thousands of men and women at Aat and Bhimrad fearlessly breaking the Salt Act.
('49', 51, 3, 12, 97222) Not a sign of mischief, not a sign of violence have I seen, despite the presence of people in such large numbers.
('49', 51, 3, 13, 97336) They have remained perfectly peaceful and non violent, although Govern ment officers have transgressed all bounds.
('49', 51, 3, 14, 97451) Here in Gujarat well tried and popular public servants have been arrested one after another, and yet the people have been perfectly non violent.
('49', 51, 3, 15, 97596) They have refused to give way to panic, and have celebrated the arrests by offering civil disobedience in ever increasing numbers.
('49', 51, 3, 16, 97727) This is just as it should be.
('49', 51, 3, 17, 97757) If the struggle so auspiciously begun is continued in the same spirit of non violence to the end, not only shall we see Purna Swaraj established in our country before long, but we shall have given to the world an object lesson worthy of India and her glorious past.
('49', 51, 3, 18, 98023) Swaraj won without sacrifice cannot last long.
('49', 51, 3, 19, 98070) I would, there fore, like our people to get ready to make the highest sacrifice that they are capable of.

('49', 53, 2, 3, 100776) April 9, 1930
('49', 53, 3, 4, 100790) MAHADEV, I am halting in Surat for a few hours on my way to Bhimrad.
('49', 53, 3, 5, 100859) The car took the wrong road, with the result that I missed the train and came here by car.
('49', 53, 3, 6, 100950) At present my very thoughts have grown wings and they seem to have effect even when not expressed in speech or action.
('49', 53, 3, 7, 101069) That is a fact.
('49', 53, 3, 8, 101085) Thoughts which are part of tapascharya are single pointed, and hence their power is greater than that of electricity or of still subtler ether.

('49', 53, 3, 25, 102601) As for you, I think you will not be a free man for long.

('49', 59, 0, 1, 114921) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 60
('49', 59, 1, 2, 114962) 52. NOTES
('49', 59, 2, 3, 114972) CONGRATULATIONS
('49', 59, 3, 4, 114988) Pandit Malaviyaji and the other members of the Assembly who have resigned deserve the heartiest congratulations of the nation for their patriotic resignations.
('49', 59, 3, 5, 115148) How any self respecting person can cling to an institution where he cannot preserve his self respect it would be difficult to understand if we did not know our capacity for self deception.
('49', 59, 3, 6, 115337) The Government, instead of telling us, show by their many unmistakable acts that they will do anything but sacrifice the material interest of their principals the British manufacturers and the like who live on India’s exploitation.
('49', 59, 3, 7, 115569) The legislatures, central and pro vincial, are like their other institutions, powerful and tempting devices for draining India of whatever she has still left.
('49', 59, 3, 8, 115728) They would, if they could, leave her only when she has no more left to be plundered.
('49', 59, 3, 9, 115813) Pandit Malaviyaji and the others have left the Assembly none too soon.
('49', 59, 3, 10, 115884) With a faith worthy of a better cause he stuck to the so called legislatures for a quarter of a century in the teeth often of popular opposition.
('49', 59, 3, 11, 116030) He rendered at critical moments valuable services to the Government.
('49', 59, 3, 12, 116099) No Indian living has the unbroken record Pandit Malaviyaji has of service rendered with a single mindedness not often to be found in men.
('49', 59, 3, 13, 116237) The Government have therefore lost an ally whom they will never be able to replace.
('49', 59, 3, 14, 116321) I hope that Panditji and his companions will now devote their energy to the popular work that awaits them.
('49', 59, 3, 15, 116428) They will soon discover as many have done that the real work can only be done outside the legislatures.
('49', 59, 3, 16, 116532) They will be good only when they are so fashioned as to register real public opinion, not that of certain groups or classes.
('49', 59, 3, 17, 116657) They are positively harmful when they are so manipulated as merely to give effect to the official will.
('49', 59, 3, 18, 116761) For the time being, therefore, servants of the nation have to forge san ctions and create a public opinion that will not be flouted.
('49', 59, 4, 19, 116894) A VICIOUS INSINUATION
('49', 59, 5, 20, 116916) An M. B. writes as follows : 1
('49', 59, 6, 21, 116947) The Lancet, a leading medical journal of London, in its edition dated 8th March 1930 (page 531) has made the following observations: “Whatever political agitators may say and in spite of the growth of medical education in India, that country will need British doctors for a long time to
('49', 59, 7, 22, 117234) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('49', 60, 0, 1, 117271) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 61
('49', 60, 1, 2, 117312) Even Mr. Gandhi (who was himself operated by a British surgeon in the I. M. S.) would probably admit the truth of this statement.”
('49', 60, 2, 3, 117443) So far as I know you were operated by the Civil Surgeon of Poona while you were a prisoner in jail.
('49', 60, 2, 4, 117543) But the insinuation seems to be that you preferred to be operated by a British I. M. S. officer, because he was more capable.
('49', 60, 2, 5, 117669) The insinuation made by the writer in the Lancet is baseless and vicious.
('49', 60, 2, 6, 117743) At the time the operation was performed I was certainly a prisoner, but I was given the choice of having my own surgeon to per form the operation.
('49', 60, 2, 7, 117890) I did not distrust Col.
('49', 60, 2, 8, 117914) Maddock, the British surgeon referred to, and the late Dr. Dalal and Dr. Jivraj Mehta (my surgeon and physician respectively) not having arrived in time, the operation was performed by Col.
('49', 60, 2, 9, 118104) Maddock, whose care and attention I have acknowledged more than once.
('49', 60, 2, 10, 118174) I have never felt the dearth of Indian surgeons or physicians of the highest calibre.
('49', 60, 2, 11, 118260) Indeed, I have sent several of my European friends to Indian surgeons and phy sicians and they have derived full benefit from the skill of these Ind ian medical men.
('49', 60, 2, 12, 118426) It is in military science alone, thanks to the British policy, that India perhaps stands in need of assistance from European instructors.
('49', 60, 2, 13, 118564) But, so far as I am aware, in every other dep artment, if the British withdrew India could be self contained without the slightest difficulty and that in spite of open or veiled obstruction from the ruling caste.
('49', 60, 2, 14, 118777) Young India, 10 4 1930
('49', 60, 3, 15, 118800) 53. THE IMMORAL FOUNDATION
('49', 60, 4, 16, 118827) This Indian Empire was conceived in immorality, for it was to perpetuate the exploitation of India’s resources that it was founded.
('49', 60, 4, 17, 118959) The pages of history written by Englishmen amply prove the assertion that no fraud was considered too much, no force too frightful by Eng lishmen, to gain the end.
('49', 60, 4, 18, 119123) There is perhaps not an inch of ground lawfully acquired by or for the British crown in India.
('49', 60, 4, 19, 119218) The rule is nurtured by immoral means.
('49', 60, 4, 20, 119257) English statesmen assure us that it is the British bayonet that keeps the Empire free from attack both from without and within.
('49', 60, 4, 21, 119385) It is supported by revenues derived from immoral sources.
('49', 60, 4, 22, 119443) I have sufficiently demonstrated the hideous immorality, because inhu manity, of the salt tax.
('49', 60, 4, 23, 119538) The immorality of the drink and drug revenue is self demonstrated.
('49', 61, 0, 1, 119605) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 62
('49', 61, 1, 2, 119646) The immorality of the land revenue is not self demonstrated.
('49', 61, 1, 3, 119707) But those who have followed the Bardoli agitation, who have studied the so called revenue laws and their administration, cannot fail to perc eive the immorality of the system.
('49', 61, 1, 4, 119883) I call the revenue laws so called bec ause they give arbitrary powers to revenue officers whose decisions are not subject to judicial control.
('49', 61, 1, 5, 120026) This land revenue, like the salt tax, presses most heavily upon the poor ryot whether under the ryotwari system or the permanent system.
('49', 61, 1, 6, 120163) How it oppresses the peasant under the ryotwari system we saw in Bardoli and recently in Matar and Mehemedabad.
('49', 61, 1, 7, 120275) The permanent settlement crushes the ryot more than those affected by the ryotwari system.
('49', 61, 1, 8, 120366) That the ryot himself is partly to blame for his woes I have no hesitation in admi tting.
('49', 61, 1, 9, 120456) But that fact is irrelevant to the present consideration.
('49', 61, 1, 10, 120514) There is no inherent or independent right belonging to the State to tax the land, whether it be considered to be the State property or the indiv idual’s.
('49', 61, 1, 11, 120668) The State has no more right to exact its toll from land under any circumstance than the owner of an ox has a right to exact work from it irrespective of its capacity.
('49', 61, 1, 12, 120835) That there is a kind of class fication of land and some regulations about remissions, etc., is no answer to the charge here made.
('49', 61, 1, 13, 120965) The claim here made is that in the vast majority of cases the ryot is wholly unable to pay any tax.
('49', 61, 1, 14, 121065) In sha ping its taxation policy a wise State will always take note of the citizen’s habits, customs and even his weaknesses.
('49', 61, 1, 15, 121190) This Government had no time for such consideration.
('49', 61, 1, 16, 121242) It had its fixed minimum to exact anyhow; and so in the words of the late Lord Salisbury the lancet had to be applied where there was yet any blood to be drawn.
('49', 61, 1, 17, 121403) So much about some of the visible sources of revenue.
('49', 61, 1, 18, 121457) The invi sible sources are equally tainted if not much more so.
('49', 61, 1, 19, 121521) The unco nsci onable forced inflation of the rupee has by a stroke of the pen drained India of millions.
('49', 61, 1, 20, 121626) The favoured treatment of British cloth in a variety of unseen ways drains India of sixty crores of rupees annually, leaving behind partial unemployment of the starving millions.
('49', 61, 1, 21, 121805) Thus the Government trades upon our vices and exacts payment by questionable methods principally from those who are least able to make it.
('49', 61, 1, 22, 121944) There is therefore no way open to the people save to end a system whose very foundations are immoral.
('49', 61, 1, 23, 122046) Let us therefore pray and work for the destruction of this demonstrably immoral system and for ending it take the boldest risks consistently with the national creed or policy (as the case may be) of non violence.
('49', 61, 1, 24, 122259) Young India, 10 4 1930
('49', 62, 0, 1, 122282) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 63
('49', 62, 1, 2, 122323) 54. AN ENGLISH FRIEND’S DIFFICULTY
('49', 62, 2, 3, 122358) An English friend writes: 1
('49', 62, 3, 4, 122386) To us India is a composite country sharply divided by the caste system, by religious differences, and by semi independent and loyal kingdoms, which could by no means be left to act together without the most careful safeguards against civil strife or religious persecution, and which, if left alone, would soon be a chaos of conflicting forces.
('49', 62, 3, 5, 122730) But we are anxious to do the right thing as the Government responsible for the welfare of the land.
('49', 62, 4, 6, 122830) A mere political reform is quite useless unless it improves the lot of the people and removes any injustice from which they suffer and it appears to us that the British could do these things far better than a mixed Indian Government.
('49', 62, 5, 7, 123064) The question is: What is the injustice from which they suffer?
('49', 62, 6, 8, 123127) Are they too heavily taxed?
('49', 62, 6, 9, 123155) Are the courts of justice unfair?
('49', 62, 7, 10, 123189) Do the British rulers act with tyranny?
('49', 62, 8, 11, 123229) Are there any monopolies which are unjust?
('49', 62, 9, 12, 123272) Are the wages of the workers less than they would be under a native
('49', 62, 10, 13, 123340) government?
('49', 62, 10, 14, 123352) Or hours longer?
('49', 62, 10, 15, 123369) Could such a Government prevent the famines which afflict the country?
('49', 62, 10, 16, 123440) Or, when they came, relieve them so effectually?
('49', 62, 10, 17, 123489) This letter is typical of the average good but ill informed Englishman.
('49', 62, 10, 18, 123561) Take the 4th 2 paragraph.
('49', 62, 10, 19, 123587) It betrays the false teaching with which Eng lishmen are fed from their school going age.
('49', 62, 10, 20, 123677) It does not occur to the writer that India left to herself will deal with the difficulties pointed out.
('49', 62, 10, 21, 123781) He does not see that if a century of British rule has not dealt with the difficulties but has, if anything, rather accentuated them, with the pro gress of time they are not going to be solved or diminished during British occupation.
('49', 62, 10, 22, 124014) The writer does not know that according to the testimony of English historiansthe innumerable villages have rem ained unaffected by the difficulties mentioned by him and many more I can name.
('49', 62, 10, 23, 124206) It should be remembered that India’s is a predominantly rural civilization.
('49', 62, 10, 24, 124282) Before the devastating British occupation the seven hundred thousand villages of India were so many self contained rep ublics.
('49', 62, 10, 25, 124409) It was left for the marvellous
('49', 62, 11, 26, 124440) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('49', 62, 11, 27, 124477) 2 The first three paragraphs having been omitted, this refers to the first paragraph of the letter as given here.
('49', 63, 0, 1, 124591) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 64
('49', 63, 1, 2, 124632) organizing British ability, used not for “the welfare of the land” as the writer imagines, but misused for its systematic exploitation, to disturb the placid and comparatively happy life of the villager.
('49', 63, 1, 3, 124836) Rulers have before now come and gone leaving these villages untouched and without leaving chaos behind.
('49', 63, 1, 4, 124940) Why should the disappearance of British rule result in chaos?
('49', 63, 1, 5, 125002) If the British people play the game, they will be expected to undo the great wrong they have done to India by rendering to free and independent India such assistance as her free Government may need.
('49', 63, 1, 6, 125201) If they will not play the game what need is there for any Englishman to worry whether there is chaos or concord after the end of British rule?
('49', 63, 1, 7, 125344) Ruthless exploitation of India is too great a price to pay for securing the so called orderly Government.
('49', 63, 1, 8, 125450) I have no difficulty in agreeing with the writer that “a mere political reform is quite useless unless it improves the lot of the people and removes any injustice from which they suffer.” But it is a fatal mistake to suppose that “the British could do these things better than a mixed Indian Government.” English friends like the writer will better understand the nationalist position by the following answers to the very relevant questions he puts: 1. The people are too heavily taxed as has been maintained elsewhere in this very issue and as can be amply proved from auth oritative sources.
('49', 63, 1, 9, 126044) 2. The courts have been proved to be unfair in political cases and in cases as between Indians and Europeans.
('49', 63, 1, 10, 126154) 3. British rulers have been known repeatedly to rule with tyranny and almost invariably to act arrogantly and in total disregard of Indian opinion.
('49', 63, 1, 11, 126302) 4. There are numerous unjust monopolies of which the salt monopoly is a glaring example.
('49', 63, 1, 12, 126391) 5. If by workers only city labour is meant, it is but a drop in the ocean of Indian humanity.
('49', 63, 1, 13, 126485) They do not number more than two million in all India, i.e., 150th of the whole population.
('49', 63, 1, 14, 126577) Moreover these are a British institution.
('49', 63, 1, 15, 126619) How they will fare under an indigenous Government it is difficult to foresee except that they will be better able to wrest justice from it than from an all powerful alien Govern ment that can afford to be indifferent.
('49', 63, 1, 16, 126837) In so far as the vast mass of the workers in the Indian villages are concerned, I maintain, and it has been proved in these pages, that they are worse off now than they ever were.
('49', 64, 0, 1, 127017) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 65
('49', 64, 1, 2, 127058) 6. Whenever there is famine in the land it is a famine of money, i.e., incapacity of the people to buy the grain and the cloth they need.
('49', 64, 1, 3, 127196) Under indigenous Government, therefore, when the spinning wheel is restored, no one need starve for want of money as they do today because they are unemployed for at least four months in the year.
('49', 64, 1, 4, 127393) 7. The chief wrongs have been enumerated in my letter 1 to the Viceroy published in these pages.
('49', 64, 1, 5, 127490) 8. What India wants is independence pure and simple.
('49', 64, 1, 6, 127543) This need not exclude British help if Great Britain will lend it on India’s terms.
('49', 64, 1, 7, 127626) I do not ask the friend to accept the categorical statements made by me.
('49', 64, 1, 8, 127699) I should be satisfied if my reply stimulates an impartial study of the charges made by me.
('49', 64, 1, 9, 127790) There is ample literature on the subject.
('49', 64, 1, 10, 127832) The volumes of Young India will provide instructive reading.
('49', 64, 1, 11, 127893) Let the Eng lish friends who will know the truth not summarily reject all Indian evidence.

('49', 64, 2, 14, 128057) 55. SOME CONDITIONS
('49', 64, 3, 15, 128077) Securing complete independence is difficult as well as easy.
('49', 64, 3, 16, 128138) It is difficult if we wish to do nothing.
('49', 64, 3, 17, 128180) It is easy if the masses understand their duty.

('49', 64, 3, 27, 128653) Men, women, boys and girls of no less than eight villages were able to do this.
('49', 64, 3, 28, 128733) They had not received any previous training.
('49', 64, 3, 29, 128778) 2. Everyone can spin on the takli.
('49', 64, 3, 30, 128813) Everyone of course cannot get a spinning wheel, for it is a little costly.
('49', 64, 3, 31, 128888) But taklis can be made in every home even from bamboo.
('49', 64, 3, 32, 128943) The general public can also buy taklis for a few pice each.
('49', 64, 3, 33, 129003) If millions of people take to carding and plying the takli we can produce as much khadi as we may need.
('49', 64, 4, 34, 129107) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Irwin”, 2 3 1930.

('49', 65, 1, 2, 129189) work also does not require any elaborate training.
('49', 65, 1, 3, 129240) Besides, it is work for leisure hours.
('49', 65, 1, 4, 129279) If people can grasp this, if they undergo a change of heart, millions of men and women, young and old, can take up this work and save sixty crores of rupees every year.
('49', 65, 1, 5, 129448) Let us boycott all foreign cloth and wear khadi alone.

('49', 75, 1, 2, 140664) 73. SPEECH TO VOLUNTEERS
('49', 75, 2, 3, 140689) JALALPUR, April 10, 1930
('49', 75, 3, 4, 140714) Addressing his volunteers this morning, Mahatma Gandhi said that their mettle would soon be put to the test.
('49', 75, 3, 5, 140823) There should, however, be no impatient hurry to court arrest.
('49', 75, 3, 6, 140885) They should refuse to be stampeded into hasty action by provocation from police.
('49', 75, 3, 7, 140966) Should authorities at any place “go mad and terrorize people” they should proceed there and set an example of calm courage and undaunted suffering.
('49', 75, 4, 8, 141114) Mahatma Gandhi exhorted them to prefer death to national humiliation of the type perpetrated by General Dyer.
('49', 75, 4, 9, 141224) The Bombay Chronicle, 11 4 1930
('49', 75, 5, 10, 141256) 74. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA April 10, 1930
('49', 75, 6, 11, 141314) My attention has been drawn to the report in The Times of India of my Aat speech.
('49', 75, 6, 12, 141396) It is a mischievous distortion of what I said.
('49', 75, 6, 13, 141443) On seeing a man’s wrist bleeding from a slight injury done to it, whilst the police, four or five against one, were snatching the salt in his poss ession, I said that the salt picked up by civil resisters was a token of India’s honour, and the civil resisters were expected to defend India’s honour with their lives.
('49', 75, 6, 14, 141760) People, I said, should hold on to the salt in their possession as long as it was possible for them to bear the force that might be used against them, and that they should not mind even if blood was drawn while the police were delivering their assault upon their defenceless victims.
('49', 75, 6, 15, 142043) I added that, in resisting this dispossession, people should not bear any malice nor should they be angry nor utter a word of abuse.
('49', 75, 6, 16, 142176) In order to avoid needless injury, I advised the pe ople to take only a handful of salt which could be contained in their closed fists and invited even women and children, if they had the cou rage to take part in the battle, and challenged the police to lay their hands upon women and children.
('49', 75, 6, 17, 142471) If the police laid their hands upon women and children, I said that the whole of India would bec ome inflamed, and resent the insult by inviting suffering ofthe same kind as they.
('49', 75, 6, 18, 142651) The manner in which I expected Indians to respond to such an insult was by taking up other methods of civil resistance, and by students boycotting schools and Government servants giving up
('49', 76, 0, 1, 142840) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 77
('49', 76, 1, 2, 142881) service by way of protest.
('49', 76, 1, 3, 142908) There is no departure from my creed of non violence, and I regard this snatching of salt from the civil resisters as a piece of barbarity.
('49', 76, 1, 4, 143047) The greater the barbarity of the Government, the greater will be my call for self suffering.
('49', 76, 1, 5, 143140) The Hindu, 11 4 1930
('49', 76, 2, 6, 143161) 75. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('49', 76, 3, 7, 143190) JALALPUR, April 10, 1930
('49', 76, 4, 8, 143215) I asked Mahatmaji to define the scope of “defensive non violent resistance”.
('49', 76, 4, 9, 143292) A volunteer, Mahatmaji had advised, should not yield his salt to the police until it was wrested from him by superior force.
('49', 76, 4, 10, 143417) “Is it permissible for the volunteer,” I asked, “to struggle with the police in clinging to it desperately, moving this way and that in his attempts not to yield, and possibly causing hurt to his opponent?” Mahatmaji said: It is his duty to cling to the salt as though it was his life, provided he was not offering violence to his opponent.
('49', 76, 4, 11, 143758) Just as a mother would save her child against the attempts of others to deprive her of it, so should a satyagrahi cling to his salt.
('49', 76, 5, 12, 143891) Gandhiji, continuing stated that in no civilized country was it considered proper for the police to take the law into their own hands.
('49', 76, 5, 13, 144026) When a volunteer refused to hand over his salt he would have committed an offence, but on that account, the police should not inflict corporal punishment on him.
('49', 76, 5, 14, 144188) The police officers had got the right of arresting a volunteer and marching him to the police station and of putting him up for trial.
('49', 76, 6, 15, 144323) Asked how a police officer could discharge the duty imposed on him of seizing the salt, Gandhiji said that his quarrel was exactly with that sort of law.
('49', 76, 7, 16, 144477) The conversation then turned on Mahatmaji’s statement that if women were touched by the police, the whole country would be inflamed unless people were napunsakas.
('49', 76, 7, 17, 144640) That passage, I pointed out, had been criticized as a threat against the legitimate arrest of women.
('49', 76, 8, 18, 144741) Mahatmaji laughed and said he had deliberately made the statement that the country would, in such a contingency, become inflamed, but not necessarily into committing acts of violence.
('49', 76, 8, 19, 144925) He continued: When Sri S. Subramania Aiyer threw away his titles because Dr. Besant had been arrested he had been inflamed, but his feelings involved no violence.
('49', 76, 8, 20, 145088) It is that kind of inflammation that I had referred to.
('49', 76, 9, 21, 145144) Referring to a report circulated by a news agency that his volunteers were
('49', 77, 0, 1, 145219) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 78
('49', 77, 1, 2, 145260) revolting against the diet prescribed for them, Mahatmaji pooh poohed the idea, adding: There was some difficulty in the choice of diet, but once I decided on it, all accepted it without a murmur.
('49', 77, 1, 3, 145457) The Hindu, 11 4 1930
('49', 77, 2, 4, 145478) 76. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, ABRAMA 1
('49', 77, 3, 5, 145517) April 10, 1930 I was told that last night I was going to be arrested and hence at about 11 o’clock I finished some of my correspondence and did some writing.
('49', 77, 3, 6, 145675) The night went by but the expected did not happen I have read in the papers today that the price of salt has fallen by half but my contention is why should there be any price for it?
('49', 77, 4, 7, 145858) Gandhiji then stressed the necessity of complete prohibition and promotion of khaddar.
('49', 77, 5, 8, 145945) Proceeding, he referred to the reports of his speeches appearing in a distorted form in various papers and especially in the Times and remarked that these Press
('49', 77, 6, 9, 146106) reporters were doing a definite disservice to the country.
('49', 77, 6, 10, 146165) He had to contradict a report appearing in The Times of India.
('49', 77, 6, 11, 146228) That report was a sheer distortion of his views.
('49', 77, 7, 12, 146277) would be wrong to say that all reporters were so but he had to admit that many were or else they did not understand his village dialect.
('49', 77, 7, 13, 146414) I did not ask for the reporters but if the papers wanted to send them they should select such as knew his language.
('49', 77, 7, 14, 146530) Ignorant reporters did harm both to him and the cause.
('49', 77, 7, 15, 146585) Non violence was not a new creed with him, he had laid stress on it for at least fifteen years.
('49', 77, 7, 16, 146681) Nobody should imagine that with the advance of years he had lost his sense to such an extent that he should wish to go to jail by paying the price in blood.
('49', 77, 7, 17, 146838) Even for going to jail he would not wish harm to anybody.
('49', 77, 7, 18, 146896) What he had said was that they should not give up salt in their fists even if that might involve serious injury.
('49', 77, 7, 19, 147009) That was not at all contrary to non violence.
('49', 77, 7, 20, 147055) He had received a wire from Delhi that four volunteers were so much battered there that at last they fainted.
('49', 77, 7, 21, 147165) Government had started the game in which only a beginning was made.
('49', 77, 7, 22, 147233) That should not come in the way of their duty.
('49', 77, 7, 23, 147280) It was ashame that Government were arresting even ladies.
('49', 77, 7, 24, 147338) He wanted to show to the world that theirs was a fight in which everyone could take part.
('49', 77, 7, 25, 147428) The Bombay Chronicle, 11 4 1930
('49', 77, 8, 26, 147460) 1 About 5,000 villagers attended the meeting.

('49', 88, 1, 2, 159119) 93. ARRESTS AND BRUTAL JUSTICE
('49', 88, 2, 3, 159150) Gujarat, it may be said, has saved our honour.
('49', 88, 2, 4, 159197) Whole villages here have set out to offer civil disobedience.
('49', 88, 2, 5, 159259) Men, women and chil dren are taking part in it.
('49', 88, 2, 6, 159307) At many places, we can see fields of salt.
('49', 88, 2, 7, 159350) Illegal salt has found its way into people’s houses.
('49', 88, 2, 8, 159403) Gujarat no longer needs Government salt for its use.
('49', 88, 2, 9, 159456) With a little bit of effort anyone who requires salt can carry away as much readymade salt as he wishes.
('49', 88, 2, 10, 159561) But how could the Government tolerate this?
('49', 88, 2, 11, 159605) It started arresting people.
('49', 88, 2, 12, 159634) From Dholar at one end to Jalalpur taluka at the other there has been an awakening and leaders have been arrested.
('49', 88, 2, 13, 159749) Amritlal Sheth, Manilal Kothari, Fulchand Kasturchand Shah, Dr. Hariprasadji, Rohit Mehta, Durbar Gopaldas, Gokuldas Talati, Ravishankar Vyas, Raojibhai Man ibhai Patel, Ashabhai, Dr. Chandulal, Keshubhai Ganeshji, Ramdas Gan dhi, Chimanlal Pranshankar, Bhikshuk or Darbari Sadhu, Kikubhai, Manubhai and others are gracing prisons with their presence.
('49', 88, 2, 14, 160101) There are many names which I have omitted.
('49', 88, 2, 15, 160144) What does it matter whether all the names are mentioned or not?
('49', 88, 2, 16, 160208) Durbar and his companions are in fetters and their heads have been shaved in prison.
('49', 88, 2, 17, 160293) All this is good provided Gujarat values it.
('49', 88, 2, 18, 160338) The fact that those who at Aat, Ahmedabad and Dholka tried to protect their honour through the medium of salt were beaten is signi ficant and unexpected.
('49', 88, 2, 19, 160492) I had expected that the Government would not indulge in brutality and that it would send people to prison after duly trying them under laws.
('49', 88, 2, 20, 160633) My expectations have been belied.
('49', 88, 2, 21, 160667) How can one change one’s nature all of a sudden?
('49', 88, 2, 22, 160716) The Government has yet only given us a taste of its bloody claws; we can be sure there is more to come.
('49', 88, 2, 23, 160820) Going beyond Gujarat, we find Jamnalalji, Nariman and others have been arrested in Bombay.
('49', 88, 2, 24, 160911) The cases are proceeding at great speed.
('49', 88, 2, 25, 160952) But the sentences, it is apparent, will depend upon the whim of the magistrate.
('49', 88, 2, 26, 161032) In Delhi, Devdas Gandhi’s companions have been beaten.
('49', 88, 2, 27, 161087) Devdas and his companions have been arrested.
('49', 88, 2, 28, 161133) What reply will the nation give to this now?
('49', 88, 2, 29, 161178) By the time this article is published, much else will have happened.
('49', 88, 2, 30, 161247) I expect still more from the people.
('49', 88, 2, 31, 161284) A bonfire should be made of foreign cloth, there should be a takli in every hand.
('49', 88, 2, 32, 161366) Schools and
('49', 89, 0, 1, 161378) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 90
('49', 89, 1, 2, 161419) colleges should become empty.
('49', 89, 1, 3, 161449) Lawyers and doctors can help in vari ous ways.
('49', 89, 1, 4, 161496) I have written separately regarding women.
('49', 89, 1, 5, 161539) All aspects of a nation aspiring for freedom should be developed.
('49', 89, 1, 6, 161605) It is a sign of weak ness that Government jobs have not yet lost their fascination.

('49', 89, 2, 11, 161965) 94. MILL OWNERS AND KHADI
('49', 89, 3, 12, 161991) Shri Ranchhodlal Amritlal, who is himself a mill owner, writes to say: 1
('49', 89, 4, 13, 162064) It is a distressing tale.
('49', 89, 4, 14, 162090) I am convinced, however, that as people’s sacrifices increase, the hearts of the mill owners will melt.
('49', 89, 4, 15, 162194) I know that the khadi activity has benefited Indian mills.
('49', 89, 4, 16, 162253) If, however, the latter instead of enjoying the sweet fruit of the tree attempt to eat up its roots, they will find they cannot do so and will even lose the fruit.
('49', 89, 4, 17, 162417) Let me cite a brief example.
('49', 89, 4, 18, 162446) Let us suppose that boycott of foreign cloth is successful; let us suppose that spurious khadi is passed off as gen uine; and let us suppose that genuine khadi is unable to lift its head.
('49', 89, 4, 19, 162634) In that case, one of two results could follow.
('49', 89, 4, 20, 162681) Spurious khadi and other cloth made in mills would not be adequate.
('49', 89, 4, 21, 162749) As people are not used to khadi they would clamour for foreign cloth and we would be worse off than we previously were, Indian mills would be swept away in the storm, the chain of non violence would be broken and the enraged public would take to boycotting Indian mills.
('49', 89, 4, 22, 163020) Or, supposing the goods from Lancashire were totally rejected, since the shield of khadi would not be there, the capitalists from Lancashire might start their mills in this country and Indian mills would suffer as a result of foreign cap ital and foreign talent establishing themselves here and thereafter swadeshi mills would regard it their duty to join the foreign mills in exploiting the people.
('49', 89, 4, 23, 163420) Though one cannot yet claim that the sentiment for khadi has taken root in villages, nevertheless it has established itself to the extent that many well educated persons are prepared to dedicate themselves to the cause of khadi.
('49', 89, 4, 24, 163649) They will not allow khadi to
('49', 89, 5, 25, 163678) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('49', 89, 5, 26, 163715) The correspondent, enclosing samples, had complained that many mills were manufacturing spurious khadi and selling it under the stamp of “pure swadeshi khadi”.
('49', 90, 0, 1, 163875) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 91
('49', 90, 1, 2, 163916) die so long as they are themselves alive.
('49', 90, 1, 3, 163958) If, therefore, mill owners do not stop producing and selling mill made cloth as khadi, there is every possibility of a fierce movement being launched against them.
('49', 90, 1, 4, 164122) It will become our duty to start such a movement.
('49', 90, 1, 5, 164172) They ought to save themselves from such a movement.
('49', 90, 1, 6, 164224) It is in their hands to do so.
('49', 90, 1, 7, 164255) Here are the terms: (1) Indian mills must not produce cloth which resembles khadi.
('49', 90, 1, 8, 164338) (2) That which has been already produced should he exported.
('49', 90, 1, 9, 164399) (3) They should altogether stop using the khadi stamp.
('49', 90, 1, 10, 164454) (4) They should give up making cloth which could compete with khadi.
('49', 90, 1, 11, 164523) (5) They should consult with the Charkha Sangh and produce only such cloth as is beyond the scope of khadi.
('49', 90, 1, 12, 164631) (6) In consultation with the khadi committee, they should fix reasonable prices for mill made cloth.
('49', 90, 1, 13, 164732) (7) No foreign yarn should be used in mills even for making borders.
('49', 90, 1, 14, 164801) (8) Mill owners and others should totally give up using foreign cloth and wear only khadi as far as possible.
('49', 90, 1, 15, 164911) (9) They should stock khadi in the shop attached to mills.
('49', 90, 1, 16, 164970) During this period of self purification it is highly essential for the mills to observe the above rules.
('49', 90, 1, 17, 165075) If they do so the boycott of foreign cloth can be accomplished soon.
('49', 90, 1, 18, 165144) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 4 1930

('49', 91, 1, 2, 165222) 95. TO THE WOMEN
('49', 91, 2, 3, 165239) Last week, writing about prohibition, I had mentioned that there was another activity also which women could and ought to take up.
('49', 91, 2, 4, 165370) This activity is the boycott of foreign cloth through khadi.
('49', 91, 2, 5, 165431) This is, or should be, the special field of women.
('49', 91, 2, 6, 165482) For foreign cloth has ruined millions of homes and taken away from millions of women an emp loyment which sustained them.
('49', 91, 2, 7, 165604) Foreign cloth has ruined seven lakh villages in India.
('49', 91, 2, 8, 165659) While on the one hand women have lost employment, on the other they have to pay for cloth which they could have produced in their own villages.
('49', 91, 2, 9, 165803) People have developed a great liking for foreign cloth and they will not give it up without great effort and great penance.
('49', 91, 2, 10, 165927) It is the women who embody that penance.
('49', 91, 2, 11, 165968) Man can never make an impression upon people such as women can.
('49', 91, 3, 12, 166032) Besides, amongst those who wear foreign cloth the number of women exceeds that of men.
('49', 91, 3, 13, 166119) And, in the final analysis, women will create a greater impact upon other women.
('49', 91, 3, 14, 166200) Hence it is for women to start picketing in front of shops selling foreign cloth.
('49', 91, 3, 15, 166282) Men have failed in this task.
('49', 91, 3, 16, 166312) But there is no reason why women should fail.
('49', 91, 3, 17, 166358) Moreover, in 1920 21 we did not have the same climate that there is now.
('49', 91, 3, 18, 166431) It is women alone who can take advantage of this climate.
('49', 91, 3, 19, 166489) But there is also another aspect of this work.
('49', 91, 3, 20, 166536) Supposing every one was to burn their foreign clothes today, what then would they wear?
('49', 91, 3, 21, 166624) Indian mills would not be able to produce all the cloth within a short period and perhaps even if they did we would not achieve the purpose that we wish to.
('49', 91, 3, 22, 166781) That purpose would be served through khadi alone.
('49', 91, 3, 23, 166831) Khadi implies the takli or the spinning wheel.
('49', 91, 3, 24, 166878) In the latter lies the prosperity of India.
('49', 91, 3, 25, 166922) It is Annapurna 1. If people in every home work on the spin ning wheel, we can produce today as much khadi as we want.
('49', 91, 3, 26, 167041) Producing khadi means spinning yarn.
('49', 91, 3, 27, 167078) Men may well spin, but for generations the profession of spinning has been practised by women and men’s hands do not possess the same skill in this that women’s do.
('49', 91, 3, 28, 167243) Women alone can bring about this solidarity among their own sex.
('49', 91, 3, 29, 167308) I would, therefore, advise women to make this their special field of work.
('49', 91, 4, 30, 167383) 1 Giver of plenty 2 Two paragraphs following this are not translated here.
('49', 91, 4, 31, 167458) They are covered by paragraphs 11 and 12 of “To the Women of India”, p.
('49', 92, 0, 1, 167530) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 93
('49', 92, 1, 2, 167571) In this non violent campaign, although our weapons are small they are very powerful since they have in them the power of God.
('49', 92, 1, 3, 167697) Therefore, all those sisters who have faith in the spinning wheel and the takli and who wish to devote themselves to saving sixty crores of rupees every year, should take up this work of boycott and the task of propagating spinning.
('49', 92, 1, 4, 167930) It should be remembered that those sisters who wish to take up this work have to be prepared to go to the villages.
('49', 92, 1, 5, 168046) Sisters who have faith not in both but in only one of these activ ities should take up only that.
('49', 92, 1, 6, 168144) I have suggested the two activities through which millions of women can develop themselves and contri bute their full share in the yajna of swaraj.
('49', 92, 1, 7, 168292) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 4 1930

('49', 94, 1, 2, 171418) 98. SPEECH AT GUJARATI WOMEN’S CONFERENCE, DANDI
('49', 94, 2, 3, 171467) April 13, 1930 There are certain activities which are meant only for women.
('49', 94, 2, 4, 171543) Prohibition and boycott of foreign cloth are such activities; which if you do not take up, will never be accomplished.
('49', 94, 2, 5, 171662) In 1921 I compelled men to take up these tasks and they did so out of fear, but how long could it last?
('49', 94, 2, 6, 171766) In the end I had to accept defeat and suspend the activities.
('49', 94, 2, 7, 171828) I would not have had to do so had I entrusted the work to women.
('49', 94, 2, 8, 171893) But when I was utterly confused and had been defeated on all sides, God, like in that bhajan of the tortoise couple, made me entrust the work to women.
('49', 94, 2, 9, 172045) It is no doubt very difficult to picket shops but women had been taking great risks in the past.
('49', 94, 2, 10, 172142) It is for tha reason that the world is still going on.
('49', 94, 2, 11, 172197) Moreover both these activities required persuasion and change of heart.
('49', 94, 2, 12, 172269) Women alone can enter the hearts of men and trans form them.
('49', 94, 2, 13, 172330) Moreover those women who have come here must be aware of the plight of the families where husbands drink.
('49', 94, 2, 14, 172436) It is your duty to help your sisters’ families from breaking up.
('49', 94, 2, 15, 172501) Foreign cloth has taken away from fifteen crores of your sisters the noble profession of plying the spinning wheel and have rendered crores of villagers unemployed.
('49', 94, 2, 16, 172666) Khadi activity of ten insignificant years have brought ten lakhs of rupees to the women’s homes.
('49', 94, 2, 17, 172763) I want you to expand the activity so that crores of rupees are brought in.
('49', 94, 2, 18, 172838) Once you take up this work, you have to discard foreign clothes—you should burn them.
('49', 94, 2, 19, 172924) You may say you will wear out whatever you have or that you will pre serve them.
('49', 94, 2, 20, 173005) Even a drunkard might say that he would consume whatever liquour he had or keep it.
('49', 94, 2, 21, 173089) How can we keep a thing which we consider to be a poison even for a day?
('49', 94, 2, 22, 173162) We should throw it away lest our children by mistake take the poison.
('49', 94, 2, 23, 173232) You may think that you have thrown that much money into water.
('49', 94, 3, 24, 173295) A woman picketer of Vejalpore had asked what the women should do if they were attacked while they were picketing.
('49', 94, 3, 25, 173409) Gandhiji replied: There is no danger of such attack.
('49', 94, 3, 26, 173462) However if that happens or if the police try to disperse you with the help of horses then put up with it quietly.
('49', 94, 3, 27, 173576) A woman has a remarkable capacity for suffering.
('49', 94, 3, 28, 173625) Take it from me that the liquour shops will be closed down the day there is such an attack on women.
('49', 94, 3, 29, 173726) You may be certain he will give up drinking for ever from that day, [From Gujarati] Prajabandhu, 20 4 1930

('49', 95, 1, 2, 173874) 99. SPEECH AT DANDI 1
('49', 95, 2, 3, 173896) April 13, 1930 I am happy that you have on your own come here in such large numbers on this the last day of the self purification week, but you will not be happy if I do not say something to you on this occasion.
('49', 95, 2, 4, 174109) I have just concluded the women’s conference.
('49', 95, 2, 5, 174155) You will like to know your place in what I have told the women to do.
('49', 95, 2, 6, 174225) The womenhave resolved to picket shops selling foreign cloth as also those who use it, and those who sell liquor as also those who drink it.
('49', 95, 2, 7, 174366) We men may not interfere in this work.
('49', 95, 2, 8, 174405) Let us treat this as the special field of women.
('49', 95, 2, 9, 174454) The success of this work depends entirely on the self control of men.
('49', 95, 2, 10, 174524) The assumption behind this is that men cannot easily control their anger, cannot easily practise non violence, while women can do so.
('49', 95, 2, 11, 174658) Renu nciation and non violence come naturally to women.
('49', 95, 2, 12, 174714) Having been insp ired by this idea I have tried to explain it to women.
('49', 95, 2, 13, 174786) If my assum ption is false, my conclusion will also be false to the same degree.
('49', 95, 2, 14, 174867) It is the duty of men to make the atmosphere congenial for women to do their work.
('49', 95, 2, 15, 174950) We men should go to the dealers in liquor and foreign cloth and try to convince them that now that the women of India have come out they should give up trade in these two things.
('49', 95, 2, 16, 175129) Confronted by the large groups of women even liquor booth owners and owners of shops selling foreign cloth will be startled and give up their trade.
('49', 95, 2, 17, 175278) I know it is not easy to give up one’s trade.
('49', 95, 2, 18, 175324) But, at a time when the atmosphere is filled with national pride and patr iotism, the people’s capacity for renunciation automatically increases.
('49', 95, 2, 19, 175470) During this week alone this capacity has increased a hundredfold, but it should increase a thousandfold.
('49', 95, 2, 20, 175575) Dealers in foreign cloth still seem to be calculating whether to give up their trade.
('49', 95, 2, 21, 175661) They take a vow for three months or a year.
('49', 95, 2, 22, 175705) Beh ind this act there is a lurking belief that they will be able to buy foreign cloth after a year.
('49', 95, 2, 23, 175806) They do not make the effort that is needed to secure swaraj.
('49', 95, 2, 24, 175867) This is because they lack the faith.
('49', 95, 2, 25, 175904) But as this mov ement makes progress—trading in liquor and foreign cloth cannot but come to an end.
('49', 95, 3, 26, 176004) 1 Extracts from the speech were also published in Young India, 17 4 1930, under the heading “Men’s Part”.
('49', 96, 0, 1, 176110) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 97
('49', 96, 1, 2, 176151) When hundreds of thousands of our countrymen have sacrificed their all, even these sceptical traders are bound to develop the strength to make sacrifices.
('49', 96, 1, 3, 176306) If women lack funds to continue the work after once starting it, I shall stretch out my hand to you, though at present, by the blessing of God, I am able to get more funds than I need.
('49', 96, 1, 4, 176491) Only today, about a thousand rupees were collected at the women’s meeting and a lady belonging to the Galiara family of Kathor gave four gold bangles without even being asked.
('49', 96, 1, 5, 176667) If we men are not indifferent and begin the work on our own, if, for instance, for want of enough khadi it becomes necessary to wear only a loin cloth and we start doing so, to that extent we shall have lightened the burden of our womenfolk.
('49', 96, 1, 6, 176909) Miss Mayo has accused us saying that many of our men have no consideration for women, that we make them work as drudges, as if they were born to be slaves.
('49', 96, 1, 7, 177065) The world will be convinced that what Miss Mayo said was not true when women wake up and accomplish the tasks of boycotting foreign cloth and of prohibition.
('49', 96, 1, 8, 177223) The stocks of khadi in the country are dwindling and I am therefore asking everyone to spin and wear khadi and I am dem onstrating this before you every day by spinning on the takli.
('49', 96, 1, 9, 177406) Just as we grind and cook cereals which are available in every home we ought to spin the large quantities of cotton which grows in India into some kind of yarn, make cloth from it and then wear that cloth.
('49', 96, 1, 10, 177612) When spinning becomes a universal activity in the country, you can rest assured that the trade in foreign cloth will come to an end.
('49', 96, 1, 11, 177745) Mills can never entirely meet the cloth needs of India and as most mills in India are either wholly or partly foreign, cloth made by only a few of them can be used if the need arises.
('49', 96, 1, 12, 177929) Women from good families have come out to take up these activities.
('49', 96, 1, 13, 177997) Divan Shri Manubhai’s daughter Shrimati Hansa Mehta and some other ladies have only recently issued a circular and begun the work of prohibition in Bombay.
('49', 96, 1, 14, 178153) If Gujarati women continue to work in this spirit and if the men lend them support this activity will become widespread in India.
('49', 96, 1, 15, 178283) All these three things are easy.
('49', 96, 1, 16, 178316) When we have accomplished these three things we shall have saved six crores from the salt tax, twenty five crores from prohibition and sixty crores from the boycott of foreign cloth—ninety one crores in all.
('49', 96, 1, 17, 178524) We shall have become purer and added to our strength, and then it will not take long
('49', 97, 0, 1, 178609) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 98
('49', 97, 1, 2, 178650) for us to secure swaraj.
('49', 97, 1, 3, 178675) Finally, we should take care that we do not lose what we have gained during these seven days.
('49', 97, 1, 4, 178769) I have just received news that some youths in Calcutta, who were reading out passages from proscribed books at meetings, were dispersed.
('49', 97, 1, 5, 178906) On seeing the police committing such atrocities, Shri Sen Gupta, the Mayor of Calcutta, also started reading out paragraphs from those banned books and was immediately arrested.
('49', 97, 1, 6, 179084) Dr. Suresh Chandra Bannerjee, the able khadi worker of Abhoy Ashram, who at one time received a salary of Rs. 600 a month from the Government, has been sentenced to a term of two and a half years’ rigorous imprisonment for violating the salt law.
('49', 97, 1, 7, 179331) Notwithstanding such atrocities, just as we in Gujarat have not become frightened and given in, there too, they are not onlynot frigh tened but have become more resolute.
('49', 97, 1, 8, 179502) Whatever the atrocities perp etrated on us, we do not want to use force on anyone or to insult anyone.
('49', 97, 1, 9, 179605) A certain gentleman has informed me that in Bombay when they were making bonfires of foreign cloth caps from other people’s heads were forcibly removed and burnt I do not know how far this is true.
('49', 97, 1, 10, 179803) But if it is true, rest assured that this struggle cannot go on.
('49', 97, 1, 11, 179868) If force is used, people will not tolerate it; they will start fighting amongst themselves and the Government will take advantage of this situation.
('49', 97, 1, 12, 180017) If people do not want swaraj through the boycott of foreign cloth, we cannot make them do good under compulsion.
('49', 97, 1, 13, 180130) In order to melt their hearts, we must make greater sacrifices and even practise satyagraha against them if it becomes necessary to do so.
('49', 97, 1, 14, 180269) What should I do if I was convinced that people were deceiving me, that having decided to boycott foreign cloth through khadi alone they pledged themselves to do so and then broke their pledge ?
('49', 97, 1, 15, 180464) If I was convinced that I had become purified and wholly comp assionate, I should, when the occasion arose, offer satyagraha and go on a fast.
('49', 97, 1, 16, 180607) What should I do if you should raise your hands every day, say that if there is not enough khadi you will wear lungotis and then it should turn out that not a single sister spins?
('49', 97, 1, 17, 180787) I might perhaps even at this advanced age have to say the same thing I said when I saw that the labourers of Ahmedabad had broken their pledge, and do what I did at the time of the riots in Bombay.
('49', 97, 1, 18, 180985) I would do so unwillingly if I felt that we were deceiving God daily.
('49', 97, 1, 19, 181055) I have faith that the people of Guja

('49', 98, 1, 2, 181134) rat will never deceive me.
('49', 98, 1, 3, 181161) We want to live in peace and win swaraj peacefully.
('49', 98, 1, 4, 181213) I do not wish to live to see disturbances in the country.
('49', 98, 1, 5, 181271) You just came on this day of my fast and I have said simply what I wanted to.
('49', 98, 1, 6, 181349) You must prevent any use of force whether in Bom bay or elsewhere.
('49', 98, 1, 7, 181416) Whenever I hear of one of our men having abused someone, having been discourteous to someone or having used force against someone I feel deeply hurt and truly my heart begins to thump violently.

('49', 109, 8, 14, 197039) 119. UNTOUCHABILITY
('49', 109, 9, 15, 197059) As in the matter of Hindu Muslim unity so has there been misrepresentation in the matter of untouchability It has been stated that I am sacrificing the interest of the untouchables for the sake of swaraj.
('49', 109, 9, 16, 197264) I know that the lacs of untouchables will not believe any such thing of me.
('49', 109, 9, 17, 197340) For me just as there is no swaraj without communal unity, so is there no swaraj without the removal of untouchability.
('49', 109, 9, 18, 197459) But what I do feel is that without swaraj there will be neither communal unity nor removal of untouchability.
('49', 109, 9, 19, 197569) He who runs may see that it is to the interest of the ruling caste to keep up the divisions among us.
('49', 109, 9, 20, 197671) That caste is no more interested in Hindus and Mussalmans coming together than in the removal of untouchability.
('49', 109, 9, 21, 197784) In examining the sources of revenue I endeavoured the other day to show how the Government was built on an immoral foundation.
('49', 109, 9, 22, 197911) Even so has it built itself upon our weaknesses and our vices.
('49', 109, 9, 23, 197974) Take the disgraceful Nasik quarrel.
('49', 109, 9, 24, 198010) The Government knows that the Sanatanists are in the wrong.
('49', 109, 9, 25, 198070) But what has it done?
('49', 109, 9, 26, 198092) Because they repr esent a powerful interest, the untouchables have been sacrificed.
('49', 109, 9, 27, 198176) It was open to the authorities to get together the Sanatanists and reason with them.
('49', 109, 9, 28, 198261) It was open to them to reason with the untouchables and ask them not to precipitate a fight.
('49', 109, 9, 29, 198354) But this required an impartial mind, disinterestedness.
('49', 109, 9, 30, 198410) But the Government is not disinterested.
('49', 109, 9, 31, 198451) It rejoices to see the parties quarrel and then side with
('49', 110, 0, 1, 198509) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 111
('49', 110, 1, 2, 198551) the strongest.
('49', 110, 1, 3, 198566) I know that many good natured but ignorant Englishmen will cavil at this opinion.
('49', 110, 1, 4, 198648) I can only tell them that it is based on everyday exp erience.
('49', 110, 1, 5, 198711) I do not suggest that every time the action is deliberate.
('49', 110, 1, 6, 198770) ‘Might is right’, ‘divide and rule’, have become the daily routine of the official world.
('49', 110, 1, 7, 198860) Such being my deep conviction, I would be wronging the min orities and wronging the untouchables if I stopped the progress towards swaraj by inaction.
('49', 110, 1, 8, 199011) I hold that as soon as we have realized the power that is lying dormant in every one of us, that very moment we shall be free and we shall feel the glow of real unity and the unto uch ables will also feel an accession of power.
('49', 110, 1, 9, 199239) Let it be understood that everywhere the bands of civil resisters contain Mussalmans, members of other faiths as also untouchables, be these ever so few.
('49', 110, 1, 10, 199393) The fact is that the foundations of swaraj are being laid by those who regard communal unity, equality of rights and opportunity and removal of untouchability as articles of faith.
('49', 110, 1, 11, 199574) Let the untouchable brethren not be lured from the common goal because it was the presence of Englishmen that stimulated Hindu thought and brought to the untouchables a sense of their rights.
('49', 110, 1, 12, 199766) The fact is there.
('49', 110, 1, 13, 199785) But the English did not descend upon India with any such benevolent motive.
('49', 110, 1, 14, 199861) Their civilization or rather the Western civili zation does not recognize distinctions in the manner decayed Hinduism does.
('49', 110, 1, 15, 199985) We could have profited by this excellence of theirs without having the infliction of their rule.
('49', 110, 1, 16, 200082) My indictment is not against the English as men, it is against Englishmen as the ruling caste.
('49', 110, 1, 17, 200177) As men they are as good as we.
('49', 110, 1, 18, 200208) In some respects they are better, in some others they may be worse.
('49', 110, 1, 19, 200276) But as rulers they are highly unde sirable.
('49', 110, 1, 20, 200320) As rulers they can do, have done, no good to any of us.
('49', 110, 1, 21, 200376) They have pandered to, and accentuated, our vices.
('49', 110, 1, 22, 200427) And as we have deve loped the inferiority complex, their contact demoralizes us.
('49', 110, 1, 23, 200508) I have watched ourselves acting one way in their presence, another way behind their backs.
('49', 110, 1, 24, 200599) This is an unmanly and unmanning process; it is unnatural.
('49', 110, 1, 25, 200658) “The tallest of us,” said Gokhale, “has to bend before them.” When they come to their senses, they too will realize that their rule has no less debased them than us.
('49', 110, 1, 26, 200824) Now a word to the untouchables.
('49', 110, 1, 27, 200856) I have advised them and I repeat the advice that it is wholly unnecessary for them to seek to force entry into the orthodox temples even through the method of satyagraha.
('49', 110, 1, 28, 201027) It is the duty of the ‘touchable’ Hindus to secure for the
('49', 111, 0, 1, 201086) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 112
('49', 111, 1, 2, 201128) untouchables the freedom of the temples.
('49', 111, 1, 3, 201169) It is for the ‘touchables’ to offer satyagraha when the time is ripe.
('49', 111, 1, 4, 201239) The untouchables know that the Congress has appointed, with Jamnalalji as the head, a committee for that very purpose.
('49', 111, 1, 5, 201358) They know that very great progress has been made in the matter of removal of untouchability, they know that all over India are to be found hundreds of well known believing Hindus who will lay down their lives to remove untouchability.
('49', 111, 1, 6, 201593) The reformers hold it to be their duty and penance to purge the Hindu society of the evil.
('49', 111, 1, 7, 201684) Let the untouchables know that the vast majority of them are today engaged in this life and death struggle.
('49', 111, 1, 8, 201792) If they realize the truth of the statements I have made, they will at least suspend the satyagraha pending the struggle even if the whole mass of them will not join it as some of them have already done.
('49', 111, 1, 9, 201995) The Hindu reformers have undertaken the work not as patrons, not to do the favour to the untouchables, certainly not to exploit them politically.
('49', 111, 1, 10, 202141) They have undertaken the task because their conception of Hinduism peremptorily demands it.
('49', 111, 1, 11, 202233) They have either to leave Hinduism or to make good the claim that untouchability is no part of it but that it is an excrescence to be rooted out.

('49', 111, 2, 13, 202402) 120. THE INHUMAN TAX
('49', 111, 3, 14, 202423) Every new experience gained of the incidence of the salt tax shows it to be more inhuman than it appeared at first.
('49', 111, 3, 15, 202539) Living and moving as I am in the midst of the salt area in Gujarat, I find that villages have been ruined because of the prohibition of salt manufacture by the villagers.
('49', 111, 3, 16, 202710) The only use the people can make of the land is to extract salt from it which nature deposits in abundance from month to month.
('49', 111, 3, 17, 202838) This was the poor man’s staple industry in these parts.
('49', 111, 3, 18, 202894) Now all this land lies fallow.
('49', 111, 3, 19, 202925) Dandi itself has a tragic history.
('49', 111, 3, 20, 202960) It is a beautiful seaside place.
('49', 111, 3, 21, 202993) It takes its name from the fact that it was a place for a diva dandi, i.e., a lighthouse.
('49', 111, 3, 22, 203083) Now it is a deserted village.
('49', 111, 3, 23, 203113) A European and then Indians tried against nature to reclaim the soil for cultivation.
('49', 111, 3, 24, 203199) As I walk about the otherwise beautiful peace giving shore and listen for the heavenly music of the gentle waves, I see about me wasted human effort in the shape of dilapidated embanked fields without a patch of vegetation.
('49', 111, 3, 25, 203423) These very fields, immediately the hateful salt monopoly is gone, will be valuable salt pans from which villagers will extract fresh, white sparkling salt
('49', 112, 0, 1, 203578) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 113
('49', 112, 1, 2, 203620) without much labour, and it will give them a living as it did their ancestors.
('49', 112, 1, 3, 203699) Mahadev Desai has already shown that the Government communique that this salt is injurious to health is a wicked falsehood.
('49', 112, 2, 4, 203823) In spite of the inhuman regulations, the people round about this area have used none but the salt that nature provides here in abundance.
('49', 112, 2, 5, 203961) They do not seem to have felt any the worse for it.
('49', 112, 2, 6, 204013) Thousands all over this area have been during the past week eating this salt with impunity.
('49', 112, 2, 7, 204105) I hear that in Konkan people have all these years used what they regard as swadeshi salt in contradistinction to the taxed salt which they regard as sarkari or foreign, although in the first instance it was yiel ded by India’s earth and seas.
('49', 112, 2, 8, 204348) The recipe which I publish in this issue has been prepared by two careful men who have graduated in science.
('49', 112, 2, 9, 204457) According to it every household can prepare its own salt without any expense whatsoever.
('49', 112, 2, 10, 204546) One boy has merely to fetch a lota ful 2 of salt water and it has merely to be strained or filtered and put near the fire in a shallow pan and treated in accordance with the recipe and the householders have every day’s supply of salt much cleaner and healthier than the ‘sarkari’ 3 or ‘foreign’ dirty salt to be had in the bazaars.
('49', 112, 2, 11, 204878) Let the salt satyagrahis (and they are to be counted in their tens of thousands now) not waste a single grain of swadeshi salt.
('49', 112, 2, 12, 205006) Law or no law, there is now no excuse for anyone to eat the bazaar salt.
('49', 112, 2, 13, 205079) Swadeshi salt must be introduced even where there are no salt beds.
('49', 112, 2, 14, 205147) It can be easily transported in small quantities from place to place.
('49', 112, 2, 15, 205217) Let the Government prosecute tens of thousands of men and women or, if they dare, send their officials to search their persons and brutally force it from them.
('49', 112, 2, 16, 205377) Let them say: ‘The salt law allows it.’ I have already shown that the salt regulations are as inhuman as the tax itself.
('49', 112, 2, 17, 205498) If the history of the administration in the early stages of these regu lations were known, it would be found that these inhuman regulations were as inhumanely administered in order to deprive the people of their natural calling and compel them to take the bloodstained sarkari salt.
('49', 112, 2, 18, 205781) Let the reader know that even palanquins bearing purdahnashin 4
('49', 112, 3, 19, 205845) women were searched in order to prevent the transport of illicit salt.
('49', 112, 4, 20, 205916) 1 Mahadev Desai’s article entitled “A Brazen Lie” was published in Young India, 10 4 1930.
('49', 112, 5, 21, 206007) 2 A lota is a metal jug.
('49', 112, 6, 22, 206032) 3 Literally, of the Government 4 Wearing purdah
('49', 113, 0, 1, 206080) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 114
('49', 113, 1, 2, 206122) today we have to bear hardships in the attempt to have this iniquitous tax removed, we are but doing a modicum of penance for our past neglect and shameful submission to the impost.
('49', 113, 1, 3, 206304) The reader will thus see that it is not merely the tax, heavy as it is, that is offensive.
('49', 113, 1, 4, 206395) It has not one redeeming feature about it.

('49', 113, 2, 8, 206683) 121. A SURVEY
('49', 113, 3, 9, 206697) The mass manifestation in Gujarat has exceeded all exp ectations.
('49', 113, 3, 10, 206763) Bombay and its suburbs have done no less.
('49', 113, 3, 11, 206805) And the reports slowly coming to me at this out of the way place from all over India are fully encouraging.

('49', 113, 3, 18, 207217) Its very factions are symptomatic of its great awakening.
('49', 113, 3, 19, 207275) If Bengal responds in the right style it is likely to overshadow every other province.

('49', 113, 3, 21, 207475) If its emotional side is its weakness, it is also its greatest strength.

('49', 113, 3, 23, 207646) Sen Gupta’s action in response to the wanton assault on the students’ meeting has evoked the sentiment above expressed.
('49', 113, 3, 24, 207766) The sentence of Dr. Suresh Bannerji and others pales into insignificance before the possibilities of the move on the part of the Bengal students and the savage counter move on the part of the police.
('49', 113, 3, 25, 207966) I know what the Calcutta Commissioner of Police will say if he sees these lines.

('49', 113, 3, 27, 208147) His Bengal is the creation of the Government.
('49', 113, 3, 28, 208193) If the Government will cease to molest Bengal and not keep India from her cherished goal, Bengal will be as gentle as the greatest province of India.
('49', 113, 3, 29, 208343) If Bengal is seething with the violent spirit, it is because of her sufferings.
('49', 114, 0, 1, 208423) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 115
('49', 114, 1, 2, 208465) But I expect Bengal’s imagination to come to her assistance and to realize that non violence is the trump card.
('49', 114, 1, 3, 208577) All the suffering must be dedicated to the goddess of ahimsa.
('49', 114, 1, 4, 208639) Soon after the Jallianwala massacre, I used to express and reiterate the hope that next time in no part of India must people run away on bullets being discharged against them, and that theymust receive them in their chests with arms folded and with courageous resignation.
('49', 114, 1, 5, 208912) That testing time seems to be coming faster than I had expected.
('49', 114, 1, 6, 208977) And if we are to train ourselves to receive the bullet wounds or bayonet charges in our bare chests, we must accustom ourselves to standing unmoved in the face of cavalry or baton charges.
('49', 114, 1, 7, 209166) I know that it is easier said than done.
('49', 114, 1, 8, 209207) Nevertheless, I must say it if we are ever to complete our training in mass non violence.
('49', 114, 1, 9, 209297) That mass non violence is a perfect possibility has been sufficiently demonstrated during the past eight days.
('49', 114, 1, 10, 209408) Mahadev Desai has given a realistic account of the brutal treatment of volunteers in the Dholera saltbed and the volunt eers suffering the brutality with meek heroism.

('49', 116, 4, 6, 213699) The conference of women on Sunday last at Dandi became a Congress as I had wanted it to be.
('49', 116, 4, 7, 213791) Thanks to the Government proh ibition against the Baroda territory cars plying between Navsari and Dandi, many had walked the full 12 miles to Dandi.
('49', 116, 4, 8, 213941) The following resolutions were unanimously adopted: I
('49', 116, 5, 9, 213995) This conference of the women of Gujarat assembled at Dandi on 13th April, 1930 having heard Gandhiji, resolves that the women assembled will picket liquor and toddy shops of Gujarat and appeal to the shop keepers and the shop goers [to desist] from plying their trade or drinking intoxicating liquors as the case may be, and will similarly picket foreign cloth shops and appeal to the dealers and the buyers to desist from the practice of dealing in or buying foreign cloth as the case may be.
('49', 116, 7, 10, 214489) This conference is of opinion that boycott of foreign cloth is possible only through khadi and therefore the women assembled resolve henceforth to use khadi only and will so far as possible spin regularly and will learn all the previous processes and preach the message of khadi among their neighbours, teach them the processes up to spinning and encourage them to spin regularly.

('49', 122, 3, 5, 225418) 127. INTERVIEW TO FREE PRESS OF INDIA
('49', 122, 4, 6, 225456) JALALPUR, April 17, 1930 It is too early for me to speak with certainty anything about the so called riots in Calcutta and Karachi.
('49', 122, 4, 7, 225588) Having become used to grossly exaggerated accounts and distorted versions of things hap pening before my eyes, I am inclined largely to discount the stories of violence alleged to have been done by people.
('49', 122, 4, 8, 225794) But be it ever so little, I have no manner of doubt that it harms the struggle, and at the same time the struggle has to go on unchecked.
('49', 122, 4, 9, 225932) If non violence has to fight people’s violence in addition to that of Government, it must still perf orm its arduous task at any cost.
('49', 122, 4, 10, 226067) I see no escape from it.
('49', 122, 4, 11, 226092) At the very outset of the campaign I had declared that there was every possibility of some violence breaking out on the part of the people.
('49', 122, 4, 12, 226232) It seems now to have broken out; and it hurts me, only because it hurts the cause I hold as dear as life itself.
('49', 122, 4, 13, 226345) But I must say that Government have prov oked it in dispersing the meeting where no violence had been done; to prohibit public meetings and processions altogether is a thing calcu lated to precipitate violence.
('49', 122, 4, 14, 226556) Government have with utmost deli beration picked up the leaders of the people who were known to be partial to non violence and to possess controlling influence on the people.
('49', 122, 4, 15, 226731) It would have been miraculous if this gross interference with popular liberty had not evoked reprisals from easily inflammable peo ple, who were to be found in every community and in all parts of the world.
('49', 122, 4, 16, 226938) Take Gujarat itself; and in the out of the way Dholera and near Viramgam unnameable and indecent atrocities are said to have been committed upon defenceless national workers.
('49', 122, 4, 17, 227113) Their only crime was that they would not easily yield up the salt in their possession.
('49', 122, 4, 18, 227200) In the first place, I do not know that outside India under any civilized government, authority has been given to the police for cibly to take away from people anything unless it is of a dangerous character.
('49', 122, 4, 19, 227407) I know that Salt Acts do give such powers.
('49', 122, 4, 20, 227450) That merely illu strates my view.
('49', 122, 4, 21, 227484) A barbarous act does not become less so
('49', 123, 0, 1, 227524) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 124
('49', 123, 1, 2, 227566) by having the authority of law, and the practice of indecent torture is uterly intolerable and calculated to exhaust the patience of any people.
('49', 123, 1, 3, 227711) The obvious fact is that Government [do not] want peace.
('49', 123, 1, 4, 227768) I observe that Mr. Jairamdas Doulatram has come in for a bullet wound in the thigh.
('49', 123, 1, 5, 227852) I am delighted it is Mr. Jairamdas Doulatram rather than some unknown person to have been thus injured.
('49', 123, 1, 6, 227956) Mr. Jairamdas is one of the greatest persons to be found in all India.
('49', 123, 1, 7, 228027) If he was in the crowd, he was there not to incite people to violence but to prevent it.
('49', 123, 1, 8, 228116) Spilling of such innocent blood will hasten the end, but such casualties will only result in the manifestation of greater response from people.
('49', 123, 1, 9, 228260) Let me, however, warn those whom my message may reach that if they cannot restrain themselves, they must not interfere with the struggle.
('49', 123, 1, 10, 228398) If they do, they will only retard the country’s pro gress towards its goal.
('49', 123, 1, 11, 228474) I know, however, that soon my word will cease to reach the people.
('49', 123, 1, 12, 228541) All instruments I possess will have been snatched away from me, but they cannot snatch away one thing from me and that is my unshakable faith in my cause.
('49', 123, 1, 13, 228696) A mass movement like the one we see in front of us is regulated not by men but by God.

('49', 123, 1, 18, 229226) Not what happens in cities but what happens in villages will decide the fate of India.

('49', 124, 4, 19, 230484) We must do our duty and the people will understand by themselves.
('49', 124, 4, 20, 230550) I hope Gujarat has well understood the lesson of non violence, which is our religion at the present moment.
('49', 124, 4, 21, 230658) We must suffer till the goal is reached.
('49', 124, 5, 22, 230699) Continuing, Gandhiji said that he wanted that all should be prepared to serve as national volunteers till swaraj is attained and asked those who wanted to retain their services under the condition to raise their hands fearlessly.
('49', 124, 5, 23, 230929) All the volunteers except 48 raised their hands.
('49', 124, 6, 24, 230978) Gandhiji congratulated those 48 satyagrahis who did not raise their hands for their courage and assured them that they would be given other work in their own villages.
('49', 124, 7, 25, 231146) The question of ration for the national army was then discussed.
('49', 124, 7, 26, 231211) It was unanimously resolved by the volunteers, at the suggestion of Mahatmaji, that their food should be simple and should not cost more than annas 5 per head per day.
('49', 124, 7, 27, 231379) But option was given with the permission of the Captain to take meals privately at the volunteers’ own expense.
('49', 124, 7, 28, 231491) But Gandhiji wanted them to use the option as rarely as possible, as they as national soldiers were expected to behave with self restraint.
('49', 124, 7, 29, 231631) He said that in England even Kings had to work as sailors where they got the same food as ordinary sailors.
('49', 124, 8, 30, 231739) The resolution regarding smoking by soldiers of the national army evoked keen debate.
('49', 124, 8, 31, 231825) Gandhiji said that he did not want to dismiss all those who were habituated to smoke, but suggested that they must try to do without smoking.
('49', 125, 0, 1, 231967) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 126
('49', 125, 1, 2, 232009) Concluding the conference, Mahatmaji laid great stress on the fact that they
('49', 125, 2, 3, 232086) must always be at their post and asked them to observe all the rules they had
('49', 125, 3, 4, 232164) themselves passed after full deliberation and of their own free will.
('49', 125, 3, 5, 232234) He asked them to
('49', 125, 4, 6, 232251) be of good moral character.
('49', 125, 4, 7, 232279) If they did national work with impure conscience swaraj
('49', 125, 5, 8, 232335) would go farther away from them.
('49', 125, 5, 9, 232368) He said he would be glad if he saw his own national
('49', 125, 6, 10, 232420) soldiers suffering and receiving bullets on their own chests and out of the ashes of
('49', 125, 7, 11, 232505) these non violent soldiers of freedom, swaraj would be born.
('49', 125, 7, 12, 232566) The Bombay Chronicle, 18 4 1930
