('49', 132, 6, 14, 241125) 141. SPEECH AT MEETING OF HEADMEN, VEJALPUR
('49', 132, 7, 15, 241169) April 19, 1930 The way of ahimsa by itself is such that it can produce riches out of dust.
('49', 132, 7, 16, 241260) The Government’s is the way of violence.
('49', 132, 7, 17, 241301) It mixes earth with salt, while we produce salt out of earth.
('49', 132, 7, 18, 241363) The Government destroys, we create.
('49', 132, 7, 19, 241399) It has guns and cannon, we have no such arms.
('49', 132, 7, 20, 241445) It has huge factories, we have nothing of the kind.
('49', 132, 7, 21, 241497) Our factory is in our cottage, and our machinery is the takli.
('49', 132, 7, 22, 241560) For you it is a matter of faith that swaraj hangs by a thread of yarn.
('49', 132, 7, 23, 241631) It was you who took the pledge to carry out in six months the constructive programme for swaraj.
('49', 132, 7, 24, 241728) Keep that pledge and justify my faith in you.
('49', 132, 7, 25, 241774) If you do so, Bardoli can win swaraj for India.
('49', 132, 7, 26, 241822) Now that you have given up being Headmen of the Government you should become Headmen of the people.
('49', 132, 7, 27, 241922) In the villages where you served as Headmen you should now work as true Headmen; in other words you should serve the people of these villages.
('49', 132, 7, 28, 242065) There are many ways of serving.
('49', 132, 7, 29, 242097) But first take up these.
('49', 132, 7, 30, 242122) Every man in your village should break the salt law by making salt not only for use in his home, but also some to be stored for people living away from the sea coast.
('49', 132, 7, 31, 242289) But this work is not likely to take the whole of your day.
('49', 132, 8, 32, 242348) 1 K. M. Munshi; vide also “Interview to The Bombay Chronicle”, 20 4 1930.
('49', 133, 0, 1, 242422) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 134
('49', 133, 1, 2, 242464) the next item of work for you is to see that foreign cloth is banished from your villages.
('49', 133, 1, 3, 242555) The right way to do so is to sit in your homes and twirl the takli, which you can make without spending a pie.
('49', 133, 1, 4, 242666) If you Hea dmen start spinning on it the other people in the village willfollow suit.
('49', 133, 1, 5, 242752) In numbers is strength, as the saying goes.
('49', 133, 1, 6, 242796) And by making all people in the village wear khadi you will be able to save the village wealth from being drained away.
('49', 133, 1, 7, 242916) Moreover, if all of you take up the work seriously, you can soon get the liquor shops closed, since you have your finger on the pulse of the village.
('49', 133, 1, 8, 243066) Then you should provide arbitration in village disputes, which is important work.
('49', 133, 1, 9, 243148) You are well versed in these matters.
('49', 133, 1, 10, 243186) Some of you probably are addicted to this kind of work.
('49', 133, 1, 11, 243242) If they have to remain idle after resigning as Headmen they may regret having resigned.
('49', 133, 1, 12, 243330) I was myself a practising lawyer.
('49', 133, 1, 13, 243364) Having left practice I have never had to repent since I found for myself work that kept me occupied even more than legal practice had.
('49', 133, 1, 14, 243499) The Headmen may very well give up their jobs, but they should have village council meetings in their homes.
('49', 133, 1, 15, 243607) They should set up boards of arbitration.
('49', 133, 1, 16, 243649) Being well acqu ainted with the affairs of the village, these boards will be able to settle disputes in a just and satisfactory manner.
('49', 133, 1, 17, 243785) In order that you can do all this work in an organized way I suggest that you establish an association of ex Headmen.
('49', 133, 1, 18, 243903) If such an association comes into being, I should like to have regular reports of its work so that I am kept informed about all your activities.

('49', 134, 1, 2, 244127) 142. EXTRACTS FROM SPEECH AT BARDOLI
('49', 134, 2, 3, 244164) April 19, 1930 Headmen and Talatis are looking frightened.
('49', 134, 2, 4, 244223) They have a lingering belief that through the present Government they can enjoy prestige and status and plunder the people in the name of the Gove rnment.
('49', 134, 2, 5, 244378) That is why you find it necessary to persuade them to resign and to employ the weapon of social boycott against them.
('49', 134, 2, 6, 244496) Truly speaking, there should be no need to persuade anyone or to put press ure on anyone in the form of boycott.
('49', 134, 2, 7, 244609) A person should himself be able to see that his dirty job and soiled power are things to be abjured.
('49', 134, 2, 8, 244710) And why talk only of the Headmen and Talatis?
('49', 134, 2, 9, 244756) I do not believe that even others have full faith in this struggle.
('49', 134, 2, 10, 244824) But we have to build on the courage that has been roused among the people.
('49', 134, 2, 11, 244899) I want that the Headmen and Talatis who have not yet resigned should do so at once.
('49', 134, 2, 12, 244983) And those who resign should do so totally.
('49', 134, 2, 13, 245026) To keep charge of the village books and to continue waiting on the officers after resigning the post would be deceiving the people.
('49', 134, 2, 14, 245158) Rather than do so, they should boldly say: “Boycott us if you like.
('49', 134, 2, 15, 245226) But we do not yet see the need to resign.” Defying the salt law is only a part of our work.
('49', 134, 2, 16, 245318) Our aim is to win swaraj.
('49', 134, 2, 17, 245344) To that end, it is necessary to undertake other items of work also.
('49', 134, 2, 18, 245412) We should see to it that all the liquor shops are closed down.
('49', 134, 2, 19, 245475) For the present, a few of our sisters have boldly come forward and taken up the task.
('49', 134, 2, 20, 245561) It is not necessary for all the women to come out of their homes.
('49', 134, 2, 21, 245627) They should banish liquor from their own villages.
('49', 134, 2, 22, 245678) We should not abuse anyone, we should not lift our hand against anyone.
('49', 134, 2, 23, 245750) Go to the owner of the liquor shop, and entreat him to close his shop.
('49', 134, 2, 24, 245821) Plead humbly with the drink addicts also.
('49', 134, 2, 25, 245863) This is easy for women to do.
('49', 134, 2, 26, 245893) Men should help them in their work of persuasion and cut down the toddy palms for their owners.
('49', 134, 2, 27, 245989) Both men and women can do all this without leaving their villages.
('49', 134, 2, 28, 246056) The third item is the boycott of foreign cloth.
('49', 134, 2, 29, 246104) That task, too, we have entrusted to our sisters.
('49', 134, 2, 30, 246154) It may appear to you a difficult job, but to me it seems easy.
('49', 134, 2, 31, 246217) Or, to the extent that it is difficult, when acco mplished it will make the winning of swaraj easy.
('49', 134, 2, 32, 246317) There is no exag geration in saying that this Government remains in our country chiefly for its cloth trade.
('49', 134, 2, 33, 246426) You cannot think of all the other trade that
('49', 135, 0, 1, 246471) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 136
('49', 135, 1, 2, 246513) is allied to this direct trade of 66 crores.
('49', 135, 1, 3, 246558) You will, like the people of Karadi, collect and burn foreign cloth.
('49', 135, 1, 4, 246627) Brothers and sisters of Bardoli, burn with faith all the foreign cloth you have, but at the same time take a pledge that you will wear khadi.
('49', 135, 1, 5, 246769) If you do so, you will save so much expenditure on clothes.
('49', 135, 1, 6, 246829) If you wear fine garments of foreign or mill made cloth, you will each need a score or more of them.

('49', 136, 1, 2, 248113) 144. MY NOTES
('49', 136, 3, 3, 248127) When a great struggle is on, generous people empty out their pockets and look upon everyone as a public worker.
('49', 136, 3, 4, 248239) At such times, traitors see their opportunity and rob everyone wherever they can.
('49', 136, 3, 5, 248321) Any one who wants to sells swadeshi salt; anyone who wants to collects funds.
('49', 136, 3, 6, 248399) People, being gullible, pay up.
('49', 136, 3, 7, 248431) At such a time, it is necessary for people to be on their guard.
('49', 136, 3, 8, 248496) No one should make any con tributions unless they know those making collections and never without getting a receipt.
('49', 136, 3, 9, 248613) The receipt should bear the signature of an office holder of the Congress and the stamp of that office.
('49', 136, 3, 10, 248717) The com mittees should maintain accounts of every pie and publish the names of the donors.
('49', 136, 3, 11, 248808) The receipt books should be numbered and the rule should be that only these should be used for acknowledging contri butions.
('49', 136, 3, 12, 248933) And then accounts should be maintained accordingly.
('49', 136, 3, 13, 248985) Des pite such care, however, some misappropriation is bound to be there.
('49', 136, 3, 14, 249058) A thief has a hundred prying eyes; a banker can glance only now and then.
('49', 136, 3, 15, 249132) Nevertheless, it is the duty of all public institutions to be as much on their guard as possible.
('49', 136, 4, 16, 249230) MILL HANDS OF AHMEDABAD
('49', 136, 5, 17, 249254) The mill hands of Ahmedabad are contributing their share in the yajna of swaraj in an excellent manner.
('49', 136, 5, 18, 249358) Many of them wear khadi.
('49', 136, 5, 19, 249383) Their children, if not they themselves, spin and they are picketing the liquor booths.
('49', 136, 5, 20, 249470) Some have also offered civil disobedience against the salt law.
('49', 136, 5, 21, 249534) As a result of the movement for prohibition, the income from liquor has greatly diminished.
('49', 136, 5, 22, 249626) In 1928 29 the average sale of six liquor booths in Ahmedabad was 231_ gallons.
('49', 136, 5, 23, 249706) The sale this year has been 45_ gallons.
('49', 136, 5, 24, 249747) In other words, there has been a decrease of over 81 per cent, that is, only 19 per cent is left.
('49', 136, 5, 25, 249845) If this movement continues, we may hope that the liquor booths in Ahmedabad, at least, will have to close down.
('49', 136, 5, 26, 249957) Labourers as well as the organizers deserve to be congratulated on such good results.
('49', 136, 5, 27, 250043) Labourers alone act as pickets before liquor booths and it may be said that this is done in an ideal manner.
('49', 136, 5, 28, 250152) Perfect peace has been maintained.
('49', 136, 5, 29, 250187) If other labourers follow the example of these, their incomes will at once be doubled as money
('49', 137, 0, 1, 250282) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138
('49', 137, 1, 2, 250324) saved is money earned.

('49', 139, 4, 6, 254017) 147. FOREIGN CLOTH DEALERS
('49', 139, 5, 7, 254044) I have just received a telegram from Delhi which says: “Dealers in foreign cloth want certain conditions to be considered with regard to the round the clock picketing of foreign cloth shops.
('49', 139, 5, 8, 254235) They want to be given time to cancel orders against which goods have not been received and to sell goods which they have in stock.” The question is whether such conditions can be conceded.
('49', 139, 5, 9, 254424) I have sent my opinion as follows: “Such time certainly cannot be granted.
('49', 139, 5, 10, 254499) If the traders have the faith they should rest assured that such poor merchants who have suffered a loss will be suitably compensated in swaraj.
('49', 139, 5, 11, 254644) Those who are well to do will get no compensation.
('49', 139, 5, 12, 254695) They should regard the loss that they incur on account of the goods lying in stock as a token prayashchitta for their past sins.” I feel that it is essential for swarajists to make things fully clear.
('49', 139, 5, 13, 254896) The desperate souls who have entered the field will either triumph or perish, but even while perishing they will clarify many matters.
('49', 139, 5, 14, 255031) There was not in the world a single war in which thousands did not suffer losses.
('49', 139, 5, 15, 255113) If, however, this struggle does have a peaceful ending, there would be the minimum loss with the maximum gain.
('49', 139, 5, 16, 255224) But the satyagrahis must harden themselves to put up with this loss.
('49', 139, 5, 17, 255293) Why should the boycott which is possible today be postponed?
('49', 139, 5, 18, 255354) Where would we be if every dealer in foreign cloth asked for time?
('49', 139, 5, 19, 255421) The strength of the boycott move ment would be frittered away and the doors to betrayal would be opened in front, from behind and on the sides.
('49', 139, 5, 20, 255565) Who would keep watch on which traders?
('49', 139, 5, 21, 255604) The traders who lack faith but do not wish to practice deceit can act in the following way:
('49', 140, 0, 1, 255696) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 141

('49', 140, 1, 3, 255784) If the people lose and enter into a fresh indenture of slavery, such traders will easily be able to sell their goods.
('49', 140, 1, 4, 255902) They should make out lists of their goods andhand them to well known volunteers and get these stamped by the Congress, so that, at the proper time, if it is felt that they should be given compensation, the swaraj Government could do so.
('49', 140, 1, 5, 256139) Another alternative is for them to export their goods to countries where foreign goods are sold.
('49', 140, 1, 6, 256236) Anyone who wishes to do something, finds many straightforward ways of doing it.
('49', 140, 1, 7, 256316) But a poor dancer will always find the courtyard uneven.
('49', 140, 2, 8, 256373) But why sympathize with the sufferings of traders?
('49', 140, 2, 9, 256424) What about educated lawyers?

('49', 144, 2, 3, 261640) JALALPUR, April 20, 1930 I see that several friends expect me to be in Bombay next week.

('49', 144, 2, 6, 261833) But I see that my presence in these parts is urgent and letters from several friends in Bombay tell me that I should not move from Gujarat till Bombay is better prepared.
('49', 144, 2, 7, 262004) Of enthusiasm, so far as newspapers can tell me, there is no lack in Bom bay.
('49', 144, 2, 8, 262082) Of discipline I do not know.
('49', 144, 2, 9, 262111) At the present moment what we want is the rigidest discipline, more rigid than in an army made to wage bloody warfare, side by side with the utmost defiance of the sele cted laws and consistently with the principles of non violence and truth.
('49', 144, 2, 10, 262354) There must be continued and continuous constructive work as if swaraj was to be established today.
('49', 144, 2, 11, 262453) How far this is being done in Bom bay I do not know.
('49', 144, 2, 12, 262506) I, therefore, advise friends in Bombay not to be hasty in asking me to come there.

('49', 144, 2, 14, 262716) I would, therefore, ask friends in Bombay not to build upon my coming there in the near future but I would go there with the greatest pleasure as soon as I can free myself from Gujarat and when Bombay is really ready.

('49', 145, 3, 4, 263375) Gandhiji said he feared that wherever foreign cloth boycott can be organized
('49', 145, 4, 5, 263452) perfectly non violently, it cannot be suspended upon any undertaking save that of
('49', 145, 5, 6, 263534) refraining from selling.
('49', 145, 5, 7, 263559) This is no time for bargaining.
('49', 145, 5, 8, 263591) Those who have faith in this and therefore in swaraj coming as the certain result of the present mov ement and who believe that it is good to stop buying foreign cloth should stop altogether and not for a certain period.

('49', 146, 1, 2, 264787) 154. THE BLACK REGIME
('49', 146, 2, 3, 264809) KARADI, April 21, 1930 The past week has not been one of unmixed joy.
('49', 146, 2, 4, 264879) It has seen disturbances in Calcutta 1 and Karachi.
('49', 146, 2, 5, 264931) And now comes the sad news from Chittagong.
('49', 146, 2, 6, 264975) It shows that in spite of the striking demonstration of non violence all over the country, there is still violence in the air and cities are the storehouses of it.
('49', 146, 2, 7, 265139) Calcutta and Karachi can be distin guished from Chittagong.
('49', 146, 2, 8, 265199) The first two appear to have been mad out bursts of the moment.
('49', 146, 2, 9, 265263) Chittagong seems to be a deliberate planning.
('49', 146, 2, 10, 265309) Whatever they were, they are most regrettable and interfere with the growth of the movement which is otherwise shaping itself marvellously well and gaining fresh momentum from day to day.
('49', 146, 2, 11, 265497) I can only appeal to those who believe in violence not to disturb the free flow of the non violent demonstration.
('49', 146, 2, 12, 265611) Whether they listen or not, this movement will go on.
('49', 146, 2, 13, 265665) Violence is bound to impede the progress tow ards independence.
('49', 146, 2, 14, 265729) I am unable to demonstrate how it will impede.
('49', 146, 2, 15, 265776) Those who survive the struggle will know how.
('49', 146, 2, 16, 265822) Meanwhile satyagrahis must continue their activity with red oubled vigour.
('49', 146, 2, 17, 265897) We must deal with the double edged violence ranged against us.
('49', 146, 2, 18, 265960) For me popular violence is as much an obstruction in our path as the Government violence.
('49', 146, 2, 19, 266050) Indeed I can combat the Gov ernment violence more successfully than the popular.
('49', 146, 2, 20, 266131) For one thing, in combating the latter, I should not have the same support as in the former.
('49', 146, 2, 21, 266224) Then again the motive in the latter being as honourable as that of the satyagrahis, the method to be employed has to be somewhat different from that employed in regard to the Government violence.
('49', 146, 2, 22, 266420) I hope that as in Karachi, so in Calcutta and Chittagong, there were satyagrahis attempting to check mob violence.
('49', 146, 2, 23, 266535) Brave young Dattatreya Mane who is said to have known nothing of satyagraha and being an athlete had merely gone to assist in keeping order, received a fatal bullet wound.
('49', 146, 2, 24, 266707) Meghraj Revachand, 18 years old, has also succumbed to a bullet wound.
('49', 146, 2, 25, 266778) Thus did seven men, including
('49', 146, 3, 26, 266808) 1 There had been disturbances in Calcutta during the hartal observed on April 19 following the arrests of Jawaharlal Nehru and J. M. Sen Gupta.
('49', 147, 0, 1, 266952) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 148
('49', 147, 1, 2, 266994) Jairamdas,receive bullet wounds.
('49', 147, 1, 3, 267027) Jairamdas’s injury gave me unmixed joy.
('49', 147, 1, 4, 267067) It is the injury to leaders that would bring relief.
('49', 147, 1, 5, 267120) The law of sacrifice is uniform throughout the world.
('49', 147, 1, 6, 267174) To be effective it demands the sacrifice of the bravest and the most spotless.
('49', 147, 1, 7, 267253) And Jairamdas is of the bravest and the cleanest.
('49', 147, 1, 8, 267303) I therefore could not help wiring when I heard of Jairamdas’s wound that a wound in the thigh was better than prison and wound in the heart better still.
('49', 147, 2, 9, 267457) Whilst therefore I tender my sympathy to the parents of the two brave lads who lost their lives, my inmost desire is to congratulate them for the finished sacrifices of their sons, if they would accept my congratulations.
('49', 147, 2, 10, 267679) A warrior’s death is never a matter for sorrow, still less that of a satyagrahi warrior.
('49', 147, 2, 11, 267768) One of the lessons that a nation yearning for freedom needs to learn is to shed several fears; fear of losing title, wealth, position, fear of imprisonment, of bodily injury and lastly death.
('49', 147, 2, 12, 267960) Accounts from all over India tell the same tale of growing fearl essness.
('49', 147, 2, 13, 268034) The Bihar letter published elsewhere makes soul stirring reading.
('49', 147, 2, 14, 268100) One thing we must get rid of quickly.
('49', 147, 2, 15, 268138) Lawless physical violence must be stopped even if it is to be through forcing the Government to use its guns.
('49', 147, 2, 16, 268248) And this can be done non violently.
('49', 147, 2, 17, 268284) I give only one out of several samples of indecent assaults by the police at Viramgam:
('49', 147, 3, 18, 268371) STATEMENT OF ANIRUDDHA VYAS, A STUDENT OF DAKSHINAMURTI VIDYARTHI BHAVAN VOLUNTEER NO.
('49', 147, 4, 19, 268458) I with a number of my companions got down from the 6.30 evening Mail with bags of salt at the Viramgam railway station, when from 8 to 10 policemen surrounded us.
('49', 147, 4, 20, 268621) To save the salt from being seized I sat down with the bag of salt on the ground, clinging to it with all my might.
('49', 147, 5, 21, 268737) All efforts of the police to make me get up having failed, one of them thrust apart my legs and squeezed my private parts with his hands so as to compel me to get up.
('49', 147, 5, 22, 268904) But the weight of my body and the push and the pull of the surrounding police disengaged the parts and I fell down.
('49', 147, 5, 23, 269020) I was then pulled up again.
('49', 147, 5, 24, 269048) But I bent double and held the salt bag tight under my crossed arms.
('49', 147, 5, 25, 269117) A policeman thereupon straightened my back by poking it with his foot which caused me intense pain.
('49', 147, 5, 26, 269217) Then two policemen gave a violent jerk, twisted my fingers as they liked and loosened my arms and wrested the bag from me.
('49', 147, 6, 27, 269340) 1 Vide “Telegram to N. R. Malkani”, 18 4 1930.
('49', 148, 0, 1, 269387) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 149
('49', 148, 1, 2, 269429) then let go, one officer taking my name and number.
('49', 148, 1, 3, 269481) Mahadev Desai tells me that these assaults have stopped for the time being.
('49', 148, 1, 4, 269557) But there is no knowing that they have stopped for ever and there certainly is not the slightest ground for supposing that they will not occur in other parts of Gujarat or of other provinces.
('49', 148, 1, 5, 269749) In Broach the things are growing from bad to worse.
('49', 148, 1, 6, 269801) A bullet wound is any day better than these barbarous, unnecessary, unprovoked ass aults.
('49', 148, 1, 7, 269891) The person of a citizen must be held inviolate.
('49', 148, 1, 8, 269939) It can only be touched to arrest or to prevent violence, never in the manner being done now.
('49', 148, 1, 9, 270032) It is a prostitution even of the salt laws to use them against civil resisters.
('49', 148, 1, 10, 270112) The provisions were designed to deal (even then unjustly as I hold) with surreptitious breaches of its new provisions, never to deal with masses of men openly defying them.
('49', 148, 1, 11, 270285) If the Gove rnment do not stop this brutal violation of the body, they will find the satyagrahis presently compelling them to use the guns against them.
('49', 148, 1, 12, 270438) I do not want this to happen.
('49', 148, 1, 13, 270468) But if the Government will have it, I should have no hesitation whatsoever in giving them the opportunity.
('49', 148, 1, 14, 270575) They must not physically interfere with the bands of civil resisters manufacturing or vending salt, they may arrest every man, woman and child if they wish.
('49', 148, 1, 15, 270732) If they will neither arrest, nor declare salt free, they will find people marching to be shot rather than be tortured.
('49', 148, 1, 16, 270851) It is true that the barbarous interference with the body and the indecent assaults are a heritage of the past.
('49', 148, 1, 17, 270962) This Government has by its tacit approval given it a currency which it never had before.
('49', 148, 1, 18, 271051) As I am writing these notes two volunteers have brought me salt said to have been poisoned.
('49', 148, 1, 19, 271143) Not only do the authorities wantonly destroy salt and salt pans now, they are said to poison the sources of salt manufacture.
('49', 148, 1, 20, 271269) If the report is true, the blackness of the regime becomes blacker still.
('49', 148, 1, 21, 271343) And all this against a people who without hurting anybody are seeking to gain freedom through self suffering!

('49', 152, 1, 2, 275677) 158. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('49', 152, 2, 3, 275721) NAVSARI, April 21, 1930 Chittagong news makes sad reading.
('49', 152, 2, 4, 275780) It shows that there is a large or small body of men in Bengal who do not believe in non violence whether as a policy or as a creed.
('49', 152, 2, 5, 275912) That there were such people all over India I knew but I had hoped that they would give non violence a chance.
('49', 152, 2, 6, 276022) If Chittagong is an indication and not an isolated act, as I believe Calcutta and Karachi acts to be, it is a serious affair.
('49', 152, 2, 7, 276148) But, however serious the situation becomes, there can be no suspension of the fight.
('49', 152, 2, 8, 276233) There can be no retracing.
('49', 152, 2, 9, 276260) I observe that the Viceroy has answered the Chittagong disturbance with the exercise of his extra ordinary powers.
('49', 152, 2, 10, 276375) That was only to be expected.
('49', 152, 2, 11, 276405) So long as the British people are determined to impose their rule upon unwilling people, so long must they rule in reality without law.
('49', 152, 2, 12, 276541) We in India easily delude ourselves into the belief that we have duly constituted legislatures.
('49', 152, 2, 13, 276637) Presently there will be no one remaining under any such delusion.
('49', 152, 2, 14, 276703) Civil resisters must, therefore, fight an unequal struggle—the violence of the Government and the violence of those among us who have no faith in non violence.
('49', 152, 2, 15, 276863) Satyagrahis, if they are true to their creed, will either come out victorious or will be ground to atoms between the two mills.
('49', 152, 3, 16, 276991) The Bombay Chronicle, 22 4 1930

('49', 158, 7, 10, 281684) 167. LETTER TO VITHALDAS JERAJANI
('49', 158, 8, 11, 281718) April 23, 1930
('49', 158, 9, 12, 281733) BHAISHRI VITHALDAS JERAJANI, There have been, from time to time, several changes in the khadi propaganda movement and consequently in your work.
('49', 158, 9, 13, 281878) In my view, those changes were necessary in the interest of the khadi movement and of Daridranarayana though, at the time those changes were made, they did not immediately appeal to reason.
('49', 158, 9, 14, 282068) Our experience so far has been that ultimately all those changes stood the test of reason too, and were justified by the results.
('49', 158, 9, 15, 282198) The change which I am now suggesting may, I think, seem much more risky than the earlier changes.
('49', 158, 9, 16, 282296) However, I believe that the change is as essential in the interest of khadi as it may seem dangerous to khadi lovers on a sup erficial view.
('49', 158, 9, 17, 282437) Anyone who has properly understood the rationale of boycott of foreign cloth will immediately see the necessity for this change.
('49', 158, 9, 18, 282566) We do not have in stock enough khadi to meet the present demand.

('49', 159, 1, 2, 283249) hand spun yarn.
('49', 159, 1, 3, 283265) This is the only way to make it clear to people that khadi is not a mere commodity, like foreign cloth, which can be bought for money, but that it is a symbol of the nation’s strength and aspiration.
('49', 159, 1, 4, 283465) According to the science of khadi, as long as cotton is available there can be no scarcity of khadi.

('49', 159, 1, 11, 284167) Hence a resident of Bombay may procure hand spun yarn in any way he chooses.
('49', 159, 1, 12, 284244) He may spin it himself or get it spun by members of his family or his poor neighbours or by the residents of any village in India.

('49', 160, 1, 2, 285079) 168. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY
('49', 160, 2, 3, 285103) As so much misrepresentation is being made about my attitude on the communal question, without entering into any argument I would state my position as clearly as my knowledge of the language would enable me to do.
('49', 160, 2, 4, 285317) 1.The views that I have held for the last 40 years remain unchanged.
('49', 160, 2, 5, 285386) 2.I hold that there is no swaraj without communal unity as without several other things I have repeatedly mentioned.
('49', 160, 2, 6, 285503) 3.The present campaign is not designed to establish ind ependence but to arm the people with the power to do so.
('49', 160, 2, 7, 285616) 4.When the power has been generated and the time has come for the establishment of independence, Mussalmans and all other minorities will have to be placated.
('49', 160, 2, 8, 285775) If they are not, there must ine vitably be civil war.
('49', 160, 2, 9, 285829) But I live in the hope that if we succeed in generating the power, our differences and distrust will vanish.
('49', 160, 2, 10, 285938) These are due to our weakness.
('49', 160, 2, 11, 285969) When we have the power from within we shall shed our weakness.
('49', 160, 2, 12, 286032) 5.The Nehru Constitution having lapsed the communal solution has naturally lapsed.
('49', 160, 2, 13, 286115) The Lahore Congress resolution mentionsin so many words that the communal solution not having given satisfaction either to the Sikhs or the Mussalmans the question might have to be reconsidered so as to give satisfaction to all the parties concerned.
('49', 160, 2, 14, 286366) 6. The only non violent solution I know is for the Hindus to let the minority communities take what they like.
('49', 160, 2, 15, 286477) I would not hesitate to let the minorities govern the country.
('49', 160, 2, 16, 286540) This is no academic belief.
('49', 160, 2, 17, 286568) The solution is attended with no risk.
('49', 160, 2, 18, 286607) For under a free government the real power will be held by the people.
('49', 160, 2, 19, 286678) That demonstration is being given now.
('49', 160, 2, 20, 286717) The mightiest government will be rendered absolutely impotent if the people realizing their power use it in a disciplined manner and for the common good.
('49', 160, 2, 21, 286871) In Gujarat the people are within reach of success if the strength and cohesion they are showing today are genuine and not derived from blind faith.
('49', 160, 2, 22, 287019) It must be remembered that only an infinitesimal proportion of the people can hold positions of responsibility and power in a country’s government.
('49', 160, 2, 23, 287167) Experience all the world over shows that the real power and wealth are possessed by people outside the group that hold the reins of Government.
('49', 161, 0, 1, 287311) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 161, 1, 2, 287353) India hanker after power, because our people are ignorant and will be exploited.
('49', 161, 1, 3, 287434) The power wielded today is corrupt to the core.
('49', 161, 1, 4, 287482) Ind epen dence achieved through non violent power must by its very nature reduce corruption to a minimum.
('49', 161, 1, 5, 287588) It is thus my practical wisdom which has suggested the solutions.

('49', 162, 2, 3, 289608) A friend having seen the wonderful manifestation of mass action sends the following extracts from an aritcle by Sir Martin Conway in Commerce and Finance: 1
('49', 162, 3, 4, 289765) What any generation can accomplish in faith and growth is little compared

('49', 162, 8, 10, 290146) preservation of these it has, not individuals, however great, but crowds to
('49', 162, 9, 11, 290222) For let me declare again that it is in crowds that ideals reside.

('49', 162, 11, 15, 290378) ideal, but unless he can get it incorporated in a crowd it is barren of effect, and
('49', 162, 12, 16, 290462) dies with him.

('49', 162, 13, 18, 290542) its fickleness, its lack of measure and all the other shortcomings of which we
('49', 162, 14, 19, 290621) are only too easily aware, it yet remains true that upon crowds our spiritual

('49', 162, 16, 21, 290772) those flames of love and passion and glory which make the life of each

('49', 162, 18, 23, 290891) A crowd that has never come physically together gains greatly in

('49', 162, 20, 26, 291037) bring to bear on outsiders that attractiveness which every embodied crowd
('49', 162, 21, 27, 291111) possesses.

('49', 162, 22, 29, 291161) An even more rudimentary application of the principle of crowd

('49', 162, 23, 31, 291276) The longer they can be made

('49', 162, 25, 33, 291376) outside.

('49', 167, 1, 2, 300271) 173. OUR MILLS AND FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT
('49', 167, 2, 3, 300312) Foreign cloth boycott is coming, if we will do our duty and tax ourselves to understand its purpose and the conditions of success.
('49', 167, 2, 4, 300443) I must not at present adduce reasons for the propositions set forth below.
('49', 167, 2, 5, 300518) They have been often argued in these columns.
('49', 167, 2, 6, 300564) I am having the figures prepared for reproduction.
('49', 167, 2, 7, 300615) But for the present I give my conclusions for those who are interested in them.
('49', 167, 2, 8, 300695) They are arrived at dispassionately and after due consideration of every factor and every argument for and against.
('49', 167, 2, 9, 300811) 1.It is impossible for the indigenous mills to cope with the deficiency to be created by a complete boycott within the time we expect it to come to fruition.
('49', 167, 2, 10, 300969) 2.All the mills situated in India are not swadeshi; some of them are as foreign as the foreign Government inasmuch as they drain the wealth of the country away from it.
('49', 167, 2, 11, 301138) They are close preserves for Europeans only employing Indian labour.
('49', 167, 2, 12, 301207) 3.The majority of swadeshi mills will not work for the national benefit only or even predominantly.
('49', 167, 2, 13, 301307) 4.Even when they will, they can be crushed by the Government in a variety of ways.
('49', 167, 2, 14, 301390) 5.The majority will not resist the temptation to exploit the present favourable times.
('49', 167, 2, 15, 301477) 6.Many mills use foreign yarn for weaving, especially for borders.
('49', 167, 2, 16, 301544) 7.We can only use them by not counting upon them to replace the cloth boycotted and by putting them upon their own resources and honour.
('49', 167, 2, 17, 301681) 8.This last we can do only if we can replace the cloth boycotted through cloth not manufactured in our mills.
('49', 167, 2, 18, 301791) This can only be khadi.
('49', 167, 2, 19, 301815) 9.An unlimited quantity of khadi can be manufactured without the slightest difficulty inside of one month if the spirit of khadi and the will to manufacture it can be created.
('49', 167, 2, 20, 301991) 10.Skilled weavers are to be found all over India.
('49', 167, 2, 21, 302042) The only problem therefore is that of spinning.
('49', 167, 2, 22, 302090) 11.Spinning and the antecedent processes can be learnt inside of one week by those who have the will and the industry.
('49', 168, 0, 1, 302209) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 169
('49', 168, 1, 2, 302251) 12.India produces more than enough cotton for all her requirements.
('49', 168, 1, 3, 302319) 13. Therefore all those who work for boycott of foreign cloth should concentrate on khadi production through spinning.
('49', 168, 1, 4, 302438) This does not mean boycott of swadeshi mill cloth but it means an intelligent reco gnition of the fact that the mills do not need any effort for sell ing their cloth.
('49', 168, 1, 5, 302605) The boycott movement sufficiently helps them by removing foreign cloth which competes with them and stifles them as it had suppressed the spinning wheel.
('49', 168, 1, 6, 302759) To do more for the mills than procure boycott of foreign cloth will be to harm khadi.

('49', 168, 1, 10, 303584) Let them know that that very moment is the one most propi tious for khadi production.

('49', 168, 1, 12, 303708) It knows no law, for it invents new laws.

('49', 168, 1, 16, 303935) Just as we want swaraj not to punish Englishmen but because we cannot live without it, so also we need boycott of foreign cloth not to punish Englishmen but to bring work and therefore food through the wheel to the starving millions.
('49', 168, 1, 17, 304169) Young India, 24 4 1930
('49', 169, 0, 1, 304192) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 169, 1, 2, 304234) 174. BOYCOTT THROUGH TAKLI
('49', 169, 2, 3, 304261) Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, having been for years interested in co operative banking and being a khadi expert in Andhra, may be presumed to know his figures.
('49', 169, 2, 4, 304417) He makes the calculation that five million charkhas working for five hours daily can spin enough yarn to replace the whole of foreign cloth to be boycotted.
('49', 169, 2, 5, 304574) He thinks that there are already that number of wheels lying in India’s homes.
('49', 169, 2, 6, 304653) But we will take some time to unearth these wheels and make them work.
('49', 169, 2, 7, 304724) New wheels we cannot make fast enough to meet the demand that a spinning atmosphere will create.
('49', 169, 2, 8, 304821) The wheel will again require some capital, be it ever so little.
('49', 169, 2, 9, 304886) When we think of crores of people, even the capital of one rupee per head mounts up to crores.
('49', 169, 2, 10, 304981) We want to work with as little capital as possible.
('49', 169, 2, 11, 305033) We want to teach spinning to the larg est number available as quickly as possible.
('49', 169, 2, 12, 305116) This can be done only through the takli.
('49', 169, 2, 13, 305157) If the average output of a wheel be 300 yards per hour, that of the takli will be 100. Therefore to manufacture the amount of yarn that five million wheels will spin, we require taklis to work.
('49', 169, 2, 14, 305351) And if the workers would spin not five but only fifteen million one hour, we need seventy five million taklis to work.
('49', 169, 2, 15, 305470) Seventy five million is one fourth the total population of India.
('49', 169, 2, 16, 305536) Our disbelief makes our heads turn giddy to think of eight crores of people working for one hour per day for the nation.
('49', 169, 2, 17, 305657) But if there be true national consciousness there is nothing extraordinary about one in every four inhabitants of India giving one hour per day as the price of deliverance.
('49', 169, 2, 18, 305830) Be that as it may, let workers take up the takli in faith.
('49', 169, 2, 19, 305889) Let them not think of the steel takli which was invented by Maganlal Gandhi for the city people.
('49', 169, 2, 20, 305986) If there was an immediate demand for eight crores of steel taklis, the cost would amount to a respectable sum, and the time required to manufacture so many would also be fairly long.
('49', 169, 2, 21, 306169) We must therefore dismiss the steel takli from our minds.
('49', 169, 2, 22, 306227) Taklis can be made from split bamboos and broken tiles or bad coins the size or weight of a half anna piece.
('49', 169, 2, 23, 306336) A pointed sharp knife is the only tool absolutely necessary.
('49', 169, 2, 24, 306397) The point is required to bore a hole.
('49', 169, 2, 25, 306435) Here are full instructions:
('49', 169, 3, 26, 306463) HOW TO MAKE A TAKLI
('49', 169, 4, 27, 306483) 1.Take a broken Mangalore tile or slate or the like and make
('49', 170, 0, 1, 306544) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 171
('49', 170, 1, 2, 306586) out of it a disk the size of a pice.
('49', 170, 1, 3, 306623) This can be done by gently breaking the edges and rounding them on a rough surface.
('49', 170, 1, 4, 306707) 2.Punch a straight hole in it, make it slightly larger on one side.
('49', 170, 1, 5, 306775) 3.Take a well dried bamboo splinter seven inches in length.
('49', 170, 1, 6, 306835) Smooth it round with a knife to the thickness of a pencil.
('49', 170, 1, 7, 306894) Sharpen it from one end so as to taper it to a point the thickness of a knitting needle.
('49', 170, 1, 8, 306983) Half an inch from the tapering end, make a little notch to hold the thread.
('49', 170, 1, 9, 307059) 4.Insert the length so made into the side of the disk with larger circumference to the hole so as to leave half an inch at the thick end.
('49', 170, 1, 10, 307197) 5.Test the takli by revolving it on a flat surface.
('49', 170, 1, 11, 307249) If it spins like a top it is true.
('49', 170, 1, 12, 307284) If it does not, you know that either the hole is not straight or is not in the centre of the disk or the tapering of the splinter is not even.
('49', 170, 1, 13, 307427) It is easy to detect the error and to correct it.
('49', 170, 1, 14, 307477) The highest output of the takli after a week’s practice has been found to be 110 yards per hour.
('49', 170, 1, 15, 307574) And it takes about half an hour to make such a takli.
('49', 170, 1, 16, 307628) This takli making is a pleasant pastime.
('49', 170, 1, 17, 307669) Spinning is a positive recreation.
('49', 170, 1, 18, 307704) It is the solace of the perturbed heart and a mute comp anion.
('49', 170, 1, 19, 307767) The wheel sings to you and may therefore distract your atten tion.
('49', 170, 1, 20, 307834) The takli is eloquent in its very muteness, and in that way is perhaps a fitter representative of the dumb millions.
('49', 170, 1, 21, 307951) Try it and you will experience the same joy that many of us do.
('49', 170, 1, 22, 308015) In any case he or she who spins adds to the wealth of the country and hastens the boycott movement and thus brings swaraj nearer.
('49', 170, 1, 23, 308145) Young India, 24 4 1930
('49', 171, 0, 1, 308168) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 171, 1, 2, 308210) 175. FOREIGN CLOTH DEALERS
('49', 171, 2, 3, 308237) I have given my opinion to the Press representatives on the question of foreign cloth boycott.
('49', 171, 2, 4, 308332) The nervousness of the dealers is a symptom of want of faith in the country.
('49', 171, 2, 5, 308409) Why do they want terms and time if they are sure that swaraj is coming in the near future?
('49', 171, 2, 6, 308500) Why will they not come in unconditionally and make it a greater certainty?
('49', 171, 2, 7, 308575) All this uncertainty instead of strengthening the swaraj atmosphere, weakens it and fills peoples’ minds with doubts.
('49', 171, 2, 8, 308693) This movement is largely based on faith.
('49', 171, 2, 9, 308734) There is nothing organically wrong with us to make us unfit for swaraj.
('49', 171, 2, 10, 308806) It is our hallucination that makes us—a nation of three hundred millions—feel helpless and diffident.
('49', 171, 2, 11, 308908) Let not the foreign cloth merchants strengthen the hallucination by indefinite statements.
('49', 171, 2, 12, 308999) Let them rid themselves of it and help others to do likewise.
('49', 171, 2, 13, 309061) If they cannot do so, let them not ask for terms but bravely say that they will not stop their foreign cloth trade.
('49', 171, 2, 14, 309177) To the weak and the unbelieving I make a tangible suggestion.
('49', 171, 2, 15, 309239) Let them cancel all unexecuted orders.
('49', 171, 2, 16, 309278) If swaraj is not attained and if they want to revert to their old occupation, no power can prevent them.
('49', 171, 2, 17, 309383) Let them lock up their existing stock unless they can sell it outside India and let those who are poor rely upon the swaraj Gov ernment giving them such compensation as may be necessary.
('49', 171, 2, 18, 309570) But they should make an inventory of their stock and have it certified by authorized volunteers.
('49', 171, 2, 19, 309667) The wealthy merchants may not expect any compensation.
('49', 171, 2, 20, 309722) The loss they may suffer will be part penance for the sin committed against the nation.
('49', 171, 2, 21, 309810) Lastly, though the last is a bad suggestion, if they have no faith in the country getting swaraj, let them keep their stock and begin selling it when the popular movement has died of inanition or been suppressed by force.
('49', 171, 2, 22, 310032) God forbid however that the present enthusiasm is a mere bubble or that it is capable of suppression under the severest repression.
('49', 171, 2, 23, 310164) I hope therefore that wha tever the result of the movement, the foreign cloth dealers will see clearly that the terms suggested by them are harmful to the cause and that there is ample protection for them without the terms.
('49', 171, 2, 24, 310388) Let them be patriotic enough to rise to the occasion and render picketing unn ecessary by stopping the sale of foreign cloth of their own motion.
('49', 171, 2, 25, 310534) Young India, 24 4 1930
('49', 172, 0, 1, 310557) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 173
('49', 172, 1, 2, 310599) 176. SALAAMING OR FLOGGING?
('49', 172, 2, 3, 310627) Shri Haribhau Upadhyaya writes from Ajmer: 1
('49', 172, 3, 4, 310672) If what Shri Haribhau says is true there is plenty of scope for satyagraha in the jail.
('49', 172, 3, 5, 310760) Normally it is proper for a prisoner to salaam the jailor, but if a satyagrahi does not salaam he should not be forced.
('49', 172, 3, 6, 310880) If therefore force is used against someone for not salaaming it may become the duty of others also to refuse to salaam.
('49', 172, 3, 7, 311000) It is surprising that the concessions provided in several other jails to satyagrahis have been denied to satyagrahis in this jail.
('49', 172, 3, 8, 311131) In my opinion of course satyagrahi prisoners should be treated the same as other prisoners.
('49', 172, 3, 9, 311223) But if a satyagrahi is treated in a particular way all other satyagrahis should be similarly treated.
('49', 172, 3, 10, 311325) So far as the Congress is concerned there is no difference between Pathikji or Nrisinhdasji and the President.
('49', 172, 3, 11, 311436) But how can one expect justice and fair play from this Government?

('49', 177, 0, 1, 315875) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 177, 1, 2, 315917) 184. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('49', 177, 2, 3, 315946) April 25, 1930
('49', 177, 3, 4, 315961) MAHADEV, Of course you have my blessings.
('49', 177, 3, 5, 316003) Though I see that you had no choice but to get on the lorry, in my view you did commit an error.
('49', 177, 3, 6, 316100) I am pointing it out in fact for the benefit of others, but let my criticism be for your benefit too.
('49', 177, 3, 7, 316202) There was no need to forfeit the vehicle.
('49', 177, 3, 8, 316244) I had thought that you would devise a method of carrying the salt by stages as they used to do in carrying Ganga water, and had very much liked the idea.
('49', 177, 3, 9, 316398) Suppose that we have a camp of twenty five men at every five miles or so.
('49', 177, 3, 10, 316472) A batch of twenty five, each man starting with five seers, would mean three maunds and five seers.
('49', 177, 3, 11, 316571) The first batch would hand over the stock at the second camp and stay there.
('49', 177, 3, 12, 316648) The second batch would deliver the stock at the third camp and return to its camp, after which the first batch would proceed to Dholera.
('49', 177, 3, 13, 316785) This would have provided very good training and it would have been easy to protect the salt.
('49', 177, 3, 14, 316878) There was nothing to lose in this arrangement.
('49', 177, 3, 15, 316925) The method which you followed involved the possibility of losing the cart and the certainty of losing the lorry.
('49', 177, 3, 16, 317038) Moreover, it required your hiding som ething, and the success of your plan depended on your ability to do so.
('49', 177, 3, 17, 317148) We should, of course, have nothing to hide.
('49', 177, 3, 18, 317192) Any method in which we have to hide something requires the cunning needed in the ordinary kind of war, which we ought not to practise.
('49', 177, 3, 19, 317327) Moreover, for taking possession of the salt carried in a lorry, the police would be required to use much greater force.
('49', 177, 3, 20, 317447) We should not needlessly compel them to do so.
('49', 177, 3, 21, 317494) Hence, though your plan certainly required much courage and no less intelligence, it was not based on perfect non violence.
('49', 177, 3, 22, 317618) But in the prevailing atmosphere, I do not think you would have realized this by yourself.
('49', 177, 3, 23, 317709) Who knows where I myself may be going wrong?
('49', 177, 3, 24, 317754) All I can say is that I never take a single step without thinking carefully and that I get time to do that.
('49', 177, 3, 25, 317862) My thinking nowadays takes the form exclusively of prayer.
('49', 177, 3, 26, 317921) I do not use my reason, but look into my heart.
('49', 177, 3, 27, 317969) Swami’s idea of lifting salt from Bhayander would also have involved a similar error.
('49', 177, 3, 28, 318055) Dharasana is very near from where I am but I do not let anyone approach even that.
('49', 177, 3, 29, 318138) When it is ultimately decided to attempt to seize the stocks there, a pilgrim party will start
('49', 178, 0, 1, 318233) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 179
('49', 178, 1, 2, 318275) for the purpose, after giving public notice of its intention.
('49', 178, 1, 3, 318337) Please do not blame yourself or feel sorry for what you have done because of my criticism.
('49', 178, 1, 4, 318428) I have written this only to help you in jail to think and understand the fine and subtle aspects of non violence and as guidance for the future to Kaka, Narahari and others.
('49', 178, 1, 5, 318602) But in any case it is good that you have been arrested.
('49', 178, 1, 6, 318658) You would have had no opportunity of facing bullets and on account of excessive work you would probably have fallen ill.
('49', 178, 1, 7, 318779) By the time you come out, some thousands will have lost their lives.
('49', 178, 1, 8, 318848) What grace of God to the few chosen ones that they will be automatically saved.
('49', 178, 1, 9, 318928) Those who die and those who survive, both classes of persons should be regarded as equally blessed.
('49', 178, 1, 10, 319028) We need not believe that he alone is blessed, or more so, who gets killed.
('49', 178, 1, 11, 319103) Personally I do feel, after the incidents at Peshawar and Chit tagong, that there are bound to be two or more big massacres of innocent people.
('49', 178, 1, 12, 319247) Or it may be that they would deliberately and firmly put the innocent behind the bars.
('49', 178, 1, 13, 319334) In Karachi at any rate, only the innocent were killed or wounded.
('49', 178, 1, 14, 319400) The truth is that even the Govern ment does not know where it stands and what it wants to do.
('49', 178, 1, 15, 319494) What is happ ening is something quite new for it and for the whole world.
('49', 178, 1, 16, 319568) Now take good rest.
('49', 178, 1, 17, 319588) Make a takli of wood and spin on it as much as you can.
('49', 178, 1, 18, 319644) Khadi stocks have been exhausted.
('49', 178, 1, 19, 319678) Ask other prisoners also to spin.
('49', 178, 2, 20, 319712) Blessings from
('49', 178, 4, 21, 319727) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 9858

('49', 180, 1, 2, 320537) 186. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI
('49', 180, 2, 3, 320568) April 25, 1930
('49', 180, 3, 4, 320583) JAMNADAS,
('49', 180, 4, 5, 320593) I got your letter.
('49', 180, 4, 6, 320612) It was not necessary to send the wire.
('49', 180, 4, 7, 320651) I believe that at any rate Khushalbhai will not be arrested.
('49', 180, 4, 8, 320712) It would be a fine thing if he was accompanied by a batch of men.
('49', 180, 4, 9, 320778) He should think about one thing.
('49', 180, 4, 10, 320811) Perhaps they will stop his pension for participating in civil disobedience.
('49', 180, 4, 11, 320887) Personally I think it would be good if they did so.
('49', 180, 4, 12, 320939) The more injustice they do, the sooner will it end.
('49', 180, 4, 13, 320991) If, however, he has not the courage to forgo the encumbrance that this pension is, he should give up the idea of civil disobedience, though I have no doubt at all that, in the present circumstances, civil disobedience has become the supreme religious duty.
('49', 180, 4, 14, 321248) He should not detrain at Viramgam, but proceed further to Lakhtar or to any other place which has a camp.
('49', 180, 4, 15, 321354) He may stay there as long as he feels inclined and then return home.

('49', 184, 9, 15, 327031) 194. SPEECH AT BULSAR
('49', 184, 10, 16, 327053) April 26, 1930 I was here at Bulsar only a few days ago.
('49', 184, 10, 17, 327110) If you had done some special work since and called me here to have a view of it, my visit would have been worth while.
('49', 184, 10, 18, 327229) But neither you nor the Government has done any such thing.
('49', 184, 10, 19, 327289) Ramniklal Modi was with me on the Dandi March.

('49', 184, 10, 21, 327411) You called me here to celebrate the occasion.
('49', 184, 10, 22, 327457) But what is there to celebrate in that?
('49', 184, 10, 23, 327497) Only a year for a co worker of mine !
('49', 184, 10, 24, 327535) This time we are playing a more serious game.
('49', 184, 10, 25, 327581) Jail is now a familiar thing to us and its hardships are no hardships.
('49', 184, 10, 26, 327652) Even women and children ask to go to jail as if it was some tasty dish.
('49', 184, 10, 27, 327724) In a word, we have given up the fear of jail.
('49', 184, 10, 28, 327770) People have realized that to go to jail is to share in the struggle for swaraj.
('49', 184, 10, 29, 327850) I welcome all this, but I attach no value now to jail going.
('49', 184, 10, 30, 327911) I feel no exhilaration whenI hear that some co worker of mine was sentenced to one year or two years, or, for that matter, even five years.
('49', 184, 10, 31, 328051) It would exhilarate me to hear that a co worker like Jairamdas was shot dead or that another co worker, of an equally spotless character, had had his skull broken.
('49', 184, 10, 32, 328215) The Government’s
('49', 185, 0, 1, 328232) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('49', 188, 1, 2, 334899) 195. SPEECH AT CHHARWADA
('49', 188, 2, 3, 334924) April 26, 1930 People have conferred on me the title of salt thief as a substitute for Mahatma.
('49', 188, 2, 4, 335020) I like it.
('49', 188, 2, 5, 335031) But it is no easy thing to be a salt thief, while it is easy enough to be a Mahatma.
('49', 188, 2, 6, 335116) If one makes a fuss of eating and drinking and wears a langoti, one can easily acquire the title of Mah atma in this country.
('49', 188, 2, 7, 335242) In a little while I shall go with you and get some salt from the nearby creek.
('49', 188, 2, 8, 335321) We shall not get pure salt, as the benign Government has had it all mixed with earth.
('49', 188, 2, 9, 335407) Anyway, we shall take what we can find.
('49', 188, 2, 10, 335447) But when can we be called thieves?
('49', 188, 2, 11, 335482) Only when we are punished for theft.
('49', 188, 2, 12, 335519) What kind of theft is it which no one even so much as takes notice of ?
('49', 188, 2, 13, 335591) We shall pick up a little dust.
('49', 188, 2, 14, 335623) It may well be considered theft under the law, but the world will not take it as such nor will the Government.
('49', 188, 2, 15, 335734) It will be real theft when you have your hands broken in committing it.
('49', 188, 2, 16, 335806) Though we shall be collecting salt, possibly neither you nor I will have our hands broken.
('49', 188, 2, 17, 335897) It will be real theft only when we raid those mounds of salt over there.
('49', 188, 2, 18, 335970) When I went to Untadi, I saw them from a distance and thought them quite beautiful.
('49', 188, 2, 19, 336054) Having a near view today, I find them dirty and ugly.
('49', 188, 2, 20, 336108) Let them be what they are, we shall be real salt thieves only when we lay hands on them and have our hands and wrists broken or get thrown into jails.
('49', 188, 2, 21, 336259) I would even ask you not to confer the dearly bought title of salt thief on everyone who merely goes to jail.
('49', 188, 2, 22, 336369) You do not have your ribs smashed in going to jail.
('49', 188, 2, 23, 336421) Just now I had a letter informing me that in the Kheda district some people were beaten.
('49', 188, 2, 24, 336510) They were all resp ected public workers.
('49', 188, 2, 25, 336551) Those who had beaten them were Government functionaries but they too were our own men.
('49', 188, 2, 26, 336638) In order that they might enjoy the beating better, they even put out the light.
('49', 188, 2, 27, 336718) Six or seven men are now in hospital undergoing treatment.
('49', 188, 2, 28, 336777) None of them is likely to die, but, if anyone should, we would call him a true leader of salt thieves.
('49', 188, 2, 29, 336880) You will of course come with me to take salt from the creek here, but you will not thereby earn the title of salt thieves.
('49', 188, 2, 30, 337003) Yes, we may be said to be candidates for that title.

('49', 188, 2, 34, 337243) All those salt dunes are your property from now on.’ That property is not worth even seven crores of rupees.

('49', 189, 1, 2, 337394) amount we pay direct.

('49', 189, 1, 30, 339845) The game we are now playing is, I admit, a children’s game, but from that one day we will proceed to serious business.

('49', 192, 8, 14, 344702) 197. MESSAGE TO AMERICA
('49', 192, 9, 15, 344726) [Before April 27, 1930] 2
('49', 192, 10, 16, 344752) The national demand is not for immediate establishment of Ind ependence, but is a preliminary step to a conference, that must take place if Independence is to be established peacefully, to remove certain prime grievances, chiefly economic and moral.
('49', 192, 10, 17, 345002) These are set forth in the clearest possible terms in my letter, miscalled an ultimatum to the Viceroy.
('49', 192, 10, 18, 345106) Those grievances include the salt tax, which in its incidence falls with equal pressure upon rich as well as poor and is over 1,000 per cent of the cost price.
('49', 192, 10, 19, 345266) Having been made a mon opoly, it has deprived tens of thousands of people of their supp lementary occupation and the artificially heavy cost of salt has made it very difficult, if not impossible, for poor people to give enough salt to their cattle and to their land.
('49', 192, 10, 20, 345533) This unnatural monopoly is sustained by laws, which are only so called, but which are a denial of law.
('49', 192, 10, 21, 345636) They give arbitrary powers to police, known to be corrupt, to lay their hands without warrant on innocent people, to confiscate their property and otherwise molest them in a hundred ways.
('49', 192, 10, 22, 345824) Civil resistance against the laws has caught the popular imagination as nothing else has within my experience.
('49', 192, 10, 23, 345935) Hundreds of thousands of people, including women or children from
('49', 192, 11, 24, 346001) 1 From the reference to Gandhiji’s writing to Taramati 2 This appeared in The Sunday Times, 27 4 1930.
('49', 193, 0, 1, 346104) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 193, 1, 2, 346146) many villages, have participated in the open manufacture and sale of contraband salt.
('49', 193, 1, 3, 346232) This resistance has been answered by barbarous and unmanly repressions.
('49', 193, 1, 4, 346304) Instead of arresting people the authorities have violated the persons of people who have refused to part with salt, held generally in their fists.
('49', 193, 1, 5, 346451) To open their fists, their knuckles have been broken, their necks have been pressed, they have been even indecently assaulted till they have been rendered senseless.
('49', 193, 1, 6, 346617) Some of these assaults have taken place in the presence of hundreds and thousands of pe ople, who, although well able to protect the victims and retaliate, being under a pledge of non violence, have not done so.
('49', 193, 1, 7, 346829) It is true that violence has broken out in Calcutta, Karachi, Chittagong, and now Peshawar.
('49', 193, 1, 8, 346921) The Calcutta and Karachi events should be isolated from those at Chittagong and Peshawar.
('49', 193, 1, 9, 347011) The Calcutta and Karachi incidents were an impulsive outburst on the arrest of popular leaders.
('49', 193, 1, 10, 347107) The Chittagong and Peshawar incidents though also caused for the same reason, seem to have been serious and well planned affairs, though wholly unconnected with each other, Chittagong being in the extreme east and Peshawar being in the north west border of India.
('49', 193, 1, 11, 347371) These disturbances have so far not affected other parts of India, where civil disobedience has been going on in an organized fashion and on a mass scale since the 6th instant.
('49', 193, 1, 12, 347547) People in other parts have remained non violent in spite of great provocation.
('49', 193, 1, 13, 347626) At the same time, I admit that there is need for caution but I can say without the least hesitation that, consistently with the plan of civil disobedience, every precaution conceivable is being taken to prevent civil disobedience from being used as an occasion for doing violence.
('49', 193, 1, 14, 347907) It should be noted that in Karachi, 7 wounded persons of whom 2 have died of their wounds, were volunteers engaged in keeping the peace and restraining mob fury.
('49', 193, 1, 15, 348069) It is the opinion of eye witnesses that the firing in Karachi was wholly unjustified and that there was no firing in the air or at the legs in the first instance.
('49', 193, 1, 16, 348232) In fact, the Government have lost no opportunity of incensing people.
('49', 193, 1, 17, 348302) Many of the best and purest and the most self sacrificing lea ders have been arrested and imprisoned, in many instances with mock trials.
('49', 193, 1, 18, 348440) Sentences, though, for the same offence, have varied with the idiosyncrasies of the magistrates.
('49', 193, 1, 19, 348537) In several instances they have been for more than 12 months with hard labour on well known citizens.
('49', 193, 1, 20, 348638) The enthusiasm of the people has up to now increased with every
('49', 194, 0, 1, 348702) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 195
('49', 194, 1, 2, 348744) conviction.
('49', 194, 1, 3, 348756) Thousands of people regard the manufacture of con traband salt as part of their daily routine.
('49', 194, 1, 4, 348851) In any other part of the world with a Government at all responsible to public opinion, the salt tax would have been repealed long since, but whether now or later, repealed it will be, if the present existing atmosphere of resistance abides as it promises to do.
('49', 194, 1, 5, 349113) That this is a movement of self purification is abundantly proved by the fact that women have come into it in large numbers and are organizing the picketing of liquor shops.
('49', 194, 1, 6, 349287) Thousands have taken vows to abstain from intoxicating liquor.
('49', 194, 1, 7, 349350) In Ahmedabad, a stro ng labour centre, receipts of canteens have dropped to 19 per cent and are still dropping.
('49', 194, 1, 8, 349462) A similar manifestation is taking placein the district of Surat.
('49', 194, 1, 9, 349527) Women have also taken up the question of boycott of foreign cloth.
('49', 194, 1, 10, 349594) It is spreading all over India.
('49', 194, 1, 11, 349626) People are making bonfires of foreign cloth in their possession.
('49', 194, 1, 12, 349691) Khadi, i.e., hand spun cloth, is so much in demand that the existing stock is well nigh exh austed.

('49', 194, 1, 14, 349965) In my humble opinion, a struggle so free from violence has a message far beyond the borders of India.
('49', 194, 1, 15, 350067) I have no manner of doubt that after all the sacrifice that has already been made since April 6, the spirit of the people will be sustained throughout till India has become independent and free to make her contribution to the progress of humanity.

('49', 195, 1, 2, 350399) 198. DRAFT LETTER TO VICEROY 1
('49', 195, 2, 3, 350430) [On or before April 27, 1930] 2
('49', 195, 3, 4, 350462) YOUR EXCELLENCY, We, the undersigned women of Gujarat, have come to the con clusion that we may not keep ourselves aloof from the great national upheaval that is taking place.
('49', 195, 3, 5, 350638) We are in full sympathy with the civil disobedience campaign in respect of the salt tax.
('49', 195, 3, 6, 350727) Our sisters in the villages have already begun the manufacture of con traband salt.
('49', 195, 3, 7, 350811) But we feel that we must, as women, find an additional and special field for our activity.
('49', 195, 3, 8, 350902) We feel the force of Gandhiji’s argument that women are better fitted for dealing with the question of the proh ibition of intoxicating drinks and drugs and boycott of foreign cloth.
('49', 195, 3, 9, 351085) Drink has desolated many a home, and foreign cloth has deprived millions of India’s women of their employment during leisure hours, which amount in the aggregate to no less than four months in the year.
('49', 195, 3, 10, 351288) These two are therefore questions that concern the women more than men.
('49', 195, 3, 11, 351360) And in so far as they can be dealt with through picketing, i.e., an appeal to the hearts of those who traffic in these things and those who are lured to the drink and the drug or the foreign cloth shops, we feel that we can make a more successful effort than men.
('49', 195, 3, 12, 351624) And women doing the work must automatically ensure its peaceful nature.
('49', 195, 3, 13, 351696) As we embark upon the campaign we should respectfully point out that it is essentially the duty of the State to prohibit traffic in intoxicating drinks and drugs because they ruin both mind and body and homes of those who indulge in them and to prohibit the entry of foreign cloth inasmuch as it has brought about the economic ruin of the villages of this unhappy land.
('49', 195, 3, 14, 352066) As to the importation of foreign cloth it might be urged that the argument that applies to foreign cloth applies also partially to the cloth manufactured in Indian mills.
('49', 195, 3, 15, 352237) Only the output of Indian mills is so far short of the requirements that khadi can have nothing to fear from them.

('49', 196, 1, 4, 352666) After all we are not dealing with new problems.

('49', 196, 1, 6, 352805) What we are seeking to do is to dedicate ourselves more to these questions than to the others which along with these are being dealt with in terms of the independence movement.

('49', 197, 3, 10, 354090) The names will be published in the papers and your signing the letter will mean that you will be ready to join in picketing liquor booths and foreign cloth shops and to work under the instructions of the self appointed committee formed by the signatories below.
('49', 197, 3, 11, 354352) However, there is also another way in which you may function.

('49', 197, 3, 14, 354622) Even if you do so, we shall ultimately come together and work in co operation with one another.

('49', 198, 1, 2, 355075) 200. HONOURING THE MEMORY OF VITHALBHAI LALLUBHAI
('49', 198, 2, 3, 355125) This struggle will claim many lives.
('49', 198, 2, 4, 355162) One must die to go to heaven.
('49', 198, 2, 5, 355192) Unless thousands die, swaraj, which is dearer than heaven, will not be secured.
('49', 198, 2, 6, 355272) The purer the men sacrificing themselves in this cause, the earlier shall we get swaraj and the less will be the number of people sacrificed.
('49', 198, 2, 7, 355414) If everyone realizes and does his duty, there will be no question of dying in the struggle.
('49', 198, 2, 8, 355506) But this ideal state hardly ever occurs in this world.
('49', 198, 2, 9, 355561) Sacrifice, therefore, consists in oneself being pure and innocent, but laying down one’s life [as atonement] for another’s evil.
('49', 198, 2, 10, 355690) If no one committed sin, where would be the need for sacrifice?
('49', 198, 2, 11, 355754) Sacrifice does not simply mean accepting the penalty of death at the hands of the Government.
('49', 198, 2, 12, 355848) It certainly is a sacrifice if one engaged in the struggle undergoes unmerited suffering and dies.
('49', 198, 2, 13, 355947) It is of course a sacrifice to suffer an accident, while uprooting toddy trees as part of our struggle, and to die on that account.
('49', 198, 2, 14, 356079) Such a sacrifice was made by Vithalbhai Lallubhai yesterday.
('49', 198, 2, 15, 356140) Vithalbhai was a teacher in a national school.
('49', 198, 2, 16, 356187) Being enthusiastic he had joined as a volunteer.
('49', 198, 2, 17, 356236) While he was cutting a toddy tree, the axe fell on his leg, he sustained a fracture and thorns pricked his hands.
('49', 198, 2, 18, 356350) The doctor spared no pains in treating him.
('49', 198, 2, 19, 356394) But God’s will was otherwise, and on the fourth day Vithalbhai breathed his last.
('49', 198, 2, 20, 356476) I saw Vithalbhai on the very day on which he was hurt.
('49', 198, 2, 21, 356531) I was impressed by his courage.
('49', 198, 2, 22, 356563) Though it had been a serious operation, he was cheerful.
('49', 198, 2, 23, 356620) The doctor was all praise for his fortitude.
('49', 198, 2, 24, 356665) All of us had expected that he would recover.
('49', 198, 2, 25, 356711) However, having fulfilled his life’s aim, Vithalbhai departed doing his duty and discharging his debt to the motherland fully.
('49', 198, 2, 26, 356838) The town of Navsari realized the grave loss in Vithalbhai’s death.
('49', 198, 2, 27, 356905) People flocked to where he lay, grieving.
('49', 198, 2, 28, 356947) A great crowd formed into a procession and followed his body to the cremation ground.
('49', 198, 2, 29, 357033) The procession seemed to be a celebration.
('49', 198, 2, 30, 357076) Navsari observed a hartal on that day.
('49', 198, 2, 31, 357115) Who would not ask for a death so glorious?
('49', 198, 2, 32, 357158) I regard Vith albhai’s mother, brother, wife and all others of the family worthy of
('49', 199, 0, 1, 357242) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 199, 1, 2, 357284) congratulations on their good fortune.
('49', 199, 1, 3, 357323) Why is such a death desirable, one may ask.
('49', 199, 1, 4, 357367) It is so because it purifies those left behind and awakens a greater spirit of service in them.
('49', 199, 1, 5, 357463) Has it so happened in this case?
('49', 199, 1, 6, 357496) If it has, let us fittingly honour his memory.
('49', 199, 1, 7, 357543) Vithalbhai gave his life in the fight against the drink evil.
('49', 199, 1, 8, 357605) It behoves us to apply ourselves to the task and even risk our lives in it.
('49', 199, 1, 9, 357681) Vithalbhai lost his life in Jalalpur taluka.
('49', 199, 1, 10, 357726) It, therefore, becomes the special duty of this taluka to see that the toddy trees, stained with his blood, are rooted out, that the liquor and toddy shops are closed down and that the addicts give up drinking.
('49', 199, 1, 11, 357937) I had been to Bodali yesterday.
('49', 199, 1, 12, 357969) The people there paid a glowing tribute to the departed soul.
('49', 199, 1, 13, 358031) On my request a number of leading men of the place granted permission for felling the toddy palm trees owned by them.
('49', 199, 1, 14, 358149) As we lost Vithalbhai, so did we lose Dattatreya and Meghraj.
('49', 199, 1, 15, 358211) These latter offered their lives to bullets at Karachi.
('49', 199, 1, 16, 358267) For Vithalbhai, who was engaged in ending the drink evil, I suggested a method of honouring his memory befitting the cause he served.
('49', 199, 1, 17, 358401) As for Dattatreya and Meghraj, let us honour their memory by promoting peacefulness among us.
('49', 199, 1, 18, 358495) In the measure that disturbances increase, we shall have to suffer more acutely and in larger numbers; and to that extent the winning of swaraj will be delayed.

('49', 210, 1, 2, 378558) 211. LETTER TO RAMESHWARDAS BIRLA
('49', 210, 2, 3, 378592) JALALPUR, April 28, 1930
('49', 210, 3, 4, 378617) BHAI RAMESHWARDASJI,
('49', 210, 4, 5, 378638) I have your letter.
('49', 210, 4, 6, 378658) I know your love for khadi.
('49', 210, 4, 7, 378686) That is why I hesitate to offer comments on your scheme.
('49', 210, 4, 8, 378743) However, I must tell you that your scheme is not workable because the mill owners will not give up their interests.
('49', 210, 4, 9, 378859) For many matters Government aid is essential; it will never be available for the boycott [of foreign cloth].
('49', 210, 4, 10, 378968) If the boycott can be successfully implemented by the efforts of the mill owners only, khadi need have no place in it.
('49', 210, 4, 11, 379087) But I am confident that boycott will be successful only with khadi.
('49', 210, 4, 12, 379155) This does not mean that mills have no place in the scheme at all.
('49', 210, 4, 13, 379221) The mills can take their proper place only by recognizing the worth of khadi.
('49', 210, 4, 14, 379299) According to the doctrine that various individual deities are included in God, we destroy them by worshipping them separately because they have no independent existence, and we do not reach God either.
('49', 210, 4, 15, 379501) For all these reasons, the prosperity of the mills and the success of foreign cloth boycott lie in spreading the love of khadi and increasing its production.
('49', 210, 4, 16, 379659) Verb Sap.
('49', 210, 4, 17, 379669) Hope you will not find any difficulty in deciphering my hand writing.
('49', 210, 6, 18, 379739) MOHANDAS

('49', 211, 7, 14, 380444) 213. INTERVIEW TO “ THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('49', 211, 8, 15, 380486) JALALPUR, April 28, 1930 A raid on Government salt depots was inevitable, but the plan of action was incomplete.
('49', 211, 9, 16, 380599) Asked if a raid on Dharasana salt depot was finally decided upon, Mahatmaji said: I have taken no final decision.
('49', 211, 9, 17, 380713) I am praying for light.
('49', 211, 10, 18, 380737) In reply to a question if he would send intimation of the raid to the Viceroy, Gandhiji observed: I shall certainly not take the step without due intimation.
('49', 211, 10, 19, 380895) If the raid comes at all it will come very soon.
('49', 211, 10, 20, 380944) Asked how he proposed to carry out the raid if the police barred the entrance to the salt pans.
('49', 211, 10, 21, 381040) Gandhiji replied: I do not know; but I shall know the way when the block stares me in the face.
('49', 211, 10, 22, 381136) When I talk about the raid I simply think audibly, as is my wont.
('49', 211, 10, 23, 381202) But so far as I can see the raid is inevitable.

('49', 212, 9, 15, 382187) Gandhiji addressing the meeting said he did not want to put the Indian States in
('49', 212, 10, 16, 382268) an awkward position either by making speeches or breaking the Salt Act.
('49', 212, 10, 17, 382340) Let us first
('49', 212, 11, 18, 382353) of all settle everything with the British and everything that is to be done in the States

('49', 212, 12, 22, 382692) Liquor trade has ruined our labour class and it is the duty of every citizen, be he a State subject or a British subject, to save them and ladies alone can successfully bring about that change of heart among the drunkards, which is so essential.

('49', 213, 1, 5, 383339) They would not like to be our brothers but would prefer to be our masters.

('49', 213, 3, 11, 383768) 216. VEILED MARTIAL LAW 1
('49', 213, 4, 12, 383794) [BILIMORA, April 29, 1930] The revival in the form of an ordinance of the Press Act that was supposed to be dead was only to be expected, and I observe that in its new form the Act contains additional provisions making the whole piece more deadly than before.
('49', 213, 4, 13, 384054) Whether we realize it or not, for some days past we have been living under a veiled form of martial law.
('49', 213, 4, 14, 384159) After all, what is martial law if it is not the will of the commanding officer for the time being?
('49', 213, 4, 15, 384258) The Viceroy is that officer, and wherever he considers it desirable he supersedes the whole of the law, both common and statute, and imposes ordinances on a people too subm issive to resent or resist him.
('49', 213, 4, 16, 384463) I hope, however, that the time for tame submission to the dictation from British rulers is gone for ever.
('49', 213, 4, 17, 384569) I hope that the people will not be frightened by this ordinance.
('49', 213, 4, 18, 384634) The Press men, if they are worthy representatives of public opinion, will not be frightened by the ordinance.
('49', 213, 4, 19, 384744) Let us realize the wise dictum of Thoreau that it is difficult under tyrannical rule for honest men to be wealthy.
('49', 213, 4, 20, 384859) And if we have decided to hand over our bodies without a murmur to the authorities let us also be equally ready to hand over our property to them and not sell our souls.
('49', 213, 4, 21, 385029) I would, therefore, urge
('49', 213, 5, 22, 385054) 1 This formed the basis of an interview to The Bombay Chronicle and was published with the following note: “Below is given the full text of Gandhiji’s statement on the Press Act that has already appeared in a more or less mutilated form in the various English Papers.”
('49', 214, 0, 1, 385323) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 215
('49', 214, 1, 2, 385365) Press men and publishers to refuse to furnish securities, and if they are called upon to do so, either to cease publication or to challenge the authorities to confiscate whatever they like.
('49', 214, 1, 3, 385555) When freedom is actually knocking at our door and when for the sake of wooing it thousands have suffered tortures, let it not be said of the Press representatives that they were weighed and found wanting.
('49', 214, 1, 4, 385760) They may confiscate type and machinery, they will not confiscate pen and still less speech, but I recognize that they can succeed in confiscating even these last two.
('49', 214, 1, 5, 385927) But what they will never succeed in suppressing and what is after all the thing that matters is the thought of the nation and at the present moment there is hardly a man or woman breathing in India who with every breath does not breathe in disaffection, sedition, disloyalty and whatever other term one may use to describe the mentality of the nation which has set its mind on destroying the existing system of Government.
