('49', 216, 5, 6, 388282) 221. STATEMENT ON POISONING OF SALT BED
('49', 216, 6, 7, 388322) JALALPUR, April 30, 1930 Since the repudiation, after further and careful investigation my informant sticks to the statement that he made to me.
('49', 216, 6, 8, 388467) I had the samples analysed, and the result of all my investigation is that there certainly was some tampering with the salt bed in question.
('49', 216, 6, 9, 388608) Whether the substance added rendered the salt poisonous or not I am unable to say, but it certainly contaminated it.
('49', 216, 6, 10, 388725) The sudden change in the comp lexion of the bed and the colour of the water are absolutely beyond question.
('49', 216, 6, 11, 388833) What then remains to be proved is, whether this change happened through human agency or a superhuman one, and if through a human agency, whether it happened through that of the Government or some other.
('49', 216, 6, 12, 389036) Seeing that Government officials have been tampering with salt beds, destroying them by mixing mud in them and otherwise, the burden of proof rests on their shoulders that there was no contamination produced so as to render the salt unfit for human use.
('49', 216, 7, 13, 389290) The Hindu, 4 5 1930
('49', 216, 8, 14, 389310) 1 In reply to the addressee’s letter regarding the order of the Madras Government permitting the collector of Tanjore to prosecute the satyagrahis breaking the salt law in the South 2 The addressee had been arrested on April 30, 1930, during the Vedaranyam Salt Satyagraha.
('49', 216, 8, 15, 389584) 3 A Tamil proverb, written in the Tamil script by Gandhiji

('49', 221, 4, 4, 394283) JAMNADAS,

('49', 221, 5, 6, 394313) You need not have given your name.
('49', 221, 5, 7, 394348) I think they will not arrest Khushalbhai 1. It will be befitting if he is accompanied by a batch of volunteers.

('49', 223, 11, 15, 397000) I have hardly time to notice arrests and imprisonments even of eminent Indians.
('49', 223, 11, 16, 397080) I do not even come to know of them immediately.
('49', 223, 11, 17, 397128) Being constantly on the move and living in a village, often twenty four hours elapse before I know some of the important events.
('49', 223, 11, 18, 397257) Happily it is unnecessary for me to know them.
('49', 223, 11, 19, 397304) When many important persons act as one man and undergo suffering and when many imp ortant events take place at the same time, both become common things and it is a happy sign.
('49', 223, 11, 20, 397480) We take no notice of the myriads of sunbeams each as important as the sun itself.
('49', 223, 11, 21, 397562) We pay homage to each when we worship the sun which is the crowning act of the simultaneous action of the beams.
('49', 223, 11, 22, 397675) Even so do we worship daily the ever waxing sun of India’s freedom which is in the process of formation.

('49', 224, 1, 2, 397953) chaos going under the false name of Government, Mahadev’s arrest was a courteous and reluctant business on the part of the authorities.
('49', 224, 1, 3, 398089) Though he set ablaze the whole of Gujarat from Viramgam and Dholera to Ahmedabad, the authorities recognizedthat it was a life giving fire, that they were safer under Mahadev’s rule than their own and that he was well able to control the forces he had brought into being.
('49', 224, 2, 4, 398361) But Mahadev made it impossible for the authorities to keep him free.
('49', 224, 2, 5, 398430) He had managed to “smuggle in” a lorry load of salt from Dholera.
('49', 224, 2, 6, 398496) The authorities were wide awake.
('49', 224, 2, 7, 398529) They intercepted the lorry.
('49', 224, 2, 8, 398557) They had hoped not to find Mahadev in it.
('49', 224, 2, 9, 398599) But when he saw that the lorry was to be arrested together with its precious load, he got out of the car in which he was following and jumped into the lorry.
('49', 224, 2, 10, 398757) And so if they were to arrest the lorry they could not help arresting him.
('49', 224, 2, 11, 398832) Nor could Mahadev help jumping into the lorry in the circumstances.
('49', 224, 2, 12, 398900) With him was a youth who was to have appeared for his final L.L.B. the following day; two were young men from the Gujarat College and two were sons of wealthy men.
('49', 224, 2, 13, 399064) The lorry was given by Sjt.
('49', 224, 2, 14, 399092) Ranchhodlal, a mill owner who, when warned what might befall the lorry, said, “What fear about the loss of the lorry when I am prepared to lose all for swaraj?” Mahadev has got his well deserved rest.
('49', 224, 2, 15, 399293) For hundreds of strenuous workers the jail has become a resting house.
('49', 224, 2, 16, 399364) Mahadev yearned as he says after “a better fate but evidently had not yet deserved it”.
('49', 224, 3, 17, 399452) He has appointed as his successor Imam Saheb Abdul Kadir Bawazeer, a comrade from South Africa and Vice Chairman of the Ashram Committee and one of its trustees.
('49', 224, 3, 18, 399614) Imam Saheb is an elderly man hardly capable of strenuous labours.

('49', 224, 3, 22, 399938) He is an orthodox Mussalman in the sense that he never misses his prayers or his fasts.

('49', 225, 2, 2, 400149) contact in the midst of all sorts of people for an unbroken period of nearly twenty years.
('49', 225, 3, 3, 400240) But the swaraj of my—our—dream recognizes no race or religious distinctions.
('49', 225, 3, 4, 400317) Nor is it to be the monopoly of lettered persons nor yet of moneyed men.

('49', 226, 1, 2, 401473) 234. TO CORRESPONDENTS
('49', 226, 2, 3, 401496) My correspondence accumulates daily.
('49', 226, 2, 4, 401533) I have purposely deprived myself of much assistance.

('49', 226, 2, 6, 401630) It is therefore impossible for me to cope with the cor respondence from day to day.
('49', 226, 2, 7, 401714) I have invited co workers whom I have sent away to different parts of the country to keep me duly informed of their doings.

('49', 226, 2, 10, 401937) The fact is that I should be regarded as a half prisoner permitted to receive letters but prevented from writing in reply except occasionally.
('49', 226, 2, 11, 402080) Presently I shall be a full prisoner if not something higher.
('49', 226, 2, 12, 402142) Therefore when fellow workers and others do not receive letters from me they should know that I have had no time to write to them.

('49', 226, 4, 15, 402310) If what is going on in Gujarat is any indication of what is going on in other parts of India, even Dyerism pales into insignificance.
('49', 226, 4, 16, 402444) This may appear to be an exaggerated statement.
('49', 226, 4, 17, 402492) But it is meant to be literally true.
('49', 226, 4, 18, 402530) The massacre of Jallianwala was a clean sweep.

('49', 226, 4, 27, 403424) This is what Dr. Narsinhbhai Mehta, a retired Chief Medical
('49', 227, 0, 1, 403484) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 227, 2, 2, 403522) Officer of Junagadh, who at the age of 66 was enthused with the spirit of satyagraha, saw with his own eyes:
('49', 227, 3, 3, 403631) I brought a party of about 120 satyagrahis, each with a bag of ten lb.
('49', 227, 3, 4, 403702) of contraband salt from Wadhvan Camp this evening.
('49', 227, 4, 5, 403753) As I led the party, I was the first to meet the inspecting party consisting of one European officer, two Indian officers and about 4 or 5 police constables.
('49', 227, 4, 6, 403910) Over and above this there were about fifty spare constables watching the entrance of the staircase.
('49', 227, 5, 7, 404010) I was asked what I had got in the bag under my armpit.
('49', 227, 5, 8, 404065) I replied, “Ten lb.
('49', 227, 5, 9, 404085) of contraband salt.” “All right, old doctor, you can go,” they said.
('49', 227, 5, 10, 404154) I said, “I am leading a party of about 120 satyagrahis, each with a bag of such salt.
('49', 227, 5, 11, 404240) So I want to see personally how you deal with them, or whether you allow them to go freely just like other passengers.” He said, “All right, you stand apart on one side, and watch.” One by one the satyagrahis were made to pass through the said inspecting party and immediately all the seven or eight of them, including the European officer, caught hold of each resister and snatched the bag from the hands of the satyagrahi, handling the resister most roughly.
('49', 227, 5, 12, 404701) Almost every satyagrahi was treated likewise.
('49', 227, 5, 13, 404747) It was a disgraceful proceeding.
('49', 227, 5, 14, 404780) I had a very high opinion of Englishmen all throughout my life.
('49', 227, 5, 15, 404844) This was the first experience of the kind during sixty six years.
('49', 227, 6, 16, 404910) When I could bear the treatment no longer and expostulated, the officer said: “Speak to the public outside about this and write to the papers!” And the whole performance went on as before.
('49', 227, 6, 17, 405099) Mark the callousness with which Dr. Mehta’s entreaty was met.
('49', 227, 6, 18, 405161) It was a jolly performance for the British officer and his fell ow loyalists to indulge in the sport of dispossessing young men of their precious possession.
('49', 227, 6, 19, 405319) It was no use telling them that the victims were not running away nor hiding anything.
('49', 227, 6, 20, 405406) The law had to be resp ected without any waiting for the law’s delay on the part of its ad ministrators.
('49', 227, 6, 21, 405511) But even this was nothing compared to the scenes enacted in the Kheda district.
('49', 227, 6, 22, 405591) I own that the brave sons and daughters of Kheda have carried out fairly successfully the legitimate boycott of officials who are no longer able to impose their will upon the people.
('49', 227, 6, 23, 405774) They have brutally struck a graduate and professor of the Gujarat Vidyapith who had committed no offence, but who had gone simply to see what was happening when he heard the beating.
('49', 227, 6, 24, 405957) In the same district near Borsad a few police supported by a local Thakore and his minions armed with long armed sickles without notice put out the lights at a meeting and mercilessly fell upon their victims.
('49', 227, 6, 25, 406166) The audience consisted of Patidars
('49', 228, 0, 1, 406201) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 229
('49', 228, 1, 2, 406243) and Rajputs who were fully able to defend themselves.
('49', 228, 1, 3, 406297) But not a stone was thrown, not a word was uttered.
('49', 228, 1, 4, 406349) For the sake of discipline they suffered.
('49', 228, 1, 5, 406391) One man narrowly escaped death.
('49', 228, 1, 6, 406423) Seven are still lying in a hospital.
('49', 228, 1, 7, 406460) Altogether thirty five have been traced as having been injured.

('49', 228, 1, 9, 406568) Then take Ahmedabad.
('49', 228, 1, 10, 406589) A liquor dealer finding his till empty from day to day got so exasperated that he savagely attacked the pickets one of whom lay senseless.
('49', 228, 1, 11, 406728) The picketing was of the most peaceful as acknowledged by everybody.
('49', 228, 1, 12, 406797) There was not even any demonstration.

('49', 229, 3, 3, 408055) THE SPEAKER’S RESIGNATION

('49', 229, 4, 5, 408149) It would have been surprising if he had not resigned.
('49', 229, 4, 6, 408203) By his courage combined with impartiality, he won the affection of Congressmen and commanded the admiration of opponents.

('49', 229, 4, 11, 408664) His firmness in the Chair was undoubtedly embarrassing to the Government; his vacating it in the manner he has done is still more so.
('49', 229, 5, 12, 408798) FRONTIER PROVINCES
('49', 229, 6, 13, 408817) When I marched to Dandi, friends in the Frontier Provinces had offered to send some volunteers to help me.
('49', 229, 6, 14, 408924) I sent them thanks in appreciation of their offer but did not avail myself of it.
('49', 229, 6, 15, 409006) How nice perhaps it would have been if they had not actively participated in the movement.
('49', 229, 6, 16, 409097) Those who, not being sure of perfect non violence being observed, do not take an active part in the struggle are most assuredly helping it.
('49', 229, 6, 17, 409237) Those who wanting to serve take part in it and violence results, as happened at Peshawar, are as assuredly harming the movement.
('49', 229, 6, 18, 409366) That the people in Peshawar meant well I have no doubt.
('49', 229, 6, 19, 409422) They are perhaps more impatient (if such a thing were possible) than I am to win freedom.
('49', 229, 6, 20, 409512) But nobody can get freedom today in this land except through non violence.
('49', 229, 6, 21, 409587) We cannot get India’s freedom through the way of violence; we are within reach of it if we would but keep up non violence to the end.
('49', 229, 6, 22, 409721) The way lies not through the burning of armoured cars and taking the lives of administrators of the Government machinery; it lies through disciplined organized self suffering.
('49', 229, 6, 23, 409897) I deeply regret the occurrences in Peshawar.
('49', 229, 6, 24, 409942) Brave lives have been thrown away without the cause itself being served.

('49', 232, 2, 8, 414560) 237. QUESTIONS ANSWERED
('49', 232, 3, 9, 414584) Professor Syed Rauf Pasha caught hold of me when last I was in Bulsar 1 and asked me some pertinent questions on Hindu Muslim unity.
('49', 232, 3, 10, 414717) At my request he reduced the questions in writing so that I could give precise answers.
('49', 232, 3, 11, 414805) The reader will find the questions and the answers below:
('49', 232, 4, 12, 414863) Q. 1. You say that the present campaign is intended only to create the
('49', 232, 5, 13, 414934) necessary strength among the people to gain independence rather than to establish
('49', 232, 6, 14, 415016) independence.
('49', 232, 6, 15, 415030) If you feel that Dominion Status on the basis of the Nehru Report will
('49', 232, 7, 16, 415101) create that strength, will you accept it when the Muslims feel that it would be only
('49', 232, 8, 17, 415186) Hindu strength rather than National strength that would be gained thereby?
('49', 232, 9, 18, 415261) A. I should never feel that any grant can give us strength.
('49', 232, 9, 19, 415321) In no case could the Nehru scheme be revived or accepted if only because the communal solution suggested therein does not satisfy those con cerned in it and also because it does not stipulate for Independence as it obviously could not at the time.
('49', 232, 10, 20, 415569) Q. 2. Do you consider the Ali Brothers to be sincere in differing from you over
('49', 232, 11, 21, 415649) the time of starting the disobedience of the salt law and over the question of
('49', 232, 12, 22, 415728) participation in the Round Table Conference; and that they were in no way influenced
('49', 232, 13, 23, 415813) by the British Government in the adoption of such an attitude?
('49', 232, 14, 24, 415876) A. I certainly consider the Ali Brothers to be sincere in what they say.
('49', 232, 14, 25, 415949) If I believed them to be insincere or capable of being influenced by the British Government, I should never hope of their being weaned from what to me appears to be a grievous error as my action appears to them to be.
('49', 232, 15, 26, 416167) 1 On April 26, 1930
('49', 233, 0, 1, 416187) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 233, 2, 2, 416225) Q. 3. Do you realize or not that the Ali Brothers still have a great following
('49', 233, 3, 3, 416304) among the Muslim masses throughout India and who would swell your ranks
('49', 233, 4, 4, 416376) tomorrow if only the Ali Brothers assure them that such a step will not be detrimental
('49', 233, 5, 5, 416463) to their interests?
('49', 233, 6, 6, 416483) Further, don’t you think that even the Ali Brothers with all their
('49', 233, 7, 7, 416550) influence were and still are powerless to dispel their suspicion of the Mahasabha
('49', 233, 8, 8, 416632) Hindus just as you were and still are powerless to carry the Hindu community with you
('49', 233, 9, 9, 416718) in the settlement of the communal question although your leadership in other matters
('49', 233, 10, 10, 416803) is not questioned?
('49', 233, 11, 11, 416822) A. How can it be otherwise?
('49', 233, 11, 12, 416850) Their record of service will always secure for the Ali Brothers a following among the Muslim masses.
('49', 233, 11, 13, 416951) There is no doubt therefore that their coming would mean additional strength to the cause.
('49', 233, 12, 14, 417042) Deep rooted suspicions cannot be dispelled by leaders however influential they may be.
('49', 233, 13, 15, 417129) Q. 4. Do you think that Muslims specially of the N.W.F. Province and
('49', 233, 14, 16, 417198) Malabar are sufficiently trained for non violent fight as the Hindus specially of
('49', 233, 15, 17, 417280) Gujarat are; and do not past recent occurrences in these provinces impress on you the
('49', 233, 16, 18, 417366) necessity of stopping such unprepared provinces from immediate participation until
('49', 233, 17, 19, 417449) such organization is complete and that otherwise there would be an unnecessary loss
('49', 233, 18, 20, 417533) of Muslim life?
('49', 233, 19, 21, 417549) A. I have repeatedly warned those provinces that are unprepared for strict non violence against participation in the struggle.
('49', 233, 19, 22, 417676) It is quite enough if they can give their sympathy.

('49', 234, 1, 2, 417792) 238. LIQUOR AND PARSIS
('49', 234, 2, 3, 417815) Several Parsi friends seem to be under the apprehension that liquor picketing is to be confined only to Parsi liquor dealers.
('49', 234, 2, 4, 417941) This is wholly a misconception.
('49', 234, 2, 5, 417973) Picketing is now going on all over India in a more or less organized fashion.
('49', 234, 2, 6, 418051) And in the parts other than Gujarat there are more Hindu dealers than Parsis.
('49', 234, 2, 7, 418129) Even in Gujarat the tho usands of toddy trees that are being uprooted belong overw helm ingly to Hindus.
('49', 234, 2, 8, 418234) Toddy booths owned by Hindus are certainly to be picketed on a most extensive scale.
('49', 234, 2, 9, 418319) Organized picketing, it should be remembered, has only just commenced.
('49', 234, 2, 10, 418390) In my speeches I have made a pointed appeal to Parsis because there is an indissoluble bond between them and me and because they are the most advanced and organized community in all India and therefore more readily ame nable to reason.
('49', 234, 2, 11, 418626) They read newspapers.
('49', 234, 2, 12, 418648) Parsi liquor dealers attend my mee tings, whereas Hindu dealers are too ignorant to do so.
('49', 234, 2, 13, 418739) The latter can only be reached by personal visits made to them in their own booths or homes.
('49', 234, 2, 14, 418832) Indeed the response I am getting from Parsi friends is quite encouraging, though not yet adequate.
('49', 234, 2, 15, 418931) It is a Parsi sister—Mithubai Petit—who, assisted among others by a Parsi pleader, is org anizing picketing in the Surat district.
('49', 234, 2, 16, 419062) Behram Mehta and Dhanjisha Darbari have gone to jail in the same cause.
('49', 234, 2, 17, 419134) They were ostensibly arrested for breach of salt laws, but I have a suspicion that they were arrested for the possibility of their undoubted influence spreading among liquor dealers.
('49', 234, 2, 18, 419317) Anyway, they were engaged in the anti drink work as much as the Salt Satyagraha.
('49', 234, 2, 19, 419398) It was a matter of joy to me too that some Parsi liquor dealers who came to me the other day went away satisfied to find that I had fully the intention of picketing toddy booths just as much as liquor shops.
('49', 234, 2, 20, 419606) One complaint was that we were leaving alone the liquor shops in the adjacent Baroda territory.
('49', 234, 2, 21, 419702) The charge is true.
('49', 234, 2, 22, 419722) But I am hoping that the Baroda State people will organize the picketing of Baroda canteens.
('49', 234, 2, 23, 419815) Prohibition is first and foremost a moral reform.
('49', 234, 2, 24, 419865) The Indian States are as much interested in it as the rest of India.
('49', 234, 2, 25, 419934) The States’ people may take up this reform, and ought to do so.
('49', 234, 2, 26, 419998) The friends who saw me raised also the question of their living.
('49', 234, 2, 27, 420063) It is here that the Parsis as a community have to step in to find a solution.
('49', 234, 2, 28, 420141) Parsi associations can prepare statistics and organize bureaux for the employment of those who would need relief when the only
('49', 235, 0, 1, 420268) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 235, 2, 2, 420306) source of their income is gone, as it ought to have long ago.
('49', 235, 2, 3, 420368) It cannot be a matter of pride that this great community has so many of its members living on an immoral traffic.
('49', 235, 2, 4, 420482) Young India, 1 5 1930
('49', 235, 3, 5, 420504) 239. ‘TRIUMPH OF NON VIOLENCE’
('49', 235, 4, 6, 420535) Who does not know Shri Rajendra Prasad?
('49', 235, 4, 7, 420575) He writes from Patna: 1
('49', 235, 5, 8, 420599) The more I become aware of the present trend in the country the more I am convinced that people have fully learnt the lesson of peace.
('49', 235, 5, 9, 420734) There is still something lacking to be sure.
('49', 235, 5, 10, 420779) But if people are peaceful and fearless to the end swaraj is not far away.
('49', 235, 5, 11, 420854) There are three prerequisites for swaraj: purity, fearlessness and work.
('49', 235, 5, 12, 420927) Giving up of liquor and other intoxicating things is a sign of purity.
('49', 235, 5, 13, 420998) Through civil disobedience of the salt law people are learning the lesson of fearlessness.
('49', 235, 5, 14, 421089) When the charkha or the takli has become universal one can say that people have become industrious.
('49', 235, 5, 15, 421189) The economic gain from these things is of course there.
('49', 235, 5, 16, 421245) Giving up of liquor, etc., will save us Rs. 25 crores.
('49', 235, 5, 17, 421300) Abolition of the salt tax will save at least Rs. 6 crores and the takli through the manufacture of khadi, Rs. 60 crores.
('49', 235, 5, 18, 421421) May God grant the people of this country strength to do all this.
('49', 235, 6, 19, 421487) [From Hindi]
('49', 235, 7, 20, 421500) Hindi Navajivan, 1 5 1930
('49', 235, 8, 21, 421526) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('49', 235, 8, 22, 421563) Rajendra Prasad had described how events in Patna had ended in a procession of about 15,000 being taken out on April 23 and how in the face of police violence the huge assembly had remained wholly peaceful and disciplined.
('49', 235, 8, 23, 421786) He had called it a triumph of non violence.

('49', 237, 6, 6, 423634) 242. EXTRACTS FROM SPEECH AT OLPAD
('49', 237, 7, 7, 423669) May 1, 1930 The Government has been testing us thoroughly by taking away our leaders from us one by one.
('49', 237, 7, 8, 423774) It believes that, deprived of our leaders, we shall either hide ourselves in our homes or become violent.
('49', 237, 7, 9, 423880) What can be better for the Government than if we hide?
('49', 237, 7, 10, 423935) If we do not raise our heads, if we go on paying the land revenue year after year, continue drinking liquor, buy salt at a rupee and a quarter a maund and wear foreign cloth, the Government will want nothing more.
('49', 237, 7, 11, 424149) On the other hand, if we resort to violence it can stand it since the consu mption of ammunition will then go up, the industry in England will stand to gain, and its generals, captains and soldiers will have honours and awards conferred on them.
('49', 237, 7, 12, 424395) There is just one thing the Government cannot put up with, and that is that we should refuse to obey its laws and to submit to its authority.
('49', 237, 7, 13, 424537) We have not been true to our salt.
('49', 237, 7, 14, 424572) That is why we disregard the cloth made by the hands of our poor and virtuous brothers and sisters and import cloth from abroad.
('49', 237, 7, 15, 424701) Islam had a Caliph who was the greatest among all the Caliphs.
('49', 237, 7, 16, 424764) What did he tell the great governors from Baghdad who had come dressed in silken robes?
('49', 237, 7, 17, 424852) “Your Prophet wore only coarse cloth.
('49', 237, 7, 18, 424890) Where did you learn to wear such soft garments?” Holy men in those days had such power that people trembled before them.
('49', 237, 7, 19, 425011) And this they did, not because they brandished the sword, but because they wielded spiritual power.
('49', 237, 7, 20, 425111) Now people, whether Hindus or Muslims, tell me that they find khadi too coarse.
('49', 237, 7, 21, 425191) I laugh when I hear that, though, in truth, I ought to weep.
('49', 237, 7, 22, 425252) I have been told that in Surat when some of our sisters were on their round, the owners of toddy booths behaved badly.
('49', 237, 7, 23, 425371) Some even threw clods of earth at them.
('49', 237, 7, 24, 425411) I was ashamed to hear this.
('49', 237, 7, 25, 425439) A man should die before he insults such women or swears at them or lifts a stone against them.
('49', 237, 7, 26, 425534) What though the person behaving thus be a
('49', 238, 0, 1, 425576) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 239
('49', 238, 1, 2, 425618) drunkard?
('49', 238, 1, 3, 425628) Haven’t drunkards their mothers and sisters?
('49', 238, 1, 4, 425673) These women do not go and abuse them.
('49', 238, 1, 5, 425711) They only humbly entreat them.
('49', 238, 1, 6, 425742) Is it a crime to do so?
('49', 238, 1, 7, 425766) Every man in this country should have the spirit in him not to tolerate women being insulted.
('49', 238, 1, 8, 425860) This does not mean that one should lose one’s temper with the person who abuses them.
('49', 238, 1, 9, 425946) But how can any man have the audacity to abuse a woman or lift a stone against her?
('49', 238, 1, 10, 426030) He ought rather to pray: O God, may my hand come unstuck before I commit such a crime.
('49', 238, 1, 11, 426117) Against whom can you raise your hand?
('49', 238, 1, 12, 426155) Perhaps against a man who attacks you, though even that is at present forbidden.
('49', 238, 1, 13, 426236) To raise one’s hand against a woman is cowardly.
('49', 238, 1, 14, 426285) It is unthinkable.
('49', 238, 1, 15, 426304) I hope no Indian is behind these incidents.
('49', 238, 1, 16, 426348) I hope the clod of earth fell accidentally on some sister.
('49', 238, 1, 17, 426407) I had believed that though there might be wicked Indians, even they would observe some decorum.
('49', 238, 1, 18, 426503) However, even if a few women have their heads smashed as some men have had theirs, we will not give up what we have undertaken in the name of God.
('49', 238, 1, 19, 426650) If it is the fate of our sisters to be beaten they will be beaten.
('49', 238, 1, 20, 426717) But let those who drink as well as those who sell liquor note that drinking will soon be a matter of the past.
('49', 238, 2, 21, 426828) The way of the Raghus it has been ever,
('49', 238, 3, 22, 426868) Life may fail but a pledge never.
('49', 238, 4, 23, 426902) We all brothers and sisters have now learnt to recite this quatrain and we are no actors in a play who only sing and do not act.
('49', 238, 4, 24, 427031) Just as we know that the salt law is as good as abolished, let us also have the faith that the drink evil, too, will be gone.
('49', 238, 4, 25, 427157) Remember my humble prayer.
('49', 238, 4, 26, 427184) I also want you to carry my message—the message of an old man—to all concerned and to the liquor booth owners of Surat.
('49', 238, 4, 27, 427304) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 11 5 1930

('49', 239, 2, 2, 427379) 243. SPEECH AT RANDER
('49', 239, 3, 3, 427401) May 1, 1930 I appeal to Muslim friends to realize that at present we have embarked upon a movement of self purification.
('49', 239, 3, 4, 427522) The time has not yet come to divide the gains among ourselves.
('49', 239, 3, 5, 427585) When that time comes, we shall decide the share of each.
('49', 239, 3, 6, 427642) If it is our misfortune to fight then, we shall fight it out.
('49', 239, 3, 7, 427704) But personally I believe that when that day comes, there will be no need for us to fight.
('49', 239, 3, 8, 427794) There will be no cause then for mutual distrust or fear.
('49', 239, 3, 9, 427851) At present our fight is directed mainly against the salt tax.
('49', 239, 3, 10, 427913) Such a tax is forbidden in Islam.
('49', 239, 3, 11, 427947) Salt is a necessity for all.
('49', 239, 3, 12, 427976) The majority of Hindus and Muslims are poor people and the burden of the tax falls on them.
('49', 239, 3, 13, 428068) In Rander, however, we have millionaires and multi millionaires.
('49', 239, 3, 14, 428133) They can see the facts if only they go with me into villages.
('49', 239, 3, 15, 428195) Our second task is to banish foreign cloth.
('49', 239, 3, 16, 428239) Everyone can see from the accounts of the Spinners’ Association that because of this movement we pay thousands of rupees to Muslim women and weavers.
('49', 239, 3, 17, 428389) The large number of women in Vijapur who earn a living through this work and bless me are all Muslims.
('49', 239, 3, 18, 428492) These poor women have often wept when my workers could not supply them enough slivers.
('49', 239, 3, 19, 428579) The third task is eradication of the drink evil.
('49', 239, 3, 20, 428628) In which religion is drinking not forbidden?
('49', 239, 3, 21, 428673) In the course of my life I have mixed a great deal with Muslims and attended many dinners given by Muslim hosts.
('49', 239, 3, 22, 428786) Muslims cannot but join the movement for ban ish ing liquor and other intoxicants from the country.
('49', 239, 3, 23, 428886) Are those mill workers not Muslims who picket liquor booths in Ahmedabad and plead with proprietors and drink addicts, patiently submitting to assaults and abuses?
('49', 239, 3, 24, 429050) This is God’s work.
('49', 239, 3, 25, 429070) He alone can do it who is ready to sacrifice his life for it.
('49', 239, 3, 26, 429132) Only he who is ready to dive into the sea can bring up pearls from it.
('49', 239, 3, 27, 429203) I only beg of my Muslim clients and other Muslims to realize that this movement of self purification is not a monopoly of any community, and wish that all people shouldheartily join it.
('49', 239, 3, 28, 429389) We will see afterwards how to share the gains when the Government asks us what we want.
('49', 239, 3, 29, 429477) My prophecy about that day, however, is that we shall then no longer think it necessary to fight, that one brother will invite another to take anything he wants.
('49', 239, 3, 30, 429639) We shall then have nobility among us and the bargaining spirit will have disappeared.
('49', 239, 3, 31, 429725) We have to do this
('49', 240, 0, 1, 429744) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 241
('49', 240, 1, 2, 429786) work in God’s name, in the name of the poor.
('49', 240, 1, 3, 429831) Let all the communities help in it and let the town of Rander, too, give all the help it can and bring glory to its fair name.
('49', 240, 1, 4, 429958) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 11 5 1930

('49', 247, 0, 1, 436381) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 247, 2, 2, 436419) 257. TO THE PEOPLE OF KHEDA
('49', 247, 3, 3, 436447) In Gujarat at present the Kheda district seems to have become the centre of our struggle.
('49', 247, 3, 4, 436537) Nowhere else in Gujarat do we find the same repression as in that district.
('49', 247, 3, 5, 436613) There they arrest or release whom they like, beat up or abuse all and sundry.
('49', 247, 3, 6, 436691) People may be said to have remained fairly quiet and peaceful in spite of provocation.
('49', 247, 3, 7, 436778) But Kaka saheb observed some shortcomings also.
('49', 247, 3, 8, 436826) People submit to the rep ression but in their severe boycott of the Government men there is anger and ill will and hence violence.
('49', 247, 3, 9, 436957) They harass the Government officials in petty ways and call them names.
('49', 247, 3, 10, 437029) This is not the way to success.
('49', 247, 3, 11, 437061) We may denounce bureaucracy to our heart’s content, but not the men in office.
('49', 247, 3, 12, 437140) The poor officer is like any of us.
('49', 247, 3, 13, 437176) Time was when, if not we, our own kinsmen wanted to be Headmen or Mamlatdars and we flattered the Mamlatdars.
('49', 247, 3, 14, 437286) Now that our love of office is gone, how can we expect that theirs too should go?
('49', 247, 3, 15, 437368) It is true that it should go.
('49', 247, 3, 16, 437398) We should humbly try to cure them of their infatuation, and show them the evil that is there in the office of Mamlatdar or Sub Inspector of police, but in no way should we vent our anger on a Mamlatdar or a Sub Inspector of police.
('49', 247, 3, 17, 437630) No matter how severe our boycott, it should be full of sweetness and courtesy.
('49', 247, 3, 18, 437709) If it is not so, some day even a riot may break out.
('49', 247, 3, 19, 437762) The Mamlatdar or the Sub Inspector may cross the limits of decency.
('49', 247, 3, 20, 437830) One might say that the Sub Inspectors of Police have already crossed the limits, for I know that one of them insulted a person like Maganbhai Desai and manhandled him.
('49', 247, 3, 21, 437998) Would it be surprising, then, if people should similarly cross the limits?
('49', 247, 3, 22, 438073) If some regard it decent not to go beyond abusive speech, how can they blame others who draw the line at slapping the former?
('49', 247, 3, 23, 438199) And once violent hands are laid on another, where will it all end?
('49', 247, 3, 24, 438266) As things are still under control, it is time for the Kheda people to take heed and change things wherever necessary.
('49', 247, 3, 25, 438384) Within the limits I have laid down, they are free to continue the different boycotts they have put into effect.
('49', 247, 3, 26, 438496) Let me mention those limits.
('49', 247, 3, 27, 438525) The reader should go through and understand Kakasaheb’s article along with this.
('49', 247, 3, 28, 438606) Let us take a Headman as an example.
('49', 247, 3, 29, 438643) If the Headman belongs to the village, he cannot be deprived of his place of residence or denied provisions.
('49', 247, 3, 30, 438752) The boycott should be confined to his duties as Headman.
('49', 247, 3, 31, 438809) That is, his orders should not be carried out, not a drop of water demanded by virtue of his authority
('49', 248, 0, 1, 438912) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 249
('49', 248, 1, 2, 438954) should be given and no provisions demanded by him for the visiting officials should be supplied.
('49', 248, 1, 3, 439051) Should he, however, fall ill, we ought to serve him lovingly.
('49', 248, 1, 4, 439113) If we lack the power or the love to help him thus we should give up the boycott altogether.
('49', 248, 1, 5, 439205) Take it as gospel truth that if any boycott proceeds from a feeling of malice or enmity it will bring us no good, at any rate in our present struggle.
('49', 248, 1, 6, 439356) Some may say that this non violence is a difficult thing.
('49', 248, 1, 7, 439414) That is true.
('49', 248, 1, 8, 439428) And still non violence is as easy as it is difficult.
('49', 248, 1, 9, 439482) It is easy for those who understand it.
('49', 248, 1, 10, 439522) For others it is more difficult than even flying in the air.
('49', 248, 1, 11, 439583) It was because I was fully aware of this that I did not include in our programme the boycott of officials.
('49', 248, 1, 12, 439690) As the people themselves took it up, I have let it go on and even encouraged it in my speeches.
('49', 248, 1, 13, 439786) But I have always mentioned the limits within which it should be practised.
('49', 248, 1, 14, 439862) Nothing will be lost and it is still not too late, if the boycott is given up because the limits of non violent boycott cannot in practice be observed.
('49', 248, 1, 15, 440014) I ought to admit that I am unconcerned with defeat or success.
('49', 248, 1, 16, 440077) For I know that victory will come only with non violence and that, whatever the good results violent methods may seem to promise, ultimately they will bring defeat.
('49', 248, 1, 17, 440242) The ruddy cheeks of a tuberculous patient are not a sign of health, but a portent of imminent death.
('49', 248, 1, 18, 440343) This, however, is not my whole story.
('49', 248, 1, 19, 440381) It does not surprise me that people cannot digest the non violence that requires them to suffer beatings without demur.
('49', 248, 1, 20, 440501) And yet that is what our original pledge contains.
('49', 248, 1, 21, 440552) People have on occasion done quite well.
('49', 248, 1, 22, 440593) I know that when the Thakore of Dehvan in complicity with the police made an attack on the people, the people could have fought back but did not.
('49', 248, 1, 23, 440739) There have been several other occasions of the same kind, but people proved their fortitude by remaining quite peaceful.
('49', 248, 1, 24, 440860) They deserve to be congratulated on their conduct.
('49', 248, 1, 25, 440911) However, if they do not regard peaceful conduct as their duty but remain peaceful reluctantly, such peace will not last long.
('49', 248, 1, 26, 441037) People will either begin to run away or fight back in self defence, and both these are forbidden in our present struggle.
('49', 248, 1, 27, 441159) People can neither run away nor fight back.
('49', 248, 1, 28, 441203) The present struggle is one which requires us to learn the secret of living by dying.
('49', 248, 1, 29, 441289) No one has ever said so far that there is no victory in store for those prepared to face death.
('49', 248, 1, 30, 441385) Some there are who doubt whether the people have the capacity to die, but many no longer have that
('49', 249, 0, 1, 441484) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 249, 2, 2, 441522) It is possible to take the figures for the last World War and show that our loss in men and money during the four weeks of this struggle is only a fraction compared to that borne by each State participating in the terrible war in Europe.
('49', 249, 2, 3, 441760) And, moreover, we have advanced.
('49', 249, 2, 4, 441793) If our present struggle remains non violent to the very last, we shall win swaraj without having incurred, during our whole struggle, the loss in men and money incurred in a single day of the European War.
('49', 249, 2, 5, 441999) After this there should be no room for doubt.
('49', 249, 2, 6, 442045) And if doubt goes, the necessary climate of public spirit is certain to build up.
('49', 249, 2, 7, 442127) So much for social boycott.
('49', 249, 2, 8, 442155) Now about discipline.
('49', 249, 2, 9, 442177) If the volunteers lack the sense of discipline, we shall find ourselves in a difficult position.
('49', 249, 2, 10, 442274) In war discipline is everything.
('49', 249, 2, 11, 442307) At the time of the Crimean War, the officers of the British army committed such blunders that vast numbers of soldiers were killed.
('49', 249, 2, 12, 442439) The poor soldiers went on obeying the orders given and met their death.
('49', 249, 2, 13, 442511) The stupidity of the officers has been forgotten, but the bravery of the soldiers has been immortalized in the golden words of a famous poem by Tennyson.
('49', 249, 2, 14, 442665) This is how he enumerates the virtues of true soldiers:
('49', 249, 3, 15, 442721) Theirs not to make reply,
('49', 249, 4, 16, 442747) Theirs not to reason why,
('49', 249, 5, 17, 442773) Theirs but to do and die.
('49', 249, 6, 18, 442799) I feel that this is as it should be.
('49', 249, 6, 19, 442836) It does not mean that the true soldier suppresses his reason.
('49', 249, 6, 20, 442898) Before a man enlists in the army he should fully use his power of reason, know his commander and study the rules of service.
('49', 249, 6, 21, 443023) After this, if he discusses at every step the sub rules as and when they are framed, and if he weighs the pros and cons of the orders issued, his time would be wasted in thinking and arguing and the progress of work will be hindered.
('49', 249, 6, 22, 443257) If every soldier claims for himself the right to argue with the commander, the battle might be lost.
('49', 249, 6, 23, 443358) Therefore a soldier, having enlisted himself, should suspend his reason.
('49', 249, 6, 24, 443431) If after enlisting oneself as a soldier, one gives free rein to one’s reason and indulges in arguments on the subject of one’s duties, one’s reason will lose steadiness of purpose.
('49', 249, 6, 25, 443612) That would be misuse of reason.
('49', 249, 6, 26, 443644) Everyone in Kheda who understands this should carefully observe our rules of discipline.
('49', 249, 6, 27, 443733) Carding and spinning are essential aspects of this discipline.
('49', 250, 0, 1, 443796) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 251
('49', 250, 1, 2, 443838) volunteers who do not card and spin should leave this movement for swaraj.
('49', 250, 1, 3, 443913) Our motto is: ‘Swaraj through the thread of yarn.’ To those who have accepted the motto, it is no longer a subject of discussion, but a duty to be practised.
('49', 250, 1, 4, 444071) No matter if spinning does not seem necessary as part of the Salt Satyagraha; it is essential as part of the swaraj movement.
('49', 250, 1, 5, 444197) True the salt tax has not been removed; our struggle, however, is not merely for its abolition but for winning our freedom.
('49', 250, 1, 6, 444321) Just as carding and spinning are essential, so is being clad in khadi from head to foot.
('49', 250, 1, 7, 444410) This goes without saying.
('49', 250, 1, 8, 444436) The people of Kheda have been evincing boundless enthusiasm.
('49', 250, 1, 9, 444497) If that enthusiasm is pure and non violent, the peaceful activity of spinning is both its sign and its food.
('49', 250, 1, 10, 444606) Quiet enthusiasm is always constructive, and its opposite begins and ends only as a wave of excitement.
('49', 250, 1, 11, 444710) I have one thing in particular to add.
('49', 250, 1, 12, 444749) Not only Raas, but other villages also have taken the pledge of non payment of land revenue.
('49', 250, 1, 13, 444842) I like this pledge.
('49', 250, 1, 14, 444862) Those who keep it will make a name in Indian history as heroes.
('49', 250, 1, 15, 444926) But the consequences of the pledge need to be considered.
('49', 250, 1, 16, 444984) The person taking the pledge should be ready to let go his land, his homestead and his cattle, and do it without resorting to violence himself or through others.
('49', 250, 1, 17, 445146) He who has faith that we shall get swaraj will not let anything disturb him.
('49', 250, 1, 18, 445223) He is prepared to lose his land and his homestead.
('49', 250, 1, 19, 445274) Even if he loses them now, he will have them returned to him.
('49', 250, 1, 20, 445336) The Government can never appropriate them for all time.
('49', 250, 1, 21, 445392) But those who lack such faith should at present take no risk at all of non payment of the land revenue.
('49', 250, 1, 22, 445496) In the Congress programme at present there is no mention whatever of non payment of revenue, and hence one who pays up the tax has nothing to be ashamed of.
('49', 250, 1, 23, 445653) However, the man who has self confidence, who has the power to endure suffering, who can make sacrifices for his country or his com mander, such a person will, on his own responsibility, refuse to pay land revenue.
('49', 250, 1, 24, 445868) He has the right not to pay it.
('49', 250, 1, 25, 445900) [From Gujarati] Navajivan,4 5 1930
('49', 251, 0, 1, 445935) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 251, 2, 2, 445973) 258. LAWYERS’ DUTY
('49', 251, 3, 3, 445992) I have never minced words in criticizing lawyers.
('49', 251, 3, 4, 446042) Mahadev, during his short reign, castigated them to his heart’s content.
('49', 251, 3, 5, 446115) But the lawyers did not misunderstand him.
('49', 251, 3, 6, 446158) They saw that the shafts he aimed at them were shafts of love.
('49', 251, 3, 7, 446221) Though the lawyers deserve criticism, their contribution to the fight for freedom is no mean one.
('49', 251, 3, 8, 446319) Pherozeshah Mehta, the uncrowned king of Bombay, was an eminent lawyer.
('49', 251, 3, 9, 446391) The Lokamanya was a lawyer.
('49', 251, 3, 10, 446419) Manmohan Ghosh, Lalmohan Ghosh and Lalaji, the Lion of the Punjab, all of them were lawyers.
('49', 251, 3, 11, 446512) Deshbandhu, who sacrificed lakhs in the service of the country, was also a lawyer.
('49', 251, 3, 12, 446595) Motilalji, Malaviyaji, Vithalbhai Patel, Sardar, Jairamdas, Raj agopalachari, Prakasam, Venkatapayya, Santhanam, Munshi, Kamdar, Purushottamdas Trikumdas and Broker, all these are lawyers, and the President of the Congress himself is a lawyer.
('49', 251, 3, 13, 446839) This list is not exh austive.
('49', 251, 3, 14, 446869) I have mentioned only the names which occur to me at the moment, but many others can be mentioned.
('49', 251, 3, 15, 446968) The lawyers have, therefore, no reason to feel ashamed of their contribution, but there is none to feel elated either.
('49', 251, 3, 16, 447087) If despite the sacrifices of all these lawyers people speak ill of lawyers—even I have done so—there is reason for that.
('49', 251, 3, 17, 447208) People expect every lawyer to be a patriot, as they expect every Brahmin to possess spiritual knowledge.
('49', 251, 3, 18, 447313) A lawyer, by his very profession, is an advocate of people’s rights, an expert in law and politics and one who saves the victims of oppression by the State.
('49', 251, 3, 19, 447470) When, therefore, a class of people who should regard service of the country as their profession give themselves up to the pursuit of self interest, lead a life of self indulgence or have no other aim than making money by encouraging litigation, people naturally speak ill of them.
('49', 251, 3, 20, 447751) Though, taken absolutely, the number of patriotic lawyers named above will not appear insignificant, if we have regard to the total number of lawyers and the magnitude of their task, it will appear small indeed.
('49', 251, 3, 21, 447963) Lawyers have not remained untouched by the present awa kening.
('49', 251, 3, 22, 448026) The sacrifices of Shri Munshi and other lawyers stem from the present struggle.
('49', 251, 3, 23, 448106) I see that lawyers who dare not or cannot give up practice, still wish to do some service.
('49', 251, 3, 24, 448197) I hear that many lawyers in Bombay have stopped wearing hats and foreign clothes.
('49', 251, 3, 25, 448279) Some lawyers in Gujarat have come forward to investigate the cases of those against
('49', 252, 0, 1, 448363) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 253
('49', 252, 1, 2, 448405) whom atrocities are being committed.
('49', 252, 1, 3, 448442) All this is welcome indeed.
('49', 252, 1, 4, 448470) But, leaving aside the question of their giving up practice, the important thing is that they should come forward in large numbers to offer civil disobedience and remain undeterred if the courts cancel their sanads.
('49', 252, 1, 5, 448686) They cannot betray the country for the sake of their sanads.
('49', 252, 1, 6, 448747) If in consequence of their doing national work they lose their sanads, they should welcome this as if they had been cleansed of dirt.
('49', 252, 1, 7, 448881) If lawyers thus become fearless they can help the people of their districts in many ways.
('49', 252, 1, 8, 448971) If they shed fear, lawyers can 1. keep accounts of public funds; 2. explain legal intricacies to the people; 3. enquire into civil disobedience cases which have been arbitrarily dealt with and bring them to light; 4. be present at places where there is fear of violence; 5. explain to the people all cases of arbitrary use of authority; 6. enquire into injustices being perpetrated at present and point out to the public the Government’s misdeeds; 7. help in manufacturing khadi; 8. help the women in bringing about boycott of foreign cloth; 9. since in every province almost all the prominent leaders have been arrested, lawyers can lead the people and encourage the present spirit of fearlessness.
('49', 252, 1, 9, 449671) I have suggested these items only by way of illustration.
('49', 252, 1, 10, 449729) Those who are keen on doing service will think up many fields in which they may do it.
('49', 252, 2, 11, 449816) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 5 1930
('49', 253, 0, 1, 449852) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 253, 2, 2, 449890) 259. NOTES
('49', 253, 3, 3, 449901) PICKETING
('49', 253, 4, 4, 449911) The proprietor of a liquor booth in Ahmedabad thrashed inn ocent labourers who had committed no crime.
('49', 253, 4, 5, 450014) In Surat, foul abuses were hurled at women and clods of earth thrown at them.
('49', 253, 4, 6, 450092) In Jalalpur, they have started using filthy language towards women.
('49', 253, 4, 7, 450160) The women who endured all this deserve to be complimented.

('49', 254, 1, 2, 451646) 260. ATTACK ON PRINTING PRESSES
('49', 254, 2, 3, 451678) I hope that no one will be frightened by the sword which the Viceroy has hung over the printing presses.
('49', 254, 2, 4, 451783) It is the duty of the people to criticize the bureaucracy.
('49', 254, 2, 5, 451842) It is our duty to wish that it be destroyed, to commit civil disobedience, to persuade Government servants to give up their jobs and the recruits to leave the army, and to persuade the people to refuse to pay taxes when they have the strength to do that.
('49', 254, 2, 6, 452097) And yet, under the Government’s law, every one of these acts is an offence.
('49', 254, 2, 7, 452173) The new Ordinance notifies that the Government can seize any press which is guilty of any one of these offences.
('49', 254, 2, 8, 452286) Every editor and printer of a newspaper should regard it as a sin to obey such a law.
('49', 254, 2, 9, 452372) If at the present time, when the people have shed fear and are committing civil disobedience of immoral laws, editors of newspapers show weakness, they are bound to harm the cause of the country.
('49', 254, 2, 10, 452568) Any press, therefore, which is served with a notice to fur nish security should refuse to do so and prefer to close down the paper instead.
('49', 254, 2, 11, 452708) If all the presses act in this manner, the Government’s Ordinance will remain unenforced.
('49', 254, 2, 12, 452798) In this struggle full advantage is being taken of the help which newspapers can give, but it does not at all depend on such help.
('49', 254, 2, 13, 452928) People have realized their strength and know what they should do.
('49', 254, 2, 14, 452994) So there is little at present which newspapers can give them.
('49', 254, 2, 15, 453056) We may not get some news of distant places, but we can do without it.
('49', 254, 2, 16, 453126) I hope, therefore, that no press will furnish security.
('49', 254, 2, 17, 453182) If people observe this measure of self restraint, they will find that the new Ordinance does not remain in force for long.
('49', 254, 2, 18, 453305) Newspapers can be brought out hand written and, if people now feel a burning desire to work for the welfare of the country, countless such newspapers can be brought out every day.
('49', 254, 2, 19, 453485) If people really wish, they can make thousands of copies of hand written papers.
('49', 254, 2, 20, 453566) For instance, I may dictate the contents of one issue to fifty men at a time and distribute the copies to fifty persons.
('49', 254, 2, 21, 453687) The latter should then produce fifty copies each with the help of their friends.
('49', 254, 2, 22, 453768) We shall thus have 2,500 copies.
('49', 254, 2, 23, 453801) If these 2,500 copies repeat the process once again, how many copies would we get?
('49', 254, 2, 24, 453884) The poor at any rate would not object to doing this.
('49', 254, 2, 25, 453937) All that is necessary is to create such zeal in them.
('49', 254, 2, 26, 453991) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 5 1930

('49', 259, 4, 4, 460360) DEAR FRIEND, God willing, it is my intention on .

('49', 259, 4, 6, 460475) and demand possession of the Salt Works.

('49', 259, 4, 8, 460578) This is mere camouflage.
('49', 259, 4, 9, 460603) It is as effectively under Government control as the Viceroy’s House.
('49', 259, 4, 10, 460673) Not a pinch of salt can be removed without the previous sanction of the authorities.
('49', 259, 4, 11, 460758) It is possible for you to prevent this raid, as it has been playfully and mischievously called, in three ways: 1. by removing the salt tax; 2. by arresting me and my party unless the country can, as I hope it will, replace everyone taken away; 3. by sheer goondaism unless every head broken is replaced, as I hope it will.
('49', 259, 4, 12, 461081) It is not without hesitation that the step has been decided upon.
('49', 259, 4, 13, 461147) I had hoped that the Government would fight the civil resisters in a civilized manner.
('49', 259, 4, 14, 461234) I could have had nothing to say if in dealing with the civil resisters the Government had satisfied itself with applying the ordinary processes of law.
('49', 259, 4, 15, 461386) Instead, whilst the known leaders have been dealt with more or less according to the legal formality, the rank and file has been often savagely and in some cases even indecently assa ulted.
('49', 259, 4, 16, 461576) Had these been isolated cases, they might have been ove rlooked.

('49', 259, 4, 22, 462293) That the flag was subsequently restored betrayed a guilty conscience.
('49', 259, 4, 23, 462363) In Bengal there seem to have been only a few prosecutions and assaults about salt, but unthinkable cruelties are said to have been practised in the act

('49', 261, 2, 20, 467485) I have said also that every violent act, word and even thought interferes with the progress of non violent action.
('49', 261, 2, 21, 467600) If in spite of such repeated warnings people will resort to violence, I must disown resp onsibility save such as inevitably attaches to every human being for the acts of every other human being.
('49', 261, 2, 22, 467795) But the question of respon sibility apart, I dare not postpone action on any cause whatsoever, if non violence is the force the seers of the world have claimed it to be and if I am not to belie my own extensive experience of its working.
('49', 261, 2, 23, 468033) But I would fain avoid the further step.

('49', 264, 8, 16, 471591) 268. INTERVIEW TO J. B. KRIPALANI 2
('49', 264, 9, 17, 471627) May 4, 1930
('49', 264, 10, 18, 471639) Mahatmaji had anticipated the situation which had arisen today.
('49', 264, 10, 19, 471703) He had fully expected that his lieutenants would be taken from him and he was glad to observe that the younger folks had kept up their spirits and were yearning for more work.
('49', 264, 10, 20, 471879) He was, however, most anxious that this energy should be harnessed to the utmost in constructive work.
('49', 264, 10, 21, 471982) If the Government did not arrest the volunteers, Mahatmaji felt they should engage themselves in constructive work, such as producing more yarn and carrying on intensive propaganda to popularize the charkha and the takli.
('49', 264, 10, 22, 472204) He also wanted them to learn to live the camp life, and to live like soldiers.
('49', 264, 10, 23, 472283) The soldiers did their own cleaning and polishing and engaged in mock fights and other healthy sports and the volunteers also should do so.
('49', 264, 10, 24, 472423) Volunteers should not lose sight of drilling.
('49', 264, 10, 25, 472469) Discipline, Mahatmaji felt, would be half the battle won.
('49', 264, 11, 26, 472527) 1 On heating of the arrest of Lala ShamlaI of Rohtak, the addressee with Gandhiji’s permission, had gone to Punjab in April; vide also.
('49', 264, 11, 27, 472663) “Letter to Lala Dunichand”, 6 4 1930. 2 Based on a report of the interview.
('49', 264, 11, 28, 472739) J. B. Kripalani had met Gandhiji a few hours before the latter’s arrest.
('49', 265, 0, 1, 472812) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 265, 2, 2, 472850) Mahatmaji felt that it was the Government game not to arrest the rank and file of law breakers but to tire them out.
('49', 265, 2, 3, 472967) He wanted the volunteers not to play into the Government’s hands by losing their patience.
('49', 265, 2, 4, 473058) He wanted them to carry on the work in every branch of national regeneration, namely, production of khaddar and more khaddar to replace foreign cloth.
('49', 265, 2, 5, 473209) He also wanted the volunteers to engage themselves in an intensive prohibition programme by propaganda, picketing and felling of date trees.
('49', 265, 2, 6, 473350) It was not necessary that women alone should do all this, especially in the United Provinces and Bihar, where there are very few women.
('49', 265, 2, 7, 473486) In provinces like Bihar and U.P., Mahatmaji wanted that women should be helped by men.
('49', 265, 2, 8, 473573) He felt that the initiative in these provinces should be taken by men.
('49', 265, 2, 9, 473644) Mahatmaji also felt that the people could select other laws also to break wherever they could conveniently do so without prejudice to the salt laws.
('49', 265, 2, 10, 473793) Mahatmaji also felt that this should be the case particularly in the provinces in which salt could not be produced on an economic basis, or where there were no facilities to manufacture salt.
('49', 265, 2, 11, 473985) Mahatmaji had in view in this connection, the Chaukidari Tax in Bihar and the Forest Laws in the Central Provinces.
('49', 265, 2, 12, 474101) Mahatmaji also felt .
('49', 265, 2, 13, 474123) that Dharasana would supply many volunteers with work, as volunteers from other parts of the country might be required if the Gove rnment were to effect the arrest of the “raiders”.
('49', 265, 2, 14, 474305) Mahatmaji saw the possibility of another Gurukabag at Dharasana.
('49', 265, 2, 15, 474370) He also felt that the stage had come when those who could do constructive work need not court jail.
('49', 265, 2, 16, 474470) If the present enthusiasm were to be utilized for the lasting good of the country, it must be directed into constructive channels even as the electric current generated by a dynamo.
('49', 265, 2, 17, 474652) Regarding picketing, Acharya Kripalani said that he had narrated to Mahatmaji his experiences of picketing of shops, which contained both foreign and swadeshi cloth.
('49', 265, 2, 18, 474818) He explained how some merchants dumped on the market mill cloth as khaddar.
('49', 265, 2, 19, 474894) In reply, Mahatmaji said that he had expected that picketing would not be quite effective but it was necessary to create an atmosphere for swadeshi, which could suc ceed only by the production of khaddar on a mass scale.
('49', 265, 2, 20, 475115) Will agents, he said, could help if they co operated with the political workers, and themselves helped in the production of khaddar by refraining from producing cloth below a particular count, which could be left to hand spinning.
('49', 265, 2, 21, 475346) In this connection, Mahatmaji said he had many talks with Seth Ambalal Sarabhai and Mr. Birla.
('49', 265, 2, 22, 475441) Mr. Birla had understood his point of view, and had decided to open a khadi organization near his village in Marwar under his own supervision.
('49', 265, 2, 23, 475584) Seth Ambalal Sarabhai also had very nearly understood his point; but it looked as if other mill owners only wanted to use him (Gandhiji) as their advertising agent.
('49', 265, 2, 24, 475749) Mahatmaji was apprehensive that unless there was extensive spinning taken on hand at once the swadeshi movement would fail in the absence of production and it would be possible for merchants to cheat the public.
('49', 265, 2, 25, 475961) When once the public discerned that they were paying higher prices for doubtful stuff, their confidence in the national workers would be so shaken that they would cease to listen to them and even would fight them.
('49', 266, 0, 1, 476175) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 267
('49', 266, 1, 2, 476217) Therefore, the only possible way for the mill owners to fight Lancashire and Japan was to co operate with the nationalist workers by refusing to spin yarn below a particular count and, what was also equally important, by controlling the prices.
('49', 266, 1, 3, 476462) The Hindu, 14 5 1930
('49', 266, 2, 4, 476483) 269. SPEECH AT SURAT
('49', 266, 3, 5, 476504) May 4, 1930 It is not by means of the power of intellect that people are able to observe vows they take.
('49', 266, 3, 6, 476609) 1 There must be a thorough change of heart and faith in God, which alone could give them the necessary strength.
('49', 266, 3, 7, 476722) I have been defeated in prohibition campaign as a man and therefore I have asked women to help the movement.
('49', 266, 3, 8, 476831) If anybody could melt the heart of drunkards it is woman.
('49', 266, 3, 9, 476889) I have often asked Ministers in charge of Excise Department to put a stop to drink traffic.
('49', 266, 3, 10, 476981) They have replied that I must find out for them new sources of revenue.
('49', 266, 3, 11, 477053) I have told them to stop giving education to boys but they would not adopt the suggestion.
('49', 266, 3, 12, 477144) If in swaraj we have liquor traffic, our President will have to face a similar problem afterwards.
('49', 266, 3, 13, 477243) We are also not as adventurous as Americans, who are successfully making America dry.
('49', 266, 3, 14, 477329) We have become emasculated and therefore I appeal to you to tackle this question first.
('49', 266, 3, 15, 477417) The present time is the most opportune and auspicious.
('49', 266, 3, 16, 477472) I appeal to you with all earnestness to observe the vows you have taken.
('49', 266, 3, 17, 477545) Do not deceive me; if you are unable to give up drinking, say so openly; I will congratulate you even then.
('49', 266, 3, 18, 477653) My own son confesses honestly that he is not able to give up the drinking habit, and I congratulate him on his truthfulness.
('49', 266, 3, 19, 477778) Even so you must be truthful so that I may not mis calculate.
('49', 266, 3, 20, 477840) God alone will help him, my son, and you, who are unable to give up drink.
('49', 266, 3, 21, 477915) If you deceive me, you deceive your community and the whole country.
('49', 266, 4, 22, 477984) Referring to the insult offered to some women picketers at some places Gandhiji said that if they had not considered women as low creatures working for men and as objects of their lust then nobody could have dared to raise a finger against them.
('49', 266, 4, 23, 478230) But even if they will stone them, they will continue picketing.
('49', 266, 4, 24, 478294) “Pussyfoot” lost his eye in anti drink propaganda to make America dry, but did not give up his campaign.
('49', 266, 4, 25, 478399) India will have to answer for every insult offered to women.
('49', 266, 4, 26, 478460) This is my last throw; and I am out to lose my all.
('49', 266, 4, 27, 478512) But all this I do for the liberation of India.
('49', 266, 4, 28, 478559) If one district
('49', 266, 5, 29, 478575) 1 Panchayats of Surat city had passed resolutions asking members of their respective communities not to drink liquor.
('49', 267, 0, 1, 478693) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 267, 2, 2, 478731) is ready, we will surely have swaraj.
('49', 267, 2, 3, 478769) You must purify yourself, you must be industrious; there is no other way for achieving swaraj.

('49', 268, 1, 2, 480021) 272. LETTER TO SATYAGRAHA COMMITTEE, BOMBAY
('49', 268, 2, 3, 480065) [Before May 5, 1930] Friends from Bombay have been to me asking me to lead a raiding party from there instead of from Karadi, assuming of course that a raid is to be decided upon.
('49', 268, 2, 4, 480245) I should be proud and consider it a privilege to lead it provided that certain preliminary conditions are fulfilled.
('49', 268, 2, 5, 480362) I observe that there is a great deal of misunderstanding about this contemplated raid.
('49', 268, 2, 6, 480449) It has arisen because of the use of the word “raid”.
('49', 268, 2, 7, 480502) Now all my speeches in Gujarat are invariably delivered in Gujarati.
('49', 268, 2, 8, 480571) The word “raid” therefore is not the one I had used.
('49', 268, 2, 9, 480624) I admit, however, that it is a legitimate translation of the original.
('49', 268, 2, 10, 480695) But my audience knew the original word “dhad” used to alliterate with “dhar” in “Dharasana”, was used playfully.
('49', 268, 2, 11, 480808) Fortunately or unfortunately even for a non violent war military expressions have got to be used.
('49', 268, 2, 12, 480906) But even as nobody is deceived by the use of such military expressions, no one need be perturbed over the use of the word “raid” when it is to be civil, non violent or satyagrahi.
('49', 268, 2, 13, 481086) The use of that potent adjective alters the whole colour of the transaction.
('49', 268, 2, 14, 481163) But however innocent the raid, if it ever comes into being, may be, it will be fraught with consequences perhaps far more serious than those flowing from a violent raid.
('49', 268, 2, 15, 481333) Those, therefore, who would join the contemplated raid have to satisfy some test, and since the battle is meant not merely for the removal of the salt tax but for establishing Purna Swaraj, the conditions have to be in keeping with the objective.
('49', 268, 2, 16, 481580) They are three: 1. Observance of complete discipline.
('49', 268, 2, 17, 481634) 2. Complete abstention from drink under a permanent pledge.
('49', 268, 2, 18, 481694) 3. Wearing of hand spun khaddar also under a permanent pledge and actual spinning on the takli for one hour per day except when spinning is made impossible through want of time or capacity.
('49', 268, 2, 19, 481884) If Bombay produces a hundred thousand such men I should lead them without the slightest hesitation.
('49', 268, 2, 20, 481984) I know that the citizens of Bombay will not laugh at my conditions nor will they consider them impossible of fulfilment.
('49', 268, 2, 21, 482105) The only difficulty they might feel will be about the takli.
('49', 268, 2, 22, 482166) Surely if a hundred thousand men in Bombay have the will takli spinning is child’s play.
('49', 268, 2, 23, 482255) Sustained work from day to day may be a task for easy going citizens of Bombay but Freedom’s battle has never been won by easy going people.
('49', 268, 2, 24, 482396) No one need be irritated against me for maintaining these conditions because they are not in
('49', 269, 0, 1, 482489) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 269, 2, 2, 482527) any sense obligatory; they are meant to be a consideration in a voluntary contract.
('49', 269, 2, 3, 482611) It is open to the citizens of Bombay to reject my terms and do as they please.
('49', 269, 2, 4, 482690) Rejection then of terms will not make them less Congressmen than they are today.
('49', 269, 2, 5, 482771) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 5 1930
('49', 269, 3, 6, 482802) 273. ARREST AT MIDNIGHT
('49', 269, 4, 7, 482826) KARADI, May 5, 1930
('49', 269, 5, 8, 482846) The Magistrate proceeded to Gandhiji’s hut and woke him up.
('49', 269, 5, 9, 482906) 1 “I have a warrant for your arrest, Mr. Gandhi,” said the Magistrate.
('49', 269, 5, 10, 482977) Gandhiji asked politely: I am not surprised, but will you read out the warrant to me?
('49', 269, 6, 11, 483063) The Magistrate complied with this request and read the following which was signed by Sir Frederick Sykes, Governor of Bombay.
('49', 269, 7, 12, 483189) “Whereas the Government view with alarm the activities of Mr. M. K. Gandhi, they direct that he should be placed under restraint under Regulation 25 of 1827 and suffer imprisonment during the pleasure of the Government and be immediately removed to the Yeravda Central Jail.”
('49', 269, 8, 13, 483465) Gandhiji was smiling when the warrant was being read.
('49', 269, 8, 14, 483519) He said: I am prepared to accompany you, but will you allow me to have a wash and clean my teeth?
('49', 269, 9, 15, 483617) “With pleasure,” said the Magistrate.
('49', 269, 10, 16, 483655) In the meantime, the whole Ashram was up, and everyone was anxious to have a parting ‘darshan’ of Gandhiji.
('49', 269, 10, 17, 483763) Having finished his wash, Gandhiji came out of the cottage to say his prayers.
('49', 269, 10, 18, 483842) The whole Ashram knelt down to recite the prayers while the police officers watched.
('49', 269, 10, 19, 483927) Gandhiji himself led the chorus.
('49', 269, 10, 20, 483960) He then collected his papers and gave them in charge of a volunteer whom he had chosen as Captain during his incarceration.
('49', 269, 10, 21, 484084) The Bombay Chronicle, 6 5 1930
('49', 269, 11, 22, 484115) 1 The District Magistrate accompanied by the Superintendent of Police and a party of 20 armed constables arrived at Gandhiji’s camp at 12.45 a.m., when Gandhiji was asleep.

('49', 270, 1, 2, 484330) 274. INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY TELEGRAPH”
('49', 270, 2, 3, 484370) BORIVLI, May 5, 1930 Gandhi seemed surprised when he saw my companion and myself, for both of us were known to him.
('49', 270, 2, 4, 484486) He greeted us in the most friendly manner.
('49', 270, 3, 5, 484529) “Have you a farewell message you would like to give, Mr. Gandhi?” I asked.
('49', 270, 3, 6, 484604) He replied: Shall I give it now or shall I wait?
('49', 270, 4, 7, 484653) “You had better give it now,” I replied.
('49', 270, 4, 8, 484694) He paused, seeming to be at a loss for words and somewhat dazed by events.
('49', 270, 4, 9, 484769) Then he answered: Tell the people of America to study the issues closely and to judge them on their merits.
('49', 270, 5, 10, 484877) “Have you any bitterness or ill will towards anyone?” I asked.
('49', 270, 5, 11, 484940) None whatsoever; I had long expected to be arrested.
('49', 270, 6, 12, 484993) Do you think your arrest will lead to great disturbances throughout India?
('49', 270, 6, 13, 485068) No, I do not; in any case I can honestly say that I have taken every possible precaution to avert disturbances.
('49', 270, 6, 14, 485180) Then you anticipate no troubles?
('49', 270, 6, 15, 485213) The Mahatma hesitated for a moment and then replied: I hope not; I have done my best to prevent them.
('49', 270, 7, 16, 485315) At this point the law intervened.
('49', 270, 7, 17, 485349) Inspector Gordon stepped forward, saying; “Now, Mr. Gandhi, if you are ready, please.” Only one person accompanied Gandhi from the train, a doctor of the Indian Medical Service, who remained silent in the background.
('49', 270, 7, 18, 485566) He now took his seat alongside the prophet, with Inspector Gordon sitting by the chauffeur.
('49', 270, 8, 19, 485658) The Hindu, 27 5 1930
('49', 270, 9, 20, 485679) 1 Gandhiji was escorted in a train to Borivli, a suburban station of Bombay, and from there taken by car to Yeravda.

('49', 272, 1, 2, 486790) 276. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE 1
('49', 272, 2, 3, 486819) YERAVDA, May 10, 1930
('49', 272, 3, 4, 486841) DEAR MAJOR DOYLE,
('49', 272, 4, 5, 486859) Having thought over our conversation, I have come to the con clusion that I must avoid, as much as possible, the special privileges offered to me by the Government!
('49', 272, 4, 6, 487024) Books and newspapers I do not want through the Government.
('49', 272, 4, 7, 487083) Of newspapers, I would send for these if permitted: The Bombay Chronicle, The Times of India, Indian Social Reformer, Modern Review, Young India and Navajivan (Hindi and Gujarati).
('49', 272, 4, 8, 487264) If these are allowed, I take it that they will not be mutilated.
('49', 272, 4, 9, 487329) The Government have suggested Rs. 100 as monthly allowance.
('49', 272, 4, 10, 487389) I hope I shall need nothing near it.
('49', 272, 4, 11, 487426) I know that my food is a costly affair.
('49', 272, 4, 12, 487466) It grieves me, but it has become a physical necessity with me.
('49', 272, 4, 13, 487529) Neither you nor the Government will, I hope, consider me ungrateful for not accepting all the facilities offered to me.
('49', 272, 4, 14, 487649) It is an obsession (if it is to be so called) with me that we are all living at the expense of the toiling semi starved millions.
('49', 272, 4, 15, 487779) I know too that the saving caused by my economy can but be an infinitesimal drop in the limitless ocean of waste I see going on round me, whether in prison or outside of it—much more out of it.
('49', 272, 4, 16, 487973) I admit nevertheless it is given to man only to do very little.
('49', 272, 4, 17, 488037) He dare not omit to do that little.
('49', 272, 4, 18, 488073) Again, I hold radical views about prison treatment.
('49', 272, 4, 19, 488125) I have never taken kindly to the classification recently made.
('49', 272, 4, 20, 488188) I hold that a murderer is just as much entitled to have his needs supplied as any other prisoner.
('49', 272, 4, 21, 488286) What is therefore needed is not a mechanical makeshift, but a human adjustment.
('49', 272, 5, 22, 488366) 1 The text of this was communicated by Doyle to the Home Department on May
('49', 273, 0, 1, 488441) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 274
('49', 273, 1, 2, 488483) One thing I must mention.
('49', 273, 1, 3, 488509) I do feel the necessity of contact with the satyagrahi prisoners who are in this jail.
('49', 273, 1, 4, 488596) It is wholly unnecessary, it is cruel, to isolate me from them.
('49', 273, 2, 5, 488660) Yours truly,
('49', 273, 3, 6, 488673) M. K. GANDHI

('49', 273, 5, 8, 488737) 277. LETTER TO MIRABEHN 1
('49', 273, 6, 9, 488763) YERAVDA, May 12, 1930
('49', 273, 7, 10, 488785) MIRA, Yours is the first letter I take up to write from the jail and that on the silence day.
('49', 273, 7, 11, 488879) I have been quite happy and have been making up for arrears of rest.
('49', 273, 7, 12, 488948) The nights here are cool and as I am permitted to sleep right under the sky, I have refreshing sleep.
('49', 273, 7, 13, 489050) About the change made in the manner of taking the diet, you will learn from my general letter.
('49', 273, 7, 14, 489145) It was a great treat to receive the wheel so thoughtfully sent and with things so carefully packed in it.
('49', 273, 7, 15, 489251) The carding bow, the Sup erintendent tells me, was lost on the way by the friends who brought it.
('49', 273, 7, 16, 489349) I am in no hurry for it as you have sent me a liberal quantity of slivers.
('49', 273, 7, 17, 489424) I do not know who sent me the books.
('49', 273, 7, 18, 489461) They are not what I wanted.
('49', 273, 7, 19, 489489) They were to be sent back to the library.
('49', 273, 7, 20, 489531) The list of books that were to be sent to me when I was arrested was given by me to Kusum.
('49', 273, 7, 21, 489622) But I suppose she left the Ashram without giving instructions to anybody as to what was to be sent or, if she did, she gave wrong instructions.
('49', 273, 7, 22, 489766) However this mistake does not matter much as I do not miss the books just now.
('49', 273, 7, 23, 489845) I am giving as much time as I can to the takli.
('49', 273, 7, 24, 489893) I find that I have no speed on it at all.
('49', 273, 7, 25, 489935) I hardly get thirty rounds in one hour.
('49', 273, 7, 26, 489975) For the first day I gave nearly seven hours to nearly reach 160 rounds.
('49', 273, 7, 27, 490047) I was washed out at the end of the performances.
('49', 273, 7, 28, 490096) I must learn the trick of getting more speed.

('49', 274, 4, 7, 490635) 278. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 274, 5, 8, 490666) [May 12, 1930] 1
('49', 274, 6, 9, 490683) NARANDAS, Show this letter to all, so that I need not write about the same things to everyone.
('49', 274, 6, 10, 490778) Most probably I shall be able to write to you and you will be able to send a reply once a week.
('49', 274, 6, 11, 490874) I keep excellent health.
('49', 274, 6, 12, 490899) I get up in the morning and go through the routine according to the Ashram rules.
('49', 274, 6, 13, 490981) There is a light in the room so that, according to my rule, I can read chapters from the Gita.
('49', 274, 6, 14, 491076) I have been resting after many days of fatigue and, therefore, must be sleeping for probably two or three hours during the day.
('49', 274, 6, 15, 491204) Generally I sleep at eight in the morning and twelve at noon.
('49', 274, 6, 16, 491266) I have resumed eating oranges, which I had given up during the march.
('49', 274, 6, 17, 491336) On the first day I took cold milk, and I have continued it for the time being.
('49', 274, 6, 18, 491415) I take about three seers.
('49', 274, 6, 19, 491441) Probably I shall have to reduce the quantity a little.
('49', 274, 6, 20, 491496) Or I may have some of it made into curds.
('49', 274, 6, 21, 491538) In the morning, too, I drink cold water instead of hot water.
('49', 274, 6, 22, 491600) This I do only as an experiment.
('49', 274, 6, 23, 491633) The authorities have of course supplied the facilities for heating water, etc.
('49', 274, 6, 24, 491712) If, however, I can preserve my health with cold water, why should I go to the trouble of heating it?
('49', 274, 6, 25, 491813) I have given up honey.
('49', 274, 6, 26, 491836) Even for bathing I have been using cold water, but I intend to change over to hot water from tomorrow.
('49', 274, 6, 27, 491939) The goat is brought before me and milked in my presence, so that the milk is as clean as I would like it to be.
('49', 274, 6, 28, 492051) If cold milk does not suit me, I will certainly heat it.
