('49', 283, 1, 2, 501724) 288. LETTER TO VICEROY
('49', 283, 2, 3, 501747) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, May 18, 1930 1
('49', 283, 3, 4, 501786) H. E. THE VICEROY OF INDIA
('49', 283, 4, 5, 501813) DEAR FRIEND, The authorities having permitted the use of newspapers, I am able somewhat to follow the course of events in the country.
('49', 283, 4, 6, 501948) I should fail in my duty if I did not express my opinion on your latest statement.
('49', 283, 5, 7, 502031) You seem to ignore the simple fact that disobedience ceases to be such immediately masses of people resort to it.
('49', 283, 5, 8, 502145) Do you not see that hundreds of men who have been known for their peaceful nature, who have an unbroken record of service to their credit 3 and whose integrity is beyond suspicion are imprisoned?
('49', 283, 5, 9, 502341) They are no law breakers; they are no haters of the English.
('49', 283, 5, 10, 502402) And what of the most peaceful demon stration of thousands of simple villagers who are by instinct the most law abiding?
('49', 283, 5, 11, 502522) To describe the movement of such men and women as lawlessness is, in my opinion, doing violence to the language.
('49', 283, 5, 12, 502635) The very motive which is the essence of crime is lacking.
('49', 283, 5, 13, 502693) It is the noblest of motives which 4 takes away men like the hoary headed Abbas Tyabji from their soft ease to court the hardships of a jail life.
('49', 283, 6, 14, 502840) You protest your affection for India.
('49', 283, 6, 15, 502878) I believe in your profession.
('49', 283, 6, 16, 502908) But I deny the correctness of your diagnosis of India’s disease.
('49', 283, 6, 17, 502973) The best constitution that can be devised will fail to bring real contentment and peace unless the grievances on which public attention is conc entrated are immediately removed.
('49', 283, 6, 18, 503151) The salt tax cannot remain.
('49', 283, 6, 19, 503179) The liquor revenue must go.
('49', 283, 6, 20, 503207) The foreign cloth importation which has produced a partial paralysis of the village life must be stopped.
('49', 283, 6, 21, 503313) Have you not noted the strength of popular feeling in these matters?
('49', 283, 6, 22, 503382) Or are the hundreds of thousands of men and
('49', 283, 7, 23, 503426) 1 The letter was drafted on May 12, finalized on May 18 and handed to the Superintendent, Major Martin, the following day.
('49', 283, 7, 24, 503549) 2 On May 12, announcing that steps were being taken to hold the Round Table Conference in October, the Viceroy had declared: “Neither my Government nor His Majesty’s Government will be deflected by these unhappy events from our firm determination to abide by the policy I was privileged to announce in November last.” 3 The draft did not have the words: “to their credit”.
('49', 283, 7, 25, 503922) 4 The draft has “that”.
('49', 283, 7, 26, 503946) 5 Abbas Tyabji was arrested on May 12.
('49', 284, 0, 1, 503985) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 285
('49', 284, 1, 2, 504027) women who are taking part in the movement wicked minded or misled or fools and the English officials the best judges of what is good for India?
('49', 284, 1, 3, 504171) If I am not mistaken, you will find the spirit of the people to be proof against repression, no matter how severe 1 it may be.
('49', 284, 1, 4, 504298) You will not coerce millions of people into subjection for all time.
('49', 284, 1, 5, 504367) India must not live for England.
('49', 284, 1, 6, 504400) She must live for herself, so as to en able her to make her contribution to the world’s progress.
('49', 284, 1, 7, 504498) As a slave nation she is a mere burden on earth because it is a false life.

('49', 286, 2, 3, 506886) Silence Day [May 19, 1930] 1
('49', 286, 3, 4, 506915) GANGABEHN,
('49', 286, 4, 5, 506926) I remember every day all the women and the children, but I do not worry about anything.
('49', 286, 4, 6, 507014) Here, too, I keep myself busy and do not remain unoccupied even for a minute.
('49', 286, 4, 7, 507092) That way alone can I have peace of mind.
('49', 286, 4, 8, 507133) I can see God only through work.
('49', 286, 4, 9, 507166) The Lord says that He is ever working without taking a moment’s rest.
('49', 286, 4, 10, 507236) How else, then, can we know Him except through work?
('49', 286, 4, 11, 507289) If you do not read the translation of the Gita and if you have time, read it.
('49', 286, 4, 12, 507367) If, however, you have no time, you need not read it.
('49', 286, 4, 13, 507420) Devotion to duty is the living Gita; the other one is merely a book.
('49', 286, 4, 14, 507489) I have written to as many persons as I could.
('49', 286, 4, 15, 507535) But I do think of even those men and women to whom I have not written.
('49', 286, 4, 16, 507606) How can I possibly write to all?
('49', 286, 4, 17, 507639) I write to those who I feel specially need some words of comfort from me.

('49', 286, 4, 21, 507824) He ought to visit the Ashram occasionally.

('49', 289, 1, 2, 509893) 296. INTERVIEW TO “ DAILY HERALD” 1
('49', 289, 2, 3, 509929) May 20, 1930
('49', 289, 3, 4, 509942) Our conversation began with a general exchange of ideas on British and Indian
('49', 289, 4, 5, 510020) politics.
('49', 289, 4, 6, 510030) I then asked him to explain frankly what he meant by Independence.
('49', 289, 5, 7, 510097) demand Independence as ultimately implied in Dominion Status?
('49', 289, 5, 8, 510159) Or did he insist on
('49', 289, 6, 9, 510179) separation from the British Commonwealth?
('49', 289, 7, 10, 510221) I have always heard that in England Dominion Status is understood to mean Independence, but by the Indian authorities it is not so understood.
('49', 289, 7, 11, 510364) Therefore when Independence is resisted by them in contradistinction to Dominion Status we naturally asked for Independence.
('49', 289, 8, 12, 510489) When I asked him if he thought that Canada and South Africa were not in all
('49', 289, 9, 13, 510565) essential respects independent, he acknowledged they were.
('49', 289, 9, 14, 510624) He added significantly:
('49', 289, 10, 15, 510648) But we are not offered a status like theirs.
('49', 289, 11, 16, 510693) I asked him if he had calculated all the perils involved in his campaign of civil disobedience.
('49', 289, 11, 17, 510789) He replied that he had:
('49', 289, 12, 18, 510813) I have taken what has been called a mad risk.
('49', 289, 12, 19, 510859) But it is a justifiable risk.
('49', 289, 12, 20, 510889) No great end has been achieved without incurring danger.
('49', 289, 13, 21, 510946) Nevertheless he was gravely alarmed at the violence said to have been
('49', 289, 14, 22, 511016) committed at Sholapur.
('49', 289, 14, 23, 511039) He grieved at the death of two policemen killed there, but he
('49', 289, 15, 24, 511101) was convinced the violence had not come from the civil resisters.
('49', 289, 15, 25, 511167) They had, he said,
('49', 289, 16, 26, 511186) been ordered to suffer everything, even violence, without offering resistance.
('49', 289, 17, 27, 511265) I asked if he thought that in a struggle between law breakers and the authorities Government could acknowledge defeat, and Gandhi smiled.
('49', 289, 17, 28, 511403) He said:
('49', 289, 18, 29, 511412) I am an optimist.
('49', 289, 18, 30, 511430) In forty years of struggle I have frequently been told I was attempting the impossible, but invariably I proved the contrary.
('49', 289, 19, 31, 511556) Nevertheless he did not refuse to negotiate.
('49', 289, 20, 32, 511601) My life has been nothing but a record of settlements.
('49', 289, 20, 33, 511655) If the Government is in earnest in its desire to satisfy India it should grant the eleven points demanded in my last letter to the Viceroy.
('49', 289, 21, 34, 511795) 1 The interviewer was George Slocombe.
('49', 290, 0, 1, 511834) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 291
('49', 290, 1, 2, 511876) I can only judge the tree by its fruits.
('49', 290, 1, 3, 511917) Until we get satisfaction we shall fight on until the end, and give our lives if need be in the cause of Indian freedom.
('49', 290, 1, 4, 512038) We shall fill all the jails in India with our passive resisters and our breakers of the salt laws, and we shall make all administration impossible by our opposition.
('49', 290, 2, 5, 512204) Mr. Gandhi admitted, however, that even in the remote event of victory
('49', 290, 3, 6, 512275) negotiation would still be necessary, and he was prepared to do anything to avoid
('49', 290, 4, 7, 512357) bloodshed and suffering if the essential cause of Indian nationalism did not lose
('49', 290, 5, 8, 512439) thereby.
('49', 290, 6, 9, 512448) From our subsequent conversation I gathered that even at this critical hour a
('49', 290, 7, 10, 512526) settlement is possible and that Mr. Gandhi is prepared to recommend to Congress the
('49', 290, 8, 11, 512610) suspension of the Civil Disobedience Movement and co operation in the Round Table
('49', 290, 9, 12, 512692) Conference on the following terms:
('49', 290, 10, 13, 512727) (1) The terms of reference of the Round Table Conference to include the
('49', 290, 11, 14, 512799) framing of a Constitution giving India “the substance of independence”.
('49', 290, 12, 15, 512871) (2) Satisfaction to be granted to Mr. Gandhi’s demands for the repeal of the
('49', 290, 13, 16, 512948) salt tax, the prohibition of liquor, and a ban on foreign cloth.
('49', 290, 14, 17, 513013) (3) An amnesty for prisoners convicted of political offences to coincide with
('49', 290, 15, 18, 513091) the end of the Civil Disobedience campaign.
('49', 290, 16, 19, 513135) (4) The remaining seven points raised in Mr. Gandhi’s letter to the Viceroy to
('49', 290, 17, 20, 513214) be left for future discussion.
('49', 290, 18, 21, 513245) The Bombay Chronicle, 23 5 1930

('49', 291, 1, 2, 513319) 297. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 291, 2, 3, 513350) YERAVDA MANDIR, May 18/21, 1930
('49', 291, 3, 4, 513382) NARANDAS,
('49', 291, 4, 5, 513392) The letter I wrote to you last Monday seems to have been posted as late as Friday.
('49', 291, 4, 6, 513475) That is what a jail is, after all.
('49', 291, 4, 7, 513510) See that my letters are not published.
('49', 291, 4, 8, 513549) Write to Thakkar Bapa and inquire whether the work on wells for Antyajas is proceeding.
('49', 291, 4, 9, 513637) If he is short of funds, give him some money from what is lying with us, that is, from the money which we have handed over to Jamnalalji.
('49', 291, 4, 10, 513775) My hours are divided as follows:
('49', 291, 5, 11, 513808) Brushing the teeth, lavatory, bath 2 hours Prayers, twice 1 hour Nap during day time 1_ hours Meals and preparation for them 3 hours Repairing the spinning wheel, blowing and spraying the yarn, etc.
('49', 291, 5, 12, 514007) 3_ hours Spinning on the takli 2_ hours Walking in the yard 1_ hours Reading, meeting the Jailor 2 hours From 4 a.m.
('49', 291, 5, 13, 514124) to 9 p.m.
('49', 291, 5, 14, 514134) 17 hours I discovered from experience that oranges were not necessary.
('49', 291, 5, 15, 514205) I have, therefore, given them up for the present.
('49', 291, 5, 16, 514255) This means that my diet consists of dates, raisins, milk and curds, and sour lime and soda bicarb.
('49', 291, 5, 17, 514354) If I find it necessary to do so, I will include oranges.
('49', 291, 5, 18, 514411) I found today that by adding a fairly good quantity of curd to unboiled milk, we get well formed curd.
('49', 291, 5, 19, 514514) Yesterday I had mixed curd in unboiled milk.
('49', 291, 5, 20, 514559) I still take unboiled milk.
('49', 291, 5, 21, 514587) I keep good health.
('49', 291, 5, 22, 514607) I was weighed again and I found that I had lost no weight.
('49', 291, 5, 23, 514666) I am at present reading Edwin Arnold’s The Light of Asia.
('49', 291, 5, 24, 514724) I do get a newspaper.
('49', 291, 5, 25, 514746) It is the Times 1. I shall now be supplied the Chronicle
('49', 291, 6, 26, 514803) 1The Times of India
('49', 292, 0, 1, 514823) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 293
('49', 292, 1, 2, 514865) I have been permitted to get Young India, Navajivan, The Modern Review and Indian Social Reformer.
('49', 292, 1, 3, 514964) If I want, I can get some others too.
('49', 292, 1, 4, 515002) I think I wrote to you that I had started bathing in hot water.
('49', 292, 1, 5, 515066) You need not worry about me at all.
('49', 292, 1, 6, 515102) This time going to jail is enjoying oneself.
('49', 292, 1, 7, 515147) I was very glad to read Kumarappa’s name in Young India.
('49', 292, 1, 8, 515204) He is certainly a worthy man.

('49', 294, 1, 2, 517436) 299. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('49', 294, 2, 3, 517460) YERAVDA PLEASURE HOUSE, May 25, 1930
('49', 294, 3, 4, 517497) MIRA, Again I commence this on Sunday after the silence and after the evening prayer.
('49', 294, 3, 5, 517583) When you came time seemed to be running against us.
('49', 294, 3, 6, 517635) I therefore simply allowed you all to talk instead of myself talking and asking a lot of questions.
('49', 294, 3, 7, 517735) You were not at all looking well.
('49', 294, 3, 8, 517769) You seemed to have been pulled down.
('49', 294, 3, 9, 517806) That won’t do.
('49', 294, 3, 10, 517821) You must take proper exercise and proper food.
('49', 294, 3, 11, 517868) You must take all the fruit you may need and keep yourself fit.
('49', 294, 3, 12, 517932) I realize now as never before how careless I was not to have mastered the details about arranging the large bow.
('49', 294, 3, 13, 518045) As I have some mechanical ability, I have suspended it and have already begun working at it since Thursday last and have a fair stock of punis 1 but there is something wrong about it.
('49', 294, 3, 14, 518229) The long cord hangs from the roof.
('49', 294, 3, 15, 518264) There are two strings hanging from the bamboo.
('49', 294, 3, 16, 518311) I have joined the two and I pass the thin cord over the joined strings thus: The bamboo work does not stand steady but is inclined to turn round and round.
('49', 294, 3, 17, 518467) Of course, the wall prevents it.
('49', 294, 3, 18, 518500) But I fancy that it should not turn at all even if there was no wall preventing it.
('49', 294, 3, 19, 518584) If you have understood what I have described and if there is any flaw, you will tell me.
('49', 294, 3, 20, 518673) Your takli is well made but it [is] too heavy for fine spinning.
('49', 294, 3, 21, 518738) I have no doubt that the bamboo is the thing.
('49', 294, 3, 22, 518784) My speed is better now.
('49', 294, 3, 23, 518808) I have done 65 rounds today in 1_ hours—not bad for me.
('49', 294, 3, 24, 518864) I would do better when I shed my nervousness and draw the thread without fearing to break it.
('49', 294, 3, 25, 518958) My translation of one verse per day from the prayer book continues.
('49', 294, 3, 26, 519026) I wish I could do more.
('49', 294, 3, 27, 519050) But the spinning and carding won’t leave me any more time.
('49', 294, 3, 28, 519109) And now I must make time for the sewing machine.
('49', 294, 3, 29, 519158) I was glad you came.
('49', 294, 5, 30, 519179) 1 Slivers
('49', 295, 0, 1, 519189) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 296
('49', 295, 1, 2, 519231) [PS.] How do you make rigid the little wheel on the spindle when it gets loose?
('49', 295, 2, 3, 519311) From the original: C.W. 5397. Courtesy: Mirabehn; also G.N. 9631

('49', 296, 8, 18, 520812) 302. LETTER TO SUSHILA GANDHI
('49', 296, 9, 19, 520842) YERAVDA MANDIR, May 26, 1930
('49', 296, 10, 20, 520871) SUSHILA,
('49', 296, 11, 21, 520880) What kind of a husband have I given you?
('49', 296, 11, 22, 520921) But no, you cannot say that I gave him to you.
('49', 296, 11, 23, 520968) He was your own choice.
('49', 296, 11, 24, 520992) You cannot, therefore, blame me.
('49', 296, 11, 25, 521025) I hope you do remember how much I had cautioned you.
('49', 296, 11, 26, 521078) In any case, you can go one better than he; so how can you or I complain?
('49', 296, 11, 27, 521152) I hope Sita alias Dhairyabala is quite happy.
('49', 296, 12, 28, 521198) Blessings from
('49', 296, 14, 29, 521213) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 1180. Courtesy: Sushila Gandhi; also G.N. 4768

('49', 297, 0, 1, 521362) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 298
('49', 297, 1, 2, 521404) 303. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 297, 2, 3, 521435) YERAVDA MANDIR, May 26, 1930
('49', 297, 3, 4, 521464) CHI, NARANDAS, Gujarati letters were received here last week, but they have not yet been given to me.
('49', 297, 3, 5, 521566) I got Mirabehn’s and Mathew’s letters because they were in English.
('49', 297, 3, 6, 521634) That is how it is!
('49', 297, 3, 7, 521653) But this will not go on for many days—if God wills.
('49', 297, 3, 8, 521705) My weight is practically the same; perhaps it has gone up by half a pound.
('49', 297, 3, 9, 521780) The diet, too, continues to be the same.
('49', 297, 3, 10, 521821) Now I get perfect curds from unboiled milk.
('49', 297, 3, 11, 521865) The milk forms into curd in 24 hours.
('49', 297, 3, 12, 521903) I had mixed a fairly good quantity of curd with the milk.
('49', 297, 3, 13, 521961) I have finished reading two books: The Light of Asia and The Saints of Islam.
('49', 297, 3, 14, 522039) I am now reading a book on prisons written by an Inspector General of Prisons of the Punjab, which was sent to me by a friend.
('49', 297, 3, 15, 522166) I simply get no time for reading.
('49', 297, 3, 16, 522200) Seven hours are taken up by the spinning wheel, the takli and carding.
('49', 297, 3, 17, 522271) On some days, when the wheel requires no repair, it is less than seven hours, and on some other days it is more.
('49', 297, 3, 18, 522384) I am not unhappy about this.
('49', 297, 3, 19, 522413) I love work.
('49', 297, 3, 20, 522426) My skill in the work increases because I have to do everything myself, and I discover very small faults.
('49', 297, 3, 21, 522531) The yarn which I spin on the takli has improved very much in quality.
('49', 297, 3, 22, 522601) The speed, too, has gone up.
('49', 297, 3, 23, 522630) I think very little about things outside.
('49', 297, 3, 24, 522672) I am so busy with work that I get no time to think about them.
('49', 297, 3, 25, 522735) I fix my eyes on the central teaching of the Gita, and so enjoy peace of mind.
('49', 297, 3, 26, 522814) If I did not do that, though I am supplied newspapers, reading about all that happens would have made it difficult for me to experience peace.
('49', 297, 3, 27, 522957) The prayers twice a day and the daily reading of the Gita have proved a great support to me.
('49', 297, 3, 28, 523050) Is there any news about Krishna Nair, Surajbhan and Jayanti Prakash?
('49', 297, 3, 29, 523119) How is Satis Babu?
('49', 297, 3, 30, 523138) Write to all to whom you send letters and tell them that they are not to be published.
('49', 297, 3, 31, 523225) Friends may certainly read them.
('49', 297, 3, 32, 523258) How is Jamna’s health?
('49', 297, 3, 33, 523281) Blessings from BAPU From Gujarati: C.W. 8112. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('49', 308, 0, 1, 532898) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 309
('49', 308, 1, 2, 532940) 324. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('49', 308, 2, 3, 532967) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, May 30, 1930
('49', 308, 3, 4, 533004) DEAR MAJOR DOYLE, Today four visitors came to see me.
('49', 308, 3, 5, 533058) Among these were Mrs. Captain and Mr. Reginald Reynolds.
('49', 308, 3, 6, 533115) The other two were Miss Slade (Mirabai) and Mr. Mathuradas Trikumjee.
('49', 308, 3, 7, 533185) The last two were admitted.
('49', 308, 3, 8, 533213) As the Superintendent could not admit the other two, I had to decline to see Miss Slade and Mr. Mathuradas.
('49', 308, 3, 9, 533321) At our very first conversation, you will recollect, I made it clear to you that I recognized no distinction between blood relations and others and that if the Gov ernment wanted me to meet my blood relations they should appreciate my viewpoint and let me also see those who like Mrs. Captain and Mr. Reynolds are as good as blood relations.
('49', 308, 3, 10, 533662) I thought you had agreed to the position.
('49', 308, 3, 11, 533704) But I may have misunderstood you.
('49', 308, 3, 12, 533738) I want to blame nobody.
('49', 308, 3, 13, 533762) I want no special privileges.
('49', 308, 3, 14, 533792) I simply wish [you] to understand my position and would like the Government to know my viewpoint though they may not endorse it.
('49', 308, 3, 15, 533921) I may not see my relatives if I may not see the others.
('49', 308, 3, 16, 533977) This is no new attitude with me.
('49', 308, 3, 17, 534010) I took it up in 1922 also and at that time there was no difficulty about my seeing those who were not blood relations.
('49', 308, 3, 18, 534129) Of course, it is understood all along that there can be no political messages received or sent by me.
('49', 308, 3, 19, 534231) There are, too, my weekly letters hanging fire.
('49', 308, 3, 20, 534279) These too I wrote as per our understanding, as I thought it was, namely, that non political affairs 1 written to my Ashram friends in one envelope would count as one letter.
('49', 308, 3, 21, 534453) I would appreciate an early clearance of both these issues.
('49', 308, 5, 22, 534513) Yours sincerely,
('49', 308, 6, 23, 534530) M. K. GANDHI
('49', 308, 7, 24, 534543) Bombay Secret Abstracts, 750(5) A, p.
('49', 308, 7, 25, 534581) 65; also S.N. 19973
('49', 308, 8, 26, 534601) 1 The draft (S.N. 19973) here has “letters”.
('49', 309, 0, 1, 534646) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 310
('49', 309, 1, 2, 534688) 325. LETTER TO EDITOR, “WORLD FEDERATION”
('49', 309, 2, 3, 534730) May, 1930
('49', 309, 3, 4, 534740) DEAR FRIEND, Just a line to thank you for your letter.
('49', 309, 3, 5, 534795) I am too preoccupied to say more just now.

('49', 310, 7, 8, 536292) 328. LETTER TO R. V. MARTIN
('49', 310, 8, 9, 536320) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, June 11, 1930 1
('49', 310, 9, 10, 536360) DEAR MAJOR MARTIN, You have told me that the Government will permit seven of my blood relations to see me twice per week and the others only by their special permission.
('49', 310, 9, 11, 536530) This means that my wife, who is not a blood relative, and naturally her brothers and other relatives, have to obtain special permission.
('49', 310, 9, 12, 536667) I am sure this is a mere slip.
('49', 310, 9, 13, 536698) But what is obviously contemplated is that those who are not related to me by blood or through marriage can, except Shrimati Mirabai Slade, 2 see me only by special permission of the Government.
('49', 310, 9, 14, 536893) If this decision is not revised, I fear I must not see my relatives.
('49', 310, 9, 15, 536962) I have in the Ashram and outside many widows, girls, boys and men, who are perhaps more to me than many a blood relative.
('49', 310, 9, 16, 537084) If they may not see me on the same terms as relatives, to be just to the former, I must not see the latter.
('49', 310, 10, 17, 537192) 1 The letter was delivered to R. V. Martin, the Jail Superintendent, the next day.
('49', 310, 10, 18, 537275) 2 The words “except Shrimati Mirabai Slade” do not appear in the draft available under S.N. 19974. 3 Regarding the privileges to be allowed to Gandhiji, the Secretary of the Home Department on June 17 wrote to the Inspector General of Prisons: “ .
('49', 310, 10, 19, 537523) I am directed to state that the word ‘relations’ should be substituted for the words ‘blood relations’ .
('49', 310, 10, 20, 537628) It was of course not intended to exclude Mr. Gandhi’s wife, or his brother in law and the like.
('49', 310, 10, 21, 537724) I am further to say that if Mr. Gandhi refuses to see his relations, the only thing that can be done is to treat them like strangers and interviews regulated accordingly.
('49', 311, 0, 1, 537895) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 312
('49', 311, 1, 2, 537937) Although it is now a fortnight, I do not know what has happened to the Ashram letters that were received and those that I wrote.
('49', 311, 1, 3, 538066) You told me that you had sent them 1 to the I.G. There is one more matter.
('49', 311, 1, 4, 538141) I see Sjt.
('49', 311, 1, 5, 538152) Kalelkar is to be brought here as companion for me.
('49', 311, 1, 6, 538204) He is an esteemed co worker, but if I conveyed the impression that I would like him to be brought here to keep me company, I am sorry.
('49', 311, 1, 7, 538339) I would not like him to be torn from so many companions with whom he is placed at the Sabarmati Jail and come here to share my isolation.
('49', 311, 1, 8, 538477) If he could mix freely with the other satyagrahi prisoners and keep company with me, I would naturally value his company, but I have no desire to have the joy of his com pany at his expense.
('49', 311, 1, 9, 538668) What I would desire is naturally to be able to see all my satyagrahi friends who are in this jail.
('49', 311, 1, 10, 538767) I repeat what I have told you so often: I do not desire special privileges.
('49', 311, 1, 11, 538843) But if an ordinary prisoner may have the company of his fellows who may chance to be in the same prison, it may be lawful for me to entertain such a desire.
('49', 311, 3, 12, 539000) Yours sincerely,
('49', 311, 4, 13, 539017) M. K. GANDHI

('49', 314, 1, 2, 541143) 333. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('49', 314, 2, 3, 541167) June 22, 1930
('49', 314, 3, 4, 541181) MIRA, After many weeks I take up the pen to write Ashram letters again.
('49', 314, 3, 5, 541253) The batch I sent you last I knew was held up and so was the batch from the Ashram.
('49', 314, 3, 6, 541336) In the circumstances, I did not want to write.
('49', 314, 3, 7, 541383) The way now seems to be fairly clear though I have not yet got all the weekly letters and I know that some have been withheld.
('49', 314, 3, 8, 541510) They are from children.
('49', 314, 3, 9, 541534) I am trying to secure them.
('49', 314, 3, 10, 541562) I must have some reminders now and then at least of prison life.
('49', 314, 3, 11, 541627) No visits can be entertained so long as the difficulty remains, as it does, unremoved.
('49', 314, 3, 12, 541714) If visits cannot be had on honourable terms, we must be content with writing letters if they can be honourably continued.
('49', 314, 3, 13, 541836) If, therefore, you do not hear from me regularly, know that I am a prisoner.
('49', 314, 3, 14, 541913) If I am really ill, walls will speak.
('49', 314, 3, 15, 541951) The authorities will themselves proclaim it as they did last time and you could always inquire from them whenever you hear rumours, and I expect they will promptly give you the information.
('49', 314, 3, 16, 542141) But I am hoping that there will be plain sailing so far as letter writing is concerned.
('49', 314, 3, 17, 542229) Just at present there is nothing wrong with me save for a trifling constipation.
('49', 314, 3, 18, 542310) There is no cause for any anxiety whatsoever.
('49', 314, 3, 19, 542356) I have your latest letter, i.e., of the 9th instant.
('49', 314, 3, 20, 542409) Nothing since.
('49', 314, 3, 21, 542424) The instructions you give about the bow are quite good and quite enough.
('49', 314, 3, 22, 542497) Yet I have hung it up the wrong way up but it has worked with perfect smoothness.
('49', 314, 3, 23, 542579) The bow itself has not required any atten tion.
('49', 314, 3, 24, 542627) I have finished carding all the cotton I had.
('49', 314, 3, 25, 542673) The gut has not given in at all as yet.
('49', 314, 3, 26, 542713) I used not neem leaves but leaves of some other tree resembling the tamarind.
('49', 314, 3, 27, 542791) They are quite serviceable.
('49', 314, 3, 28, 542819) You may send two pounds of cotton per anyone who may be going to Poona.
('49', 314, 3, 29, 542891) There is no hurry.
('49', 314, 3, 30, 542910) I have slivers enough to last till 15th July at least.
('49', 314, 3, 31, 542965) I need not touch the bow till then.
('49', 314, 3, 32, 543001) When I do, I shall rearrange the apparatus in accordance with your instructions.
('49', 314, 3, 33, 543082) About adjusting the wheel on the spindle too I understand.
('49', 314, 3, 34, 543141) But here again nature has been kind to me.
('49', 314, 3, 35, 543184) I adjusted the wheel inmy own way and it has remained quite fixed.
('49', 314, 3, 36, 543251) If there is trouble I shall try your prescription.
('49', 314, 3, 37, 543302) I note all you say about your own work.
('49', 314, 3, 38, 543342) You shall act just as
('49', 315, 0, 1, 543364) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 316
('49', 315, 1, 2, 543406) God leads you and your strength permits.

('49', 316, 1, 2, 544214) 335. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 316, 2, 3, 544245) YERAVDA MANDIR, June 22/23, 1930
('49', 316, 3, 4, 544278) CHI NARANDAS, I get your letters one by one.
('49', 316, 3, 5, 544323) You will read about this from my letter to Mirabehn.
('49', 316, 3, 6, 544376) I got three letters of yours, of 19th and 26th May and 10th June, one after another during the last six days.
('49', 316, 3, 7, 544486) Other letters sent by you must be passing from hand to hand.
('49', 316, 3, 8, 544547) I think I have still to receive two letters, of June 2 or 3 and of June 16. In future give me inyour letters the names of those whose letters you may have forwarded.
('49', 316, 3, 9, 544713) This is because some of them have not been given to me.
('49', 316, 3, 10, 544769) Do everything you can to please Ratilal.
('49', 316, 3, 11, 544810) I am writing to him.
('49', 316, 3, 12, 544831) Please give the Japanese friend who wants to translate My Experiments with Truth the permission to do so.
('49', 316, 3, 13, 544937) With this is a letter for the Bengali women.
('49', 316, 3, 14, 544982) Rasjibhai and Shivabhai must have completely recovered now.
('49', 316, 3, 15, 545042) What work is Jagannath doing?
('49', 316, 3, 16, 545072) The experiment of making curds from unboiled milk has proved completely successful.
('49', 316, 3, 17, 545156) Mostly I take curds instead of milk.
('49', 316, 3, 18, 545193) Hence my present diet is curds, raisins or dates and juice of a lemon once a day.
('49', 316, 3, 19, 545275) I still do not take any hot drink.
('49', 316, 3, 20, 545310) Once only, when I had to take castor oil, I had taken hot water, lemon juice and salt twice.
('49', 316, 3, 21, 545403) I drank milk on that day, but it was unboiled.
('49', 316, 3, 22, 545450) This diet has had no harmful effects.
('49', 316, 3, 23, 545488) I think, therefore, that I shall keep to this diet for the present.
('49', 316, 3, 24, 545556) The weight is practically steady.
('49', 316, 3, 25, 545590) It fluctuates by a pound.
('49', 316, 3, 26, 545616) It is 105 at present.
('49', 316, 3, 27, 545638) Kakasaheb was brought here four days ago.
('49', 316, 3, 28, 545680) He is keeping very fit.
('49', 316, 3, 29, 545704) His diet is milk, bread, ghee and some fruit from what is allowed to me.
('49', 316, 3, 30, 545777) He has made a request for vegetables, which will probably be granted.
('49', 316, 3, 31, 545847) I have added sewing to my daily work.
('49', 316, 3, 32, 545885) I had asked for a sewing machine from Lady Vithaldas and it has now arrived.
('49', 316, 3, 33, 545962) I sew jail caps at present.
('49', 316, 3, 34, 545990) I give to this work three quarters to one hour daily.
('49', 316, 3, 35, 546044) My rate of spinning is 375 rounds minimum.
('49', 316, 3, 36, 546087) The average would be 400. Spinning on the takli is also going on.
('49', 316, 3, 37, 546153) I also spend considerable time in making my takli.
('49', 316, 3, 38, 546204) I am trying to spin fine yarn.
('49', 317, 0, 1, 546235) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 318
('49', 317, 1, 2, 546277) The hand has set well and I spin with greater ease every day.
('49', 317, 1, 3, 546339) I disover new virtues in the takli daily.
('49', 317, 1, 4, 546381) Even more than the spinning wheel it may prove to be the support of people in want, though, of course, both give peace of mind.
('49', 317, 1, 5, 546509) I compared them today with the sewing machine and clearly realized the moral value of manual work.
('49', 317, 1, 6, 546608) Though I look upon the sewing machine as an invaluable benefit, I do not regard it as a source of peace.
('49', 317, 1, 7, 546713) When you work on it, you naturally wish to increase the speed and in the end the brain is bound to get tired.
('49', 317, 1, 8, 546823) But once a person has acquired control over the takli, time passes more peacefully for him as he works on it than for the driver of a bullock cart.
('49', 317, 1, 9, 546971) This is my experience, though I have not become an expert spinner as yet I must wait and see what exp erience I have when I have acquired perfect control over the takli.
('49', 317, 1, 10, 547141) Kak asaheb, too, spins on it, but he has not discovered its secret yet.
('49', 317, 1, 11, 547213) These things are difficult for him to master.
('49', 317, 1, 12, 547259) He knows that they are for our good and, therefore, is trying to love them.
('49', 317, 1, 13, 547335) He does not want to start the spinning wheel at present.
('49', 317, 1, 14, 547392) He wishes to master the takli first.
('49', 317, 1, 15, 547429) I read only after I have performed the spinning yajna.
('49', 317, 1, 16, 547484) I look upon sewing as a part of this sacrifice.
('49', 317, 1, 17, 547532) I had received, and welcomed, the suggestion sent by Mathuradas.
('49', 317, 1, 18, 547597) I implement it whenever I get an opportunity.
('49', 317, 1, 19, 547643) Since Kaka is here, I am quite eager now.
('49', 317, 1, 20, 547685) I started Marathi yesterday.
('49', 317, 1, 21, 547714) I would be happy if I make at least some progress in it.
('49', 317, 1, 22, 547771) If I advise everyone to commit the verses of the Gita to memory, should not I, too, do that?
('49', 317, 1, 23, 547864) The attempt is like fixing the shape of a pot after it is baked.
('49', 317, 1, 24, 547929) If at all it is worth making, however, this is the right place.
('49', 317, 1, 25, 547993) I, therefore, started learning the verses eight days ago.
('49', 317, 1, 26, 548051) I have learnt by heart Chapter XII and have now started Chapter XIII.
('49', 317, 1, 27, 548121) Kaka’s coming has naturally interrupted the progress.
('49', 317, 1, 28, 548175) I will do nothing by stealing time from the hours apart for the spinning yajna.
('49', 317, 1, 29, 548255) I, therefore, do these things in spare moments in the course of other work or in the “library” 1, etc.
('49', 317, 1, 30, 548358) Let no one be shocked to read that I try to learn the verses of the Gita by heart in the “library”.
('49', 317, 1, 31, 548458) We have learnt from childhood that there is no spot where He is not present.
('49', 317, 1, 32, 548535) We should, therefore, feel no qualms in taking His name or doing His work there.
('49', 317, 1, 33, 548616) Yes, this certainly means that our “libraries” should be as clean as the buildings in which books are stored.
('49', 317, 1, 34, 548726) Mine at any rate is.
('49', 317, 2, 35, 548747) 1 Lavatory
('49', 318, 0, 1, 548758) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 319
('49', 318, 1, 2, 548800) For here in the jail everyone has to do all the things in the cell itself.

('49', 325, 1, 2, 555213) 347. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('49', 325, 2, 3, 555237) YERAVDA MANDIR, June 30, 1930
('49', 325, 3, 4, 555267) MIRA, I have your letter.
('49', 325, 3, 5, 555293) I think the Ashram letters will be now regularly received by me and mine by you all.
('49', 325, 3, 6, 555378) The condition is that no politics can be discussed on either side.
('49', 325, 3, 7, 555445) But if you find again an interruption, you will infer that some hitch has occurred.
('49', 325, 3, 8, 555529) I am glad you are keeping fit.
('49', 325, 3, 9, 555560) Only your weight must not go below a minimum which for your build must be 116 lb.
('49', 325, 3, 10, 555642) Yes, I am doing some sewing regularly.
('49', 325, 3, 11, 555681) Of course, it is all jail work.
('49', 325, 3, 12, 555713) When Mathuradas suggested it for cheapening khadi, I was attracted to the suggestion.
('49', 325, 3, 13, 555799) I thought I would practise on the machine here.
('49', 325, 3, 14, 555847) The machine has been sent by Lady Vithaldas who was for some time in the Ashram, if you can recall her.
('49', 325, 3, 15, 555951) As I am not likely to have visitors now, it would [be] better to send me 3 lb.
('49', 325, 3, 16, 556030) of cotton.
('49', 325, 3, 17, 556041) I said 2 in my last letter 1 but perhaps it is as well to send me 3. Kakasaheb too will need slivers.
('49', 325, 3, 18, 556143) You may pack the cotton in paper and then sew it up in sacking.
('49', 325, 3, 19, 556207) This suggestion is made to save khadi.
('49', 325, 3, 20, 556246) I told you all about the bow in my last letter.
('49', 325, 3, 21, 556294) Though the way I have fixed it works all right, I shall try your way when I get the cotton.
('49', 325, 3, 22, 556386) My love to all the friends.
('49', 325, 4, 23, 556414) BAPU [PS.] If you cannot attend to cotton, let someone else do it.

('49', 326, 7, 11, 556923) 349. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR
('49', 326, 8, 12, 556952) YERAVDA MANDIR, June 30, 1930
('49', 326, 9, 13, 556982) LILAVATI, I have your letter.
('49', 326, 9, 14, 557012) From here I cannot send you a letter in a sealed envelope.
('49', 326, 9, 15, 557071) But what is there to hide for one who has a pure heart?
('49', 326, 9, 16, 557127) You should throw away the letter you have received.
('49', 326, 9, 17, 557179) After having once given up the thought of marriage, why think about the matter again?
('49', 326, 9, 18, 557265) Moreover, for you now true marriage lies in clinging to the duty to which you have wedded yourself.
('49', 326, 9, 19, 557365) It is only in such marriage that true happiness is found.
('49', 326, 9, 20, 557423) It gives rise to no problems and there is no possibility of widowhood in it.
('49', 326, 9, 21, 557500) So you should dismiss the thought altogether from your mind.
('49', 326, 9, 22, 557561) Meditate on the last portion of the second chapter of the Gita which we daily recite.
('49', 326, 9, 23, 557647) If this does not help you to feel at peace you may write to me again and you should have no hesitation in writing freely.
('49', 326, 9, 24, 557769) Forget the past.
('49', 326, 9, 25, 557786) Take care of the present, and the future will then take care of itself.
('49', 326, 9, 26, 557858) This is the meaning, plain and simple, of non attachment.
('49', 326, 9, 27, 557916) If we do our duty today, we shall automatically know our duty tomorrow.
('49', 326, 10, 28, 557988) Blessings from

('49', 328, 1, 2, 559452) 352. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 328, 2, 3, 559483) YERAVDA MANDIR, June 30, 1930
('49', 328, 3, 4, 559513) NARANDAS, I have now received all your letters.
('49', 328, 3, 5, 559561) We have thought long about the trouble being given by the Bharwads.
('49', 328, 3, 6, 559629) To me our dharma is plain.
('49', 328, 3, 7, 559656) It is the same towards the entire world.
('49', 328, 3, 8, 559697) We should win over the Bharwads by love, and at the same time try to protect what it is our duty to protect.
('49', 328, 3, 9, 559806) That can be done only by giving our lives to the Bharwads.
('49', 328, 3, 10, 559865) In other words, we should lay down our lives in protecting our things but should never attack the Bharwads in doing so.
('49', 328, 3, 11, 559985) However, I do not wish to blame anyone for what has happ ened.
('49', 328, 3, 12, 560048) We can follow dharma only within the limits of our capacity, otherwise we would be guilty of artificiality.
('49', 328, 3, 13, 560156) We should, therefore, do what the impulse of the moment dictates.
('49', 328, 3, 14, 560222) That impulse is the measure of our strength.
('49', 328, 3, 15, 560267) As for the future, I have no doubt that our dharma is what I have stated it to be.
('49', 328, 3, 16, 560350) But before and after adopting that course for protecting our things, we should discharge two other duties.
('49', 328, 3, 17, 560457) I have been observing and saying for the last fifteen years that we have not mixed with our neighbours.
('49', 328, 3, 18, 560561) What pains me is that I myself did not follow that path.
('49', 328, 3, 19, 560618) I tried to persuade Maganlal to follow it.
('49', 328, 3, 20, 560661) Some kind of a start was made.
('49', 328, 3, 21, 560692) There were, however, difficulties in the way and the attempt was abandoned.
('49', 328, 3, 22, 560768) We are now paying for our indifference.
('49', 328, 3, 23, 560808) But recalling the past is of no value except for drawing lessons from it.
('49', 328, 3, 24, 560882) Let us look to the present.
('49', 328, 3, 25, 560910) Just now, therefore, we should discuss the problem with the Bharwads.
('49', 328, 3, 26, 560980) We should ourselves try to plead with them in the presence of persons who know them.
('49', 328, 3, 27, 561065) We should also tell them what we wish.
('49', 328, 3, 28, 561104) If they want to graze their cattle [on our land], they should pay us something.
('49', 328, 3, 29, 561184) If, however, we have no land we should explain that to them.
('49', 328, 3, 30, 561245) We should also appeal to our neighbours to plead with the Bharwads.
('49', 328, 3, 31, 561313) We should render them whatever other service we can, and should continue to do so irrespective of their behaviour.
('49', 328, 3, 32, 561428) We should explain to them why the Ashram has been established and what it aims at doing.
('49', 328, 3, 33, 561517) Even if we do all this, it is possible that they will occasionally raid the Ashram.
('49', 328, 3, 34, 561601) If they do, those
('49', 329, 0, 1, 561619) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 330
('49', 329, 1, 2, 561661) of us who can, may lay down their lives and let the Bharwads take away what they will after killing them.
('49', 329, 1, 3, 561767) If we do not have the will and the strength for this, you may do what seems best to all of you.
('49', 329, 1, 4, 561863) I have only explained the duty, as I understand it, that is proper to an Ashram.
('49', 329, 1, 5, 561944) You should, however, put out of consideration what I may write, for beyond expressing my views I can do nothing.
('49', 329, 1, 6, 562057) Moreover, an opinion expressed from a distance is likely to be erroneous.
('49', 329, 1, 7, 562131) What I might think if I were present there may very well be different from what I think from here.
('49', 329, 1, 8, 562230) Moreover, no matter with what detachment a prisoner tries to think, his conclusions are likely to be based on incomplete data.
('49', 329, 1, 9, 562357) You need not, therefore, attach much weight to my view.
('49', 329, 1, 10, 562413) I shall be satisfied if it helps you to come to your own decision.
('49', 329, 1, 11, 562480) In any case it was good that afterwards you treated the Bharwads for injuries.
('49', 329, 2, 12, 562559) I am writing to Bhansali; read that letter.
('49', 329, 2, 13, 562603) Your decisions about Chandrakanta and Giriraj seem all right.
('49', 329, 2, 14, 562665) I am getting on well.
('49', 329, 2, 15, 562687) These days I am also trying to learn by heart verses from the Gita.
('49', 329, 2, 16, 562755) I have completed Chapter XII and done half of Chapter XIII.
('49', 329, 2, 17, 562815) Does man know what he wants?
('49', 329, 2, 18, 562844) I liked Kaka’s coming, but I also see that it has turned out to be an obstacle.
('49', 329, 2, 19, 562924) Since his coming my daily study has fallen behind.
('49', 329, 2, 20, 562975) Without him I would have proceeded faster with the Gita.
('49', 329, 2, 21, 563032) Actually, I tried to prevent his coming, but failed.
('49', 329, 2, 22, 563085) My reason for doing that was quite different.
('49', 329, 2, 23, 563131) I did not like that he, too, should be confined within four walls as I was.
('49', 329, 2, 24, 563207) But the Government had made up its mind to provide me company and did so.
('49', 329, 2, 25, 563281) I, therefore, tolerate Kaka.
('49', 329, 2, 26, 563310) And he has to bear separation from the large company at Sabarmati.
('49', 329, 2, 27, 563377) Thus we find the situation a mixture of all sentiments—there are at least the pathetic, the humorous and the heroic.
('49', 329, 2, 28, 563494) However, if I have relaxed in one field of my daily study, I have started Marathi.
('49', 329, 2, 29, 563577) I would have become proud if I had become altogether self reliant.
('49', 329, 2, 30, 563644) Now that I have been receiving invisible services from Kakasaheb, they will help me in reminding me of my right place.
('49', 329, 2, 31, 563763) Besides, the exercise which my reason gets in sweet disc ussions about the Gita and other works is an additional benefit.
('49', 329, 2, 32, 563885) Thus I get an opportunity of another kind for self examination.
('49', 329, 2, 33, 563949) I can, therefore, say that I would have been content if Kaka had not come, and am also content now that he has come.
('49', 329, 2, 34, 564066) Who can weigh and decide whether his coming is a gain or a loss to me?
('49', 329, 2, 35, 564137) To him who believes that
('49', 330, 0, 1, 564162) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 331
('49', 330, 1, 2, 564204) anything he gets unasked comes from God, every such thing is a benefit—is a gift of His grace.
('49', 330, 1, 3, 564299) Kaka’s coming, therefore, is such a gift.
('49', 330, 1, 4, 564341) It does not matter if the study of the Gita has slowed down.
('49', 330, 1, 5, 564402) Convey my greetings to Vallabhbhai.
('49', 330, 1, 6, 564438) The question of Kaka’s diet has been settled.
('49', 330, 1, 7, 564484) He gets two pounds of cow’s milk, ten tolas of butter, twenty tolas of fresh, uncooked vegetables and twenty tolas of chapati.
('49', 330, 1, 8, 564611) He turns the milk into curds.
('49', 330, 1, 9, 564641) He is getting on quite well.
('49', 330, 1, 10, 564670) His weight has increased by one pound.
('49', 330, 1, 11, 564709) By way of vegetables, he gets brinjals and radishes by turn during the week.
('49', 330, 1, 12, 564786) He cooks the brinjals and eats the radishes raw.
('49', 330, 2, 13, 564835) Blessings from
('49', 330, 4, 14, 564850) From Gujarati: C.W. 8114. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('49', 331, 1, 2, 565556) 354. LETTER TO CHANDRAKANTA
('49', 331, 2, 3, 565584) Y.M., June 30, 1930

('49', 341, 1, 2, 576474) for to us a sadhu and an emperor are the same.

('49', 342, 3, 7, 578957) 371. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI PANDYA
('49', 342, 4, 8, 578989) July 7, 1930
('49', 342, 5, 9, 579002) BHAGWANJI, I have your letter.
('49', 342, 5, 10, 579033) Please do not feel miserable.
('49', 342, 5, 11, 579063) Since you have not given up effort I have no doubt all will end well.
('49', 342, 5, 12, 579133) The body is under our control and therefore we ought to check it and restrain our feelings.
('49', 342, 5, 13, 579225) One who makes a show of physical self control but indulges in all manner of pleasures mentally is a hypocrite, a double dealer.
('49', 342, 5, 14, 579353) One who controls one’s body and also endeavours to always restrain one’s mind is an active aspirant; one whose mind as well as body are fully under control is God [Himself].
('49', 342, 5, 15, 579527) It is enough if we are or [try to] become active aspirants of the middling category.
('49', 342, 5, 16, 579612) We should never let our minds remain unclean.
('49', 342, 5, 17, 579658) An evil thought should be thrown out no sooner than it occurs.
('49', 342, 5, 18, 579721) We should know that our mind is like our body, which gets soiled every day and which we clean every day.
('49', 342, 5, 19, 579826) The fact that we are obliged to accommodate Shankarbhai’s father or others like him is a help to us in preserving our dharma.
('49', 342, 5, 20, 579952) Non violence means being strict towards one’s self and liberal towards others; this is the sign of tolerance.
('49', 342, 5, 21, 580062) Those who do not observe the rules, etc., deserve to be pitied, never to be hated.
('49', 342, 5, 22, 580145) That we have given up tea, etc., that we abide by the rules is because we like it; if some do not, how can it be an excuse for us to swerve from our own stand?
('49', 342, 5, 23, 580305) On the contrary let us hope that having observed our humble yet firm conduct people like Shankarbhai’s father would be touched and give up their undesirable habits.
('49', 342, 6, 24, 580470) Blessings from
('49', 342, 8, 25, 580485) From a copy of the Gujarati: C.W. 320. Courtesy: Bhagwanji Purushottam Pandya
('49', 343, 0, 1, 580563) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 344
('49', 343, 1, 2, 580605) 372. LETTER TO R. V. MARTIN
('49', 343, 2, 3, 580633) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, July 8, 1930
('49', 343, 3, 4, 580670) DEAR MAJOR MARTIN, With further reference to my letter about interviews, I enclose herewith a trial list to show what I mean when I say that I can see Mrs. Gandhi and others of my family only if on the same terms I can see those who are like blood relations to me, as those in the list are.
('49', 343, 3, 5, 580961) The alternative proposed by the Government is unacceptable to me for the simple reason that I do not wish to expose my wife and children to the indignity of having to apply to the Government for permission each time they may desire to see me.
('49', 343, 3, 6, 581204) 1 I recognize that the Government need not let anybody see me.
('49', 343, 3, 7, 581267) But if they do let me see anybody, I must refuse to avail myself of such permission if it is bereft of grace as, in my opinion, the present position about interviews is.
('49', 343, 3, 8, 581437) I know the Government’s preoccupations and it pains me to have to take up their time over what is for them comparatively a trivial matter.
('49', 343, 3, 9, 581576) I have reverted to it only because I had a talk with you about it and because I would like it finally decided one way or other.
('49', 343, 3, 10, 581704) If the list is approved, I reserve the right to submit a further list.
('49', 343, 3, 11, 581775) It is impossible for me to recall at once the names of all who are intimately connected with me and are not known to political fame.
('49', 343, 3, 12, 581908) I may observe that such names I have purposely omitted.
('49', 343, 3, 13, 581964) A large number are boys and girls under 16. I have also omitted the names of relatives as they are already allowed and I have omitted those who to my knowledge are already imprisoned.
('49', 343, 5, 14, 582148) Yours sincerely,
('49', 343, 6, 15, 582165) K. GANDHI
('49', 343, 7, 16, 582175) 1 Vide “Letter to R.V.Martin”, 11 6 1930.

('49', 355, 6, 15, 593904) 389. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('49', 355, 7, 16, 593928) UNREVISED, July 14, 1930
('49', 355, 8, 17, 593953) MIRA, I have your letter.
('49', 355, 8, 18, 593979) I am likely now to get the Ashram post regularly.
('49', 355, 8, 19, 594029) Your taking cold baths I do not mind so long as the body reacts immediately.
('49', 355, 8, 20, 594106) There should be no chill felt.
('49', 355, 8, 21, 594137) The full benefit of a cold bath according to the Indian style is dependent upon vigorous rubbing as the water is being poured.
('49', 355, 8, 22, 594264) This is followed by equally vigorous rubbing with a dry towel till all the parts are thoroughly dry.
('49', 355, 8, 23, 594365) But please do not try unboiled water.
('49', 355, 8, 24, 594403) My case here is different.
('49', 355, 8, 25, 594430) I get the same water, which is strained and stored in a separate earthen pot.
('49', 355, 8, 26, 594508) The whole water supply for the jail is filtered.
('49', 355, 9, 27, 594557) 1 Daughter of Dalbahadur Giri who, along with her brothers, sisters and widowed mother, was residing in the Ashram 2 Girls on whose shoulders Gandhiji leaned while walking 3 The original letter was in Gujarati.
('49', 356, 0, 1, 594768) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 357
('49', 356, 1, 2, 594810) My constipation has almost altogether abated.
('49', 356, 1, 3, 594856) This was due to my having reverted to milk in the morning instead of curds.
('49', 356, 1, 4, 594932) If I find the heating of milk or hot water necessary, I shall not hesitate to take either or both.

('49', 356, 1, 6, 595078) Fresh fruit does not appear to be necessary for me.
('49', 356, 1, 7, 595130) I am not losing weight.
('49', 356, 1, 8, 595154) Last week it was between 103 and 104 lb.
('49', 356, 1, 9, 595195) I do not consider this a bad weight.
('49', 356, 1, 10, 595232) You will thus see that there is no cause for anxiety on my account.
('49', 356, 1, 11, 595300) You ask for the Gita translation.
('49', 356, 1, 12, 595334) I should love to do it.
('49', 356, 1, 13, 595358) But just now what little time I do get is given to the translation of the Bhajanavali 1 also undertaken for you.
('49', 356, 1, 14, 595471) I am going at a snail’s pace.
('49', 356, 1, 15, 595501) I therefore do not know when that will be finished.
('49', 356, 1, 16, 595553) The Gita translation is a big task.
('49', 356, 1, 17, 595589) You will agree I may not suspend the spinning for it.
('49', 356, 1, 18, 595643) For the spinning is applied translation of the Gita if one may coin that expression.
('49', 356, 1, 19, 595728) But if I have long enough of this quiet, I shall certainly undertake the translation.
('49', 356, 1, 20, 595814) We cannot have at the Ashram the worship of the kind you refer to.
('49', 356, 1, 21, 595881) Of course, we have the little samadhi near Magan Kutir.
('49', 356, 1, 22, 595937) But nobody save a few look at it.
('49', 356, 1, 23, 595971) The inmates of the Ashram have no living faith in that kind of worship.
('49', 356, 1, 24, 596043) For the worship of the invisible, the intellect is ready but the heart does not respond.
('49', 356, 1, 25, 596132) We have, however, to plod in that direction.
('49', 356, 1, 26, 596177) As pointed out in the 12th chapter, that way is undoubtedly hard to tread but it is not impossible.
('49', 356, 1, 27, 596277) It will come.
('49', 356, 1, 28, 596291) Everyone is subconsciously recognizing the worth of the Ashram prayer.
('49', 356, 1, 29, 596362) It has been the sole solace of many.
('49', 356, 1, 30, 596399) Those that attend it are not scoffers.
('49', 356, 1, 31, 596438) They are not wittingly irreverent either.
('49', 356, 1, 32, 596480) The spirit is willing, the flesh is weak.
('49', 356, 1, 33, 596522) They are all striving.
('49', 356, 1, 34, 596545) And no one who has honestly striven has ever been known to have failed.
('49', 356, 1, 35, 596617) Ours is, you should remember, a somewhat original attempt.
('49', 356, 1, 36, 596676) We have no sol emn looking building for prayer.
('49', 356, 1, 37, 596724) We have simply the open space.
('49', 356, 1, 38, 596755) But it is a sound thing especially as we represent the famishing millions.
('49', 356, 1, 39, 596830) For us the sky must be an all sufficing roof and the four directions our limitless walls.
('49', 356, 1, 40, 596920) But we shall take time before we outgrow habits handed down from generations, if not ages.
('49', 356, 1, 41, 597011) And yet, if we are to break through all bonds of race, class and creed, we can have but the openest of house of prayer and in the way we are having it.
('49', 356, 1, 42, 597163) Am I clear?

('49', 358, 8, 9, 598733) 393. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 358, 9, 10, 598764) YERAVDA MANDIR, July 13/15, 1930 1
('49', 358, 10, 11, 598799) NARANDAS, This time all the letters were delivered to me as soon as they were received, and probably that is what they will do in future too .
('49', 358, 10, 12, 598942) Last time I wrote 47 letters and then added two at the last moment, but could not change the figure which I had mentioned in your letter.
('49', 358, 10, 13, 599080) For the Jail Superintendent arrived then and I handed over the packet to him after inserting into it those two slips of paper.
('49', 358, 10, 14, 599207) My speed has not increased to 400 rounds, or even yards, and it is not likely to do so.
('49', 358, 10, 15, 599295) I believe that my body simply does not have the capacity for that.
('49', 358, 10, 16, 599362) Formerly I used to spin 160 rounds during the day; instead, I now spin 375 rounds.
('49', 358, 10, 17, 599445) But to spin that takes on an average four hours.
('49', 358, 10, 18, 599494) Even on days on which everything goes well, I take not less than three hours.
('49', 358, 10, 19, 599572) The average probably comes to 400 rounds a day.
('49', 358, 10, 20, 599620) The speed used to be 160, which has now risen to 200 rounds, but that only on the day on which I have sufficient energy and the materials are well arranged.
('49', 358, 10, 21, 599777) Make this correction.
('49', 358, 10, 22, 599799) I have become slackabout the takli these days.
('49', 358, 10, 23, 599846) I get pretty tired working on the spinning wheel.
('49', 358, 10, 24, 599896) Ever since my illness I have lost the strength to sit up
('49', 358, 11, 25, 599953) 1 This letter written on different days is placed under the date on which it was completed.

('49', 360, 1, 2, 602505) July 14, 1930 One of the boys asks me in his letter why I use slips of paper.
('49', 360, 1, 3, 602583) The reply is that a prisoner should consume the minimum of everything.
('49', 360, 1, 4, 602654) Secondly, he who observes the vow of non possession is a trustee of all property and, therefore, I must use the property of this prison, too, like a miser.
('49', 360, 1, 5, 602810) Thirdly, isn’t this property really ours ?
('49', 360, 1, 6, 602853) With whose money have these things been bought ?
('49', 360, 1, 7, 602902) Fourthly, in this poor country the less the consumption of such things the better.
('49', 360, 1, 8, 602985) Fifthly, it hurts me to use anything extravagantly at a time like this.
('49', 360, 1, 9, 603057) I hear today that there is a railway receipt in the office, which means that the cotton is likely to have arrived.
('49', 360, 1, 10, 603172) If I cannot mention the total number of letters, I am sure you will see the serial number on the last letter.

('49', 366, 1, 11, 610033) All of us are blind, but some of us who have more knowledge than the others, are trying to find remedies for the blindness and to employ them.
('49', 366, 1, 12, 610176) That being so, how can it be otherwise than that our prayer should be imperfect?
('49', 366, 1, 13, 610257) If Narandas has the time to do so, I have suggested to him to introduce whatever reforms are possible.
('49', 366, 1, 14, 610360) The prayer ultimately is a matter of faith.
('49', 366, 1, 15, 610404) We have to bring ourselves to take sufficient interest in prayer to keep up that faith.
('49', 366, 1, 16, 610492) After all, if you go in the mornings and join the prayer group in that spirit, it will be sufficient prayer for you, no matter in what language the prayer is offered.
('49', 366, 1, 17, 610659) The practice of collective silent prayer also is prevalent in the world.
('49', 366, 1, 18, 610732) Devout men and women among the Roman Catholics can sit for hours together, absorbed in silent prayer.
('49', 366, 1, 19, 610834) Our aim is somehow to find peace of mind.
('49', 366, 1, 20, 610876) You need to cultivate the habit of reading with proper attention whatever you read.
('49', 366, 1, 21, 610960) It can be cultivated by practice.
('49', 366, 1, 22, 610994) Even in this, however, if thinking too much confuses your mind, then give up the effort to think.
('49', 366, 1, 23, 611092) Do not be overeager in this matter either.
('49', 366, 1, 24, 611135) We have clung to the practice of prayer all these years with a pure motive.
('49', 366, 1, 25, 611211) We are therefore sure to discover the right key some day.
('49', 366, 1, 26, 611269) Till then, be content with the fact that the people have begun coming.
('49', 366, 1, 27, 611340) For some things, time is the only remedy.
('49', 366, 1, 28, 611382) The more we think about it, the worse the thing gets but if we wait in patience, we will discover the remedy.
('49', 366, 1, 29, 611492) This is not likely to give much satisfaction to one like you.
('49', 366, 1, 30, 611554) But just now I cannot think of anything more satisfying than this.
('49', 366, 1, 31, 611621) It is therefore best to endure what cannot be cured.
('49', 366, 1, 32, 611674) I understand what you say about the spinning wheel.
('49', 366, 1, 33, 611726) Insist that all the girls who are carrying on the experiment, clean their spinning wheels properly.
('49', 366, 1, 34, 611826) Banish from your mind the thought that the girls will never do or cannot do this work.

('49', 372, 1, 2, 617344) 413. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('49', 372, 2, 3, 617368) UNREVISED July 20, 1930
('49', 372, 4, 4, 617392) It pained me to have to refuse to see you.
('49', 372, 4, 5, 617435) 1 But the proof of my having done the right thing came the next morning.
('49', 372, 4, 6, 617508) The Government have rejected my offer and therefore there can be no interviews now.
('49', 372, 4, 7, 617592) It would be unbecoming for me to press my view point.
('49', 372, 4, 8, 617646) They are entitled to refuse every facility to prisoners as was done all the world over only a century ago or even much later.
('49', 372, 4, 9, 617772) It is enough that the exchange of letters is permitted.
('49', 372, 4, 10, 617828) But you will recognize that even this is a precarious thing.
('49', 372, 4, 11, 617889) Any moment they may stop the correspondence or impose unacceptable conditions.We can only gain by self denial.
('49', 372, 4, 12, 618000) Therefore, there need be no heartburning over this stoppage of interviews.
('49', 372, 4, 13, 618075) It is better that spirit meets spirit.
('49', 372, 4, 14, 618114) No power on earth can stop that blessed contact.
('49', 372, 5, 15, 618163) Now for the gifts you left.
('49', 372, 5, 16, 618191) I note the extraordinary care over the smallest detail.
('49', 372, 5, 17, 618247) I began the use of the new wheel immediately.
('49', 372, 5, 18, 618293) This, therefore, was the second day of use.
('49', 372, 5, 19, 618337) Today is Sunday after the commencement of silence.
('49', 372, 5, 20, 618388) But whilst this love is deep, it is not as wise as it might be.
('49', 372, 5, 21, 618452) Your wheel has not lessened the strain.
('49', 372, 5, 22, 618492) As I explained to Mathuradas, the strain was in the having to sit out for five hours in practically one posture.
('49', 372, 5, 23, 618605) If I could reduce the hours and get the same amount of production, it would be another matter.
('49', 372, 5, 24, 618700) That the new wheel is not likely to do.
('49', 372, 5, 25, 618740) As it is, the strain on the left arm is felt in using the new wheel.
('49', 372, 5, 26, 618809) For in this you have to move the arm away from you and raise it too, where [ as] in the box wheel, the arm is in a horizontal position and moves towards oneself.
('49', 372, 5, 27, 618971) Moreover, you could ill afford to give time to a matter like this and take up that of skilled workmen unless it is required by me.
('49', 372, 5, 28, 619102) I must be allowed to be capable of looking
('49', 372, 6, 29, 619145) 1 Vide “Note to Mirabehn”, 18 7 1930.
('49', 373, 0, 1, 619183) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 374
('49', 373, 1, 2, 619225) after myself and expressing my wants.
('49', 373, 1, 3, 619263) Thirdly, I have not yet been able to draw as fine a thread as on the box wheel.
('49', 373, 1, 4, 619343) The result is the use of 50 per cent more slivers—a national waste!
('49', 373, 1, 5, 619411) Enough however of criticism.
('49', 373, 1, 6, 619440) I am not going, lightly, to leave aside a thing that has come charged with so much love.

('49', 375, 1, 2, 621225) 416. LETTER TO RATILAL SHAH
('49', 375, 2, 3, 621253) July 20, 1930
('49', 375, 3, 4, 621267) BHAISHRI RATILAL,
('49', 375, 4, 5, 621285) I have your letter.
('49', 375, 4, 6, 621305) The event is sad but it is the kind of thing that is going on all the time.
('49', 375, 4, 7, 621381) I have come to the conclusion that we needlessly regard death as a matter for sorrow.
('49', 375, 4, 8, 621467) Like all other natural processes, death is also a necessary and beneficial phenomenon.
('49', 375, 4, 9, 621554) Hence even to a person denying the existence of the soul or its attributes, it is no cause for fear, and it is much less so for one who believes in the soul and its immortality.
('49', 375, 4, 10, 621732) We should not regard it as a cause for grief that Behn Zabak left the body that had outlived its utility.
('49', 375, 4, 11, 621838) As for books, I have not come across many which deserve to be read carefully and pondered.
('49', 375, 4, 12, 621929) For me, the Gita and Tulsidas suffice, and, among modern writings those of Raychandbhai.
('49', 375, 4, 13, 622018) However, if you wish to read anything recent you may read Kishorelal’s Jivanshodhan.

('49', 380, 1, 2, 626003) 424. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 380, 2, 3, 626034) July 18/22, 1930
('49', 380, 3, 4, 626051) NARANDAS,
('49', 380, 4, 5, 626061) I got your packet yesterday.
('49', 380, 4, 6, 626090) So many letters cannot be carried safely in an envelope of ordinary paper.
('49', 380, 4, 7, 626165) It was quite torn when it arrived.
('49', 380, 4, 8, 626200) You should either use envelopes lined with cloth or even though the cover is treated as a letter for purposes of postage, you should secure it strongly with a string on all sides so that the letters cannot slip out unless the string is broken.
('49', 380, 4, 9, 626444) I got the cotton as late as on the 16th.
('49', 380, 4, 10, 626485) But I was put to no difficulty.
('49', 380, 4, 11, 626517) Prabhudas and Munnalal speak in their letters about the prayers being dull.
('49', 380, 4, 12, 626593) Does not Balkrishna lead bhajans?
('49', 380, 4, 13, 626627) Would not you or somebody else speak something about the Gita or on some other subject?
('49', 380, 4, 14, 626715) Balkrishna can do so if he decides.
('49', 380, 4, 15, 626751) If we cannot do anything besides reciting Sanskrit verses, we may be content with that, but if we can we must introduce something more.
('49', 380, 4, 16, 626887) Or start reading something in Gujarati.
('49', 380, 4, 17, 626927) Discuss the matter with Prabhudas and Munnalal, then have a talk with Balkrishna and do what you think proper.
('49', 380, 4, 18, 627038) I know that you cannot spare time even to think about a matter like this.
('49', 380, 4, 19, 627112) Even then I make the suggestion.
('49', 380, 4, 20, 627145) Do what is possible.
('49', 380, 4, 21, 627166) We should make an attempt to mix with the Bharwads and make them feel one with us.
('49', 380, 4, 22, 627249) July 19, 1930 Much of what I write in these letters is meant for the whole of our group there and so I don’t mention those things in the letters to others.
('49', 380, 4, 23, 627405) One such thing is Kakasaheb’s blessings.
('49', 380, 4, 24, 627446) Let everyone know that the letter to him or her carries them.
('49', 380, 4, 25, 627508) Kakasaheb receives greetings from all the persons there, for he reads all the letters which they write and his name is mentioned in every one of them.
('49', 380, 4, 26, 627659) Both of us are glad to know this and to realize that the members of our group have humility.
('49', 380, 4, 27, 627752) Thinking about the diary, I feel that it is of priceless value to me.
('49', 380, 4, 28, 627822) For a person who has dedicated himself to the pursuit of truth, it
('49', 381, 0, 1, 627889) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 382
('49', 381, 1, 2, 627931) serves as a means of keeping watch over himself, for such a person is determined to write in it nothing but the truth.
('49', 381, 1, 3, 628050) If he has idled away his time or has done less work than usual, he must mention that.
('49', 381, 1, 4, 628136) Thus a diary helps in many ways.
('49', 381, 1, 5, 628169) It is, therefore, necessary that everyone there should realize its value.
('49', 381, 1, 6, 628243) Once we start keeping a diary regularly, we know automatically what to write and how to write it.
('49', 381, 1, 7, 628341) Yes, there is one condition, namely, that we should aim at being truthful.
('49', 381, 1, 8, 628416) If that is not so, a diary will be like a false coin.
('49', 381, 1, 9, 628470) If it contains nothing but the truth, it is of greater value than a gold mohur.
('49', 381, 1, 10, 628550) Letter No.
('49', 381, 1, 11, 628561) 60 is for Mrs. Zaulinger; read that.
('49', 381, 1, 12, 628598) Try to find out from her what her difficulty is.
('49', 381, 1, 13, 628647) I see that it is a hardship for you to have to make a list of the letters.
('49', 381, 1, 14, 628722) If that takes too much of your time, you may stop doing it.
('49', 381, 1, 15, 628782) It will suffice if you merely give the total number.
('49', 381, 1, 16, 628835) You may make a list if you can do so without inconvenience.
('49', 381, 1, 17, 628895) I must now write off visits.
('49', 381, 1, 18, 628924) You will know the reason from my letter to Mirabehn.
('49', 381, 1, 19, 628977) I don’t write about it again in this letter.
('49', 381, 1, 20, 629022) What would I do if I could not even write ?
('49', 381, 1, 21, 629066) I should give up doing that, too, if I cannot preserve my self respect while writing.
('49', 381, 1, 22, 629152) The path of bhakti is a difficult one.
('49', 381, 1, 23, 629191) But we have no other before us.
('49', 381, 1, 24, 629223) Do not worry if the number of letters goes on increasing.
('49', 381, 1, 25, 629281) Let anyone who wants to write do so freely.
('49', 381, 1, 26, 629325) It will be enough if they observe the restrictions imposed by jail rules.
('49', 381, 1, 27, 629399) Political questions should not be discussed, nor can I write anything about them.
('49', 381, 1, 28, 629481) There is, and should be, no objection to giving news about everyone.
('49', 381, 1, 29, 629550) Tell Dr. Haribhai that I often remember him.
('49', 381, 1, 30, 629595) Has Dr Kanuga completely recovered now?
('49', 381, 1, 31, 629635) After morning prayers, July 22, 1930 There is a suggestion in Vishvanath’s letter that every week I should write and send a discourse to be read out at prayer time.
('49', 381, 1, 32, 629800) I thought about the request and felt that it deserved to be complied with.
('49', 381, 1, 33, 629875) Treat these discourses as my contribution to the attempt to make the prayers more alive.
('49', 381, 1, 34, 629964) I am considering with Kakasaheb if we can send anything for the other six days as well.
('49', 381, 1, 35, 630052) Here is something for this week.
('49', 381, 2, 36, 630085) 1 This and the other discourses on the Ashram vows contained in the letters to
('49', 382, 0, 1, 630164) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 383
('49', 382, 1, 2, 630206) I deal first with truth, as the Satyagraha Ashram owes its very existence to the pursuit and the attempted practice of truth.
('49', 382, 1, 3, 630332) The word ‘satya’ is derived from sat, which means that which is.
('49', 382, 1, 4, 630397) Satya means a state of being.
('49', 382, 1, 5, 630427) Nothing is or exists in reality except Truth.
('49', 382, 1, 6, 630473) That is why sat or satya is the right name for God.
('49', 382, 1, 7, 630525) In fact it is more correct to say that Truth is God than to say that God is Truth.
('49', 382, 1, 8, 630608) But as we cannot do without a ruler or general, the name God is and will remain more current.
('49', 382, 1, 9, 630702) On deeper thinking, however, it will be realized that sat or satya is the only correct and fully significant name for God.
('49', 382, 1, 10, 630825) And where there is Truth, there also is knowledge which is true.
('49', 382, 1, 11, 630890) Where there is no Truth, there can be no true knowledge.
('49', 382, 1, 12, 630947) That is why the word chit or knowledge is associated with the name of God.
('49', 382, 1, 13, 631022) And where there is true knowledge, there is always ananda, bliss.
('49', 382, 1, 14, 631088) There sorrow has no place.
('49', 382, 1, 15, 631115) And even as Truth is eternal, so is the bliss derived from it.
('49', 382, 1, 16, 631178) Hence we know God as Sat chit ananda, one who combines in Himself Truth, knowledge and bliss.
('49', 382, 1, 17, 631272) Devotion to this Truth is the sole justification for our existence.
('49', 382, 1, 18, 631340) All our activities should be centred in truth.
('49', 382, 1, 19, 631387) Truth should be the very breath of our life.
('49', 382, 1, 20, 631432) When once this stage in the pilgrim’s progress is reached, all other rules of correct living will come without effort and obedience to them will be instinctive.
('49', 382, 1, 21, 631593) But without Truth it is impossible to observe any principles or rules in life.
('49', 382, 1, 22, 631672) Generally speaking, [observance of the law of] Truth is under stood merely to mean that we must speak the truth.
('49', 382, 1, 23, 631785) But we in the Ashram should understand the word satya or Truth in a much wider sense.
('49', 382, 1, 24, 631871) There should be Truth in thought, Truth in speech and Truth in action.
('49', 382, 1, 25, 631942) To the man who has realized this Truth in its fullness, nothing else remains to be known, because, as we have seen above, all knowledge is necessarily included in it.
('49', 382, 1, 26, 632109) What is not included in it is not Truth, and so not true knowledge; and there can be no real bliss without true knowledge.
('49', 382, 1, 27, 632232) If we once learn how to apply this never failing test of Truth, we will at once be able to find out what is worth doing, what is worth seeing, what is worth reading.
('49', 382, 1, 28, 632398) But how is one to realize this Truth, which may be likened to the
('49', 382, 2, 29, 632464) Narandas Gandhi first appeared in book form under the title Mangal Prabhat (Tuesday Morning).
('49', 382, 2, 30, 632558) The translation is reproduced from From Yeravda Mandir, with a few changes to bring it into conformity with the Gujarati.
('49', 382, 2, 31, 632680) Gandhiji states in the preface to the booklet that he had gone through it carefully and revised the translation in places.
('49', 383, 0, 1, 632803) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 384
('49', 383, 1, 2, 632845) philosopher's stone or the cow of plenty?
('49', 383, 1, 3, 632887) By abhyasa, single minded devotion, and vairagya, indifference to all other interests in life— replies the Bhagavad Gita.
('49', 383, 1, 4, 633009) Even so, what may appear as truth to one person will often appear as untruth to another person.
('49', 383, 1, 5, 633105) But that need not worry the seeker.
('49', 383, 1, 6, 633141) Where there is honest effort, it will be realized that what appear to be different truths are like the countless and apparently different leaves of the same tree.
('49', 383, 1, 7, 633304) Does not God Himself appear to different individuals in different aspects?
('49', 383, 1, 8, 633379) Yet we know that He is one.
('49', 383, 1, 9, 633407) But Truth is the right designation of God.
('49', 383, 1, 10, 633450) Hence there is nothing wrong in every man following Truth according to his lights.
('49', 383, 1, 11, 633533) Indeed it is his duty to do so.
('49', 383, 1, 12, 633565) Then if there is a mistake on the part of anyone so following Truth, it will be automatically set right.
('49', 383, 1, 13, 633670) For the quest of Truth involves tapascharya, self suffering, sometimes even unto death.
('49', 383, 1, 14, 633758) There can be no place in it for even a trace of self interest.
('49', 383, 1, 15, 633821) In such selfless search for Truth, nobody can lose his bearings for long.
('49', 383, 1, 16, 633895) Directly he takes to the wrong path he stumbles, and is thus redirected to the right path.
('49', 383, 1, 17, 633986) Therefore the pursuit of Truth is true bhakti, devotion.
('49', 383, 1, 18, 634043) Such bhakti is “a bargain in which one risks one's very life”.
('49', 383, 1, 19, 634106) It is the path that leads to God.
('49', 383, 1, 20, 634140) There is no place in it for cowardice, no place for defeat.
('49', 383, 1, 21, 634200) It is the talisman by which death itself becomes the portal to life eternal.
('49', 383, 1, 22, 634277) But now we have come to the border line beyond which lies ahimsa.
('49', 383, 1, 23, 634343) We shall discuss it next week.
('49', 383, 1, 24, 634374) In this connection, it would be well to ponder over the lives and examples of Harishchandra, Prahlad, Ramachandra, Imam Hasan and Imam Husain, the Christian saints, etc.
('49', 383, 1, 25, 634544) How beautiful it would be if all of us, young and old, men and women, meditated, till next week, on these thoughts at all hours of the day, whether working, eating, drinking or playing, and were rewarded with innocent sleep?
('49', 383, 1, 26, 634769) God as Truth has been for me, at any rate, a treasure beyond price.
('49', 383, 1, 27, 634837) May He be so to every one of us.

('49', 384, 2, 3, 635218) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, July 23, 1930
('49', 384, 3, 4, 635256) CONSTITUTIONAL ISSUE2
('49', 384, 4, 5, 635278) 1. So far as this question is concerned, my personal position is that if the Round Table Conference is restricted to a discussion of safeguards that may be necessary in connection with full Self Government during the period of transition, I should have no objection, it being understood that the question of independence should not be ruled out if anybody raises it.
('49', 384, 4, 6, 635645) I should be satisfied before I could endorse the idea of the Congress attending the Conference about its whole composition.
('49', 384, 5, 7, 635769) CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE AND ITS CALLING OFF3
('49', 384, 6, 8, 635809) 2. If the Congress is satisfied as to the Round Table Conference, naturally civil disobedience would be called off, that is to say, dis obedience of certain laws for the sake of disobedience, but peaceful picketing of foreign cloth and liquor will be continued unless the Government themselves can enforce prohibition of liquor and foreign cloth.
('49', 384, 6, 9, 636156) But manufacture of salt by the populace will have to be continued and the penal clauses of the Salt Act should not be enforced.
('49', 384, 6, 10, 636284) There will be no raids on Government Salt Depots or private depots.
('49', 384, 6, 11, 636352) I will agree even if this clause is not made a clause in these terms, but is accepted as an understanding in writing.
('49', 384, 6, 12, 636470) 3 (a) Simultaneously with the calling off of the civil disobedience, all satyagrahi prisoners and other political prisoners convicted or under trial, who have not been guilty of violence or incitement to violence should be ordered to be released, and (b) properties confiscated under the Salt Act and Press Act and

('49', 385, 1, 3, 637453) (d) All officers including village officers who have resigned or who may have been dismissed during the civil disobedience move ment and who may desire to rejoin Government service should be restored.

('49', 386, 5, 6, 639359) My position is essentially awkward.
('49', 386, 5, 7, 639395) Being temperamentally so built, I cannot give a decisive opinion on matters happening outside the prison walls.
('49', 386, 5, 8, 639507) What I have therefore given to our friends is the rou ghest draft of what is likely to satisfy me personally.

('49', 386, 6, 14, 640009) You and I can only give our advice to him.
