('49', 386, 6, 16, 640167) But Jawahar and, for that matter, also you may consider my position to be inconsistent with the intrinsic Congress policy or the present temper of the people.
('49', 386, 6, 17, 640326) I should have no hesitation in supporting any stronger position up to the letter of the Lahore resolution.
('49', 386, 6, 18, 640433) You need therefore attach no weight to my memorandum unless it finds an echo in the hearts of you both.
('49', 386, 6, 19, 640537) I know that neither you nor Jawahar were enamoured of the eleven points brought out in my first letter to the Viceroy.
('49', 386, 6, 20, 640656) I do not know whether you still have the same opinion.
('49', 386, 6, 21, 640711) My own mind is quite clear about them.
('49', 386, 6, 22, 640750) They are to me the substance of independence.
('49', 386, 6, 23, 640796) I should have nothing to do with anything that would not give the nation the power to give immediate effect to them.
('49', 386, 6, 24, 640913) In restricting myself to the three only in the memorandum, I have not waived the other eight.But the three are now brought out to deal with civil disobedience.

('49', 389, 2, 3, 643707) July 26, 1930
('49', 389, 3, 4, 643721) BHAGWANJI,
('49', 389, 4, 5, 643732) I have your letter.
('49', 389, 4, 6, 643752) What you did in the case of Manibehn is quite correct.
('49', 389, 4, 7, 643807) In the case of a lady whom we have accommodated we would have done our duty after having pointed out her faults dispa ssionately.
('49', 389, 4, 8, 643937) In this case too you should do the same.
('49', 389, 4, 9, 643978) You should explain to her that your suspicion will not be removed by [her] under taking a fast.
('49', 389, 4, 10, 644074) Why should she undertake a fast if she has committed no fault?

('49', 389, 4, 13, 644225) If she refuses to be persuaded in spite of all this, let events take their own course.
('49', 389, 4, 14, 644312) But tell Manibehn on my behalf that fasting without my permission is forbidden.
('49', 389, 4, 15, 644392) She should therefore give up her fast if she hasn’t already done so.

('49', 390, 1, 2, 644589) 432. LETTER TO BALIBEHN M. ADALAJA
('49', 390, 2, 3, 644624) [After July 26, 1930] 1
('49', 390, 3, 4, 644648) BALI, Your letter has come after a long time.
('49', 390, 3, 5, 644694) I can understand that Harilal’s behaviour pains you.
('49', 390, 3, 6, 644747) But what else do we have to learn in the world except facing happy as well as unhappy times?
('49', 390, 3, 7, 644840) It is true that even though I have regarded you sisters as daughters.
('49', 390, 3, 8, 644910) I have not been able to do anything.
('49', 390, 3, 9, 644947) Nor has Ramdas been able to do anything.
('49', 390, 3, 10, 644988) But at present, do I have anything except good feelings for my kith and kin?
('49', 390, 3, 11, 645065) My way of life is unusual.
('49', 390, 3, 12, 645092) If you can understand that while serving a miserable untouchable I am also serving you, then you will forgive me; but if you do not understand, you are bound to be angry.
('49', 390, 3, 13, 645263) I must put up with it.
('49', 390, 3, 14, 645286) I asked you to live with me and absorb yourselves with my work, but you have not done it.
('49', 390, 3, 15, 645376) Hence, far that I am, what more can I do except wish you well?
('49', 390, 3, 16, 645439) You have started giving ornaments to Manu 2. I have just heard that you have pierced her ears.
('49', 390, 3, 17, 645534) I was pained to hear that.
('49', 390, 3, 18, 645561) By doing that, you have broken your agreement with me.
('49', 390, 3, 19, 645616) I do not wish to hurt your feelings.
('49', 390, 3, 20, 645653) But let us not make Manu a shuttle cock between us.
('49', 390, 3, 21, 645705) If you are agreeable to my request, bring her up according to my wishes.
('49', 390, 3, 22, 645778) If you insist on not listening, then what can I say to you?
('49', 390, 3, 23, 645838) I am not able to tell you anything and I am not able to bear such an act on your part.
('49', 390, 3, 24, 645925) Write and explain.
('49', 390, 3, 25, 645944) Blessings from
('49', 390, 5, 26, 645959) From the Gujarati original : C. W. 5050. Courtesy : Surendra Mashruwala

('49', 398, 1, 2, 653599) 444. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('49', 398, 2, 3, 653623) [July 28, 1930] 1
('49', 398, 4, 4, 653641) I have your letter.
('49', 398, 4, 5, 653661) I am sticking to your wheel.
('49', 398, 4, 6, 653690) It is now causing less strain.
('49', 398, 4, 7, 653721) The mal has not given any trouble at all.
('49', 398, 4, 8, 653763) In that respect yours is a better wheel.
('49', 398, 4, 9, 653804) I have still difficulty in getting the required fineness.
('49', 398, 4, 10, 653862) Anyway, I shall not easily let it go.
('49', 398, 4, 11, 653900) The speed is still poor.
('49', 398, 4, 12, 653925) Today for the first time I got 154 rounds in 65 minutes.
('49', 398, 4, 13, 653982) This was encouraging for me.
('49', 398, 4, 14, 654011) On the travelling wheel I had reached 200 rounds per hour when the machine went on without a break.
('49', 398, 4, 15, 654111) In translating the hymns for you I am giving myself much joy.
('49', 398, 4, 16, 654173) Have I not expressed my love oftener in storms than in gentle soot hing showers of affection?
('49', 398, 4, 17, 654267) The memory of these storms adds to the pleasure of this exclusive translation for you.
('49', 398, 4, 18, 654354) But it is a long affair.
('49', 398, 4, 19, 654379) I did the 10th hymn today.
('49', 398, 4, 20, 654406) The verses took me a long time.
('49', 398, 4, 21, 654438) The hymn I am doing one per day.
('49', 398, 4, 22, 654471) And I have still nearly 170 to do!
('49', 398, 4, 23, 654506) There is, therefore, not much likelihood of my reaching the Gita just yet.
('49', 398, 4, 24, 654581) Your fever is disturbing.
('49', 398, 4, 25, 654607) You are still sensitive to changes.
('49', 398, 4, 26, 654643) Do please take care of yourself and do not hesitate to travel 2nd if you find it at all necessary.
('49', 398, 4, 27, 654742) I am looking forward to this week’s letter.

('49', 405, 5, 11, 661861) 455. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 405, 6, 12, 661892) July 28/31, 1930
('49', 405, 7, 13, 661909) NARANDAS, I got your letter.
('49', 405, 7, 14, 661938) Kakasaheb remarks that the ink and the paper which you use are such that the ink comes out on the other side of the sheet, and hence it will not do to write on both sides.
('49', 405, 7, 15, 662110) What he says is correct.
('49', 405, 7, 16, 662135) In such a case, it is desirable to write on one side only.
('49', 405, 7, 17, 662194) This time the letters were properly packed.
('49', 405, 7, 18, 662238) I preserve the envelopes and will use them when I need them.
('49', 405, 7, 19, 662299) I have already told you in my previous letter that I had received the cotton.
('49', 405, 7, 20, 662377) I could card some of it only today.
('49', 405, 7, 21, 662413) The air was very moist because of the rains.
('49', 405, 7, 22, 662458) It is not the spinning which tires me out, but the sitting for long hours.
('49', 405, 7, 23, 662533) I shall discover some way by and by.
('49', 405, 7, 24, 662570) I will not readily accept defeat.
('49', 405, 7, 25, 662604) There is nothing in this which need cause you concern.
('49', 405, 7, 26, 662659) Even when I was out of jail, did I ever sit at the spinning wheel for four or five hours at a stretch?
('49', 405, 7, 27, 662762) The injury to Keshu’s finger must have healed by now.
('49', 405, 7, 28, 662816) Can Balkrishna’s body stand the strain of night watch?
('49', 405, 7, 29, 662871) He should not do anything beyond his strength.
('49', 405, 7, 30, 662918) Both of us keep good health.
('49', 405, 7, 31, 662947) On a spring balance Kakasaheb weighed 109 lb.
('49', 405, 7, 32, 662993) He must be walking about 8 miles a day, including the walking he does for exercise and during work.
('49', 405, 7, 33, 663093) The exertion of spinning is in addition to this.
('49', 405, 7, 34, 663142) His diet is still the same.
('49', 405, 7, 35, 663170) If there are any men or women to whom I have not written and who expect letters from me, let me know their names.
('49', 405, 7, 36, 663284) I should have had a letter from Ramabehn (Ranchhodbhai’s).
('49', 405, 7, 37, 663343) She must have received mine.
('49', 405, 7, 38, 663372) Now about ahimsa.
('49', 406, 0, 1, 663390) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 407
('49', 406, 1, 2, 663432) Tuesday morning The commencement of this discourse is both comic and painful.
('49', 406, 1, 3, 663510) We two had a discussion on how to economize in the use of cloth lined envelopes and save the same envelopes for use again and again.
('49', 406, 1, 4, 663643) The question was whether to paste a blank sheet on the whole side of the envelope or paste only slips over portions where something was written.
('49', 406, 1, 5, 663788) This was a futile discussion.
('49', 406, 1, 6, 663818) We wasted on it 15 minutes of beautiful time after prayers, demonstrating our foolishness thereby.
('49', 406, 1, 7, 663917) In doing this we violated truth and ahimsa and displayed lack of discrimination.
('49', 406, 1, 8, 663998) Truth was violated, because the discussion was not inspired by an ardent desire for its search.
('49', 406, 1, 9, 664094) Ahimsa was shamed, because I, who ought to give every moment of my time to discover the sufferings of the people and in thinking about the ways of ending them, wasted 15 priceless minutes in a futile discussion.
('49', 406, 1, 10, 664306) We displayed lack of discrimination, because if we had thought about the utility of the discussion, it would not have lasted even a minute.
('49', 406, 1, 11, 664446) After we had stolen 15 minutes from people’s time, we realized our foolishness and thanked God for opening our eyes.
('49', 406, 1, 12, 664563) I have purposely given this introduction.
('49', 406, 1, 13, 664605) The path of Truth is as narrow as it is straight.
('49', 406, 1, 14, 664655) Even so is that of ahimsa.
('49', 406, 1, 15, 664682) It is like balancing oneself on the edge of a sword.
('49', 406, 1, 16, 664735) By concentration an acrobat can walk on a rope.
('49', 406, 1, 17, 664783) But the concentration required to tread the path of Truth and ahimsa is far greater.
('49', 406, 1, 18, 664868) The slightest inattention brings one tumbling to the ground.
('49', 406, 1, 19, 664929) One can realize Truth and ahimsa only by ceaseless striving.
('49', 406, 1, 20, 664990) But it is impossible for us to realize perfect truth so long as we are imprisoned in this mortal frame.
('49', 406, 1, 21, 665094) We can only visualize it in our imagination.
('49', 406, 1, 22, 665139) We cannot, through the instrumentality of this ephemeral body, see face to face truth which is eternal.
('49', 406, 1, 23, 665243) That is why in the last resort we must depend on faith.
('49', 406, 1, 24, 665299) It appears that the impossibility of full realization of truth in this mortal body led some ancient seeker after truth to the appreciation of ahimsa.
('49', 406, 1, 25, 665449) The question which confronted him was: “Shall I bear with those who create difficulties for me, or shall I destroy them?” The seeker realized that he who went on destroying others did not make headway but simply stayed where he was, while the man who suffered those who created difficulties marched ahead and at times even took the others with him.
('49', 406, 1, 26, 665798) The first act of destruction taught him that the truth which was the object of his quest was not outside himself but
('49', 407, 0, 1, 665915) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 407, 1, 2, 665957) within.
('49', 407, 1, 3, 665965) Hence the more he took to violence, the more he receded from truth.
('49', 407, 1, 4, 666033) For in fighting the imagined enemy without, he neglected the enemy within.
('49', 407, 1, 5, 666108) We punish thieves because we think they harass us.
('49', 407, 1, 6, 666159) They may leave us alone; but they will only transfer their attentions to another victim.
('49', 407, 1, 7, 666248) This other victim, however, is also a human being, ourselves in a different form, and so we are caught in a vicious circle.
('49', 407, 1, 8, 666372) The trouble from thieves continues to increase, as they think it is their business to steal.
('49', 407, 1, 9, 666465) In the end we see that it is better to tolerate the thieves than to punish them.
('49', 407, 1, 10, 666546) The forbearance may even bring them to their senses.
('49', 407, 1, 11, 666599) By tolerating them we realize that thieves are not different from ourselves, they are our brethren, our friends, and may not be punished.
('49', 407, 1, 12, 666737) But whilst we may bear with the thieves, we may not endure the infliction.
('49', 407, 1, 13, 666812) That would only induce cowardice.
('49', 407, 1, 14, 666846) So we realize a further duty.
('49', 407, 1, 15, 666876) Since we regard the thieves as our kith and kin, they must be made to realize the kinship.
('49', 407, 1, 16, 666967) And so we must take pains to devise ways and means of winning them over.
('49', 407, 1, 17, 667040) This is the path of ahimsa.
('49', 407, 1, 18, 667068) It may entail continuous suffering and the cultivating of end less patience.
('49', 407, 1, 19, 667145) Given these two conditions, the thief is bound in the end to turn away from his evil ways and we shall get a clearer vision of truth.
('49', 407, 1, 20, 667279) Thus step by step we learn how to make friends with all the world; we realize the greatness of God, of Truth.
('49', 407, 1, 21, 667389) Our peace of mind increases in spite of suffering; we become braver and more ent erprising; we understand more clearly the difference between what is everlasting and what is not; we learn how to distinguish between what is our duty and what is not.
('49', 407, 1, 22, 667638) Our pride melts away and we become humble.
('49', 407, 1, 23, 667681) Our worldly attachments diminish and likewise the evil within us diminishes from day to day.
('49', 407, 1, 24, 667774) Ahimsa is not the crude thing it has been made to appear.
('49', 407, 1, 25, 667832) Not to hurt any living thing is no doubt a part of ahimsa.
('49', 407, 1, 26, 667891) But it is its least expression.
('49', 407, 1, 27, 667923) The principle of ahimsa is hurt by every evil thought, by undue haste, by lying, by hatred, by wishing ill of anybody.
('49', 407, 1, 28, 668042) It is also violated by our holding on to what the world needs.
('49', 407, 1, 29, 668105) But the world needs even what we eat day by day.
('49', 407, 1, 30, 668154) In the place where we stand there are millions of micro organisms to whom the place belongs and who are hurt by our presence there.
('49', 407, 1, 31, 668286) What should we do then?
('49', 407, 1, 32, 668310) Should we commit suicide ?
('49', 407, 1, 33, 668337) Even that is no solution, if we believe, as we do, that so long as the spirit is attached to the flesh, on every destruction of the body it weaves for itself another.
('49', 407, 1, 34, 668504) The body will cease to be only when
('49', 408, 0, 1, 668540) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 409
('49', 408, 1, 2, 668582) we give up all attachment to it.
('49', 408, 1, 3, 668615) This freedom from all attachment is the realization of God as Truth.
('49', 408, 1, 4, 668684) Such realization cannot be attained in a hurry.
('49', 408, 1, 5, 668732) Realizing that this body does not belong to us, that it is a trust handed over to our charge, we should make the right use of it and progress towards our goal.
('49', 408, 1, 6, 668892) I wished to write something which would be easy for all to understand, but I find that I have written a difficult discourse.
('49', 408, 1, 7, 669017) However, no one who has thought even a little about ahimsa should find any difficulty in understanding what I have written.
('49', 408, 1, 8, 669141) It is perhaps clear from the foregoing that without ahimsa it is not possible to seek and find Truth.
('49', 408, 1, 9, 669243) Ahimsa and Truth are so intertwined that it is practically impossible to disentangle and separate them.
('49', 408, 1, 10, 669347) They are like the two sides of a coin, or rather of a smooth unstamped metallic disc.
('49', 408, 1, 11, 669433) Who can say which is the obverse and which is the reverse?
('49', 408, 1, 12, 669492) Nevertheless, ahimsa is the means and Truth is the end.
('49', 408, 1, 13, 669548) Means to be means must always be within our reach, and so ahimsa becomes our supreme duty and Truth becomes God for us.
('49', 408, 1, 14, 669668) If we take care of the means, we are bound to reach the end sooner or later.
('49', 408, 1, 15, 669745) If we resolve to do this, we shall have won the battle.
('49', 408, 1, 16, 669801) Whatever difficulties we encounter, whatever apparent reverses we sustain, we should not lose faith but should ever repeat one mantra: “Truth exists, it alone exists.
('49', 408, 1, 17, 669968) It is the only God and there is but one way of realizing it; there is but one means and that is ahimsa.
('49', 408, 1, 18, 670072) I will never give it up.
('49', 408, 1, 19, 670097) May the God that is Truth, in whose name I have taken this pledge, give me the strength to keep it.”
('49', 408, 2, 20, 670198) Blessings from
('49', 408, 3, 21, 670213) BAPU [PS.] There are 57 letters.

('49', 409, 7, 15, 670770) 457. NOTE TO M. R. JAYAKAR 2
('49', 409, 8, 16, 670799) August 2, 1930 (1) No constitutional scheme would be acceptable to Mr. Gandhi which did not contain a clause allowing India the right to secede from the Empire at her desire and another clause which gave the right and power to India to deal satisfactorily with his eleven points.
('49', 409, 8, 17, 671079) (2) The Viceroy should be made aware of this position of Mr. Gandhi in order that the Viceroy should not consider later that these views of Mr. Gandhi had taken him by surprise when they were urged at the Round Table Conference.
('49', 409, 8, 18, 671308) The Viceroy should also be made aware that Mr. Gandhi would insist at the Round Table Conference on a clause giving India the right to have examined by an independent tribunal all the British claims and concessions given to Britishers in the past.
('49', 409, 8, 19, 671556) The Hindu, 5 9 1930
('49', 409, 9, 20, 671576) 1 From the contents; vide “Letter to Govind Patel”, 17 7 1930.
('49', 409, 10, 21, 671639) 2 On July 31, August 1 and August 2, M. R. Jayakar again saw Gandhiji who dictated this note which was to form the basis of negotiations with the Viceroy.

('49', 419, 0, 1, 683933) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 419, 1, 2, 683975) It is not likely to help me even if you send me a spinning wheel made of bamboo.
('49', 419, 1, 3, 684056) I am a lame duck in so far as spinning is concerned.
('49', 419, 1, 4, 684109) I love it, I work hard and pay great attention to it but the speed simply does not increase.
('49', 419, 1, 5, 684202) How can I blame the spinning wheel which I use?
('49', 419, 1, 6, 684250) I have not been able to see where my stupidity lies.
('49', 419, 1, 7, 684303) When I was out of jail, no one took the courage to explain it to me.

('49', 419, 1, 9, 684474) I see my error now.
('49', 419, 1, 10, 684494) But every fool has the words ‘too late’ inscribed on his forehead.
('49', 419, 1, 11, 684561) If now I let you send a bamboo spinning wheel, that would be our illustration of the saying “a dull student needs a lot of pens to use”.
('49', 419, 1, 12, 684698) I don’t want that.
('49', 419, 1, 13, 684717) I must suffer the consequences of my folly.
('49', 419, 1, 14, 684761) I am patiently observing, and improving my method wherever improvement is possible.
('49', 419, 1, 15, 684845) Moreover, I can increase the speed if my physical strength improves.
('49', 419, 1, 16, 684914) If it does not, I shall be content to live as Rama wills.
('49', 419, 1, 17, 684972) Ultimately, the blame will be His.
('49', 419, 1, 18, 685007) If I do my best, He cannot blame me.
('49', 419, 1, 19, 685044) His law ever prevails without exception, and since He is the first to obey His law, and does that perfectly, we need have no fear.
('49', 419, 1, 20, 685175) Being as great as He is, if He were to act wilfully, wouldn’t we be utterly destroyed ?
('49', 419, 1, 21, 685263) Tuesday morning Next among our observances comes brahmacharya.
('49', 419, 1, 22, 685326) As a matter of fact all observances are deducible from Truth and are meant to subserve it.
('49', 419, 1, 23, 685417) The man who is wedded to Truth and worships Truth alone proves unfaithful to it if he applies his talents to anything else.
('49', 419, 1, 24, 685541) How then can he minister to the senses?
('49', 419, 1, 25, 685581) A man, whose activities are wholly consecrated to the realization of Truth, which requires utter selflessness, can have no time for the selfish purpose of begetting children and running a household.
('49', 419, 1, 26, 685780) Realization of Truth through self gratification should, after what has been said before, appear a contradiction in terms.
('49', 419, 1, 27, 685902) If we look at it from the standpoint of ahimsa, we find that the fulfilment of ahimsa is impossible without perfect brahmacharya.
('49', 419, 1, 28, 686032) Ahimsa means universal love.
('49', 419, 1, 29, 686061) If a man gives his love to one woman, or a woman to one man, what is there left for all the world besides?
('49', 419, 1, 30, 686168) It simply means, “we two first, and the devil take all the rest of them.” As a faithful wife must be prepared to sacrifice her all for the sake of her husband, and a faithful husband for the sake of his wife, it is clear that such persons cannot rise to the height of universal love, or look upon all mankind as kith and kin.
('49', 419, 1, 31, 686494) For they have created a boundary wall or
('49', 420, 0, 1, 686535) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 421
('49', 420, 1, 2, 686577) one has been created round their love.
('49', 420, 1, 3, 686616) The larger their family, the farther are they from universal love.
('49', 420, 1, 4, 686683) We see this in the wholeworld.
('49', 420, 1, 5, 686714) Hence one who would obey the law of ahimsa cannot marry, not to speak of gratification outside the marital bond.
('49', 420, 1, 6, 686827) Then what about people who are already married?
('49', 420, 1, 7, 686875) Will they never be able to realize Truth?
('49', 420, 1, 8, 686917) Can they never offer their all at the altar of humanity?
('49', 420, 1, 9, 686974) There is a way out for them.
('49', 420, 1, 10, 687003) They can behave as if they were not married.
('49', 420, 1, 11, 687048) On this path I have known nothing as beautiful as such a relationship.
('49', 420, 1, 12, 687119) Those who have enjoyed this happy condition will be able to bear me out.
('49', 420, 1, 13, 687192) Many have to my knowledge successfully tried the experiment.
('49', 420, 1, 14, 687253) If the married couple can think of each other as brother and sister, they are freed for universal service.
('49', 420, 1, 15, 687360) The very thought that all the women in the world are his sisters, mothers or daughters will at once ennoble a man and snap his chains.
('49', 420, 1, 16, 687495) The husband and wife do not lose anything here, but only add to their resources and even to their family.
('49', 420, 1, 17, 687601) Their love becomes free from the impurity of lust and so grows stronger.
('49', 420, 1, 18, 687674) With the disappearance of this impurity, they can serve each other better, and the occasions for quarrelling become fewer.
('49', 420, 1, 19, 687797) There are more occasions for quarrelling where the love is selfish and bounded.
('49', 420, 1, 20, 687877) If the foregoing argument is appreciated, a consideration of the physical benefits of chastity becomes a matter of secondary importance.
('49', 420, 1, 21, 688014) How foolish it is intentionally to dissipate vital energy in sensual enjoyment!
('49', 420, 1, 22, 688094) It is a grave misuse to fritter away for physical gratification that which is given to man and woman for the full development of their bodily and mental powers.
('49', 420, 1, 23, 688255) Such misuse is the root cause of many a disease.
('49', 420, 1, 24, 688304) Brahmacharya like all other observances must be expressed in thought, word and deed.
('49', 420, 1, 25, 688389) We are told in the Gita, and experience will corroborate the statement, that the foolish man who appears to control his body but is nursing evil thoughts in his mind makes a futile effort.
('49', 420, 2, 26, 688578) It may be harmful to suppress the body, if the mind is at the same time allowed to go astray.
('49', 420, 2, 27, 688672) Where the mind wanders, the body must follow sooner or later.
('49', 420, 2, 28, 688734) It is necessary here to appreciate a distinction.
('49', 420, 2, 29, 688784) It is one thing to allow the mind to harbour impure thoughts; it is a different thing altogether if it strays among them in spite of ourselves.
('49', 420, 2, 30, 688928) Victory will be ours in the end if we non co operate with the mind in its evil
('49', 421, 0, 1, 689007) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 421, 1, 2, 689049) wanderings.
('49', 421, 1, 3, 689061) We experience every moment of our lives that often while the body is subject to our control the mind is not.
('49', 421, 1, 4, 689170) This physical control should never be relaxed, and in addition we must put forth a constant endeavour to bring the mind under control.
('49', 421, 1, 5, 689305) We can do nothing more, nothing less.
('49', 421, 1, 6, 689343) If we give way to the mind, the body and the mind will pull in different ways and we shall be false to ourselves.
('49', 421, 1, 7, 689457) Body and mind may be said to go together so long as we continue to resist the approach of every evil thought.
('49', 421, 1, 8, 689567) The observance of such brahmacharya has been believed to be very difficult, almost impossible.
('49', 421, 1, 9, 689662) In trying to find a reason for this belief, we see that the term brahmacharya has been taken in a narrow sense.
('49', 421, 1, 10, 689774) Mere control of animal passion has been thought to be tantamount to observing brahmacharya.
('49', 421, 1, 11, 689866) I feel that this conception is incomplete and wrong.
('49', 421, 1, 12, 689919) Brahmacharya means control of all the organs of sense.
('49', 421, 1, 13, 689974) He who attempts to control only one organ and allows all the others free play is bound to find his effort futile.
('49', 421, 1, 14, 690088) To hear suggestive stories with the ears, to see suggestive sights with the eyes, to taste stimulating food with the tongue, to touch exciting things with the hands, and yet at the same time to expect to control the generative organ is like putting one’s hands in the fire and expecting to escape being burnt.
('49', 421, 1, 15, 690398) He, therefore, who is resolved to control the one must be likewise determined to control the rest.
('49', 421, 1, 16, 690497) I have always felt that much harm has been done by the narrow definition of brahmacharya.
('49', 421, 1, 17, 690587) If we practise simultaneous self control in all directions, the attempt will soon be possible of success; nay, only then will it be possible.
('49', 421, 1, 18, 690729) Perhaps the palate is the chief sinner.
('49', 421, 1, 19, 690769) That is why in the Ashram we have assigned the control of the palate a separate place among our observances.
('49', 421, 1, 20, 690878) We shall discuss it next time.
('49', 421, 1, 21, 690909) Let us remember the root meaning of ‘brahmacharya’ ‘Charya’ means course of conduct; ‘brahmacharya’, conduct adapted to the search of Brahman, i.e., Truth.
('49', 421, 1, 22, 691065) From this etymological meaning arises the special meaning, viz., control of all the senses.
('49', 421, 1, 23, 691157) We must entirely forget the incomplete definition which restricts itself to the sexual aspect only.

('49', 421, 3, 25, 691272) BAPU [PS.] There are 45 letters.

('49', 433, 1, 2, 702523) 491. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI
('49', 433, 2, 3, 702555) August 11, 1930
('49', 433, 3, 4, 702571) PRABHDAS,
('49', 433, 4, 5, 702581) I got your letter.
('49', 433, 4, 6, 702600) Kakasaheb has liked your translation of the sthitaprajna 1. I had expected something different.
('49', 433, 4, 7, 702696) I cannot of course make any corrections from here 2 and send the thing back to you.
('49', 433, 4, 8, 702780) For the present, therefore, the translation will remain with me.
('49', 433, 4, 9, 702845) Your effort is certainly very good.
('49', 433, 4, 10, 702881) Continue learning in that manner.
('49', 433, 4, 11, 702915) It will be good if now you go to Almora as early as possible.
('49', 433, 4, 12, 702977) Let me caution you somewhat regarding your model of the spinning wheel.
('49', 433, 4, 13, 703049) I am of no use and you may take it that Kakasaheb is of no use either, nor Vinoba.
('49', 433, 4, 14, 703132) Our reasons for desiring that you should study the matter, are different from one another’s.
('49', 433, 4, 15, 703225) But from your point of view, it is sufficient that we are useless for your purpose.
('49', 433, 4, 16, 703309) Your reasoning does not seem to be correct.
('49', 433, 4, 17, 703353) The experiences which you have gathered through others, convincingly show that there will not be much increase in speed, nor will the yarn spun be even.
('49', 433, 4, 18, 703506) The fact is that your model of the spinning wheel follows the model in use at present, that is, it is not purely a machine.
('49', 433, 4, 19, 703630) A mac hine is that which requires no intelligence or dexterity.
('49', 433, 4, 20, 703694) Plying the spi nning wheel is an art and it can, therefore, be mastered only by one who has the required skill.
('49', 433, 4, 21, 703806) You should copy the Singer [sewing machine] or the spinning jenny but you are not such an expert mechanic.
('49', 433, 4, 22, 703913) It seems that a spinning wheel on which the speed can be increased only with great difficulty and which moreover is costly, has no place in our programme.
('49', 433, 4, 23, 704068) Have I been able to make this quite clear to you?
('49', 433, 4, 24, 704118) If not, write to me again.
('49', 433, 4, 25, 704145) It will be a different matter if, though you have understood what I have said, you think that my reasoning is faulty.
('49', 433, 4, 26, 704263) I have not written all this to dishearten you, but only to suggest that you should not lose your head over this particular model of the spinning wheel.
('49', 433, 4, 27, 704415) You have many other things to do in that
('49', 433, 5, 28, 704456) 1 Presumably the verses 54 to 72, chapter II of the Bhagavad Gita which describe the characteristics of a sthitaprajna, i.e., of one who is firmly established in spiritual wisdom.
('49', 433, 5, 29, 704636) 2 In Yeravda Prison
('49', 434, 0, 1, 704656) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 435
('49', 434, 1, 2, 704698) direction.
('49', 434, 1, 3, 704709) Try to understand what I have been saying about the takli.
('49', 434, 1, 4, 704768) I do not propose the takli as a substitute for the spinning wheel but the takli can enter a field where the spinning wheel cannot.
('49', 434, 1, 5, 704899) The whole plan of spinning depends upon the number of people who take it up.
('49', 434, 1, 6, 704976) If merely a handful of us had occupied this vast country, spinning would have had no place here.
('49', 434, 1, 7, 705073) If a small number of people occupy a large area, that small number has to be violent by nature.
('49', 434, 1, 8, 705169) Of what use is the takli or the spinning wheel to them as a symbol of ahimsa?
('49', 434, 1, 9, 705247) The takli or the spinning wheel is a tool to man as mandestroys the very basis of competition.
('49', 434, 1, 10, 705342) We must not think of either of them from the present day commercial point of view.
('49', 434, 1, 11, 705425) Rather, they imply the transformation of the commercial point of view itself.
('49', 434, 1, 12, 705503) In Almora, therefore, you should pursue your work in regard to wool from this point of view and not from the point of view of Kashmir.
('49', 434, 1, 13, 705638) If you give more and more importance to the principle that one should wear cloth made from yarn spun by oneself, you will have no cause to be disappointed, and will readily appreciate the great value of the takli.
('49', 434, 1, 14, 705852) Yes, if you can make suitable changes in the spinning wheel so that wool can be spun on it, do so.
('49', 434, 1, 15, 705951) That is done even in this jail.
('49', 434, 1, 16, 705983) With but a few changes, even the spinning wheels in current use will permit the spinning of wool and will produce more yarn than the takli.
('49', 434, 1, 17, 706123) However, for the roaming tribes of cowherds and shepherds, etc., the takli will certainly remain.
('49', 434, 1, 18, 706221) In that way, on the whole, the takli will be found superior from the point of view of numbers.
('49', 434, 1, 19, 706316) If you have still not followed all this, ask me again.
('49', 434, 1, 20, 706371) Belief in the usefulness of the takli is a matter not of faith but purely of reason.
('49', 434, 1, 21, 706456) In such a matter, to depend on faith may be a sign of indolence.

('49', 435, 0, 1, 706575) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 435, 1, 2, 706617) 492. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 435, 2, 3, 706648) Tuesday morning, August 12, 1930
('49', 435, 3, 4, 706681) NARANDAS, Control of the palate: Control of palate is very closely connected with the observance of brahmacharya.
('49', 435, 3, 5, 706795) I have found from experience that the observance of celibacy becomes comparatively easy if one acquires mastery over the palate.
('49', 435, 3, 6, 706924) This does not figure among the observances of time honoured recognition.
('49', 435, 3, 7, 706997) Could it be because even great sages found it difficult to achieve ?
('49', 435, 3, 8, 707066) In the Satyagraha Ashram we have elevated it to the rank of an independent observance, and must therefore consider it by itself.
('49', 435, 3, 9, 707195) Aswad means not to enjoy savour; savour means pleasure.
('49', 435, 3, 10, 707251) Food has to be taken as we take medicine, that is, without thinking whether it is palatable or otherwise and only in quantities limited to the needs of the body.
('49', 435, 3, 11, 707413) Food means everything we eat.
('49', 435, 3, 12, 707443) Hence milk and fruit are also included in it.
('49', 435, 3, 13, 707489) Just as medicine taken in too small a dose does not act or acts only partially, and as too large a dose injures the system, so it is with food.
('49', 435, 3, 14, 707633) It is, therefore, a breach of this observance to take anything just for its pleasant taste.
('49', 435, 3, 15, 707725) It is equally a breach to take too much of what one finds to one’s taste.
('49', 435, 3, 16, 707799) From this it follows that to put salt in one’s food in order to increase or modify its taste or in order to cure its insipidity is a breach of the observance.
('49', 435, 3, 17, 707958) But the addition is not a breach if it is considered necessary for health to have a certain proportion of salt with food.
('49', 435, 3, 18, 708080) Of course it would be sheer hypocrisy to add salt or any other thing to our food, deluding ourselves that it is necessary for the system if as a matter of fact it is not.
('49', 435, 3, 19, 708251) Reasoning along these lines, we find we have to give up many things that we have been enjoying, as they are not needed for nutr ition.
('49', 435, 3, 20, 708386) And one who thus gives up a multitude of eatables will acquire self control in the natural course of things.
('49', 435, 3, 21, 708495) The proverbs “one cooking vessel expects thirteen different ingredients”, “the stomach makes one submit to forced labour”, “the stomach makes one a flatterer”, etc., are full of meaning.
('49', 435, 3, 22, 708682) This subject has received such scant attention that choice of food with this observance in view isa very difficult matter.
('49', 435, 3, 23, 708805) Parents, out of false affection, give their children a
('49', 436, 0, 1, 708860) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 437
('49', 436, 1, 2, 708902) variety of foods, ruin their constitutions and create in them artificial tastes.
('49', 436, 1, 3, 708983) When they grow up, they have diseased bodies and perverted tastes.
('49', 436, 1, 4, 709050) The evil consequences of this early indulgence dog us at every step; we waste much money and fall an easy prey to the medicine man.
('49', 436, 1, 5, 709182) Most of us, instead of keeping the organs of sense under control, become their slaves.
('49', 436, 1, 6, 709269) An experienced physician once observed that he had never seen a healthy man.
('49', 436, 1, 7, 709346) The body is injured every time that one overeats, and the injury can be partially repaired only by fasting.
('49', 436, 1, 8, 709454) No one need take fright at my observations or give up the effort in despair.
('49', 436, 1, 9, 709531) The taking of a vow does not mean that we are able to observe it completely from the very beginning; it does mean constant and honest effort in thought; word and deed with a view to its ful filment.
('49', 436, 1, 10, 709730) We must not practise self deception by resorting to some make believe.
('49', 436, 1, 11, 709801) To degrade or cheapen an ideal for our convenience is to practise untruth and to lower ourselves.
('49', 436, 1, 12, 709899) To understand an ideal and then to make a Herculean effort to reach it, no matter how difficult it is, this is purushartha, manly endeavour.
('49', 436, 1, 13, 710040) (The word ‘purusha’ should be interpreted in its etymological sense, and, not merely to mean a man.
('49', 436, 1, 14, 710140) That which dwells in the pura, the body, is purusha.
('49', 436, 1, 15, 710193) If we interpret the word ‘purushartha’ in this sense, it can be used equally for men and women.) One who at all times fulfils the key observances in their perfection has nothing else left for him to do in this world, he is Bhagavan, perfect man; he is a yogi.
('49', 436, 1, 16, 710453) We are but humble creatures, aspiring after moksha and seeking knowledge, determined to follow Truth and dedicated to its quest.
('49', 436, 1, 17, 710582) As taught in the Gita, therefore, we should keep on struggling humbly but vigilantly.
('49', 436, 1, 18, 710668) If we do so, one day we shall be fit for God’s grace and then all our pleasures in objects of sense will disappear.
('49', 436, 1, 19, 710784) If we have realized the importance of this observance, we should make fresh effort to practise it.
('49', 436, 1, 20, 710883) For that, it is not necessary to think about food all the hours of the day.
('49', 436, 1, 21, 710959) The only thing needful is perpetual vigilance, which will help us to find out very soon when we eat for self indulgence and when in order only to sustain the body.
('49', 436, 1, 22, 711123) This being discovered, we must resolutely set our faces against mere indulgence.
('49', 436, 1, 23, 711204) A common kitchen where this principle is observed is very helpful, as it relieves us from the necessity of thinking out the menu for each day, and provides us with acceptable food of which we may take only a limited quantity with a contented and thankful mind.
('49', 436, 1, 24, 711465) By eating thus we are able to observe without any difficulty the vow of
('49', 437, 0, 1, 711537) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 437, 1, 2, 711579) controlling the palate.
('49', 437, 1, 3, 711603) The authorities of a common kitchen lighten our burden and serve as watch dogs of our observance.
('49', 437, 1, 4, 711701) They will not pamper us, they will cook only such food as helps us to keep the body a fit instrument for service.
('49', 437, 1, 5, 711815) In ideal conditions we should require the use of fire but rarely or not at all.
('49', 437, 1, 6, 711895) We should find our food from what the great fire, the sun, cooks.
('49', 437, 1, 7, 711961) If we look at the matter from this point of view, it becomes clear to us that man is purely a herbivorous creature.
('49', 437, 1, 8, 712077) But here we need not go so deep into the matter.
('49', 437, 1, 9, 712126) All that is necessary for us to consider here is the nature of the vow of controlling the palate, the difficulties involved in its observance and its close connection with the observance of brahmacharya.
('49', 437, 1, 10, 712330) Having understood this, let everyone make an honest effort to observe the vow to the best of his or her ability.
('49', 437, 2, 11, 712443) Blessings from
('49', 437, 3, 12, 712458) BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro—9: Shri Narandas Gandhine, Part I, pp.

('49', 440, 5, 8, 718801) 494. LETTER TO T. B. SAPRU AND M. R. JAYAKAR 1
('49', 440, 6, 9, 718848) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, August 15, 1930
('49', 440, 7, 10, 718888) DEAR FRIENDS, We are deeply grateful to you for having undertaken the duty of trying to effect a peaceful settlement between the British Government and the Congress.
('49', 440, 7, 11, 719054) After having perused the correspondence between yourselves and His Excellency the Viceroy and having had the benefit of protracted talks with you and having discussed among ourselves, we have come to the conclusion that the time is not yet ripe for securing a settlement honourable for our country.
('49', 440, 7, 12, 719353) Marvellous as has been the massawakening during the past five months and great as has been the sufferings of the people among all grades and classes representing the different creeds, we feel that the sufferings have been neither sustained enough nor large enough for the immediate attainment of the end.
('49', 440, 7, 13, 719658) Needless to mention we do not in any way share your view or the Viceroy’s that civil disobedience has harmed the country or that it is ill timed or unconstitutional.
('49', 440, 7, 14, 719824) English history teems with instances of bloody revolts whose praises Englishmen have sung unstintingly and
('49', 440, 8, 15, 719931) 1 A joint interview took place in the Yeravda Jail on August 14 and 15 between Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and M. R. Jayakar on the one hand and Gandhiji, Motilal Nehru, Jawaharlal Nehru, Vallabhbhai Patel, Dr. Syed Mahmud, Jairamdas Doulatram and Sarojini Naidu on the other.
('49', 440, 8, 16, 720202) After the discussions this letter was given to Sapru and Jayakar with permission to show it to the Viceroy.
('49', 440, 8, 17, 720310) For Sapru and Jayakar’s reply, vide “Letter from T.B.Sapru and M.R.Jayakar to congress leaders”, 16 8 1930.
('49', 441, 0, 1, 720418) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 441, 1, 2, 720460) taught us to do likewise.
('49', 441, 1, 3, 720486) It therefore ill becomes the Viceroy or any intelligent Englishman to condemn a revolt that is in intention and that has overwhelmingly remained in execution peaceful, but we have no desire to quarrel with condemnation, whether official or unofficial, of the present civil disobedience campaign.
('49', 441, 1, 4, 720782) The wonderful mass response to the movement is, we hold, its sufficient justification.
('49', 441, 1, 5, 720869) What is, however, the point here is the fact that we gladly make common cause with you in wishing, if it is at all possible, to stop or suspend civil disobedience.
('49', 441, 1, 6, 721033) It can be no pleasure to us needlessly to expose the men, women and even the children of our country to imprisonment, lathi charges and worse.
('49', 441, 1, 7, 721176) You will, therefore, believe us when we assure you and through you the Viceroy that we would leave no stone unturned to explore any and every channel for honourable peace, but we are free to confess as yet we see no such sign on the horizon.
('49', 441, 1, 8, 721418) We notice no symptom of conversion of the English official world to the view that it is India’s men and women who must decide what is best for India.
('49', 441, 1, 9, 721568) We distrust the pious declarations of the good intentions, often well meant, of officials.
('49', 441, 1, 10, 721659) The age long exploitation by the English of the people of this ancient land has rendered them almost incapable of seeing the ruin, moral, economic and political, of our country which this exploitation has brought about.
('49', 441, 1, 11, 721879) They cannot persuade themselves to see that one thing needful for them to do is to get off our backs and do some reparation for the past wrongs, by helping us to grow out of the dwarfing process that has gone on for a century of British domination, but we know you and some of our learned countrymen think differently.
('49', 441, 1, 12, 722198) You believe a conversion has taken place, at any rate, sufficient to warrant participation in the proposed Conference.
('49', 441, 1, 13, 722317) In spite, therefore, of the limitation we are labouring under, we would gladly co operate with you to the extent of our ability.
('49', 441, 1, 14, 722446) The following is the utmost response it is possible for us, circumstanced as we are, to make to your friendly endeavour.
('49', 441, 1, 15, 722567) We feel the language used by the Viceroy in the reply given to your letter about the proposed Conference is too vague to enable usto assess its value in terms of the National Demand framed last year in Lahore nor are we in a position to say anything authoritative without reference to a properly constituted meeting of the Working Committee of the Congress and if necessary to the A.I.C.C., but we can say that for
('49', 442, 0, 1, 722982) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 443
('49', 442, 1, 2, 723024) us individually no solution will be satisfactory unless (a) it recognizes in as many words the right of India to secede at will from the British Empire, (b) it gives to India complete national Government responsible to her people including the control of defence forces and economic control and covers all the eleven points raised in Gandhiji’s letter to the Viceroy and (c) it gives to India the right to refer if necessary to an independent tribunal such British claims, concessions and the like including the so called public debt of India as may seem to the national Government to be unjust or not in the interest of the people of India.
('49', 442, 2, 3, 723666) Such adjustments as may be necessitated in the interests of India during the transference of power to be determined by India’s chosen representatives.
('49', 442, 2, 4, 723817) (2) If the foregoing appears to be feasible to the British Government and a satisfactory declaration is made to that effect, we should recommend to the Working Committee the advisability of calling off civil disobedience, that is to say, disobedience of certain laws for the sake of disobedience but peaceful picketing of foreign cloth and liquor will be continued unless Government themselves can enforce prohibition of liquor and foreign cloth.
('49', 442, 2, 5, 724264) The manufacture of salt by the people will have to be continued and the penal clauses of the Salt Act should not be enforced.
('49', 442, 2, 6, 724390) There will be no raids on Government or private salt depots.
('49', 442, 2, 7, 724451) (3) Simultaneously with the calling off of civil disobedience (a) all the satyagrahi prisoners and other political prisoners convicted or under trial who have not been guilty of violence or incitement to violence should be ordered to be released, (b) properties confiscated under the Salt Act, the Press Act, the Revenue Act and the like should be restored, (c) fines and securities taken from convicted satyagrahis or under the Press Act should be refunded, (d) all the officers including village officers who have resigned or who may have been dismissed during the civil disobedience movement and who may desire to rejoin Government service should be reinstated.
('49', 442, 2, 8, 725116) The foregoing sub clauses refer also to the Non cooperation period.
('49', 442, 2, 9, 725184) (e) All the Viceregal Ordinances should be repealed.

('49', 443, 1, 2, 725279) (4) The question of the composition of the proposed Conference and of the Congress being represented at it can only be decided after the foregoing preliminaries are satisfactorily settled.

('49', 444, 3, 4, 726146) PREMA, You should not lose patience.
('49', 444, 3, 5, 726183) It is not easy to control the mind.
('49', 444, 3, 6, 726219) But you should have faith that, with proper effort, it can be done.
('49', 444, 3, 7, 726287) What effect did the eating of bitter gourds have on your health?

('49', 449, 6, 19, 730706) 507. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('49', 449, 7, 20, 730737) Unrevised
('49', 449, 8, 21, 730747) YERAVDA MANDIR, Tuesday morning, August 19, 1930
('49', 449, 9, 22, 730796) NARANDAS, We now come to the observance of non stealing.
('49', 449, 9, 23, 730853) On deeper reflection we see that all observances are implicit in Truth and ahimsa or truth alone.
('49', 449, 9, 24, 730951) This can be expressed thus: Truth Truth Ahimsa Ahimsa or
('49', 449, 10, 25, 731008) Brahmacharya Control of Non Non Fearlessness the Palate stealing possession and so on
('49', 450, 0, 1, 731094) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 451
('49', 450, 1, 2, 731136) Ahimsa may be deduced from Truth, or may be paired with Truth.
('49', 450, 1, 3, 731199) Truth and ahimsa are one and the same thing.
('49', 450, 1, 4, 731244) I am partial to Truth, however.
('49', 450, 1, 5, 731276) In the final analysis there can only be a single reality.
('49', 450, 1, 6, 731334) The highest Truth stands by itself.
('49', 450, 1, 7, 731370) Truth is the end, ahimsa is the means thereto.
('49', 450, 1, 8, 731417) We know what ahimsa or non violence is, although we find it difficult to follow the law of love.
('49', 450, 1, 9, 731514) But as for Truth, we know only a fraction of it.
('49', 450, 1, 10, 731563) Perfect knowledge of Truth is difficult of attainment for man even like the perfect practice of non violence.
('49', 450, 1, 11, 731673) Asteya means non stealing.
('49', 450, 1, 12, 731700) It is impossible that a person should steal and simultaneously claim to know Truth or cherish love.
('49', 450, 1, 13, 731800) Yet every one of us is consciously or unconsciously, more or less, guilty of theft.
('49', 450, 1, 14, 731884) We may steal not only what belongs to others, but also what belongs to ourselves, as is done, for instance, by a father who eats something secretly, keeping his children in the dark about it.
('49', 450, 1, 15, 732076) The Ashram kitchen stores are our common property, but one who secretly removes a single crystal of sugar from it stamps himself a thief.
('49', 450, 1, 16, 732214) A child who takes another’s pen steals.
('49', 450, 1, 17, 732254) It is theft to take anything belonging to another without his permission, even if it be with his knowledge.
('49', 450, 1, 18, 732362) It is equally theft to take something in the belief that it is nobody’s property.
('49', 450, 1, 19, 732444) Things found on the roadside belong to the ruler or the local authority.
('49', 450, 1, 20, 732517) Anything found near the Ashram must be handed over to the secretary, who in his turn will pass it on to the police if it is not Ashram property.
('49', 450, 1, 21, 732662) Thus far, it is pretty smooth sailing.
('49', 450, 1, 22, 732701) But the observance of non stealing goes very much farther.
('49', 450, 1, 23, 732760) It is theft to take something from another even with his permission if we have no real need of it.
('49', 450, 1, 24, 732859) We should not receive any single thing that we do not need.
('49', 450, 1, 25, 732919) Theft of this description generally has food for its object.
('49', 450, 1, 26, 732980) It is theft for me to take any fruit that I do not need, or to take it in a larger quantity than is necessary.
('49', 450, 1, 27, 733091) We are not always aware of our real needs, and most of us improperly multiply our wants and thus unconsciously make thieves of ourselves.
('49', 450, 1, 28, 733229) If we devote some thought to the subject we shall find that we can get rid of quite a number of our wants.
('49', 450, 1, 29, 733336) One who follows the observance of non stealing will bring about a progressive reduction of his wants.
('49', 450, 1, 30, 733438) Much of the distressing poverty in this world has arisen out of breaches of the principle of non stealing.
('49', 450, 1, 31, 733545) Theft thus far considered may be termed external or physical theft.
('49', 450, 1, 32, 733613) There is, besides, another kind of theft, subtler and far more
('49', 451, 0, 1, 733676) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 451, 1, 2, 733718) degrading to the human spirit.
('49', 451, 1, 3, 733749) It is theft mentally to desire acquisition of anything belonging to others, or to cast a greedy eye on it.
('49', 451, 1, 4, 733856) It is mental theft if anyone, whether a grown up person or a child, feels tempted by the sight of an attractive thing.
('49', 451, 1, 5, 733975) One who takes no food, physically speaking, is generally said to be fasting, but he is guilty of theft as well as a breach of his fast if he gives himself up to a mental contemplation of pleasure when he sees others taking their meals.
('49', 451, 1, 6, 734211) He is similarly guilty if, during his fast, he is continually planning the varied menu he will have after breaking the fast.
('49', 451, 1, 7, 734336) One who observes the principle of non stealing will refuse to bother himself about things to be acquired in future.
('49', 451, 1, 8, 734452) This evil anxiety for the future will be found at the root of many a theft.
('49', 451, 1, 9, 734528) Today we only desire possession of a thing; tomorrow we shall begin to adopt measures, straight if possible, crooked when thought necessary, to acquire its possession.
('49', 451, 1, 10, 734696) Ideas may be stolen no less than material things.
('49', 451, 1, 11, 734746) One who egotistically claims to have originated some good idea, which, really speaking, did not originate with him, is guilty of a theft of ideas.
('49', 451, 1, 12, 734893) Many learned men have committed such theft in the course of world history, and pla giarizm is by no means uncommon even today.
('49', 451, 1, 13, 735020) Supposing, for instance, that I see a new type of spinning wheel in Andhra and manufacture a similar wheel in the Ashram, passing it off as my own invention, I practise untruth and am clearly guilty of stealing another’s invention.
('49', 451, 1, 14, 735252) One who takes up the observance of non stealing has, therefore, to be humble, thoughtful, vigilant and in habits simple.
('49', 451, 1, 15, 735373) I have written the Ashram letters today under much pressure of time.
('49', 451, 1, 16, 735442) Motilalji and others are here and I spent practically the whole of the last week in discussions with them.
('49', 451, 1, 17, 735549) Even now I must give some time to them.
('49', 451, 1, 18, 735589) I could, therefore, take up writing letters only yesterday evening after the prayers and started writing this after the morning prayers today.
('49', 451, 1, 19, 735732) There are, therefore, the fewest letters this time and I have made them as short as I could.
('49', 451, 1, 20, 735825) You will read about .
('49', 451, 1, 21, 735847) .behn 1 in my letters to Gan gabehn and Bhansali.
('49', 451, 1, 22, 735897) Be firm and go on doing what you think proper.
('49', 451, 1, 23, 735944) My immediate reaction is that, if .
('49', 451, 1, 24, 735980) .behn’s mind has become steady and recovered its purity, we can condone her violation of the pledge to go away and live outside the Ashram.
('49', 451, 1, 25, 736120) The chief thing to consider now is how to help her to overcome her passion and, on the other hand, to safeguard her freedom.
('49', 451, 1, 26, 736245) Women have been so completely suppressed that in their helplessness they cannot even think.
('49', 451, 1, 27, 736337) The Ashram,
('49', 451, 2, 28, 736349) 1 The name has been omitted.
('49', 452, 0, 1, 736378) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 453

('49', 452, 1, 3, 736483) This involves many risks.
('49', 452, 1, 4, 736509) We should take them if we wish to serve women.
('49', 452, 1, 5, 736556) Act upon this view within the limits of your capacity.
('49', 452, 1, 6, 736611) When I see .
('49', 452, 1, 7, 736624) .behn’s face in my mind’s eye, I see nothing but inno cence and fear on it.
('49', 452, 1, 8, 736700) She is not the cause of her fall.

('49', 455, 1, 2, 740676) 512. LETTER TO MATHURADAS PURUSHOTTAM
('49', 455, 2, 3, 740714) YERAVDA MANDIR, August 21, 1930
('49', 455, 3, 4, 740746) CHI.MATHURADAS, I have your letter and the chapter on carding.
('49', 455, 3, 5, 740809) The oil has not arrived yet.
('49', 455, 3, 6, 740838) Have you tried the use of kerosene ?
('49', 455, 3, 7, 740875) It also helps to keep away mosquitoes.
('49', 455, 3, 8, 740914) If the spot where they often settle is besmeared with kerosene, they keep away from it.
('49', 455, 3, 9, 741002) I did not know about cotton seed oil.
('49', 455, 3, 10, 741040) As we are permitted to sleep in the open here, we are not harassed.
('49', 455, 3, 11, 741108) I like all your articles on carding.
('49', 455, 3, 12, 741145) In some places the language seems to be unduly emphatic.
('49', 455, 3, 13, 741202) My experience is that there can be no guarantee that yarn will be evenly drawn if the cotton has been well carded.
('49', 455, 3, 14, 741317) Though I am a very careful spinner, the yarn is not always even, even if the carding has been of the highest quality.
('49', 455, 3, 15, 741435) The drawing of even yarn is also an art by itself and depends on deftness in using one’s fingers.
('49', 455, 3, 16, 741533) Anyone whose fingers have become inert, so to say, will certainly find difficulty in drawing even yarn.
('49', 455, 3, 17, 741637) I have seen spinners with quick fingers drawing even yarn from badly carded cotton.
('49', 455, 3, 18, 741721) I do not say this to minimize the importance of carding.
('49', 455, 3, 19, 741778) I only wish to make it clear that good carding does not solve all the difficulties of the spinner.
('49', 455, 3, 20, 741877) The art of spinning, as I have said, includes all activities from the plucking of cotton from the pods to the making of hanks, and a spinner should have acquired mastery over all of them.
('49', 455, 3, 21, 742065) If even one of these processes has not been efficiently carried out, careful spinning by itself will not compensate for the deficiency.
('49', 455, 3, 22, 742201) We should not assert anything if we are not perfectly sure about it.
('49', 455, 3, 23, 742270) Ask Lakshmidas to go through your articles before publishing them.
('49', 455, 3, 24, 742337) It will be good if you show them to some other person also who is an expert in the craft.

('49', 461, 1, 2, 748617) APPENDIX II
('49', 461, 2, 3, 748629) JAWAHARLAL NEHRU’S NOTE ON MINORITIES 1
('49', 461, 3, 4, 748669) The curtain has gone up again on the Indian stage and all the world is witness
('49', 461, 4, 5, 748748) to our struggle for freedom.
('49', 461, 4, 6, 748777) It is a strange struggle and our methods are novel.
('49', 461, 4, 7, 748829) But it is
('49', 461, 5, 8, 748839) also a grim struggle and the pledge that India took on Independence Day, January
('49', 461, 6, 9, 748920) 26th, will not be forgotten.
('49', 461, 6, 10, 748949) The spark that was lit by our leader on the banks of the
('49', 461, 7, 11, 749006) Sabarmati is already spreading like a prairie fire throughout the country, and soon the
('49', 461, 8, 12, 749094) whole land will try to redeem that pledge.
('49', 461, 8, 13, 749137) Many a tragic scene will be enacted and
('49', 461, 9, 14, 749177) many an actor on this vast stage will suffer torment before the curtain rings down
('49', 461, 10, 15, 749260) finally on a free India.
('49', 461, 11, 16, 749285) But even when the fight is fiercest and consumes all our energies we must
('49', 461, 12, 17, 749359) remember that the true solution of our difficulties can come only when we have won
('49', 461, 13, 18, 749442) over and given satisfaction to our minorities.
('49', 461, 13, 19, 749489) Today it is unfortunately the fact that
('49', 461, 14, 20, 749529) some of them fear the majority and for fear of it keep apart from the struggle for
('49', 461, 15, 21, 749612) freedom.
('49', 461, 15, 22, 749621) It is sad that some who were our comrades in arms ten years ago are not with
('49', 461, 16, 23, 749698) us today.
('49', 461, 16, 24, 749708) None of us who had the privilege of marching shoulder to shoulder with
('49', 461, 17, 25, 749779) them then can forget the brave part they took and the sacrifices they made.
('49', 461, 18, 26, 749855) cherish that memory and we are assured that when the fight thickens they must take
('49', 461, 19, 27, 749938) their rightful place in the forefront.
('49', 461, 20, 28, 749977) The history of India and of many of the countries of Europe has demonstrated
('49', 461, 21, 29, 750054) that there can be no stable equilibrium in any country so long as an attempt is made to
('49', 461, 22, 30, 750142) crush a minority or to force it to conform to the ways of the majority.
('49', 461, 22, 31, 750214) There is no
('49', 461, 23, 32, 750226) surer method of rousing the resentment of the minority and keeping it apart from the
('49', 461, 24, 33, 750311) rest of the nation than to make it feel that it has not got the freedom to stick to its
('49', 461, 25, 34, 750399) own ways.
('49', 461, 25, 35, 750409) Repression and coercion can never succeed in coercing a minority.
('49', 461, 26, 36, 750475) but make it more self conscious and more determined to value and hold fast to what it
('49', 461, 27, 37, 750561) considers its very own.
('49', 461, 27, 38, 750585) It matters little whether logic is on its side or whether its own
('49', 461, 28, 39, 750651) particular brand of culture is worth while or not.
('49', 461, 28, 40, 750702) The mere fear of losing it makes it
('49', 461, 29, 41, 750738) Freedom to keep it would itself lessen its value.
('49', 461, 29, 42, 750788) The new Russia has gone a long
('49', 461, 30, 43, 750819) way in solving its minorities’ problem by giving each one of them the fullest
('49', 461, 31, 44, 750897) cultural, educational and linguistic freedom.
('49', 461, 32, 45, 750943) Therefore we in India must make it clear to all that our policy is based on granting this freedom to the minorities and that under no circumstances will any
('49', 461, 33, 46, 751100) 1 Vide “The Problem of Minorities”, 5 5 1930.
('49', 462, 0, 1, 751146) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 463
('49', 462, 1, 2, 751188) coercion or repression of them be tolerated.
('49', 462, 1, 3, 751233) There is hardly any likelihood of economic questions affecting the minorities as such, but should they do so we can also lay down as our deliberate policy that there shall be no unfair treatment of any minority.
('49', 462, 1, 4, 751445) Indeed we should go further and state that it will be the business of the State to give favoured treatment to minority and backward communities.
('49', 462, 2, 5, 751590) In a free India political representation can only be on national lines.
('49', 462, 2, 6, 751662) I would like this representation to be on an economic basis which would fit in with modern conditions far more than territorial representation and would also automatically do away with the lines of demarcation along communal lines.
('49', 462, 2, 7, 751894) With religious and cultural and linguistic freedom granted, the principal questions that will arise in our legislatures will be economic ones and divisions on them cannot be on communal lines.
('49', 462, 2, 8, 752087) But whatever the method of representation adopted may be, it must be such as to carry the goodwill of the minorities.
('49', 462, 3, 9, 752205) If these principles are accepted and adhered to, I do not think any minority can have a grievance or feel that it is ignored.
('49', 462, 3, 10, 752331) It is possible however that, while agreeing to these principles, the minority may doubt the bona fides of the majority in giving
('49', 462, 4, 11, 752460) effect to them.
('49', 462, 4, 12, 752476) To that the only effective answer can be the translation of these principles into action.
('49', 462, 4, 13, 752566) Unfortunately the ability to translate them into action can only come with the conquest of power in the State.
('49', 462, 4, 14, 752677) If the bona fides of the majority
('49', 462, 5, 15, 752711) are doubted, as they might well be, then even pacts and agreements are of little value.
('49', 462, 5, 16, 752799) A general and countrywide adoption of certain broad principles can create a public opinion strong enough to prevent even an aggressive and evil intentioned majority from going astray.
('49', 462, 5, 17, 752983) But temporary pacts between individuals or even representatives cannot have the same value.
('49', 462, 6, 18, 753075) These principles should apply to all minority groups.
('49', 462, 6, 19, 753129) To the Muslims who really are in such large numbers in India that it is inconceivable that any majo rity can coerce them; to the Sikhs who, although small in number, are a powerful and well knit group; to the Parsis; to the Anglo lndians or Eurasians who are gradually drifting to nationalism; and to all other minorities.
('49', 462, 7, 20, 753452) What is the present position of the Congress on this vital question?
('49', 462, 7, 21, 753521) The Nehru Report has lapsed, but surely the non controversial parts of the report remain.
('49', 462, 7, 22, 753611) The Fundamental Rights, as stated there, included religious, cultural, linguistic and educa tional freedom.
('49', 462, 7, 23, 753719) This declaration must remain, and it removes at once the major fears of a minority.
('49', 462, 7, 24, 753803) So far as other matters are concerned, minorities as such will hardly be affected, and the Lahore Congress has declared that in an Independent India such questions should be solved on strictly national lines.
('49', 462, 7, 25, 754012) It has gone further.
('49', 462, 7, 26, 754033) It has assured the Muslims, the Sikhs and other minorities that if any solution of any communal problem is proposed in future, it will not be accepted by the Congress unless it gives full satisfaction to the parties concerned.
('49', 462, 7, 27, 754260) A more complete guarantee
('49', 463, 0, 1, 754286) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 463, 1, 2, 754328) could not have been given, and if the Congress remains true to its word no minority need have the least fear.
('49', 463, 2, 3, 754438) Thus the Congress has endeavoured to give effect to the principles that should
('49', 463, 3, 4, 754517) govern the treatment of minorities.
('49', 463, 3, 5, 754553) If in the eyes of some it is still suspect, it is not
('49', 463, 4, 6, 754607) because of what it has done but because of want of trust and unjustified fear.
('49', 463, 4, 7, 754686) The Con 
('49', 463, 5, 8, 754695) gress, I trust, will remain true to these principles and will demonstrate to the country
('49', 463, 6, 9, 754784) that in communal matters it will not deviate to the right or the left and will hold the
('49', 463, 7, 10, 754872) centre impartially.
('49', 463, 7, 11, 754892) It will, I hope, prove to the minority communities that in
('49', 463, 8, 12, 754951) Independent India, for which we strive, theirs will be an honoured and a favoured
('49', 463, 9, 13, 755033) And by its sacrifices and its determined courage in the fight for freedom it will
('49', 463, 10, 14, 755115) convince all of its bona fides.
('49', 463, 10, 15, 755147) Young India, 15 5 1930
('49', 463, 11, 16, 755170) APPENDIX III
('49', 463, 12, 17, 755183) EXTRACTS FROM “THE DAILY TELEGRAPH” REPORT 1
('49', 463, 13, 18, 755228) The prophet is no longer at large, and he is now safely interned at
('49', 463, 14, 19, 755296) Yeravda, close to Poona, in the most comfortable prison in the presidency, writes
('49', 463, 15, 20, 755378) Mr. Ashmead Bartlett, the special correspondent of The Daily Telegraph in its issue of
('49', 463, 16, 21, 755465) 6th instant.
('49', 463, 17, 22, 755478) Gandhi will be charged with no specific offence as his followers have been: he
('49', 463, 18, 23, 755557) will be interned under Ordinance 25 of 1827, without trial in Bombay.
('49', 463, 19, 24, 755627) This Ordinance is framed in such general terms that it enables the Government
('49', 463, 20, 25, 755705) to intern almost anyone on any charge which can possibly be construed as a menace
('49', 463, 21, 26, 755787) to public order, or for stopping internal commotion.
('49', 463, 21, 27, 755840) It was last employed in the year
('49', 463, 22, 28, 755873) 1906 for the detention of the Natu brothers after the Rand murder.
('49', 463, 23, 29, 755940) The arrest itself was carried out with the utmost quietude at dead of night.
('49', 463, 24, 30, 756017) The Mahatma was fast asleep in his camp at Karadi, near Surat, when about 1
('49', 463, 25, 31, 756093) the District Police Superintendent with the District Magistrate and a score of
('49', 463, 26, 32, 756172) armed police, entered his room.
('49', 463, 26, 33, 756204) They turned a flash lamp on him and he awoke at
('49', 463, 28, 34, 756252) Gandhi took matters very coolly, and merely asked that the warrant be read to
('49', 463, 29, 35, 756330) 1 Vide “Interview to The Daily Telegraph”, 5 5 1930.
('49', 464, 0, 1, 756383) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 465
('49', 464, 1, 2, 756425) him, and that he be allowed to clean his teeth, which is with the Hindus an invariable
('49', 464, 2, 3, 756512) religious rite on getting up.
('49', 464, 3, 4, 756542) Both requests were complied with, and shortly afterwards he was taken to a
('49', 464, 4, 5, 756617) motor lorry, which, accompanied by police, was driven off to the railway station.
('49', 464, 5, 6, 756699) There he and his guards entered a special saloon attached to the Ahmedabad Bombay
('49', 464, 6, 7, 756781) Express, en route for Borivli, whence he was to be taken by motor to the Yeravda
('49', 464, 7, 8, 756862) prison.
('49', 464, 7, 9, 756870) On arrival at the jail he appeared to be in excellent health and spirits, and
('49', 464, 8, 10, 756948) expressed gratitude for the manner in which his journey had been arranged.
('49', 464, 9, 11, 757023) It was generally known throughout Bombay yesterday that Gandhi’s arrest was
('49', 464, 10, 12, 757099) imminent, and in the afternoon details of the Government plan of operations were
('49', 464, 11, 13, 757180) made known to foreign correspondents, but not a word was allowed to be cabled, a
('49', 464, 12, 14, 757261) strict censorship having been in force for the past three days.
('49', 464, 13, 15, 757325) The main object of the Government has been to put Gandhi safely under lock
('49', 464, 14, 16, 757400) and key, before the news became known to the public, so as to avoid any
('49', 464, 15, 17, 757472) demonstrations leading to riots and bloodshed in the course of his journey to Poona.
('49', 464, 16, 18, 757557) The mere fact of handing in despatches to the cable office containing the news would
('49', 464, 17, 19, 757642) at once have made known the Government’s plans all over Bombay.
('49', 464, 18, 20, 757706) Gandhi’s arrest was finally decided upon at the Council of State held in Simla a
('49', 464, 19, 21, 757787) few days ago, and was originally planned for May 4, but the change was decided upon
('49', 464, 20, 22, 757871) to avoid Sunday, and 1 a.m.
('49', 464, 20, 23, 757899) on Monday (Indian time) was therefore named as the “zero
('49', 464, 21, 24, 757956) hour” for his apprehension in Surat.
('49', 464, 22, 25, 757993) Mr. Hotson kindly informed me of his programme, which was to take Gandhi
('49', 464, 23, 26, 758066) from the train at a small wayside station called Borivli, thirteen miles from Bombay,
('49', 464, 24, 27, 758152) and from there to send him by car to Poona.
('49', 464, 25, 28, 758196) The Hindu, 27 5 1930
