('49', 465, 1, 2, 758259) APPENDIX IV (A)
('49', 465, 2, 3, 758275) NOTE FROM NEHRUS 1
('49', 465, 3, 4, 758294) CENTRAL PRISON, NAINI, ALLAHABAD, July 28, 1930
('49', 465, 4, 5, 758342) We have had a long conversation with Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar and they have informed us of the various events which led to their seeking interviews with Gandhiji and with us in our respective prisons in order, if possible, to terminate or suspend the present hostilities between the people of India and the British Government.
('49', 465, 4, 6, 758682) We appreciate their earnest desire for peace and would gladly explore all avenues which might lead to it provided such a peace was an honourable one for the people of India who have already sacrificed so much in the national struggle and want freedom for our country.
('49', 465, 4, 7, 758950) As representatives of the Congress we have no authority to alter in any material particular its resolutions, but we might be prepared under certain circumstances to recommend variation in details provided the fundamental position taken up by the Congress was accepted.
('49', 465, 4, 8, 759219) We are, however, faced with initial difficulty.
('49', 465, 4, 9, 759267) Both of us are in prison and for some time past have been cut off from the outside world and the national movement.
('49', 465, 4, 10, 759383) One of us for nearly three months was not allowed any daily newspaper.
('49', 465, 4, 11, 759454) Gandhiji has also been in prison for several months.
('49', 465, 4, 12, 759507) Indeed almost all our colleagues of the original Working Committee of the Congress are in prison and the Committee itself has been declared an illegal organization.
('49', 465, 4, 13, 759672) Of the 360 members of the All India Congress Committee which is the final authority in the National Congress organization subject only to a full session of the Congress, probably 75 per cent are in prison.
('49', 465, 4, 14, 759878) Cut off as we are from the national movement, we cannot take upon ourselves the responsibility of taking a definite step without the fullest consultation with our colleagues and especially Gandhiji.
('49', 465, 4, 15, 760077) As regards the Round Table Conference we feel unlikely to achieve anything unless an agreement on all vital matters is previously arrived at.
('49', 465, 4, 16, 760219) We attach great importance to such an agreement which must be definite and there must be no room for misunderstanding or misinterpretation.
('49', 465, 4, 17, 760359) Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar have made very clear and Lord Irwin has also stated in his published letter to them that they are acting on their own behalf and cannot commit him or his Government.
('49', 465, 4, 18, 760563) It is, however, possible they may succeed in paving way to such an agreement between the Congress and the British Government.
('49', 465, 4, 19, 760689) As we are unable to suggest any definite terms for truce without
('49', 465, 5, 20, 760754) 1 Vide “Letter to Motilal Nehru”, 23 7 1930.
('49', 466, 0, 1, 760799) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 467
('49', 466, 1, 2, 760841) consulting Gandhiji and other colleagues, we refrain from discussing the suggestions made by Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar and by Gandhiji in the note of his dated 23rd July which has been shown to us.
('49', 466, 1, 3, 761051) We might, however, agree generally with Gandhiji's 2nd and 3rd points, but we should like the details of these points and specially his point (I) to discuss with him and others before we can finally make our suggestions.
('49', 466, 1, 4, 761272) We suggest this note of ours be treated confidential and be shown only to such persons as see Gandhiji's note dated 23 7 1930.
('49', 466, 2, 5, 761399) The Hindu, 5 9 1930
('49', 466, 3, 6, 761419) APPENDIX IV (B)
('49', 466, 4, 7, 761435) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU1
('49', 466, 5, 8, 761465) CENTRAL PRISON, NAINI, July 28, 1930
('49', 466, 6, 9, 761502) MY DEAR BAPUJI,
('49', 466, 7, 10, 761518) It is a delight to write you again after a long interval even though it be from
('49', 466, 8, 11, 761598) one prison to another.
('49', 466, 8, 12, 761621) I would like to write at length, but I am afraid I cannot do so at
('49', 466, 9, 13, 761688) present.
('49', 466, 9, 14, 761697) I shall, therefore, confine myself to the matter in issue.
('49', 466, 9, 15, 761756) Dr. Sapru and Mr.
('49', 466, 10, 16, 761774) Jayakar came yesterday and had a long interview with father and me.
('49', 466, 10, 17, 761842) Today they are
('49', 466, 11, 18, 761857) coming again.
('49', 466, 11, 19, 761871) As they have already put us in possession of all facts and shown us
('49', 466, 12, 20, 761939) your note and letter, we felt we could discuss the matter between us two and arrive at
('49', 466, 13, 21, 762026) some decision even without waiting for a second interview.
('49', 466, 13, 22, 762085) Of course if anything new
('49', 466, 14, 23, 762111) turns up at the second interview we are prepared to vary any previously formed
('49', 466, 15, 24, 762190) opinion.
('49', 466, 15, 25, 762199) Our conclusions for the time being are given in the note which we are
('49', 466, 16, 26, 762269) giving to Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar.
('49', 466, 16, 27, 762318) This is more or less brief but it will,
('49', 466, 17, 28, 762358) I hope, give you some idea of how our minds are working.
('49', 466, 17, 29, 762415) I might add that father and I
('49', 466, 18, 30, 762445) are in full agreement in regard to what our attitude should be.
('49', 466, 18, 31, 762509) I might confess your
('49', 466, 19, 32, 762530) point (1) regarding the constitutional issue has not won me over nor does father fancy
('49', 466, 20, 33, 762617) I do not see how it fits in with our position or our pledges or with the realities of
('49', 466, 21, 34, 762703) Father and I entirely agree with you that we can be “no parties to any truce
('49', 466, 22, 35, 762780) which would undo the position at which we have arrived today”.
('49', 466, 22, 36, 762843) It is because of this
('49', 466, 23, 37, 762865) that fullest consideration is essential before any final decision is arrived at.
('49', 466, 24, 38, 762946) confess I do not see an appreciable advance yet from the other side and I greatly fear a
('49', 466, 25, 39, 763035) false or weak move on our part.
('49', 466, 25, 40, 763067) I am expressing myself moderately.
('49', 466, 25, 41, 763102) For myself I
('49', 466, 26, 42, 763115) delight in warfare.
('49', 466, 26, 43, 763135) It makes me feel that I am alive.
('49', 466, 26, 44, 763169) Events of the last four months in
('49', 466, 27, 45, 763203) 1 Vide “Letter to Motilal Nehru”, 23 7 1930.
('49', 467, 0, 1, 763248) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 467, 1, 2, 763290) India have gladdened my heart and have made me prouder of Indian men, women and
('49', 467, 2, 3, 763370) even children than I had ever been, but I realize that most people are not warlike and
('49', 467, 3, 4, 763457) like peace and so I try hard to suppress myself and take a peaceful view.
('49', 467, 4, 5, 763531) congratulate you on the new India you have created by your magic touch!
('49', 467, 4, 6, 763603) What the
('49', 467, 5, 7, 763612) future will bring I know not, but the past has made life worth living and our prosaic
('49', 467, 6, 8, 763698) existence has developed something of epic greatness in it.
('49', 467, 6, 9, 763757) Sitting here in Naini Jail I
('49', 467, 7, 10, 763786) have pondered on the wonderful efficacy of non violence as a weapon and have
('49', 467, 8, 11, 763863) become a greater convert with the response of a convert to it than ever before.
('49', 467, 9, 12, 763943) you are not dissatisfied with the response of the country to the non violence creed.
('49', 467, 10, 13, 764028) Despite occasional lapses, the country has stuck to it wonderfully, certainly far more
('49', 467, 11, 14, 764115) grimly than I had expected.
('49', 467, 11, 15, 764143) I am afraid I am still somewhat of a protestant regarding
('49', 467, 12, 16, 764201) your eleven points.
('49', 467, 12, 17, 764221) Not that I disagree with any one of them.
('49', 467, 12, 18, 764263) Indeed they are
('49', 467, 13, 19, 764279) important.
('49', 467, 13, 20, 764290) Yet I do not think that they take the place of independence.
('49', 467, 13, 21, 764351) But I certainly
('49', 467, 14, 22, 764367) agree with you that we should have “nothing to do with anything that would not give
('49', 467, 15, 23, 764451) the nation power to give immediate effect to them”.
('49', 467, 15, 24, 764503) Father has been unwell the last
('49', 467, 16, 25, 764535) eight days ever since he took an injection.
('49', 467, 16, 26, 764579) He has grown very weak.
('49', 467, 16, 27, 764603) This long
('49', 467, 17, 28, 764613) interview last evening tired him out.
('49', 467, 18, 29, 764651) JAWAHARLAL
('49', 467, 19, 30, 764662) Please do not be anxious about me.
('49', 467, 19, 31, 764697) It is only a passing trouble and I hope to get over it in two or three days.
('49', 467, 20, 32, 764774) MOTILAL NEHRU PS.
('49', 467, 21, 33, 764792) We have had another talk with Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Mr. Jayakar.
('49', 467, 21, 34, 764861) At their
('49', 467, 22, 35, 764870) desire we have made some alterations in our note, but they do not make any vital
('49', 467, 23, 36, 764951) difference.
('49', 467, 23, 37, 764963) Our position is quite clear and I have no doubt whatever about it.
('49', 467, 24, 38, 765030) you will appreciate it.
('49', 467, 25, 39, 765054) The Hindu, 5 9 1930
('49', 468, 0, 1, 765074) VOL.49 :3 APRIL, 1930 22 AUGUST, 1930 469
('49', 468, 1, 2, 765116) APPENDIX V
('49', 468, 2, 3, 765127) LETTER FROM T. B. SAPRU AND M. R. JAYAKAR TO CONGRESS LEADERS 1
('49', 468, 3, 4, 765191) WINTER ROAD, MALABAR HILL, BOMBAY, August 16, 1930
('49', 468, 4, 5, 765242) DEAR FRIENDS,
('49', 468, 5, 6, 765256) We desire to express our thanks to you all for the courteous and patient hearing which you have been good enough to give us, on the several occasions on which we have visited you either at Poona or at Allahabad.
('49', 468, 5, 7, 765468) We regret that we should have caused you so much inconvenience by these prolonged conversations, and we are particularly sorry that Pandit Motilal Nehru should have been put to the trouble of coming down to Poona, at a time when his health was so bad.
('49', 468, 6, 8, 765720) We beg formally to acknowledge receipt of the letter which you have handed to us and in which you state the terms on which you are prepared to recommend to the Congress the calling off of Civil Disobedience and participation in the Round Table Conference.
('49', 468, 7, 9, 765976) As we have informed you, we took up this work of mediation on the basis of
('49', 468, 8, 10, 766051) ( l )the terms of an interview given by Pandit Motilal, the then Acting President of the Congress, to Mr. Slocombe in Bombay on 20th June 1930, and particularly
('49', 468, 9, 11, 766212) (2)the terms of the statement submitted by Mr. Slocombe to Pandit Motilal Nehru in Bombay on 25th June, 1930, and approved by him (Pandit Motilal Nehru) as the basis of informal approach to the Viceroy by us.
('49', 468, 10, 12, 766421) Mr. Slocombe forwarded both the documents to us, and we thereupon approached His Excellency the Viceroy for permission to interview Mahatma Gandhi, Pandits Motilal Nehru and Jawaharlal Nehru, in order to explore the possibilities of a settlement.
('49', 468, 10, 13, 766668) A copy of the second document referred to above has been taken by you from us.
('49', 468, 11, 14, 766747) We now find that the terms embodied in the letter you gave us on the 14th instant are such that, as agreed between us, it must be submitted to His Excellency the Viceroy for his consideration, and we have to await his decision.
('49', 468, 12, 15, 766975) We note your desire that the material documents relating to these peace
('49', 468, 13, 16, 767047) negotiations including your said letter to us should be published, and we shall proceed
('49', 468, 14, 17, 767135) 1 Vide “Letter to T. B. Sapru and M. R. Jayakar”, 15 8 1930.
('49', 469, 0, 1, 767196) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('49', 469, 1, 2, 767238) to do so after His Excellency the Viceroy has considered your letter.
('49', 469, 2, 3, 767308) Before we conclude, you will permit us to say that we had reasons to believe,
('49', 469, 3, 4, 767386) as we told you, that with the actual calling off of the Civil Disobedience Movement,
('49', 469, 4, 5, 767471) the general situation would largely improve, non violent political prisoners would be
('49', 469, 5, 6, 767557) released, all Ordinances, with the exception of those affecting Chittagong and the
('49', 469, 6, 7, 767640) Lahore Conspiracy cases would be recalled, and the Congress would get a
('49', 469, 7, 8, 767712) representation at the Round Table Conference, larger than that of any other single
('49', 469, 8, 9, 767795) political party.
('49', 469, 8, 10, 767812) We need scarcely add that we emphasized also that, in our opinion,
('49', 469, 9, 11, 767879) there was substantially no difference between the point of view adopted by Pandit
('49', 469, 10, 12, 767961) Motilal Nehru in his 'interview' and the statement sent to us by Mr. Slocombe with
('49', 469, 11, 13, 768044) Pandit Motilal's approval and His Excellency the Viceroy's letter to us.
('49', 469, 12, 14, 768117) Yours sincerely,
('49', 469, 13, 15, 768134) T. B. SAPRU
('49', 469, 14, 16, 768146) M. R. JAYAKAR
('49', 469, 15, 17, 768160) Gandhi Sapru Correspondence.
('49', 469, 15, 18, 768189) Courtesy: P. N. Sapru
